|species = '''''C. australis'''''
|binomial = ''Cotula australis''
|binomial_authority = ([[Franz Sieber|Sieber]] ''ex'' [[Curt Polycarp Jaochim Sprengel|Spreng.]]) [[William Jackson Hooker|Hook.]]
|synonyms_ref=<ref>[http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/gcc-130452 The Plant List, ''Cotula australis'' (Sieber ex Spreng.) Hook.f. ]</ref>
|synonyms=
*''Anacyclus australis'' <small>Sieber ex Spreng.</small>
*''Cotula venosa'' <small>Colenso</small>
*''Lancisia australis'' <small>(Sieber ex Spreng.) Rydb.</small>
*''Soliva tenella'' <small>A.Cunn.</small>
*''Strongylosperma australe'' <small>(Sieber ex Spreng.) Less.</small>
}}
'''''Cotula australis''''' is a species of plant in the [[Asteraceae|daisy family]] known by the common names '''Bachelor's Buttons,'''<ref name=matilda/> '''annual buttonweed''',<ref name=BSBI07>{{cite web|title=BSBI List 2007 |publisher=Botanical Society of Britain and Ireland |url=http://www.bsbi.org.uk/BSBIList2007.xls |format=xls |accessdate=2014-10-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6VqJ46atN?url=http://www.bsbi.org.uk/BSBIList2007.xls |archivedate=2015-01-25 |df= }}</ref> '''southern waterbuttons''' and '''Australian waterbuttons'''. This small plant is native to [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]], but it is known in other areas of the world as a common weed ([[South America]], [[California]], [[Mexico]], [[South Africa]], etc.).<ref name=matilda>[http://bie.ala.org.au/species/urn:lsid:biodiversity.org.au:apni.taxon:308635 Atlas of Living Australia,  ''Cotula australis'' (Sieber ex Spreng.) Hook.f., Bachelor's Buttons]</ref><ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/54141#page/179/mode/1up Hooker, Joseph Dalton 1853. Botany of the Antarctic voyage of H.M. discovery ships Erebus and Terror in the Years 1839-1843 :under the command of Captain Sir James Clark Ross, part 2,  Flora Novae-Zelandiae 1: 128]</ref><ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Cotula%20australis.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref><ref>Jørgensen, P. M. & C. Ulloa Ulloa. 1994. Seed plants of the high Andes of Ecuador—A checklist. AAU Rep. 34: 1–443</ref><ref>Gibbs Russell, G. E., W. G. M. Welman, E. Retief, K. L. Immelman, G. Germishuizen, B. J. Pienaar, M. Van Wyk & A. Nicholas. 1987. List of species of southern African plants. Memoirs of the Botanical Survey of South Africa 2(1–2): 1–152(pt. 1), 1–270(pt. 2). </ref><ref>Turner, B. L. 1996. The Comps of Mexico: A systematic account of the family Asteraceae, vol. 6. Tageteae and Athemideae. Phytologia Memoirs 10: i–ii, 1–22, 43–93</ref>


''Cotula australis'' grows low to the ground in a thin mat with some slightly erect, spindly stems. The leaves are divided and subdivided into fringelike lobes. The plant flowers in [[inflorescence]]s only a few millimetres wide containing minuscule yellow [[Head (botany)|disc florets]] surrounded by greenish brown [[bract]]s and rudimentary ray florets that have been reduced to pistils with no stamens or corolla. The fruit is a tiny winged [[achene]] about a millimetre wide.<ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=242426659 Flora of North America, ''Cotula australis'' (Sieber ex Sprengel) Hooker f.]</ref>

70.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = Billy buttons
|image = Craspedia variabilis.JPG
|image caption = ''C. variabilis'' near [[Cranbrook, Western Australia|Cranbrook]], [[Western Australia]].
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]]
|ordo = [[Asterales]]
|familia = [[Asteraceae]]
|subfamilia = [[Asteroideae]]
|tribus = [[Gnaphalieae]]
|genus = ''[[Craspedia]]''
|species = '''''C. variabilis'''''
|binomial = ''Craspedia variabilis''
|binomial_authority = J.Everett & Doust
}}

'''''Craspedia variabilis''''', commonly known as '''billy buttons''' is an erect annual or perennial herb which occurs in all mainland states of [[Australia]] except for the [[Northern Territory]] and in a wide range of habitats in temperate zones but not in alpine areas.

==Description==
''Craspedia variabilis'' grows to a height of 10–60 cm, with one to five flower spikes surrounded by a rosette of leaves, with more leaves scattered along the flower spike.  Each leaf is spoon-shaped, about 5–13 cm long and 5–20 mm wide. The leaves are pale to olive-green and the flower spike straw-coloured to reddish and both leaves and flower spike are hairy. It has thick, spreading woolly roots and broad, reddish, overlapping leaf-bases which are retained at the base of the flower spike. The flowers, which appear from early spring to early summer, form a hemispherical head of about 40-100 small, golden-yellow individual small flowers, each with a short stalk.<ref name=Everett>{{cite journal|last1=Everett|first1=J.|last2=Doust|first2=A.N.L.|title=Four new Australian species o f Craspedia sens, strict. (Asteraceae: G naphalieae)|journal=Telopea - Journal of plant systematics|date=3 September 1992|volume=5|issue=1|pages=35–38|url=http://www.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/science/Scientific_publications/telopea/view_contents/b-view_contents?sq_content_src=%2BdXJsPWh0dHAlM0ElMkYlMkZwbGFudG5ldC5yYmdzeWQubnN3Lmdvdi5hdSUyRmVtdXdlYm5zd2xpdmUlMkZvYmplY3RzJTJGY29tbW9uJTJGd2VibWVkaWEucGhwJTNGaXJuJTNENzU2NDUlMjZyZWZ0YWJsZSUzRGViaWJsaW9ncmFwaHkmYWxsPTE%3D|accessdate=22 February 2015}}</ref>

==Taxonomy and naming== 
Following a review of the genus ''Craspedia'', J. Everett and A.N.L. Doust named ''C. variabilis'' as a new species, along with ''[[C. paludicola]]'', ''[[C. canens]]'' and ''[[C. haplorrhiza]]''. They describe ''C. variabilis'' as "a complex species with several forms, some of which may be separable on further work". The [[Biological nomenclature|specific epithet]] (''variabilis'') refers to the number of different forms across its wide distribution.<ref name="Everett" /><ref name="APNI 65335">{{APNI|name=''Craspedia variabilis'' J.Everett & Doust|id = 65335}}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
''C. variabilis'' is found in a wide variety of habitats but never alpine.<ref name="Everett" /> In Western Australia it grows on seasonally wet flats, granite outcrops, slopes<ref name="FloraBase 13354">{{FloraBase|name=''Craspedia variabilis'' J.Everett & Doust|id = 13354}}</ref> and in the [[Sydney]] region its distribution is described as "widespread in open forests and grassland".<ref name=Carolin>{{cite book|last1=Carolin|first1=Roger|last2=Tindale|first2=Mary|title=Flora of the Sydney region|date=1994|publisher=Reed|location=Chatswood, NSW|isbn=0730104001|page=556|edition=4th}}</ref>

==Cultivation==
Billy buttons can be propagated from seed and grown in full sun. It grows in any soil provided that it is not too wet. It can be treated as an annual and used effectively as a single specimen or as a massed bedding plant.<ref name=Wrigley>{{cite book|last1=Wrigley.|first1=John W.|last2=Fagg|first2=Murray|title=Australian native plants : a manual for their propagation, cultivation and use in landscaping|date=1983|publisher=Collins|location=Sydney|isbn=0002165759|page=107|edition=2nd}}</ref>

71.text:
{{Speciesbox
|taxon = Crinum asiaticum
|image = Crinum Lily.JPG
|image2=Crinum asiaticum (1).jpg
|authority = L.<ref>{{cite web |title= EOL Crinum asiaticum |url= http://eol.org/pages/1087153 |accessdate=2009-05-23}}</ref>
}}
'''''Crinum asiaticum''''' ('''poison bulb, giant crinum lily, grand crinum lily, spider lily''') is a plant species widely planted in many warmer regions as an ornamental. It is a bulb-forming perennial producing an umbel of large, showy flowers that are prized by gardeners. All parts of the plant are, however, poisonous if ingested. Some reports indicate exposure to the sap may cause skin irritation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Crinum asiaticum|url=http://www.floridata.com/ref/c/crin_asi.cfm|publisher=floridata.com|accessdate=18 April 2014}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|title=PlantFiles: Poison Bulb, Giant Crinum Lily, Grand Crinum Lily, Spider Lily Crinum asiaticum|url=http://davesgarden.com/guides/pf/go/93829/|publisher=Dave's Garden|accessdate=18 April 2014}}</ref> 

''C. asiaticum'' is native to southern [[China]], [[Hong Kong]], [[Jeju-do]] in [[South Korea]], [[India]], [[Nansei-shoto]] ([[Ryukyu Islands]]), [[Ogasawara-shoto]] ([[Bonin Islands]]), [[Mainland Japan]], [[Taiwan]], [[Assam]], [[Bangladesh]], [[India]], the [[Maldive Islands]], [[Sri Lanka]], the [[Andaman Islands|Andaman]] & [[Nicobar Islands]], [[Cambodia]], [[Laos]], [[Myanmar]] ([[Burma]]), the [[Paracel Islands|Paracel]] & [[Spratly Islands]], [[Thailand]], [[Vietnam]], [[Mauritius]], [[Borneo]], [[Cocos Island]], [[Java]], [[Lesser Sunda Islands]], [[Peninsular Malaysia]], [[Sulawesi]], [[Sumatra]], [[Philippines]], [[Christmas Island]], the [[Bismarck Archipelago]], [[New Guinea]], [[Norfolk Island]], [[Australia]], [[Fiji]], [[New Caledonia]], [[Samoa]] and [[Vanuatu]]. It is regarded as naturalized in [[Mexico]], the [[West Indies]], [[Florida]], [[Louisiana]], [[Micronesia]], [[Polynesia]], [[Melanesia]], [[Madagascar]] and the [[Chagos Archipelago]].<ref>{{cite web|title=World Checklist of Selected Plant Families: Royal Botanic Gardens, ''Crinum asiaticum''|url=http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=303325|publisher=Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew|accessdate=18 April 2014}}</ref>

72.text:
{{taxobox
|image = Crotalaria cunninghamii 2.jpg
|name = Green birdflower
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Fabales]]
|familia = [[Fabaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Crotalaria]]''
|species = '''''C. cunninghamii'''''
|binomial = ''Crotalaria cunninghamii''
|binomial_authority = [[Robert Brown (botanist, born 1773)|R.Br.]]
}}
[[File:Crotalaria cunninghamii.jpg|thumb|Crotalaria cunninghamii - this form has distinctive green flowers in axillary clusters.]]
[[File:Green bird flower.jpg|thumb|The green bird flower resembles a hummingbird.]]

'''''Crotalaria cunninghamii''''', also known as '''green birdflower''' or '''regal birdflower''', is a plant of the legume family [[Fabaceae]]. It is native to, and widespread in, inland northern [[Australia]]. It is named after early 19th century botanist [[Allan Cunningham (botanist)|Allan Cunningham]]. It is a coloniser of unstable sand dunes, along beaches and in Mulga communities. It is pollinated by large [[bee]]s and by [[honeyeater]]s.

==Description==
Green birdflower is a perennial shrub that grows to about 1–3 m in height. It has hairy or woolly branches and dull green foliage. The oval leaves are about 30 mm long, the large and greenish pea flowers are streaked with fine black lines, and the club-shaped seed pods are up to 50 mm long. The plant’s flowers grow on long spikes at the ends of its branches.<ref name=ANPS>Australian Native Plants Society.</ref> The flower resembles a bird attached by its beak to the central stalk of the flowerhead.<ref name=AALBG>Australian Arid Lands Botanic Garden.</ref>

==Uses and cultivation==
The sap from the leaves was used by [[Indigenous Australians|Aboriginal people]] to treat eye infections.<ref name=ANPS/><ref name=AALBG/>

Green birdflower can be grown in warm areas. It needs well-drained soils and a position in full sun. It is not suited to cold climates or where there are frosts. Propagation is from seed, which readily germinates after boiling water treatment, or from cuttings.<ref name=ANPS/>

==References==

73.text:
{{italic title}}
{{Taxobox
| name = ''Cyathea baileyana''
| status = R
| status_system = QLDNCA
| regnum = [[Plant]]ae
| divisio = [[Pteridophyta]]
| classis = [[Pteridopsida]]
| ordo = [[Cyatheales]]
| familia = [[Cyatheaceae]]
| genus = ''[[Cyathea]]''
| subgenus = ''[[Cyathea subg. Cyathea|Cyathea]]''
| sectio = ''[[Cyathea sect. Alsophila|Alsophila]]''
| species = '''''C. baileyana'''''
| binomial = ''Cyathea baileyana''
| binomial_authority = (Domin) Domin, 1929
| synonyms =
*''Alsophila baileyana'' <small>Domin, 1913</small>
}}

'''''Cyathea baileyana''''', also known as the '''wig tree fern''', is a species of [[Cyatheales|tree fern]] native to northeastern [[Queensland]] in [[Australia]], where it grows in wet [[gully|gullies]] and forest at an altitude of 850-1200 m. It is a rare species that is seldom found in the wild. The erect trunk is 4-5 m tall, approximately 10 cm in diameter and may be covered in [[Stipe (botany)|stipe]] bases in the upper regions. ''C. baileyana'' is notable for being able to develop [[Offshoot (plant)|offshoots]] from the base of the trunk. [[Frond]]s are [[bipinnate|bi-]] or [[tripinnate]] and may be exceptionally long, up to 7 m, though they are usually around 2-3 m. The [[rachis]] and stipe are dark to darkish red, [[scale (zoology)|scaly]] and may be warty, but lack spines. Scales on the rachis and stipe are purplish brown to black and have a long hair-like apex. Characteristically of this species, the last pair of [[pinnation|pinnae]] are separated from the others along the rachis and may form a clump (the "wig") around the trunk apex. [[sorus|Sori]] are circular and occur in one to three rows along the [[pinnule]] midvein. They lack [[indusium|indusia]].

The specific [[epithet]] ''baileyana'' commemorates Australian botanist [[Frederick Manson Bailey]] (1827-1915). The common name "wig tree fern" refers to the pinnae that cluster around the crown of this species, forming a structure that resembles a wig. This "wig" is green in younger plants, but may become brownish in older specimens.

''C. baileyana'' is a relatively slow-growing species. In cultivation, it should be able to withstand several degrees of frost. It is reportedly difficult to [[plant propagation|propagate]].

==References==
*Braggins, John E. & Large, Mark F. 2004. ''Tree Ferns''. Timber Press, Inc., p. 102. ISBN 0-88192-630-2
*[http://www.angelfire.com/bc/eucalyptus/treeferns/cyathea.html Cold-Hardy Tree Ferns: ''Cyathea baileyana'']
*[http://www.ipni.org/ipni/plantsearch?id=17312440-1&query_type=by_id&output_format=object_view&back_page=plantsearch&ret_wholeName=Cyathea%20baileyana The International Plant Names Index: ''Cyathea baileyana'']

74.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|image = A hand-book to the flora of Ceylon (Plate XCVI) (6430666093).jpg
|name = ''Cyperus bulbosus''
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Monocots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Commelinids]]
|ordo = [[Poales]]
|familia = [[Cyperaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Cyperus]]''
|species = '''''C. bulbosus'''''
|binomial = ''Cyperus bulbosus''
|binomial_authority = [[Martin Vahl|Vahl]]
}}
'''''Cyperus bulbosus''''' is a [[species]] of [[Cyperaceae|sedge]] found across Africa, the [[Middle East]], [[Indian subcontinent]], [[Southeast Asia]], and [[Australia]].<ref>http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=235931</ref> In Australia, it is commonly called (Australian) bush onion or "[[wild onion]]", but is not related to the [[onion]] or other [[Alliaceae]]. It is a component of Australian [[bushfood]], but is considered an agricultural [[weed]] in other areas.

==Description==
''C. bulbosus'' is [[perennial]] and [[rhizomatous]], with fine grassy foliage and triangular [[culm (botany)|culm]]s.<ref name="NWSFlora">{{cite web|url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Cyperus~bulbosus|work=New South Wales Flora Online |title=''Cyperus bulbosus'' Vahl|publisher=[[National Herbarium of New South Wales]] |accessdate=August 17, 2010}}</ref> The inflorescence is rarely branched and consists of a cluster of [[Spike (botany)|spikes]] of reddish-brown bracts, eventually producing small, three-sided seeds.<ref name="NWSFlora"/>

The small [[tuber]]s which form on short stolons are a traditional [[bush tucker]] food for [[Australian Aborigines]]. They are dug up on creek banks when the grass of the onion has dried out. The husk can also be eaten. They are eaten raw or cooked in the hot earth by the fire.{{citations needed|date=May 2012}}

==Cultural significance==
Its name in the [[Arrernte language|Arrernte]] language of [[Central Australia]] is ''merne yalke''. In a neighbouring language, [[Kaytetye language|Kaytetye]], it is called ''erreyakwerra''. Some Kaytetye, the Kwerrimpe women, have a bush onion [[Dreaming (spirituality)|dreaming]]<ref>Turpin, Myfany (comp.), ''Growing up Kaytete: Stories by Tommy Kngwarraye Thompson'', Jukurrpa Books, Alice Springs, 2003, ISBN 1-86465-049-4, pp 3-5</ref> which involves the bush onion and the origins of the Kaytetye people and language. This means they have been given stories of the origins of the bush onion, and are entitled to tell these stories and paint about them. Artists who have painted bush onion dreaming include [[Nora Andy Napaltjarri]]<ref name="DAAONora">{{cite web|url=http://www.daao.org.au/main/read/210|title=Nora Napaljarri Andy|date=2007|publisher=Dictionary of Australian Artists Online|accessdate=2009-09-19}}</ref> and her sister [[Ada Andy Napaltjarri]].<ref name="Birnberg213">{{cite book|last=Birnberg|first=Margo|author2=Janusz Kreczmanski|title=Aboriginal Artist Dictionary of Biographies: Australian Western, Central Desert and Kimberley Region|publisher=J.B. Publishing|location=Marleston, South Australia|date=2004|page=213|isbn=1-876622-47-4}}</ref>

==Agricultural pest==
Outside of its range in Australia, it is often considered an agricultural pest. For example, it is found as a weed in [[rice]] culture.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ikisan.com/links/ap_riceCommonWeedsinRiceField.shtml|title=Common weeds in rice fields|publisher=Ikisan}}</ref>

==See also==
*[[Indigenous Australian food groups]]

==References==
{{reflist}}
* Turner, Margaret-Mary, ''Arrernte Foods: Foods from Central Australia'', IAD Press, Alice Springs, 1994, ISBN 0-949659-76-2, p22.

{{italic title}}
{{taxobox

|regnum = [[Plantae]]

|unranked_classis = [[Monocots]]

|genus = ''[[Cyperus]]''
|species = '''''C. difformis'''''
|binomial = ''Cyperus difformis''
|binomial_authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]
|synonyms_ref=<ref name=kathe/>
|synonyms = *''Cyperus lateriflorus'' <small>Torr. 1859, illegitimate homonym, not Steud. 1829</small>
*''Cyperus protractus'' <small>Link 1821, illegitimate homonym, not Delile 1813</small>
*''Cyperus viridis'' <small>Willd. ex Kunth 1837, illegitimate homonym, not Krock. 1787 nor Sieber ex C. Presl 1828 nor Roxb. ex C.B. Clarke 1884</small>
*''Cyperus holoschoenoides'' <small>Jan ex Schult.</small>

}}
'''''Cyperus difformis''''' is a species of [[Cyperus|sedge]] known by several common names, including '''variable flatsedge'''<ref>{{PLANTS|id=CYDI4|taxon=Cyperus difformis|accessdate=17 January 2016}}</ref> and '''smallflower umbrella-sedge'''. This plant is native to southern [[Europe]], most of [[Africa]] and [[Asia]], and [[Australia]], and it is naturalized in other areas of the world, including large parts of the Americas.<ref name=kathe>[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=236342 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families]</ref><ref>[http://luirig.altervista.org/flora/taxa/index1.php?scientific-name=cyperus+difformis Altervista Flora Italiana, Zigolo delle risaie, Cyperus difformis L.] includes photos plus range maps for Europe and North America</ref><ref>Miller, A.G. & Morris, M. (2004). Ethnoflora of Soqotra Archipelago: 1-759. The Royal Botanic Garden, Edinburgh. </ref><ref>Sita, P. & Moutsambote, J.-M. (2005). Catalogue des plantes vasculaires du Congo , ed. sept. 2005: 1-158. ORSTOM, Centre de Brazzaville. </ref><ref>Acevedo-Rodríguez, P. & Strong, M.T. (2005). Monocotyledons and Gymnosperms of Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands. Contributions from the United States National Herbarium 52: 1-415. </ref><ref>Tanaka, N., Koyama, T. & Murata, J. (2005). The flowering plants of Mt. Popa, central Myanmar - Results of Myanmar-Japanese joint expeditions, 2000-2004. Makinoa 5: 1-102. </ref><ref>Sosef, M.S.M. & al. (2006). Check-list des plantes vasculaires du Gabon. Scripta Botanica Belgica 35: 1-438. </ref><ref>Figueiredo, E. & Smith, G.F. (2008). Plants of Angola. Strelitzia 22: 1-279. National Botanical Institute, Pretoria</ref><ref>Hoenselaar, K., Verdcourt, B. & Beentje, H. (2010). Cyperaceae. Flora of Tropical East Africa: 1-466. </ref><ref>Figueiredo, E., Paiva, J., Stévart, T., Oliveira, F. & Smith, G.F. (2011). Annotated catalogue of the flowering plants of São Tomé and Príncipe. Bothalia 41: 41-82. </ref>

''Cyperus difformis'' is a plant of [[aquatic plant|aquatic]] and moist habitats. It is a weed of [[Paddy field|rice fields]], but not generally a troublesome one. This is an annual herb with one to many thin, soft erect stems reaching over 30 centimeters in maximum height. There are usually a few long, wispy leaves around the base of the plant. The [[inflorescence]] is a rounded bundle one to three centimeters wide, containing up to 120 [[raceme|spikelets]], each long and partially or entirely covered in up to 30 [[bract]]ed flowers. The flowers are light brown with areas darker brown and sometimes a yellowish or purplish tint.<ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=2&taxon_id=242101119 Flora of China, Vol. 23 Page 226, <big>异型莎草</big> yi xing suo cao, ''Cyperus difformis'' Linnaeus, Cent. Pl. 2: 6. 1756. ]</ref><ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=242101119 Flora of North America, Vol. 23 Page 156, ''Cyperus difformis'' Linnaeus, Cent. Pl. II. 6. 1756. ]</ref>

77.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = Smooth flatsedge
|image = Starr 080609-8032 Cyperus laevigatus.jpg
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Monocots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Commelinids]]
|ordo = [[Poales]]
|familia = [[Cyperaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Cyperus]]''
|species = '''''C. laevigatus'''''
|binomial = ''Cyperus laevigatus''
|binomial_authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]
}}
'''''Cyperus laevigatus''''' is a species of [[Cyperus|sedge]] known by the common name '''smooth flatsedge'''.

==Distribution==
''Cyperus laevigatus'' is grows in wet areas, especially in [[brackish water]], wet [[alkali soils|alkaline soils]], mineral-rich [[hot spring]]s, and other moist [[saline soil|saline]] and alkaline habitat. It is known from the beaches of the [[Hawaiian Islands]] and salty pools in the deserts of the [[Southwestern United States]] ([[California]], [[Arizona]], [[Texas]]) down through [[Mexico]] and [[Central America]] to [[South America]]. It is also widespread across most of the [[West Indies]], [[Africa]], the [[Mediterranean Basin]], the [[Middle East]], [[India]], [[Central Asia]], [[Australia]] and various oceanic islands.<ref>[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=237182 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families]</ref><ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=242101122 Flora of North America]</ref><ref>Acevedo-Rodríguez, P. & Strong, M.T. (2005). Monocotyledons and Gymnosperms of Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands. Contributions from the United States National Herbarium 52: 1-415.</ref><ref>Govaerts, R. & Simpson, D.A. (2007). World Checklist of Cyperaceae. Sedges: 1-765. The Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew.</ref><ref>Dobignard, D. & Chatelain, C. (2010). Index synonymique de la flore d'Afrique du nord 1: 1-455. Éditions des conservatoire et jardin botaniques, Genève.</ref><ref>Hoenselaar, K., Verdcourt, B. & Beentje, H. (2010). Cyperaceae. Flora of Tropical East Africa: 1-466.</ref><ref>Lambdon, P. (2012). Flowering plants & ferns of St Helena: 1-624. Pisces publications for St Helena nature conservation group.</ref>

==Description==
''Cyperus laevigatus''is a perennial sedge growing up to 60 centimeters tall, sometimes in clumps interconnected on a horizontal [[rhizome]]. The [[inflorescence]] is a small array of cylindrical spikelets with one to three leaflike [[bract]]s at the base. The spikelets vary in color from green to reddish to dark brown.

==History==
In Hawai'i, ''Cyperus laevigatus'' is known as Makaloa and was used by the people of Ni'ihau to make beautiful plaited mats.  Many of the finest examples of plaiting in Hawai'i is made from Makaloa.<ref>[http://www2.bishopmuseum.org/ethnobotanydb/resultsdetailed.asp?search=makaloa Hawaiian Ethnobotany]</ref>

78.text:
{{taxobox
|image = Cyperus odoratus 1.jpg
|image_width = 240px
|image_caption = ''Cyperus odoratus''
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Monocots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Commelinids]]
|ordo = [[Poales]]
|familia = [[Cyperaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Cyperus]]''
|species = '''''C. odoratus'''''
|binomial = ''Cyperus odoratus''
|binomial_authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]
|synonyms_ref = <ref name=lovey/>
|synonyms = *''Diclidium odoratum'' <small>(L.) Schrad. ex Nees</small> 
*''Torulinium odoratum'' <small>(L.) S.S.Hooper</small>
*plus a few hundred others
}}
'''''Cyperus odoratus''''' is a species of [[Cyperus|sedge]] known by the common names '''fragrant flatsedge''' and '''rusty flatsedge'''. This plant can be found in much of the tropical and warm temperate world, including [[South America|South]], [[Central America|Central]], and [[North America]], [[Southeast Asia]], some [[Pacific Islands]], [[Australia]], [[New Guinea]], [[Madagascar]], and central [[Africa]].<ref name=lovey>[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=237787 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families]</ref><ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=2&taxon_id=242357691 Flora of China, Vol. 23 Page 240, <big>断节莎</big> duan jie suo, ''Cyperus odoratus'' Linnaeus, Sp. Pl. 1: 46. 1753. ]</ref><ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=242357691 Flora of North America, Vol. 23 Page 191, ''Cyperus odoratus'' Linnaeus, Sp. Pl. 1: 46. 1753. ]</ref> It is a plant of wet, muddy areas, including disturbed and altered sites. This species is quite variable and may in fact be more than one species included under one name. In general this is an annual plant approaching half a meter in height on average but known to grow much taller. It usually has some long, thin leaves around the base. The [[inflorescence]] is made up of one to several cylindrical spikes attached at a common point. Each of the spikes bears a large number of flat, oval-shaped [[raceme|spikelets]]. Each spikelet is usually light brown to reddish-brown and has a few to over 20 flowers. Each flower is covered by a tough, flat [[bract]] with a visible midvein. The fruit is a flat [[achene]] less than two millimeters long.<ref>[http://ucjeps.berkeley.edu/cgi-bin/get_JM_treatment.pl?7928,8084,8096 Jepson Manual Treatment]</ref>

'''''Cyperus polystachyos''''', also known as '''''Pycreus polystachyos''''' is a herbaceous species in the family [[Cyperaceae]], widespread in tropical and subtropical areas around the world, sometimes extending its range into temperate regions. In the [[United States]], it has been reported from a region from [[Texas]] to [[Maine]].<ref name=jasmine>[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=260427 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families]</ref><ref name=USDA>{{cite web|title=Cyperus polystachyos|url=http://plants.usda.gov/core/profile?symbol=CYPO|website=plants.usda.gov|publisher=[[USDA]]|accessdate=27 June 2014}}</ref><ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Cyperus%20polystachyos.png Biota of North America Program, 2013 county distribution map]</ref><ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=220003733 Flora of North America, Vol. 23 Page 160, ''Cyperus polystachyos'' Rottbøll, Descr. Pl. Rar. 21. 1772. ]</ref>

It is common in the [[Neotropics]] as a weed in grass lawns.

|regnum = [[Plantae]]

|synonyms = *''Cyperus aristatus'' <small>Torrb.</small>
*''Cyperus inflexus'' <small>Muhl.</small>
*and many others
}}
'''''Cyperus squarrosus''''' is a species of [[Cyperus|sedge]] known by several common names, including '''bearded flatsedge''' and '''awned flatsedge'''. It is found in wet environments in [[North America|North]] and [[South America]], [[Africa]], [[Australia]], southern [[Asia]] ([[China]], [[India]], [[Saudi Arabia]], [[Indochina]], etc.) and [[Italy]].<ref name=gina>[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=238625 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families]</ref><ref>[http://luirig.altervista.org/flora/taxa/index1.php?scientific-name=cyperus+aristatus Altervista Flora  Italiana, Zigolo pavese, ''Cyperus aristatus'' Rottb. ] includes photos and distribution maps</ref>

''Cyperus squarrosus'' is a small sedge, reaching a maximum height between 10 and 16 centimeters. There are one to three short, thin leaves around the base of the plant. The [[inflorescence]] is a single spherical or bunched spike of up to 30 [[raceme|spikelets]]. Each spikelet is flat and has excurved awns, meaning the tip of each of the two to eight flowers on the spikelet curls outward. The spikelets are bright green to yellowish or brown. The curved awn tips and the small size of this sedge are good identifying characteristics.<ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=242101128 Flora of North America, ''Cyperus squarrosus'' ]</ref><ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=2&taxon_id=242101128 Flora of China, Vol. 23 Page 238, <big>具芒鳞砖子苗</big> ju mang lin zhuan zi miao, ''Cyperus squarrosus'' Linnaeus, Cent. Pl. 2: 6. 1756. ]</ref>

81.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = Starfruit
|image = Damasonium_californicum.jpg
|image_caption = ''[[Damasonium californicum]]''
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Monocots]]
|ordo = [[Alismatales]]
|familia = [[Alismataceae]]
|genus = '''''Damasonium'''''
|genus_authority = [[Philip Miller|Mill.]]
|subdivision_ranks = Species
|subdivision = See text
}}
'''''Damasonium''''' is a genus of six species of [[flowering plant]]s in the family [[Alismataceae]], commonly known as '''starfruit''' and by the older name '''thrumwort'''. The genus has a [[cosmopolitan distribution|subcosmopolitan]] but very patchy distribution.<ref name=grin>Germplasm Resources Information Network: [http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/splist.pl?3377 ''Damasonium'']</ref><ref name=apni>Australian Plant Name Index: [http://www.anbg.gov.au/cgi-bin/apni?taxon_name=Damasonium%25 ''Damasonium'']</ref><ref name=fnwe>Flora of NW Europe: [http://ip30.eti.uva.nl/BIS/flora.php?selected=beschrijving&menuentry=soorten&id=4164 ''Damasonium'']</ref><ref name=fna>Flora of North America: [http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=109256 ''Damasonium'']</ref>

They are [[aquatic plant|aquatic]] [[perennial plant|perennial]] [[herbaceous plant]]s growing in shallow water or mud beside ponds. The [[leaf|leaves]] are all basal, floating, or aerial in plants on pond margins. The [[flowers]] are [[hermaphrodite]], in one to many [[Whorl (botany)|whorls]], in [[umbel]]s, [[raceme]]s or [[panicle]]s; they have six stamens, and six to nine carpels arranged in a whorl, connate at the base, each with two to many ventral ovules; The [[carpel|styles]] are terminal. The [[fruit]] is a whorl of follicles; the follicles are laterally compressed, stellately radiating, with a more or less elongated apical beak.<ref name=fnwe/><ref name=fna/>

==Species==
There are at the present time (May 2014) six currently accepted species:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/qsearch.do|title=World Checklist of Selected Plant Families: Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew|website=apps.kew.org|language=de|access-date=2017-01-26}}</ref><ref>[http://luirig.altervista.org/flora/taxa/index1.php?scientific-name=damasonium+alisma Altervista Flora Italiana, Mestolaccia stellata, Starfruit, ''Damasonium'']</ref>

*''[[Damasonium alisma]]'' <small>Mill.</small> ([[synonymy|syn.]] ''D. stellatum'' <small>Thuill.;</small> ''D. polyspermum'' <small>Cosson;</small> ''D. constrictum'' <small>Juz.).</small>  - [[Great Britain]], [[France]], [[Portugal]], [[Spain]], [[Italy]], [[Greece]], [[Russia]], [[Ukraine]], [[Moldova]], [[Kazakhstan]] 
*''[[Damasonium bourgaei]]'' <small>Coss.</small> - [[Mediterranean Basin]] and [[India]]
*''[[Damasonium californicum]]'' <small>Torr. ex Benth.</small> - western [[United States]] ([[Idaho]], [[Oregon]], [[Nevada]], [[California]], [[Montana]], [[Washington (state)|Washington State]])<ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Damasonium%20californicum.png Biota of North America Program] Image</ref> 
*''[[Damasonium constrictum]]'' <small>Juz.</small> -[[Kazakhstan]] and [[Altay Republic|Altay]] region of [[Siberia]]
*''[[Damasonium minus]]'' <small>(R. Br.) Buchenau</small> (syn. ''D. australe'' <small>Salisb.</small>). [[Australia]].
*''[[Damasonium polyspermum]]'' <small>Coss.</small> - [[Spain]], [[France]], [[Portugal]], [[Greece]], [[Sicily]], [[Algeria]], [[Libya]], [[Morocco]] 

==Ecology==
''Damasonium alisma'' grows in acidic ponds. In [[Great Britain]] it went into decline along with the [[village pond]]. It once grew in many English counties from [[Sussex]] north to [[Shropshire]], but by 1900 was reduced to two ponds in [[Buckinghamshire]] and one in [[Surrey]]. It is gradually starting to make a come back due to intense conservation efforts. It requires open, well-lit, shallow water to grow in and regularly churned up mud for its seeds to germinate.

It is very variable in form according to the depth of the water it is growing in. Dwarf plants with aerial leaves occur growing sub-terrestrially on mud. The number of ovules vary. Usually there are two in each carpel, but carpels with four to many occur over the range. Multi-ovulate forms from southwestern [[Europe]] and [[Sicily]] were originally described as ''D. polyspermum''. 

The shape of the follicles depends on the number of seeds; the beak (empty upper part) of the carpel is elongated in two-seeded plants, whereas in many-seeded plants the seeds occupy more of the follicle and the beak is relatively shorter and less well defined.

82.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = Denhamia
|image = Denhamia oleaster fruit close up.jpg
|image_caption = [[Denhamia oleaster]]
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Celastrales]]
|familia = Celastraceae
|genus = '''Denhamia'''
|genus_authority = [[Carl Daniel Friedrich Meisner|Meisn.]]
||}}
'''''Denhamia''''' is a [[genus]] of plants within the family [[Celastraceae]], with species in [[Australia]] and [[New Caledonia]]. The species inhabit a variety of environments, from [[rainforest]] to semi-arid [[savanna]]. All species grow as shrubs or small trees up to 10 metres in height. The genus is composed of nine species, with two currently unnamed species:

*''[[Denhamia celastroides]]''
*''[[Denhamia fournieri]]''
*''[[Denhamia moorei]]''
*''[[Denhamia obscura]]''
*''[[Denhamia oleaster]]''
*''[[Denhamia parviflora]]''
*''[[Denhamia pittosporoides]]''
**''[[Denhamia pittosporoides subsp. pittosporoides]]''
**''[[Denhamia pittosporoides subsp. angustifolia]]''
*''[[Denhamia viridissima]]
*''Denhamia'' sp. Jardine River
*''Denhamia'' sp. Junee Tableland

Some authors regard Denhamia as a [[Paraphyly|paraphyletic]] genus which should properly include the Australasian ''[[Maytenus]]'' species.

'''''Dentella''''' is a [[genus]] of [[flowering plant]]s in the [[Rubiaceae]] [[Family (biology)|family]]. Most species genus are endemic to [[Australia]], with one species also extending through southeast Asia to subtropical Asia and the southwestern Pacific.<ref name="WCSP">{{cite web|url=http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/qsearch.do?plantName=Dentella|title=''Dentella'' in the World Checklist of Rubiaceae|accessdate=June 2014}}</ref>

==Species==

*''[[Dentella misera]]'' <small>[[Herbert Kenneth Airy Shaw|Airy Shaw]]</small> - northern [[Australia]]
*''[[Dentella pulvinata]]'' <small>[[Herbert Kenneth Airy Shaw|Airy Shaw]]</small> - central [[Australia]]

84.text:
{{taxobox
|image = DeschampsiaCesp.jpg
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Flowering plant|Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Monocots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Commelinids]]
|ordo = [[Poales]]
|familia = [[Poaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Deschampsia]]''
|species = '''''D. cespitosa'''''
|binomial = ''Deschampsia cespitosa''
|binomial_authority = ([[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]) [[Ambroise Marie François Joseph Palisot de Beauvois|P.Beauv.]]
|synonyms = ''Deschampsia caespitosa''
|}}

'''''Deschampsia cespitosa''''', commonly known as '''tufted hairgrass''' or '''tussock grass'''<ref name="afpd">{{cite web
 | url = http://www.ville-ge.ch/cjb/bd/africa/details.php?langue=an&id=50145
 | title = ''Deschampsia caespitosa'' (L.) P.Beauv. record n° 50145
 | accessdate = 2008-05-13
 | work = African Plants Database
 | publisher = [[Natural History Museum of Geneva|South African National Biodiversity Institute, the Conservatoire et Jardin botaniques de la Ville de Genève]] and Tela Botanica
 }}</ref> is a [[perennial]] tufted plant in the grass family [[Poaceae]].<ref>''Jepson Manual''. 1993</ref> Distribution of this [[Deschampsia]] grass species is widespread including the eastern and western coasts of North America, parts of South America, Eurasia and Australia. 

==Description==

It can be found on all types of grassland, although it prefers poorly drained soil. It forms a major component of the [[British NVC community MG9]]  - ''[[Holcus lanatus]]'' to ''Deschampsia cespitosa'' [[mesotrophic soil|mesotrophic]] grasslands.  It can exist up to altitudes of 4000 ft.<ref>Grasses by C E Hubbard, 1978, published by Penguin books</ref>

A distinguishing feature is the upper surface of the leaf blade which feels rough and can cut in one direction, but is smooth in the opposite direction.  The upper side of the leaves are deeply grooved, and are dark green.

It can grow to 4.5 feet (1.5 Meters) tall, and has a long, narrow, pointed ligule.<ref>[http://www.bsbi.org.uk/identification.html Identification Resources[[BSBI]]] Identification Resources website</ref>

It flowers from June until August.

<gallery>
Image:Deschampsia cespitosa seed.jpg |Seed
Image:Deschampsia cespitosa ligula.jpeg |Ligule is long and pointed
</gallery>

==North America==
Typical native grass associates in the western North American [[California coastal prairie|coastal prairie]]s, such as the [[California coastal prairie]], are ''[[Festuca californica]]'', ''[[Festuca idahoensis]]'', ''[[Danthonia californica]]'',  and ''[[Nassella pulchra]]''.

==See also==
*[[Ornamental grass]]

==Line notes==

85.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|image =Starr 020808-0028 Dichelachne crinita.jpg 
|image_width = 240px
|image_caption = ''Longhair Plume Grass''
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Monocots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Commelinids]]
|ordo = [[Poales]]
|familia = [[Poaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Dichelachne]]''
|species = '''''D. crinita '''''
|binomial = ''Dichelachne crinita''
|binomial_authority = ([[Carl Linnaeus the Younger|L.f.]]) [[Hook.f.]] 
}}
'''''Dichelachne crinita ''''', commonly known as the '''longhair plume grass''', is a type of grass found in [[Australia]], [[New Zealand]] and islands of the Pacific Ocean. It is often seen on sandy soils near the sea as well as woodlands. The flowering panicles are open and feathery at maturity. The grass may grow up to 1.5 metres (5 ft) tall. ''Crinita'', the specific epithet, is  derived from Latin (hairy).<ref>Les Robinson - Field Guide to the Native Plants of Sydney, ISBN 9780731812110 page 269</ref>

==Taxonomy==
[[Carolus Linnaeus the Younger]] described the longhair plume grass in his ''[[Supplementum Plantarum]]'' in 1781 as  ''Anthoxanthum crinitum''. ''Crinita'' is derived from the verb ''crinio'' "I cover with hair" and refers to the hairy [[panicle]]s. [[Joseph Dalton Hooker]] gave it its current name in 1853.<ref name=abrs>{{Flora of Australia Online | name = Dichelachne crinita | id = 53303}}</ref> Longhair plumegrass is the common name in Australia,<ref name="APNI">{{APNI | name = ''Dichelachne crinita'' | id = 47764}}</ref> while clovenfoot plumegrass is a name recorded in America.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=DICR7 |title= Plants Profile - ''Dichelachne crinita'' (L. f.) Hook. f.  clovenfoot plumegrass |author=Natural Resources Conservation Service|publisher=USDA |accessdate= 23 May 2012}}</ref>

==Description==
The longhair plume grass is a tufted [[perennial plant]] which can reach 1.5 m (5 ft) high. The flowers are roughly oblong-shaped or cylindrical panicles and appear in spring.<ref name=floransw>{{NSW Flora Online|genus=Dichelachne |species=crinita|author= S. W. L. Jacobs & K. L. McClay}}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
The longhair plume grass is native to all states of Australia, New Guinea, Norfolk Island, the Kermadec Islands and New Zealand. It is unclear whether it is native or naturalised on Lord Howe Island.<ref name=abrs/> It has become naturalised on Maui in the Hawaiian Islands.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://botany.si.edu/pacificislandbiodiversity/hawaiianflora/result.cfm?genus=Dichelachne&species=crinita&rank1=&epithet1=|title=Checklist Query Results |date=2012|work=Flora of the Hawaiian Islands|publisher=Smithsonian Institution|accessdate=23 May 2012}}</ref> It grows on sandy or sandstone-based soils.<ref name=floransw/>

Within the Sydney region, it is found in grassland to open forest communities, associated with woodland trees such as smooth-barked apple (''[[Angophora costata]]''), Sydney peppermint (''[[Eucalyptus piperita]]''), silvertop ash (''[[Eucalyptus sieberi|E. sieberi]]'') and red bloodwood (''[[Corymbia gummifera]]''), in scrub with coastal banksia (''[[Banksia integrifolia]]'') and broad-leaved apple (''[[Angophora subvelutina]]'').<ref name=Benson2005>{{cite journal|author1=Benson, Doug |author2=McDougall, Lyn |year=2005|title= Ecology of Sydney Plant Species Part 10: Monocotyledon families Lemnaceae to Zosteraceae|journal= Cunninghamia|volume= 9|issue=1|pages=16–212|url=http://www.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0018/72522/Cun9Ben016.pdf}}</ref> It is a component of the Endangered [[Eastern Suburbs Banksia Scrub]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.environment.nsw.gov.au/resources/nature/recoveryFinalEsbs.pdf |title=
Eastern Suburbs Banksia Scrub Endangered Ecological Community Recovery Plan |author= NSW Department of Environment & Heritage |publisher=Department of Environment & Heritage, New South Wales Government |date=February 2004 | accessdate = 23 May 2012}}</ref> and shale/sandstone transition forest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.environment.nsw.gov.au/determinations/ShaleSandstoneTransitionForestEndComListing.htm |title = Shale/sandstone transition forest - endangered ecological community listing |author= NSW Scientific Committee |publisher=Department of Environment & Heritage, New South Wales Government |date=28 February 2011| accessdate = 23 May 2012}}</ref>

In South Australia, it is associated with such trees as drooping sheoak (''[[Allocasuarina verticillata]]''), pink gum (''[[Eucalyptus fasciculosa]]''), sugar gum (''[[Eucalyptus cladocalyx|E. cladocalyx]]''), messmate (''[[Eucalyptus obliqua|E. obliqua]]''), and shrubs such as golden wattle (''[[Acacia pycnantha]]'') and peach heath (''[[Lissanthe strigosa]]'').<ref>{{cite book|author1=John Peter Jessop |author2=Gilbert Roelof Maria Dashorst |author3=Fiona M. James |title=Grasses of South Australia: An Illustrated Guide to the Native and Naturalised Species|publisher=Wakefield Press|date=2006|pages=40|isbn=1862546940|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G0j6J7sCXAIC&pg=PA214&lpg=PA214&dq=%22Dichelachne+crinita%22+ecology&source=bl&ots=SfUm6V2EEz&sig=_AFbfI2cmjd7Ns7lc9hZtCSysIs&hl=en&sa=X&ei=K_-6T_DdF_GUiQem_-WCCQ&ved=0CFgQ6AEwBjgK#v=onepage&q=%22Dichelachne%20crinita%22%20ecology&f=false}}</ref>

}}
[[File:Digitaria ciliaris at Peradeniya Royal Botanical Garden.jpg|thumb|250px|At [[Peradeniya Royal Botanical Garden]].]]
'''''Digitaria ciliaris''''' is a species of [[Poaceae|grass]] known by the common names '''southern crabgrass''',<ref name=usda>[http://plants.usda.gov/core/profile?symbol=DICI ''Digitaria ciliaris''.] USDA Plants Profile.</ref> '''tropical finger-grass''',<ref name=BSBI07>{{cite web|title=BSBI List 2007 |publisher=Botanical Society of Britain and Ireland |url=http://www.bsbi.org.uk/BSBIList2007.xls |format=xls |archive-url=http://www.webcitation.org/6VqJ46atN?url=http://www.bsbi.org.uk/BSBIList2007.xls |archive-date=2015-01-25 |accessdate=2014-10-17 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> '''tropical crabgrass''' or '''summer grass'''.<ref name=keys>[http://keys.lucidcentral.org/keys/v3/UQCentenary/key/UQ_Centenary/Media/Html/digitariaciliaris.htm ''Digitaria ciliaris'' - Common Australian Garden Weeds].</ref>

The grass is known as "ගුරු තණ - guru thana" in [[Sri Lanka]].

==Distribution==
''Digitaria ciliaris'' is a tough plant, believed to have originated in Asia but now found all over the [[tropical belt]] of the planet, as well as in many [[Temperate climate|temperate]] regions of both hemispheres.<ref name=cabi/> This grass is an [[invasive species]] considered an aggressive [[weed]] in certain countries, including [[China]], [[Mexico]] and the [[United States]].<ref name=cabi/>
  
Together with ''[[Portulaca oleracea]]'', ''[[Ipomoea pes-caprae]]'' and ''[[Melanthera biflora]]'', ''Digitaria ciliaris'' is usually one of the first species colonizing [[Land degradation|degraded or altered environments]] in tropical zones of the planet.<ref>Heatwole, H., Done, T., Cameron, E. ''Community Ecology of a Coral Cay, A Study of One-Tree Island, Great Barrier Reef, Australia.'' Series: Monographiae Biologicae, Vol. 43, p. 102</ref>

==Description==
This grass is as annual that can grow up to 1 m tall, but is usually much shorter. The roots are at the nodes and the stems produce [[stolon|runners]] that allow the plant to grow fast forming scruffy-looking patches about 1 m across and half a metre in height. The leaves are linear to linear-ovate narrowing at the tip to 15 centimeters long. The [[inflorescence]] is at the top of a long stem, usually much taller than the leaves, with two to nine  5–10 cm long sub-digitate racemes.<ref name=cabi>[http://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/18912 ''Digitaria ciliaris'' - CABI]</ref> 
{|
|- valign="top"
|[[File:Starr 080605-6706 Digitaria ciliaris.jpg|thumb|250px|General appearance of the grass.]]
|[[File:Starr 020112-9001 Digitaria ciliaris.jpg|thumb|175px|Plant and roots.]]
|}

87.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = Air potato
|image = Dioscorea bulbifera at Kadavoor.jpg
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Monocots]]
|ordo = [[Dioscoreales]]
|familia = [[Dioscoreaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Dioscorea]]''
|species = '''''D. bulbifera'''''
|binomial = ''Dioscorea bulbifera''
|binomial_authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]<ref name=WCSP>{{WCSP | 239891 | accessdate = 17 March 2017 }}</ref>
|synonyms =
*''Helmia bulbifera'' <small>(L.) Kunth</small>
*''Polynome bulbifera'' <small>(L.) Salisb.</small>
*''Dioscorea tamifolia'' <small>Salisb.</small>
*''Dioscorea crispata'' <small>Roxb.</small>
*''Dioscorea heterophylla'' <small>Roxb.</small>
*''Dioscorea pulchella'' <small>Roxb.</small>
*''Dioscorea tenuiflora'' <small>Schltdl.</small>
*''Dioscorea latifolia'' <small>Benth.</small>
*''Dioscorea hoffa'' <small>Cordem.</small>
*''Dioscorea hofika'' <small>Jum. & H.Perrier</small>
*''Dioscorea anthropophagorum'' <small>A.Chev.</small>
*''Dioscorea longipetiolata'' <small>Baudon</small>
*''Dioscorea rogersii'' <small>Prain & Burkill</small>
*''Dioscorea korrorensis'' <small>R.Knuth</small> 
*''Dioscorea perrieri'' <small>R.Knuth</small> 
|synonyms_ref = <ref name=WCSP/>
}}
'''''Dioscorea bulbifera''''' (commonly known as the '''air potato''', '''air yam''', '''bitter yam''', '''cheeky yam''', '''potato yam'''<ref name=NTBG/>) is a species of true [[Yam (vegetable)|yam]] in the yam [[family (biology)|family]], [[Dioscoreaceae]]. It is native to Africa, southern Asia, India, [[Maldives]], China, Japan, the [[Philippines]], and [[Indonesia]] and northern Australia.<ref name=WCSP/> It is widely cultivated and has escaped to become naturalized in many regions ([[Latin America]], the [[West Indies]], the Southeastern [[United States]], and various oceanic islands).<ref name=WCSP/>

==Description==
''Dioscorea bulbifera'' is a [[Perennial plant|perennial]] [[vine]] with broad, alternate leaves, and two types of [[storage organ]]s.  The plant forms [[bulb]]ils in the leaf axils of the twining stems, and [[tuber]]s beneath the ground. These tubers are like small, oblong [[potato]]es.  Some varieties are edible and [[plant cultivation|cultivated]] as a [[agriculture|food crop]], especially in [[West Africa]].  The tubers of edible varieties often have a bitter taste, which can be removed by boiling. They can then be prepared in the same way as other yams, potatoes, and [[sweet potato]]es.

The air potato is one of the most widely consumed yam species. It can grow up to 150 ft tall.<ref>{{Failed verification|date=December 2016}}[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=2&taxon_id=200028093 Flora of China, Vol. 24 Page 287, <big>黄独</big> huang du, ''Dioscorea bulbifera'' Linnaeus, Sp. Pl. 2: 1033. 1753. ]</ref>

Air potato can grow extremely quickly, roughly 8 in per day,<ref>[http://texasinvasives.org/plant_database/detail.php?symbol=DIBU Invasives Database, TexasInvasives.org, Dioscorea bulbifera]</ref> and eventually reach over 60 ft long.{{Citation needed|date=February 2016}} It typically climbs to the tops of trees and has a tendency to take over [[native plant]]s. New plants develop from bulbils that form on the plant, and these bulbils serve as a means of [[biological dispersal|dispersal]]. The aerial [[plant stem|stems]] of air potato die back in winter, but [[sprouting|resprouting]] occurs from bulbils and underground tubers.

The primary means of spread and [[plant reproduction|reproduction]] are by the bulbils. The smallest bulbils make control of air potato difficult due to their ability to sprout at a very small stage. The vine produces small white flowers; however, these are rarely seen when it grows in Florida. The fruits are capsules.<ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=200028093 Flora of North America, ''Dioscorea bulbifera'' Linnaeus, Sp. Pl. 2: 1033. 1753. ]</ref>

==Uses==
Air potato has been used as a [[home remedy|folk remedy]] to treat [[conjunctivitis]], [[diarrhea]], and [[dysentery]], among other ailments.<ref>{{cite book |last=Duke |first=J. A. |authorlink= |author2=Judith L. DuCellier |title=Handbook of Alternative Cash Crops |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-tg7R4hU8hkC&printsec=frontcover#PPA230,M1 |year=1993 |publisher=CRC Press |location= |isbn=0-8493-3620-1}}</ref>

===Toxicity===
Uncultivated forms, such as those found growing wild in Florida, can be poisonous. These varieties contain the [[steroid]] [[diosgenin]], which is a principal material used in the manufacture of a number of [[Chemical synthesis|synthetic]] [[steroid hormones|steroidal]] [[hormone]]s, such as those used in [[hormonal contraception]].<ref name=NTBG>{{cite web |title=Meet the plants: ''Dioscorea bulbifera'' |work=National Tropical Botanical Garden |url=http://www.ntbg.org/plants/plant_details.php?plantid=4171 |accessdate=2007-11-17 }}</ref>  There have been claims<ref>{{cite web|title=Pest Plants, Air Potato: ''Dioscorea bulbifera'' |date=Jan 2010 |work=WalterReeves.com |url=http://www.walterreeves.com/landscaping/article.phtml?cat=10&id=33 |accessdate=2010-01-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061112093511/http://www.walterreeves.com/landscaping/article.phtml?cat=10&id=33 |archivedate=2006-11-12 |df= }}</ref> that even the wild forms are rendered edible after drying and boiling, leading to confusion over actual [[toxicity]].

==Invasive species==
In some places, such as Florida, it is considered a [[noxious weed]] because of its quick-growing, large-leafed vine that spreads tenaciously and shades out any plants growing beneath it. The bulbils on the vines sprout and become new vines, twisting around each other to form a thick mat. If the plant is cut to the ground, the tubers can survive for extended periods and send up new [[shoot]]s later.<ref>{{cite web |title=Air potato takes over |work=The Nature Conservancy |url=http://www.nature.org/initiatives/invasivespecies/misc/airpotato.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070515104755/http://www.nature.org/initiatives/invasivespecies/misc/airpotato.html |archivedate=May 15, 2007 |accessdate=February 10, 2013 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.invasivespeciesinfo.gov/plants/airpotato.shtml Species Profile- Air Potato (''Dioscorea bulbifera'')], National Invasive Species Information Center, [[United States National Agricultural Library]]</ref>

The [[leaf beetle]] ''[[Lilioceris cheni]]'' has been studied and employed as an agent of [[biological pest control]] for the plant, with releases in 2012.<ref name=usda>[http://www.aphis.usda.gov/plant_health/ea/downloads/2011/Lilioceris-airpotato.pdf Field release of ''Lilioceris cheni'' Gressit & Kimoto (Coleoptera: Chrysomelidae) for biological control of air potato, ''Dioscorea bulbifera'' (Dioscoreaceae), in the continental United States: Environmental Assessment.] USDA. 2011.</ref><ref name=miami>Morgan, C. [http://www.miamiherald.com/2012/09/21/3014684/in-south-florida-a-tiny-new-weapon.html In South Florida, a tiny new weapon against the invasive potato vine.] ''Miami Herald'' September 21, 2012. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121005195735/http://www.miamiherald.com/2012/09/21/3014684/in-south-florida-a-tiny-new-weapon.html |date=October 5, 2012 }}</ref>

'''''Dioscorea pentaphylla''''' is a species of flowering plant in the [[Dioscoreaceae|yam family]] known by the common name '''fiveleaf yam'''. It is native to southern and eastern [[Asia]] ([[China]], [[India]], [[Indochina]], [[Indonesia]], [[Philippines]], etc.) as well as [[New Guinea]] and northern [[Australia]]. It is widely cultivated as a food crop and naturalized in [[Cuba]] and on several island chains in the [[Pacific Islands|Pacific]] (including [[Hawaii]]).<ref name=j>[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=240656 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families]</ref><ref name=feis>Gucker, Corey L. 2009. [http://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/vine/diospp/all.html ''Dioscorea'' spp.] In: Fire Effects Information System, [Online]. U.S. Department of Agriculture, Forest Service, Rocky Mountain Research Station, Fire Sciences Laboratory.</ref><ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=2&taxon_id=200028128 Flora of China, Vol. 24 Page 289, 五叶薯蓣 wu ye shu yu, Dioscorea pentaphylla Linnaeus, Sp. Pl. 2: 1032. 1753. ]</ref><ref>Smith, A.C. (1979). Flora Vitiensis Nova. A new flora for Fiji (Spermatophytes only) 1: 1-495. Pacific Tropical Botanical Garden, Lawai.</ref><ref>Morat, P. & Veillon, J.-M. (1985). Contributions à la conaissance de la végétation et de la flore de Wallis et Futuna. Bulletin du Muséum National d'Histoire Naturelle. Section B, Adansonia 7: 259-329.</ref><ref>Tanaka, N., Koyama, T. & Murata, J. (2005). The flowering plants of Mt. Popa, central Myanmar - Results of Myanmar-Japanese joint expeditions, 2000-2004. Makinoa 5: 1-102.</ref><ref>Samanta, A.K. (2006). The genus ''Dioscorea'' L. in Darjeeling and Sikkim Himalayas - a census. Journal of Economic and Taxonomic Botany 30: 555-563.</ref><ref>Govaerts, R., Wilkin, P. & Saunders, R.M.K. (2007). World Checklist of Dioscoreales. Yams and their allies: 1-65. The Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew.</ref><ref>Wilkin, P. & Thapyai, C. (2009). Flora of Thailand 10(1): 1-140. The Forest Herbarium, National Park, Wildlife and Plant Conservation Department, Bangkok.</ref><ref>Acevedo-Rodríguez, P. & Strong, M.T. (2012). Catalogue of seed plants of the West Indies. Smithsonian Contributions to Botany 98: 1-1192.</ref>

''Dioscorea pentaphylla''  is a [[thorns, spines, and prickles|prickly]] [[vine]] that twines counterclockwise around objects and other plants. It may reach 10 meters in length. The alternately arranged leaves are compound, divided into 3 to 5 leaflets each up to 10 centimeters long. The plant produces horseshoe-shaped [[bulbil]]s about a centimeter long. New plants can sprout from the [[bulbils]]. Flowers are borne in spikes. The vine grows from a [[tuber]]. Specimens may weigh 3 pounds and may be located over a meter underground.<ref name=feis/>

The tubers of the vine can be cooked and eaten.<ref name=ethno>[http://herb.umd.umich.edu/herb/search.pl?searchstring=Dioscorea+pentaphylla ''Dioscorea pentaphylla''.] University of Michigan Ethnobotany.</ref>

[[File:Dioscoria transversa.jpg|thumb|dioscoria transversa]]

|name=Pencil yam
|synonyms=''Dioscorea punctata'' <small>R.Br.</small>

'''''Dioscorea transversa''''', '''Pencil yam''', is a vine of eastern and northern [[Australia]].<ref name=x>[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=241049 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families]</ref><ref>Govaerts, R., Wilkin, P. & Saunders, R.M.K. (2007). World Checklist of Dioscoreales. Yams and their allies: 1-65. The Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew.</ref>

The leaves are heart-shaped, shiny, with 5-7 prominent veins. The seed pods are rounded, green or pink before drying to a straw brown papery texture. The edible tubers are typically slender and long. There are two forms: an eastern [[rainforest]] and [[wet sclerophyll]] form which doesn't have [[bulbils]], and a northern form which occurs in open forests and has small bulbils and large inground [[tubers]].<ref name="Low 1988"/>

==Uses==
The tubers are a staple food of [[Australian Aboriginals]] and are eaten after cooking, usually in ground ovens.<ref name="Low 1988">{{Cite book|last= Low |first= Tim |year= 1988 |title= Wild Food Plants of Australia |location= North Ryde, N.S.W. |publisher= Angus & Robertson |isbn= 0-207-16930-6 }}</ref>

The '''Bombay ebony''', '''''Diospyros montana''''',<ref>http://www.flowersofindia.net/catalog/slides/Bistendu.html</ref> is a small deciduous tree in the [[Ebenaceae|ebony family]] up to {{convert|15|m}} tall, distributed all along the [[Western Ghats]] of [[India]], [[Sri Lanka]] and [[Australia]].<ref>http://www.biotik.org/india/species/d/diosmont/diosmont_en.html</ref><ref>[http://indiabiodiversity.org/species/show/31276 India Biodiversity]</ref>

==Common names==
* English – Mountain persimmon, mottled ebony
* Malayanum – Manjakara, Nanchimaram, Bali, Malayakathitholi
* Tamil – Karunthuvalisu, Vakanai, Vakkanatthi
* Other – Bistendu, Jagalkanti, Manjakara, Bankini, Vakkanai, Malayakathitholi

'''''Diplocyclos palmatus''''' is a [[vine]] in the [[Cucurbitaceae]] family. It is commonly known as '''Native Bryony''' or '''Striped cucumber'''.<ref name=RFK6.1/>

==Distribution==
The plant is native to [[rainforest]]s and dry rainforests ([[Tropical and subtropical dry broadleaf forests]]) habitats.  It is found in the [[Malesia]] phytoregion, including [[Papua New Guinea]], and in northern [[Australia]].<ref name=RFK6.1/>

The vine grows in thickets, monsoon forests, lowland and upland disturbed areas, and mountain rain forest.<ref name=RFK6.1/>

It grows from near sea level to {{convert|1000|m|ft}} in Australia, in [[Western Australia]], [[Northern Territory]], [[Cape York Peninsula]], and North East [[Queensland]], southwards to north-eastern [[New South Wales]].<ref name=RFK6.1/>

{{taxobox
|name = ''Diploglottis campbellii''
|image =Diploglottis campbellii juvenile leaf.jpg
|image_caption =''Diploglottis campbellii'' juvenile leaf
|status = EN

|species = '''''D. campbellii'''''
|binomial = ''Diploglottis campbellii''
|binomial_authority = [[Edwin Cheel|Cheel.]]
|}}

'''''Diploglottis campbellii''''' is a [[rainforest]] tree  northern [[New South Wales]] and southeastern [[Queensland]]. Growing to 30 metres tall, it is commonly known as the '''small-leaved tamarind'''. It is rare and threatened and is restricted to a small number of sites, each with a maximum of 3 trees per site. However, it is readily available from nurseries in the Northern Rivers area of New South Wales, and in south-eastern Queensland.

It has soft hairy new growth that becomes hairless with age. It has a grey brown trunk, the outer surface of live bark is green with orange to brown blotches, leaves 10–35 cm long, leaflets 4–8 cm, glossy upper surface, pale dull bottom surface

The [[inflorescence]] type is a [[panicle]] up to 15 centimetres long with small creamy brown flowers, Fruit usually 2 lobed but can be 1 or 3 lobed (each lobe holding a single seed), hairless, Red (rarely yellow) with a brown capsule, ripe Feb- April.

==Uses==
The fruit of small-leaved tamarind is [[Eating|edible]], and has a [[piquant]] flavour. It is used in [[sauces]] and [[preserves]]. Because the tree is very rare in the wild availability of fruit was a limitation for many years. However, increased planting of small-leaved tamarind has resulted in larger volumes of fruit becoming available for food, as well as ensuring the survival of this species.

The plant has proved adaptable in cultivation, being used in [[amenity]] [[horticulture]] and [[bushfood]] plantings. It is extensively planted in [[Lismore, New South Wales|Lismore]].

<gallery>
Image:Diploglottis campbellii YELLOW & Hicksbeachia pinnatifolia ORANGE.jpg|Unusual yellow fruit of Diploglottis campbellii and orange fruit of the rare [[Hicksbeachia pinnatifolia]]

</gallery>

94.text:
{{taxobox
|image = Dischidia major (Vahl) Merr.00.jpg
|image_caption = Plate 142 from ''[[Plantae Asiaticae Rariores]]''
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]]
|ordo = [[Gentianales]]
|familia = [[Apocynaceae]]
|subfamilia = [[Asclepiadoideae]]
|genus = ''[[Dischidia]]''
|species = '''''D. major'''''
|binomial = ''Dischidia major''
|binomial_authority = ([[Martin Vahl|Vahl]]) [[Elmer Drew Merrill|Merr.]]
}}
{{commons category}}
'''''Dischidia major''''', the '''Malayan urn vine''', is an unusual plant. ''Dischidia'' is a genus of some 80 species of trailing, twining or scandent, succulent epiphytes found throughout the tropics of [[Asia]] ([[New Guinea]], [[Moluccas]], [[Philippines]], [[India]], tropical [[Australia]], [[Hong Kong]], [[Taiwan]]) through to the western Pacific. They carry modified leaves, offering accommodation to ants, including those of the family [[Dolichoderinae]], and in return gain some sustenance from increased carbon dioxide and nitrogen levels, and a degree of protection from noxious animals and plants.<ref>[http://www.ehleringer.net/Jim/Publications/195.pdf ''Absorption of Ant-provided Carbon dioxide and Nitrogen by a Tropical Epiphyte'']{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> This [[Mutualism (biology)|mutualism]] trait, known as [[myrmecophily]], is widespread across the plant world and clearly carries considerable benefits for both ants and plant.<ref>{{citation |author=Groom, P. |year=1893 |title=On ''Dischidia rafflesiana'' (Wall.) |journal=Annals of Botany |volume=os-7 |issue=2 |pages=223–241 |url=http://aob.oxfordjournals.org/content/os-7/2/223.extract |doi=10.1093/aob/os-7.2.223}}</ref>

''Dischidia major'' twines around the branches and trunks of trees, having a preference for those that are decaying. It produces both circular succulent leaves of about 2 cm diameter, and hollow, pouch-like 12 cm long leaves, reminiscent of the fruits of ''[[Araujia sericifera]]'', a related species. These modified leaves, pitchers or ascidia, are purplish and richly dotted with stomata on the inner surface,<ref>[http://biostor.org/reference/5899 On the Structure of the Ascidia and Stomata of ''Dischidia rafflesiana'' Wall.]</ref> and have an opening at the top end near the stalk. Organic debris and rainwater, possibly augmented by secreted fluids, accumulate in the cavity over the course of time, offering a source of nutrition which the plant utilises by growing roots into the chamber. ''Dischidia astephana'' and ''D. parvifolia'' do not provide housing for resident ants, but have roots that penetrate decaying wood and humus, reaching into the ant nests and presumably obtaining nutrients from the ant waste there.<ref>[http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1095-8312.1986.tb01729.x/abstract ''A reassessment of the relations in Malaysia between ants (Crematogaster) on trees (Leptospermum and Dacrydium) and epiphytes of the genus Dischidia'']</ref><ref>[http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1096-3642.1846.tb00429.x/abstract Structure of the Ascidia]</ref>

''Dischidia major'' flowers are yellow striped with green, and arranged in few or many-flowered [[umbels]]. The fruit of ''D. major'' consists of the usual horn-shaped pair of [[follicle (fruit)|follicle]]s while the seed has a tuft of silky hairs at one end and includes an edible portion or [[elaiosome]] as incentive for ants to move the seed ([[myrmecochory]]) into nests inside the tree with an improved chance of germination and growth.
<gallery>
Dischidia major (Vahl) Merr.08a.jpg|Plate from [[Richard Wettstein]]'s ''Handbuch der Systematischen Botanik'' 1924
Annual report of the Board of Regents of the Smithsonian Institution (1896) (17813702993).jpg|Plate from Smithsonian Institution report, 1896
Dischidia rafflesiana vMH165.png|Plate from Anton Joseph Kerner von Marilaun, Adolf Hansen: Pflanzenleben
</gallery>

==Bibliography==

==External links==

*[http://www.antwiki.org/wiki/Philidris ''Philidris'' sp. and ''Dischidia major'']

The '''Chinese water chestnut''' or '''water chestnut''' (''Eleocharis dulcis'') is a grass-like [[Cyperaceae|sedge]] native to [[Asia]] ([[China]], [[Japan]], [[India]], [[Philippines]], etc.), [[Australia]], tropical [[Africa]], and various islands of the [[Pacific Islands|Pacific]] and [[Indian Ocean]]s.<ref>[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=242450 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families]. apps.kew.org</ref> It is grown in many countries for its edible [[corm]]s.<ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=2&taxon_id=200026729 Flora of China, Vol. 23 Page 191, <big>荸荠</big> bi qi, ''Eleocharis dulcis'' (N. L. Burman) Trinius ex Henschel, Vita Rumphii. 186. 1833.] efloras.org</ref>

The water chestnut is not a [[Nut (fruit)|nut]] at all, but an [[Aquatic plant|aquatic]] vegetable that grows in [[marshes]], under water, in the mud. It has stem-like, tubular green leaves that grow to about 1.5 m. The [[water caltrop]], which also is referred to by the same name, is unrelated and often confused with the water chestnut.

The small, rounded corms have a crisp, white flesh and may be eaten raw, slightly boiled, or grilled, and often are pickled or [[canning|tinned]]. They are a popular ingredient in Chinese dishes. In China, they are most often eaten raw, sometimes sweetened. They also may be ground into a [[flour]] form used for making [[water chestnut cake]], which is common as part of ''[[dim sum]]'' cuisine. They are unusual among vegetables for remaining crisp even after being cooked or canned, because their cell walls are cross-linked and strengthened by certain phenolic compounds, such as oligomers of [[ferulic acid]].<ref>Phenolics and phenolic-polysaccharide linkages in Chinese water chestnut (Eleocharis dulcis) cell walls. Grassby Terri, Doctoral thesis, 2008, University of East Anglia ([https://ueaeprints.uea.ac.uk/33057/1/Thesis_-_TGrassby.pdf link])</ref> This property is shared by other vegetables that remain crisp in this manner, including the [[tiger nut]] and [[lotus root]].<ref>{{cite book | author=McGee, Harold | title=On Food and Cooking (Revised Edition) | publisher=Scribner | year=2004 | isbn=0-684-80001-2 | page= 308}}</ref> The corms contain the antibiotic agent puchiin,<ref name="Kay_1987" /><ref name="hodge_1956">{{cite journal|date=January 1956|title=Chinese water chestnut or matai—A Paddy Crop of China|journal=Economic Botany|volume=10|issue=1|pages=49–65|doi=10.1007/BF02985317|last1=Hodge|first1=W. H.}}</ref> which is stable to high temperature.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hao|first1=Shu-xian|last2=Liu|first2=Xin|last3=Zhao|first3=Li-chao|last4=Chen|first4=Yong-quan|title=Study on the Effects of Puchiin Extract Antimicrobial Roperties|journal=Food Science|date=2005|url=http://en.cnki.com.cn/Article_en/CJFDTOTAL-SPKX200502013.htm}}</ref> Apart from the edible corms, the leaves can be used for cattlefeed, mulch or compost.<ref name="morton_1988" />

The corms are rich in [[carbohydrate]]s (about 90% by dry weight), especially [[starch]] (about 60% by dry weight), and are also a good source of [[dietary fiber]], [[riboflavin]], [[vitamin B6|vitamin B<sub>6</sub>]], [[potassium]], [[copper]], and [[manganese]].<ref>{{cite web | title=Waterchestnuts, chinese, (matai), raw | publisher=CondéNet, Inc | work=NutritionData.com | url=http://nutritiondata.com/facts-001-02s023g.html | accessdate=2007-12-31}}</ref>

If eaten uncooked, potentially, the surface of the plants may transmit [[fasciolopsiasis]].<ref>{{Cite journal
 | pmid = 12583425
| year = 2000
| author1 = Bhatti
| first1 = H. S.
| title = Fasciolopslasis--a re-emerging infection in Azamgarh (Uttar Pradesh)
| journal = Indian journal of pathology & microbiology
| volume = 43
| issue = 1
| pages = 73–6
| last2 = Malla
| first2 = N
| last3 = Mahajan
| first3 = R. C.
| last4 = Sehgal
| first4 = R
}}</ref>

==Taste==
Raw water chestnuts are slightly sweet and very crunchy. Boiled water chestnuts have a firm and slightly crunchy texture, with a very mild and slightly nutty flavour that may easily be overpowered by seasonings or sauces with which the water chestnut is served or cooked. They often are combined with [[bamboo shoot]]s, [[coriander]], [[ginger]], [[sesame oil]], and [[snow peas]]. Steamed or sauteed vegetable medleys frequently contain water chestnuts. They often are used in noodle or rice dishes.<ref>{{cite book|title=Field Guide to Produce|publisher=Quirk Productions|isbn=1-931686-80-7|year=2004|last=Green|first=Aliza|page=284}}</ref>

==Nomenclature==
The Chinese water chestnut (traditional Chinese: <big>[[wikt:荸薺|荸薺]];</big> simplified Chinese: <big>[[wikt:荸荠|荸荠]];</big> ''hanyu pinyin'': bíqi, <big>[[wikt:馬蹄|馬蹄]];</big> ''pinyin'':mǎtí) is native to China and is cultivated widely in flooded [[paddy field]]s in southern China and parts of the [[Philippines]], where it is called ''apulid''. In Vietnam, it is called ''củ mã thầy'' (in the north) and  ''củ năng'' (in the south) and is the main ingredient of ''bánh củ năng hấp, chè mã thầy''. In Thailand, it is called ''somwang'' <big>(สมหวัง)</big> and it often is used in a dessert named ''tabtim krob'' <big>(ทับทิมกรอบ).</big> In India, it is known commonly as ''singhada, shingada'', or ''singoda''.

== Agronomic properties ==

=== Cultivation ===
The crop can be cultivated in [[Paddy field|paddies]] (2-7.5m wide by up to 100m long to allow for mechanization)<ref name="rirdc_kleinhenz" /> or in a [[Hydroponics|hydroponic culture]].<ref name="agric_wa_gov_au">{{cite web|title=Chinese water chestnuts in Western Australia|url=https://www.agric.wa.gov.au/chinese-water-chestnuts/chinese-water-chestnuts-western-australia|website=Department of Agriculture and Food|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref> As it is an aquatic plant, it should always be submerged in approx. 10 cm of water.<ref name="Kay_1987" /> The crop needs continuously high soil temperatures, ideally 14-15.5 °C.<ref name="Kay_1987" /> At 13.6 °C, the corms begin to sprout.<ref name="rirdc_kleinhenz" /> Soil is ideally a sandy loam with pH 6.5 to 7.2.<ref name="greenharvest_com_au">{{cite web|title=Waterchestnuts Growing Information|url=https://www.greenharvest.com.au/Plants/Information/Waterchestnuts.html|website=greenharvest.com.au/|publisher=greenharvest.com.au/|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref> The plant produces two types of subterranean [[rhizome]]s. Under long-daylength conditions, rhizomes grow horizontally and then turn upwards forming daughter plants. Under short-daylength conditions, the rhizomes grow downward and produce a [[corm]] at the tip.<ref name="Kay_1987">{{cite book|url=http://www.nzdl.org/gsdlmod?e=d-00000-00---off-0hdl--00-0----0-10-0---0---0direct-10---4-------0-1l--11-en-50---20-about---00-0-1-00-0--4----0-0-11-10-0utfZz-8-00&a=d&c=hdl&cl=CL2.15.5&d=HASH017e5342c4df6794537cc5ed.13|title=Crop and Product Digest N°2 - Root Crops, 2nd Edition|first=Daisy E.|last2=Gooding|first2=E. G. B.|publisher=Trop.Dev. Res. Inst.|year=1987|isbn=|location=London|pages=|quote=|via=|last1=Kay}}</ref><ref name="rirdc_kleinhenz">{{cite web|last1=Kleinhenz|first1=Volker|last2=Lodge|first2=Geoff|last3=Midmore|first3=David|title=A Grower's Guide to Cultivating Chinese Waterchestnut in Australia|url=https://rirdc.infoservices.com.au/downloads/00-166|date=2001|publisher=Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation|accessdate=15 November 2016}}</ref> The [[Photoperiodism|photoperiod]] also significantly influences how fast the corms grow. Corms begin to develop much more slowly if the photoperiod exceeds 12 hours.<ref name="Kleinhenz_2000">{{cite journal|last1=Li|first1=Mei|last2=Kleinhenz|first2=V.|last3=Lyall|first3=T.|last4=Midmore|first4=D.J.|title=Response of Chinese water chestnut (                            (Burm. f.) Hensch) to photoperiod|journal=The Journal of Horticultural Science and Biotechnology|date=7 November 2015|volume=75|issue=1|pages=72–78|doi=10.1080/14620316.2000.11511203|url=http://www.volkerkleinhenz.com/publications/response-of-chinese-waterchestnut-to-photoperiod/}}</ref> The corms are also the propagating material.<ref name="rirdc_kleinhenz" /> Alternatively, transplants can be used.<ref name="agric_wa_gov_au" /> Machinery such as tractor-mounted vegetable planters can be used for plantation.<ref name="rirdc_kleinhenz" />

=== Plant nutrition ===
Nitrogen addition is beneficial for corm production, applying a dose before planting and another dose when corms begin to enlarge.<ref name="rirdc_kleinhenz" /> To further improve nutrient levels, potassium and phosphorus mineral [[fertilizer]]s can be used before planting, where the N:P:K uptake ratio is 1.00:0.50:1.75.<ref name="rirdc_kleinhenz" /> Also organic [[mulch]], especially mushroom compost, shows good results.<ref name="rirdc_kleinhenz" />

=== Harvest ===
Once the corms turn dark brown, they should be harvested.<ref name="rirdc_kleinhenz" /> If left in the soil after this point in time, corms will get sweeter, however shelf life will decline.<ref name="rirdc_kleinhenz" /> The corms can be harvested using a modified gladioli corm harvester once the paddy is drained.<ref name="agric_wa_gov_au" /> Alternatively, a "water-suction harvester" can be used without the need to drain the paddy.<ref name="rirdc_kleinhenz" /> The corms have to be washed after harvest and brushed once they are dry.<ref name="agric_wa_gov_au" />

=== Yield ===
The per plant yield was described at 2.3 kg/season (fresh matter).<ref name="morton_1988">{{cite journal|last1=Morton|first1=J.F.|last2=Sanchez|first2=C.A.|last3=Snyder|first3=G.H.|title=Chinese waterchestnut in florida - past, present, and future|journal=Proc. Fla. State Hort. Soc|date=1988|issue=101|pages=139–144|url=http://fshs.org/proceedings-o/1988-vol-101/139-144%20(MORTON).pdf|accessdate=15 November 2016}}</ref> In China, yields are reported between 20-40t/ha,<ref name="Kay_1987" /> while in the United States a range between 47-85t/ha has been mentioned.<ref name="morton_1988" />

=== Storage ===
The harvested corms are best stored at 4 °C. At this temperature, transpiration and thus weight loss are minimized.<ref name="rirdc_kleinhenz" /> This will also delay [[sprouting]] and minimize deterioration resulting from small injuries.<ref name="rirdc_kleinhenz" /> Corms should not be stored at temperatures above 13.6 °C as otherwise the corms will begin to sprout.<ref name="rirdc_kleinhenz" /> If the corms need to be stored longer term, they can also be kept in a solution of 1000 ppm sodium hypochlorite.<ref name="Kanes_1977">{{cite journal|last1=Kanes|first1=C.A.|last2=Vines|first2=H.M.|title=STORAGE CONDITIONS FOR CHINESE WATER CHESTNUTS, ELEOCHARIS DULCIS (BURM F.) TRIN.|journal=Acta Horticulturae|date=June 1977|issue=62|pages=151–160|doi=10.17660/ActaHortic.1977.62.15}}</ref>

=== Pests ===
Chinese water chestnut is usually not very prone to pests,<ref name="agric_wa_gov_au" /> nevertheless some animals and fungi may attack the plant: [[Water fowl]] may damage the stems and corms, especially when plants are young.<ref name="rirdc_kleinhenz" /> Similarly, [[rodent]]s and grazing animals pose a threat to the Chinese water chestnut, which may be discouraged by keeping the paddy inundated.<ref name="rirdc_kleinhenz" /> Fly larvae (Trichoptera sp.) and other leaf-eating [[caterpillar]]s also feed on the stems. However, unless complete defoliation below the waterline occurs, the plants can normally tolerate this damage.<ref name="rirdc_kleinhenz" /> Plant hoppers ([[Fulgoridae]]) and [[scale insect]]s feed on plant sap and may cause subsequent death.<ref name="rirdc_kleinhenz" /> Other pests represent [[nematode]]s Ditylenchus spp. and [[Dolichodorus heterocephalus]].<ref name="Kay_1987" /> Fungal species can also attack the Chinese water chestnut. In warmer climates, a rust is caused by uromyces<ref name="rirdc_kleinhenz" /> and Cylindrosporium eleocharidis is causing stem blight.<ref name="pandey_2010_aquatic_vegetables">{{cite book|last1=Pandey|first1=A.K.|title=Aquatic vegetables|date=2011|publisher=Agrotech Pub. Academy|location=Udaipur|isbn=9788183211970|edition=1st}}</ref>

{{taxobox

*''Scirpus caribaea''
*''Scirpus geniculatus''
*and numerous others
}}
'''''Eleocharis geniculata''''' is a species of [[Eleocharis|spikesedge]] known by several common names, including '''bent spikerush''' and '''Canada spikesedge'''. This is a widespread plant of wet areas in the [[Americas]], [[Asia]], [[Africa]], [[Australia]], [[Madagascar]], and some [[Pacific Islands]].<ref name=cheryl>[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=242508 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families]</ref><ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=2&taxon_id=242101135 Flora of China, Vol. 23 Page 196, <big>黑籽荸荠</big> hei zi bi qi, ''Eleocharis geniculata'' (Linnaeus) Roemer & Schultes, Syst. Veg. 2: 150. 1817. ]</ref><ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Eleocharis%20geniculata.png Biota of North America Program 2013 county distribution map]</ref> It is an annual spikesedge growing to a maximum height of about 40 centimeters. It has a few straw-colored leaves and many thin erect stems. The stems hold [[inflorescence]]s of rounded [[raceme|spikelets]] each containing at least 10 tiny flowers. The flowers are covered with dark greenish-brown [[bract]]s. The fruit is a shiny purple-brown [[achene]] not more than a millimeter long.<ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=242101135 Flora of North America, ''Eleocharis geniculata'' (Linnaeus) Roemer & Schultes in J. J. Roemer et al., Syst. Veg. 2: 150. 1817. ]</ref>

|synonyms=
*''Elephantopus carolinensis'' <small>G.Mey.</small>
*''Elephantopus sordidus'' <small>Salisb.</small>
