*''Elephantopus plurisetus'' <small>(O.Hoffm.) Clonts, syn of subsp. ''plurisetus''</small>
*''Elephantopus sinuatus'' <small>Zoll. & Moritzi, syn of var. ''sinuatus ''</small>
*''Asterocephalus cochinchinensis'' <small>Sprengel</small>
}}
'''''Elephantopus scaber''''' is a tropical species of [[flowering plant]] in the [[Asteraceae|sunflower family]].  It is native to [[tropical Africa]], [[Eastern Asia]], [[Indian Subcontinent]], [[Southeast Asia]], and northern [[Australia]]. It has become naturalized in [[tropical Africa]] and [[Latin America]]. Its natural [[habitat]] is subtropical or tropical moist [[montane forest]]s.<ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=2&taxon_id=200023877 Flora of China, 地胆草 di dan cao ''Elephantopus scaber'' Linnaeus, Sp. Pl. 2: 814. 1753. ]</ref><ref>[http://bie.ala.org.au/species/urn:lsid:biodiversity.org.au:apni.taxon:630174# Atlas of Living Australia, ''Elephantopus scaber'' L.]</ref><ref>Breedlove, D.E. 1986. Flora de Chiapas. Listados Florísticos de México 4: i–v, 1–246.</ref><ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/8108585#page/200/mode/1up Humbert, H. 1960. Composées. Fl. Madagasc. 189: 198-199] description in French</ref><ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/8108585#page/9/mode/1up Humbert, H. 1960. Composées. Fl. Madagasc. 189: plate I (1), figures 10-12 at right] line drawings of ''Elephantopus scaber''</ref><ref>Jeffrey, C. 1988. Notes on Compositae: V. The Vernonieae in East Tropical Africa. Kew Bulletin 43(2): 195–277.</ref><ref>Nelson, C. H. 2008. Catálogo de las Plantas Vasculares de Honduras 1–1576. Secretaria de Recursos Naturales y Ambiente, Tegucigalpa.</ref>

== Uses ==
''E. scaber'' is used as a [[traditional medicine]].<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 1453704 |date=Aug 1992 |author1=Poli, A |author2=Nicolau, M |author3=Simoes, Cm |author4=Nicolau, Rm |author5=Zanin, M | title = Preliminary pharmacologic evaluation of crude whole plant extracts of Elephantopus scaber. Part I: in vivo studies | volume = 37 | issue = 1 | pages = 71–6 | issn = 0378-8741 | journal = Journal of Ethnopharmacology | doi = 10.1016/0378-8741(92)90005-C }}</ref> Different parts of the plant are used in traditional medicine of India as an [[astringent]] agent, cardiac tonic, and [[diuretic]], and is used for [[eczema]], [[rheumatism]], fever, and [[bladder stone]]s.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1016/j.bcp.2014.07.018| pmid = 25083916| pmc = 4212005| title = Natural product agonists of peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPARγ): A review| journal = Biochemical Pharmacology| volume = 92| issue = 1| pages = 73–89| year = 2014| last1 = Wang| first1 = Limei| last2 = Waltenberger| first2 = Birgit| last3 = Pferschy-Wenzig| first3 = Eva-Maria| last4 = Blunder| first4 = Martina| last5 = Liu| first5 = Xin| last6 = Malainer| first6 = Clemens| last7 = Blazevic| first7 = Tina| last8 = Schwaiger| first8 = Stefan| last9 = Rollinger| first9 = Judith M.| last10 = Heiss| first10 = Elke H.| last11 = Schuster| first11 = Daniela| last12 = Kopp| first12 = Brigitte| last13 = Bauer| first13 = Rudolf| last14 = Stuppner| first14 = Hermann| last15 = Dirsch| first15 = Verena M.| last16 = Atanasov| first16 = Atanas G.}}</ref>

==Chemical constituents==
''E. scaber'' contains [[elephantopin]] which is a [[germacranolide]] [[sesquiterpene lactone]] containing two lactone rings and an epoxide functional group.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://medind.nic.in/imvw/imvw282.html |archive-url=http://archive.is/20120630160712/http://medind.nic.in/imvw/imvw282.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-06-30 |title=Antitumor activity of elephantopus scaber linn against dalton's ascitis lymphoma |journal=Indian Journal of Pharmaceutical Sciences |date=Jan–Feb 2002 |volume=64 |issue=1 |pages=71–3 |postscript= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?401632|title=Elephantopus scaber L.|publisher=USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program. Germplasm Resources Information Network - (GRIN) [Online Database]|location=National Germplasm Resources Laboratory, Beltsville, Maryland|accessdate=7 May 2011}}</ref> 17,19-Dihydrodeoxyelephantopin, iso-17,19- dihydro-deoxy elephantopin and 8-hydroxyl
naringenin are the most important bioactive compounds responsible for anti-bacterial activity.<ref>{{cite journal|first1=Muhammad Shahzad|last1=Aslam|first2=Muhammad Syarhabil|last2=Ahmad|first3=Awang Soh|last3=Mamat|title=Anti-microbial potential of Elephantopus scaber - an updated review|journal=Indian Research Journal of Pharmacy and Science|volume=2|issue=4|pages=315–322|url=http://irjps.in/journal/120.pdf}}</ref>

==Subspecies and varieties==
Varieties of ''E. scaber'' include:<ref name=r>[http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/gcc-116229 The Plant List, ''Elephantopus scaber'' L. ]</ref>
*''Elephantopus scaber'' subsp. ''plurisetus'' <small>(O.Hoffm.) Philipson</small>
*''Elephantopus scaber'' subsp. ''scaber''
*''Elephantopus scaber'' var. ''scaber''
*''Elephantopus scaber'' var. ''sinuatus'' <small>(Mor.) Miq.</small>

'''''Eragrostis desertorum''''' is a species of grass known from [[Queensland]], [[Western Australia]], and the [[Northern Territory]]. It occurs in seasonally wet habitats such as gulleys, valleys and creek fans.<ref>D.Sharp & B.K.Simon, 2002. AusGrass, Grasses of Australia.</ref> 


''Eragrostis desertorum'' is a perennial herb spreading by means of stolons. It can reach a height of 60 cm. Leaves are stiff, filiform, mostly basal, up to 12 cm long, with ciliate sheaths. Inflorescence is [[paniculate]], up to 18 cm long. It is similar to E. eriopoda but with 2 stamens.<ref>[http://ausgrass2.myspecies.info/content/eragrostis-desertorum Ausgrass, Grasses of Australia.]</ref><ref>Domin, Karel. Bibliotheca Botanica 85: 404. 1915.</ref>

==References==
{{reflist}}

'''''Erechtites glomeratus''''', common name '''New Zealand fireweed''' or '''cutleaf burnweed''',<ref>Brako, L., A.Y. Rossman & D.F. Farr. 1995. Scientific and Common Names of 7,000 Vascular Plants in the United States 1–294. </ref><ref name=cassandra/> is a species of [[plant]]s in the [[Asteraceae|sunflower family]]. It is native to [[Australia]] (all 6 states) and [[New Zealand]], and also naturalized on the [[Pacific Coast of the United States]] ([[Washington (state)|Washington]], [[Oregon]], and [[California]]).<ref>[http://bie.ala.org.au/species/urn:lsid:biodiversity.org.au:apni.taxon:674750# Atlas of Living Australia, ''Senecio glomeratus'' Desf. ex Poir., Cluster-headed Fireweed]</ref><ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Senecio%20glomeratus.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref><ref name=cassandra>[http://www.calflora.org/cgi-bin/species_query.cgi?where-taxon=Senecio+glomeratus Calflora taxon report, University of California, ''Senecio glomeratus''  Desf. ex Poir., Cutleaf burnweed ]</ref>

==Description==
''Erechtites glomeratus'' is an [[Annual plant|annual]] or [[Perennial plant|perennial]] herb up to 200 cm (80 inches) tall. Leaves are [[Leaf shape|lanceolate or linear]] with many [[Leaf shape|pinnate lobes]]. One plant can produce as many as 120 yellow or purple  [[flower heads]], each with 50 or more [[disc floret]]s but no [[ray florets]].<ref name=belinda>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=250066505 Flora of North America, ''Erechtites glomeratus'' (Desfontaines ex Poiret) de Candolle in A. P. de Candolle and A. L. P. P. de Candolle, Prodr. 6: 297. 1838. ]</ref>

'''''Erechtites minimus''''', common names '''toothed fireweed''',<ref name=z/><ref name=BSBI07>{{cite web|title=BSBI List 2007 |publisher=Botanical Society of Britain and Ireland |url=http://www.bsbi.org.uk/BSBIList2007.xls |format=xls |archive-url=http://www.webcitation.org/6VqJ46atN?url=http://www.bsbi.org.uk/BSBIList2007.xls |archive-date=2015-01-25 |accessdate=2014-10-17 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> and '''coastal burnweed'''<ref>{{PLANTS|id=ERMI8|taxon=Erechtites minimus|accessdate=21 June 2015}}</ref> is a species of [[plant]]s in the [[Asteraceae|sunflower family]]. It is native to [[Australia]] (all 6 states) and [[New Zealand]], and also naturalized on the [[Pacific Coast of the United States]] ([[Washington (state)|Washington]], [[Oregon]], and [[California]]).<ref name=z>[http://bie.ala.org.au/species/urn:lsid:biodiversity.org.au:apni.taxon:674750# Atlas of Living Australia, ''Senecio minimus'' Poir., Toothed Fireweed]</ref><ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Senecio%minimus.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref><ref name=cassandra>[http://www.calflora.org/cgi-bin/species_query.cgi?where-taxon=Senecio+minimus Calflora taxon report, University of California, ''Senecio minimus''  Poir., Coastal burnweed ]</ref>

==Description==
''Erechtites minimus'' is an [[Annual plant|annual]] or [[Perennial plant|perennial]] herb up to 200 cm (80 inches) tall. Leaves are [[Leaf shape|toothed]] but not [[Leaf shape|pinnately lobed]]. One plant can produce as many as 200 yellow or purple  [[flower heads]], each with many small [[disc floret]]s but no [[ray florets]].<ref name=belinda>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=250066506 Flora of North America, ''Erechtites minimus'' (Poir.) DC. ]</ref>

101.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:''Eremophila'' (plant)}}
{{Taxobox
|name = ''Eremophila''
|image = Eremophila maculata flowers.jpg
|image_caption = ''E. maculata'' (cultivated) at [[The Gardens at the Las Vegas Springs Preserve| Desert Demonstration Garden in Las Vegas]]
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]]
|ordo = [[Lamiales]]
|familia = [[Scrophulariaceae]]<ref name=GRIN/>
|tribus = [[Myoporeae]]<ref name=GRIN/>
|genus = '''''Eremophila'''''
|genus_authority = [[R.Br.]]
|subdivision_ranks = Species
|subdivision = See [[List of Eremophila (plant) species|List of ''Eremophila'' species]]
|}}
[[File:Eremophila abietina.jpg|thumb|right||''[[Eremophila abietina]]'']]
[[File:Eremophila glabra Murchison Magic.jpg|thumb|right||''[[Eremophila glabra]]'' 'Murchison Magic']]
[[File:Eremophila hygrophana.jpg|thumb|''[[Eremophila hygrophana]]'']]
[[File:Eremophila oldfieldii.jpg|thumb|''[[Eremophila oldfieldii]]'']]

'''''Eremophila''''' is a [[genus]] of more than 260 [[species]] of plants in the figwort [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Scrophulariaceae]] all of which are [[endemism|endemic]] to mainland [[Australia]]. (One species, ''[[Eremophila debilis]]'' is thought to be a recent arrival in [[New Zealand]]). Eremophilas are widespread in the [[arid]] areas of Australia, especially [[Western Australia]] and range in size from low-growing shrubs to small trees. The [[petal]]s are joined, at least at their bases, into a tube with the upper petals different in size and shape from the lower ones. Some species have common names including emu bush, poverty bush or fuchsia bush, reflecting the belief that emus eat the fruit, their arid environment or a superficial resemblance to the flowers of plants in the genus ''[[Fuchsia]]''.

==Description==
Eremophilas vary in size and [[Habit (biology)|habit]] from low, [[Prostrate shrub|prostrate]] shrubs such as ''[[Eremophila serpens|E. serpens]]'' to small trees in the case of ''[[Eremophila bignoniiflora|E. bignoniiflora]]''. Leaf size and shape is also variable but the leaves are usually small and are often shiny or hairy.  The flowers usually have 5 spreading [[sepal]]s and 5 [[petal]]s which are joined into a tube, at least at the base. The most common flower colours are red, purple, lilac and mauve but others are white and even green. Many species have flowers which have a combination of colours, or have spotted or streaked markings, or both. Sometimes only the petals are coloured but often the sepals are also colourful.<ref name="Chinnock" /><ref name="Buirchell" /><ref name="ANPSA" />

There is variation in flower shape, the most common being two petals at the top of the tube and three below, with the [[stamen]]s enclosed in the tube as in the case of ''[[Eremophila exilifolia|E. exilifolia]]''. Species with this arrangement are generally insect-pollinated, the lower petals acting as a landing area. Less common are those that have four petal lobes at the top of  the flower, one below which is curled under the flower and the stamens extending beyond the petal tube, as in the case of ''[[Eremophila glabra|E. glabra]]''. These flowers are generally bird pollinated, the bird holding the plant stem while it visits the flower.  A few others have flowers with a combination of these arrangements.<ref name="Chinnock" /><ref name="Buirchell" /><ref name="ANPSA" />

As the flower ages, the [[Corolla (flower)|corolla]] falls off, then the [[Calyx (botany)|calyx]] enlarges and becomes coloured as the fruit enlarges. The fruits contain from 2 to 12 seeds and may lie dormant in the ground for many years until disturbed by fire, heavy rainfall and sometimes by human activity such as roadworks. Some species such as ''[[Eremophila sturtii|E. sturtii]]'' reproduce by [[basal shoot|suckering]] and have become troublesome weeds in some areas. However, many more are rare or threatened by human activities such as land clearing, pastoral activity and mining.<ref name=Chinnock>{{cite book|last1=Chinnock|first1=R.J. (Bob)|title=Eremophila and allied genera : a monograph of the plant family Myoporaceae|date=2007|publisher=Rosenberg|location=Dural, NSW|isbn=9781877058165|page=180|edition=1st}}</ref><ref name="Buirchell" /><ref name=ANPSA>{{cite web|title=Eremophila and it relatives - background|url=http://anpsa.org.au/erem1a.html|publisher=Australian Native Plants Society Australia|accessdate=9 September 2015}}</ref><ref name=moore>{{Cite book|author=Moore, P.|year=2005|title=Plants of Inland Australia|publisher=Reed New Holland|isbn=187633486X}}</ref>

==Taxonomy and naming==
The genus ''Eremophila'' was first formally described in 1810 by the botanist [[Robert Brown (Scottish botanist from Montrose)|Robert Brown]] in ''[[Prodromus Florae Novae Hollandiae]]''<ref name=GRIN>{{Cite web | url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/genus.pl?4357 | title=Genus: ''Eremophila'' R. Br. | accessdate= | work=Germplasm Resources Information Network (GRIN)|publisher=United States Department of Agriculture, Agricultural Research Service, Beltsville Area}}</ref><ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Eremophila'' |url=https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/514305|publisher=APNI|accessdate=9 September 2015}}</ref><ref name=Brown>{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Robert|title=Prodromus Florae Novae Hollandiae (Volume 1)|date=1810|location=London|page=518|url=https://ia700407.us.archive.org/28/items/prodromusfloraen01brow/prodromusfloraen01brow.pdf|accessdate=9 September 2015}}</ref> and the first species to be named were ''[[Eremophila oppositifolia|E. oppositifolia]]'' and ''[[Eremophila alternifolia|E. alternifolia]]'' but Brown did not nominate a [[Type (biology)|type]] species. The [[Victoria (Australia)|Victorian]] government botanist, [[Ferdinand von Mueller]] was the most influential early naturalist to take an interest in the genus and described 47 species, many of which were collected during expeditions to remote areas of Australia. [[Robert Chinnock]] is the modern authority who has named more than 100 species of eremophilas but because many species grow in rarely visited places, more remain to be named. So far, 221 species have been described but another 40 have been discovered but not yet described.<ref name="Buirchell">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Andrew|last2=Buirchell|first2=Bevan|title=A field guide to the eremophilas of Western Australia|date=2011|publisher=Simon Nevill Publications|location=Hamilton Hill, W.A.|isbn=9780980348156}}</ref> The most recent additions to the list are ''[[Eremophila buirchellii]]'' and ''[[Eremophila calcicola]]'' which were formally described in 2016.<ref name="Nuytsia">{{cite journal|last1=Brown|first1=Andrew P.|last2=Davis|first2=Robert W.|title=''Eremophila buirchellii'' and ''E. calcicola'' (Scrophulariaceae), two new species from Western Australia|journal=Nuytsia|date=2016|volume=27|pages=213–216}}</ref>

The name ''Eremophila'' is derived from the [[Ancient Greek]] ''ἐρῆμος (erêmos)'' meaning "lonely" or "desert" and ''φίλος (phílos)'' meaning “dear" or "beloved”<ref name="AOD">{{cite book|last1=Moore (ed.)|first1=Bruce|title=The Australian Oxford Dictionary|date=2002|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=South Melbourne, Vic|isbn=0195507932|page=441|edition=1999}}</ref> alluding to the species' adaptation to arid environments.<ref name=ANPSA(2)>{{cite web|title=Eremophila alternifolia|url=http://anpsa.org.au/e-alt.html|publisher=Australian Native Plants Society Australia|accessdate=9 September 2015}}</ref>
[[File:Eremophila subfloccoa KP gnangarra-10.jpg|thumb|''[[Eremophila subfloccosa]]'']]

==Distribution and habitat==
Eremophilas are distributed across the Australian mainland, primarily in arid regions and the majority of species occur in [[Western Australia]]. ''[[Eremophila maculata]]'' is found in all Australian states but there are no eremophilas in [[Tasmania]]. ''[[Eremophila debilis]]'' is found in [[New Zealand]] although its appearance there is thought to be recent, most likely as a recent of introduction by people.<ref name=moore>{{Cite book|author=Moore, P.|year=2005|title=Plants of Inland Australia|publisher=Reed New Holland|isbn=187633486X}}</ref><ref name=Chinnock(2)>{{cite book|last1=Chinnock|first1=R.J. (Bob)|title=Eremophila and allied genera : a monograph of the plant family Myoporaceae|date=2007|publisher=Rosenberg|location=Dural, NSW|isbn=9781877058165|pages=228–229|edition=1st}}</ref> 

At least 229 species are found in Western Australia and about 80% of those are [[Endemism|endemic]] to that state. They are most common in arid areas - in the [[Meekatharra, Western Australia|Meekatharra]]-[[Wiluna, Western Australia|Wiluna]] area there are more than 50 eremophila species and are the most common shrubs encountered. A few species, including ''[[Eremophila complanata|E. complanata]]'' and ''[[Eremophila mirabilis|E. mirabilis]]'' have very restricted distributions and only occur on one or two rocky outcrops.<ref name="Buirchell" />

==Ecology==
''Eremophila'' includes [[Entomophily|entomophilous]] species, with flowers adapted to attract [[insect]]s, and [[Ornithophily|ornithophilous]] species, with flowers that attract [[bird]]s. Entomophilous flowers have protruding lower lips, which provide a landing area for insects, and they are often blue, purple, or white. Bird-adapted flowers are red, orange, yellow, or green, and have lobes pointing downwards which discourages insects. Bird pollinated species also tend to have longer [[stamen]]s, which brush pollen onto and off the bird's head as it feeds.<ref name=moore/> The fruits are eaten by [[emu]]s, which [[seed dispersal|disperse]] the seeds in their droppings<ref name=moore/> although the belief that this aids in the germination of the seeds is mistaken.<ref name="ANPSA" />

Some species of ''Eremophila'', such as ''[[Eremophila freelingii|E.freelingii]]'' and ''[[Eremophila latrobei|E.latrobei]]'' are toxic to stock whereas others, including ''[[Eremophila bignoniiflora|E.bignoniiflora]]'' and ''[[Eremophila oppositifolia|E.oppositifolia]]'' are useful [[fodder]] plants.<ref name="ANPSA" />

==Uses==
===Indigenous uses===
Aboriginal people used eremophilas for cultural and health reasons. For example, the [[Adnyamathanha]] people used '''Varti-varka''' (''[[Eremophila longifolia]]'') in burial ceremonies and in initiation ceremonies. Skin complaints were treated with a mixture of emu oil and the ash from burned bark of the plant.<ref name="ANPSA" />

===Use in horticulture===
Eremophilas have not often been cultivated in the past, although some species, including ''[[Eremophila maculata]]'' are well known. Their rarity in gardens was partly because they were difficult to propagate or because they were rarely seen, even in nature. As methods of propagating and growing have improved, the popularity of eremophilas has increased. The beauty and abundance of their flowers, variety of foliage and habit, and extended flowering period make them attractive garden plants. They are mostly drought resistant and many also tolerant of frost, allowing them to be grown in most situations. The difficulty of propagating from seed, and also sometimes from cuttings has prevented many species from being commercially available, but most species can be [[Grafting|grafted]] onto [[rootstock]] of ''[[Myoporum]]'' species, giving the added advantage of being able to grow in almost any soil type, including heavy clay. ''[[Myoporum insulare]]'', ''[[Myoporum montanum|M. montanum]]'' and ''[[Myoporum acuminatum|M. acuminatum]]'' are suitable, depending on where the plant is to be grown.<ref name="Boschen">{{cite book|last1=Boschen|first1=Norma|last2=Goods|first2=Maree|last3=Wait|first3=Russell|title=Australia's eremophilas : changing gardens for a changing climate|date=2008|publisher=Bloomings Books|location=Melbourne|isbn=9781876473655|pages=13–27}}</ref><ref name=ANPSA(3)>{{cite web|title=Eremophila and its Relatives - Propagation|url=http://anpsa.org.au/erem2.html|publisher=Australian Native Plants Society Australia|accessdate=9 September 2015}}</ref><ref name=Wrigley>{{cite book|last1=Wrigley|first1=John W.|last2=Fagg|first2=Murray|title=Australian native plants : a manual for their propagation, cultivation and use in landscaping|date=1983|publisher=Collins|location=Sydney|isbn=0002165759|page=212|edition=2nd}}</ref><ref name=ANPSA(4)>{{cite web|last1=Jennings|first1=Colin|title=Eremophila: The Emu Bush|url=http://anpsa.org.au/APOL22/jun01-2.html|publisher=Australian Native Plants Society Australia|accessdate=22 December 2015}}</ref> It is possible to germinate eremophila seeds but the process involves either leaving the fruit in the ground for long periods or removing the seed from the fruit without damaging the seed.<ref name=Cochrane>{{cite web|last1=Cochrane|first1=Anne|title=Seed notes for Western Australia: 5 - Eremophila|url=http://www.dpaw.wa.gov.au/images/documents/about/science/pubs/seednotes/sn05_eremophila.pdf|publisher=Government of Western Australia Department of Parks and Wildlife|accessdate=25 December 2015}}</ref>

In nature, most eremophila grow where rainfall is infrequent and are adapted to dealing with long dry spells, even droughts lasting years. Eremophilas are therefore suited to low maintenance gardens, those where water supply is limited or where gardeners want a garden that does not require large volumes of water. In fact, excessive water can kill many species. In a severe drought, some species, such as ''[[Eremophila microtheca|E. microtheca]]'' can lose their leaves and appear to be dead after a long dry period, only to recover and turn into a compact, healthy-looking shrub after a deep watering. Most also grow in nutrient-poor soil, and fertiliser is rarely needed or beneficial.<ref name="Boschen" />

==See also==
*[[List of Eremophila (plant) species]]

102.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:''Eremophila glabra'' subsp. ''glabra''}}
{{taxobox
|image = Eremophila glabra glabra (leaves and flowers).jpg
|image caption = ''E.glabra glabra'' (on a dewy morning)
|name = ''Eremophila glabra'' subsp. ''glabra''
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]]
|ordo = [[Lamiales]]
|familia = [[Scrophulariaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Eremophila (plant)|Eremophila]]''
|species = ''[[Eremophila glabra|E. glabra]]''
|subspecies = '''''E. g.'' subsp. ''glabra'''''
|trinomial = ''Eremophila glabra'' subsp. ''glabra''
|trinomial_authority = <small>  ([[Robert Brown (botanist, born 1773)|R.Br.]]) [[Carl Hansen Ostenfeld|Ostenf.]]</small>
}}

'''''Eremophila glabra'' subsp. ''glabra''''' is a plant in the figwort [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Scrophulariaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to  the mainland states of [[Australia]].  It is similar to other shrubs in the [[species]] ''[[Eremophila glabra]]'' but it distinguished from them by the pattern of fine hairs on the stems. It is found in the drier parts of the continent, including to the west of the [[Great Dividing Range]] in the eastern states.

==Description==
''Eremophila glabra'' subsp. ''glabra'' is a shrub varying in size but in the range {{convert|0.5-3|m|ft|sigfig=1}} high, sometimes spreading to {{convert|4|m|ft|sigfig=1}} wide. The stems are covered with fine white hairs, except for a strip underneath the leaf attachment, so that the hairs are in bands down the stems interspersed with [[glabrousness|glabrous]] bands. The leaves are scattered and spreading, elliptic to lance shaped with the narrower end towards the base, {{convert|15-58|mm|in|sigfig=1}} long and {{convert|2.5-12|mm|in|sigfig=1}} wide.<ref name=Chinnock>{{cite book|last1=Chinnock|first1=R.J. (Bob)|title=''Eremophila'' and allied genera: a monograph of the plant family Myoporaceae|date=2007|publisher=Rosenberg|location=Dural, NSW|isbn=9781877058165|pages=580–582|edition=1st|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=5iZlQOKoEjoC&pg=PA128&lpg=PA128&dq=Myoporum+betcheanum&source=bl&ots=Xy6WbAm780&sig=a6Px6gqVnqobcTNw99pwmDYUvFY&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CFUQ6AEwC2oVChMIttLCz9GjxwIVR9ymCh1GUwvM#v=onepage&q=Myoporum%20betcheanum&f=false|accessdate=9 September 2015}}</ref><ref name="Florabank">{{cite web|title=''Eremophila glabra|url=http://www.florabank.org.au/lucid/key/species%20navigator/media/html/Eremophila_glabra.htm|publisher=Florabank|accessdate=25 December 2016}}</ref><ref name=Lucid>{{cite web|title=''Eremophila glabra''|url=http://keys.lucidcentral.org/keys/v3/scotia/key/Plants%20and%20Fungi%20of%20south%20western%20NSW/Media/Html/Eremophila_glabra.htm|publisher=Lucidcentral|accessdate=10 September 2015}}</ref><ref name=Brown>{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Andrew|last2=Buirchell|first2=Bevan|title=A field guide to the eremophilas of Western Australia|date=2011|publisher=Simon Nevill Publications|location=Hamilton Hill, W.A.|isbn=9780980348156|page=117|edition=1st}}</ref>

The flowers are red or orange, sometimes yellow and occur singly in the leaf axils on flower stalks {{convert|4.5-7|mm|in|sigfig=1}} long. There are 5 partly overlapping [[sepal]]s which are narrow triangular to egg shaped and 5 [[petal]]s forming a tube except at the ends where the lowest lobe is thinner that the rest and is turned back below the flower. Flowering occurs from January to November and is followed by fruits which are oval to almost spherical and {{convert|6.6-9|mm|in|sigfig=1}} in diameter.<ref name="Chinnock" /><ref name="Brown" /><ref name="Florabank" /><ref name="Lucid" />[[File:Eremophila glabra glabra (habit).jpg|thumb|225px|''E. glabra glabra'' growing near [[Kalgoorlie, Western Australia|Kalgoorlie]]]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Eremophila glabra'' subsp. ''glabra'' is an [[Autonym (botany)|autonym]] and therefore the taxonomy is the same as for ''[[Eremophila glabra]]''.

==Distribution and habitat==
''Eremophila glabra'' subsp. ''glabra'' occurs in every mainland state of Australia, including the drier inland parts of [[New South Wales]], southern [[Queensland]] and [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]]. It is found throughout [[South Australia]] and in the southern half of the [[Northern Territory]] and [[Western Australia]]. It grows in a wide range of soils and vegetation associations.

==References==

103.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:''Eremophila jucunda'' subsp. ''jucunda''}}
{{taxobox
|image = Eremophila jucunda jucunda (leaves and flowers.jpg
|image caption = ''E. jucunda jucunda'' leaves and flower
|name = ''Eremophila jucunda'' subsp. ''jucunda''
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]]
|ordo = [[Lamiales]]
|familia = [[Scrophulariaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Eremophila (plant)|Eremophila]]''
|species = ''[[Eremophila jucunda|E. jucunda]]''
|subspecies = '''''E. j.'' subsp. ''jucunda'''''
|trinomial = ''Eremophila jucunda'' subsp. ''jucunda''
|trinomial_authority = <small> [[Robert Chinnock|Chinnock]]<ref name="APNI" /></small>
}}

'''''Eremophila jucunda'' subsp. ''jucunda''''' is a plant in the figwort [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Scrophulariaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to [[WesternAustralia]].  It is a small shrub with hairy leaves and white to violet flowers often growing on stony hillsides. It is similar to [[Eremophila jucunda subsp. pulcherrima|subspecies ''pulcherrima'']] but is distinguished from it by its yellow new growth and more southerly distribution.

==Description==
''Eremophila jucunda'' subsp. ''jucunda'' is a shrub which usually grows to a height of {{convert|0.2-1|m|ft|sigfig=1}}. The stems and branches are hairy and the leaves are densely arranged near the ends of branches, lance-shaped to egg-shaped, {{convert|8-20|mm|in|sigfig=1}} long and {{convert|2-6|mm|in|sigfig=1}} wide. The young leaves and branches are bright yellow.<ref name=Chinnock>{{cite book|last1=Chinnock|first1=R.J. (Bob)|title=''Eremophila'' and allied genera: a monograph of the plant family Myoporaceae|date=2007|publisher=Rosenberg|location=Dural, NSW|isbn=9781877058165|pages=515–516|edition=1st}}</ref><ref name=Brown>{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Andrew|last2=Buirchell|first2=Bevan|title=A field guide to the eremophilas of Western Australia|date=2011|publisher=Simon Nevill Publications|location=Hamilton Hill, W.A.|isbn=9780980348156|page=154|edition=1st}}</ref>

The flowers are white or lilac to purple and occur singly in the leaf axils on flower stalks {{convert|3-9|mm|in|sigfig=1}} long. There are 5 [[sepal]]s which are linear to lance-shaped, {{convert|9-17|mm|in|sigfig=1}} long and {{convert|1-3|mm|in|sigfig=1}} wide. The 5 [[petal]]s form a tube {{convert|17-29|mm|in|sigfig=1}} which is more or less hairy on the outer surface. Flowering occurs from July to September and is followed by fruit which are oval to cone-shaped and {{convert|5-9|mm|in|sigfig=1}} long.<ref name="Chinnock" /><ref name="Brown" />[[File:Eremophila jucunda jucunda (habit).jpg|thumb|225px|''E. jucunda jucunda'' growing 55km east of [[Meekatharra, Western Australia|Meekatharra]]]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Eremophila jucunda'' subsp. ''jucunda'' is an [[Autonym (botany)|autonym]] and therefore the taxonomy is the same as for ''[[Eremophila jucunda]]''.<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Eremophila jucunda'' subsp. ''jucunda''|url= http://id.biodiversity.org.au/name/apni/208494|publisher=APNI|accessdate=4 September 2016}}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Eremophila jucunda'' subsp. ''jucunda'' grows on stony flats or hillsides, often in [[Acacia aneura|mulga]] wooodland. It occurs in a broad area between [[Sandstone, Western Australia|Sandstone]] and  Mount Vernon.<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Eremophila jucunda'' subsp. ''jucunda''|id=17171}}</ref><ref name=flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=[[The Western Australian Flora – A Descriptive Catalogue|The Western Australian flora: a descriptive catalogue]]|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=337}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Eremophila jucunda'' subspecies ''jucunda'' is classified as "not threatened" by the Western Australian Government [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

{{taxobox

|trinomial_authority = <small> [[Robert Chinnock|Chinnock]]<ref name="APNI" /></small>

'''''Eremophila jucunda'' subsp. ''pulcherrima''''' is a plant in the figwort [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Scrophulariaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to [[Western Australia]].  It is a small shrub with grey, hairy leaves and [[sepal]]s and blue or mauve flowers often growing in stony places. It is similar to subspecies [[Eremophila jucunda subsp. jucunda|''jucunda'']] but is distinguished from it by its grey new growth and more northerly distribution.

==Description==
''Eremophila jucunda'' subsp. ''pulcherrima'' is a shrub which usually grows to a height of {{convert|0.2-1|m|ft|sigfig=1}}. Its branches and leaves are hairy and the leaves are densely arranged near the ends of branches, lance-shaped to egg-shaped, {{convert|8-20|mm|in|sigfig=1}} long and {{convert|2-6|mm|in|sigfig=1}} wide. The young leaves and branches are grey-coloured.<ref name=Chinnock>{{cite book|last1=Chinnock|first1=R.J. (Bob)|title=''Eremophila'' and allied genera: a monograph of the plant family Myoporaceae|date=2007|publisher=Rosenberg|location=Dural, NSW|isbn=9781877058165|pages=517-518|edition=1st}}</ref><ref name=Brown>{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Andrew|last2=Buirchell|first2=Bevan|title=A field guide to the eremophilas of Western Australia|date=2011|publisher=Simon Nevill Publications|location=Hamilton Hill, W.A.|isbn=9780980348156|page=155|edition=1st}}</ref>

The flowers are lilac-coloured to purple and occur singly in the leaf axils on flower stalks {{convert|3-9|mm|in|sigfig=1}} long. There are 5 sepals which are linear to lance-shaped, {{convert|9-17|mm|in|sigfig=1}} long and {{convert|1-3|mm|in|sigfig=1}} wide. The 5 [[petal]]s form a tube {{convert|17-29|mm|in|sigfig=1}} which is [[wikt:glabrous|glabrous]] on the outer surface. Flowering usually occurs in September and is followed by fruit which are oval to cone-shaped and {{convert|5-9|mm|in|sigfig=1}} long.<ref name="Chinnock" /><ref name="Brown" />[[File:Eremophila jucunda pulcherrima (habit).jpg|thumb|225px|''E. jucunda pulcherrima'' growing on Mount Robinson north-west of [[Newman, Western Australia|Newman]]]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Eremophila jucunda'' subsp. ''pulcherrima'' was first described by [[Robert Chinnock]] in 2007.<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Eremophila jucunda'' subsp. ''pulcherrima''|url= https://id.biodiversity.org.au/instance/apni/619455|publisher=APNI|accessdate=4 September 2016}}</ref> The epithet ''pulcherrima'' is a [[Latin]] word meaning "prettiest''.<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.|page=132}}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
This eremophila grows on rocky hils or on clay flats between [[Paraburdoo, Western Australia|Paraburdoo]] and [[Newman, Western Australia|Newman]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Eremophila jucunda'' subsp. ''pulcherrima''|id=17519}}</ref><ref name=flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=[[The Western Australian Flora – A Descriptive Catalogue|The Western Australian flora: a descriptive catalogue]]|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=337}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Eremophila jucunda'' subspecies ''pulcherrima'' is classified as "not threatened" by the Western Australian Government [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

'''''Euchiton collinus''''' ('''creeping cudweed''') is a herb native to [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]].<ref>[http://florabase.dpaw.wa.gov.au/browse/profile/19088 Florabase, the Western Australian Flora]</ref><ref>[http://nzpcn.org.nz/publications/de_Lange_PJ_and_Rolfe_J_2010.pdf Peter J. de Lange, Jeremy R. Rolfe. 2010. New Zealand indigenous vascular plant checklist. New Zealand Plant Conservation Network, Wellington]</ref> It has become naturalized in a few places in the United States ([[California]], [[Oregon]]).<ref name=i>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=250066728 Flora of North America, ''Euchiton gymnocephalus'' (de Candolle) Holub, 1974. Creeping-cudweed ]</ref><ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Euchiton%20gymnocephalus.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref><ref>[http://www.calflora.org/cgi-bin/species_query.cgi?where-calrecnum=9951 Calflora taxon report, University of California, ''Euchiton gymnocephalus''  (DC.) Anderb., creeping cudweed ]</ref>

''Euchiton collinus'' is a biennial or perennial herb up to {{convert|40|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} tall, spreading by means of [[stolons]] and [[rhizomes]]. Leaves form a basal [[Rosette (botany)|rosette]] surrounding the base of the stem and also individually farther up the stem. The plant produces a [[flower heads]] in a hemispheric cluster {{convert|1|-|2|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} across. Each head has 40-60 [[pistillate]] flowers around the edge of the head plus 3-5 [[bisexual]] florets toward the center.<ref name=i/>

not ([[G.Forst.]]) [[Arne A. Anderberg|Anderb.]] 1991[http://www.ipni.org/ipni/advPlantNameSearch.do?find_genus=Euchiton&find_species=involucratus&find_rankToReturn=spec The International Plant Names Index] |synonyms_ref=[http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/gcc-128563 The Plant List, ''Euchiton involucratus'' (G.Forst.) Holub ] |synonyms={{collapsible list|bullets = true |title=Synonymy |''Gnaphalium involucratum'' G. Forst. 1753 |''Euchiton involucratus'' (G. Forst.) Anderb. 1991 |''Euchiton forsteri'' Cass. |''Euchiton pulchellus'' Cass. |''Gnaphalium cephaloideum'' Willd. |''Gnaphalium cunninghamii'' DC. |''Gnaphalium globosum'' Hornem. |''Gnaphalium globosum'' Desf. |''Gnaphalium lanatum'' G.Forst. |''Gnaphalium lineare'' Hayata 1908 not (DC.) Sch. Bip. 1845 |''Leontopodium javanicum'' Zoll. & Mor. }}}} '''''Euchiton involucratus''''' ('''common cudweed''') is an herb in the [[Gnaphalieae|pussy's-toes tribe]] within the [[Asteraceae|sunflower family]]. It is native to [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]][http://bie.ala.org.au/species/urn:lsid:biodiversity.org.au:apni.taxon:654699 Atlas of Living Australia, ''Euchiton involucratus'' (G.Forst.) Holub, Common Cudweed] and sparingly naturalized in a few scattered locations in the United States ([[California]] + [[Massachusetts]]).[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Euchiton%20involucratus.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map][http://www.jstor.org/stable/41968065?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents Nesom, Guy L. 2002. ''Euchiton'' (Asteraceeae: Gnaphalieae) in North America and Hawaii. Sida 20(2):515-521.] summaries in parallel English + Spanish, article in English ''Euchiton involucratus'' is a biennial or perennial herb up to 40 cm (16 inches) tall, spreading by means of [[stolons]] running along the surface of the ground. Stems are usually unbranched, covered with white woolly hairs. [[Leaf shape|Leaves are narrowly lance-shaped]], green and shiny on the top side, white and woolly underneath. The plant produces [[flower heads]] in a hemispheric cluster at the top of the plant, frequently with smaller clusters in the [[axils]] of the leaves. Each head is cylindrical, with brown or copper-colored bracts on the outside. It has 80-150 [[pistillate]] flowers around the edge of the head plus 3-7 [[bisexual]] florets toward the center.[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=250066729 Flora of North America, ''Euchiton involucratus'' (G. Forster) Anderberg, 1991. Common-cudweed ] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Commons category|Euchiton involucratus}} [[Category:Gnaphalieae]] [[Category:Flora of New Zealand]] [[Category:Flora of Australia]] [[Category:Plants described in 1756]]

'''''Evolvulus alsinoides''''' ('''slender dwarf morning-glory''') is flowering plant from the family [[Convolvulaceae]]. It has a natural pantropical distribution encompassing tropical and warm-temperate regions of Australasia, Indomalaya, Polynesia, Sub-Saharan Africa and the Americas.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://pick5.pick.uga.edu/mp/20q?search=Evolvulus+alsinoides&btxt=microscope&burl=http://microscope.mbl.edu | title=Evolvulus alsinoides (L.) L. | accessdate=25 February 2014}}</ref> The species inhabits a wide range of habitats, from marshland and wet forests to deserts. A number of varieties and subspecies are recognised. It may become a weed in some situations. It is one of the plants included in [[Dasapushpam]], the ten sacred flowers of [[Kerala]].

This herb used in [[traditional medicine]] of East Asia for its purported [[psychotropic]] and [[nootropic]] properties.<ref>{{cite journal | title = Review of Ethnomedicinal Uses and Pharmacology of Evolvulus alsinoides Linn | author = Amritpal Singh | journal = Ethnobotanical Leaflets | volume = 12 | pages = 734–740 | year = 2008 | url = http://www.ethnoleaflets.com/leaflets/evolvulu.htm}}</ref> although such claims are not medically verified.

Chemical compounds isolated from ''E. alsinoides'' include [[scopoletin]], [[umbelliferone]], [[scopolin]] and [[2-methyl-1,2,3,4-butanetetrol]].<ref>{{cite journal | journal = J Enzyme Inhib Med Chem | year = 2008 | volume = 23 | issue = 4 | pages = 574–578 | doi = 10.1080/14756360701674421 | title = Evaluation of natural substances from Evolvulus alsinoides L. with the purpose of determining their antioxidant potency |vauthors=Cervenka F, Koleckar V, Rehakova Z, Jahodar L, Kunes J, Opletal L, Hyspler R, Jun D, Kuca K | pmid= 18666003}}</ref>

109.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
| name = ''Excoecaria agallocha''
| image = Excoecaria agallocha (Blind Your Eye) W IMG_6929.jpg
| image_caption = ''Excoecaria agallocha'' in [[Krishna Wildlife Sanctuary]], [[Andhra Pradesh]], [[India]].
| regnum = [[Plant]]ae
| unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
| unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
| unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
| ordo = [[Malpighiales]]
| familia = [[Euphorbiaceae]]
| tribus = [[Hippomaneae]]
| genus = ''[[Excoecaria]]''
| species = '''''E. agallocha'''''
| binomial = ''Excoecaria agallocha''
| binomial_authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]
}}
[[File:Excoecaria agallocha (Blind Your Eye) W IMG 6949.jpg|thumb|[[Habit (biology)|Growth habit]] of ''Excoecaria agallocha"]]
[[File:Blind Your Eye Flower 02.jpg|thumb|''Excoecaria agallocha'' in flower]]
'''''Excoecaria agallocha''''', a [[mangrove]] [[species]], belongs to the [[genus]] ''[[Excoecaria]]'' of the [[family (biology)|family]] [[Euphorbiaceae]]. It is common in [[mangrove]] swamps from [[Bangladesh]], India in the northwest to Australia in the southeast,[http://www.iucnredlist.org/apps/redlist/details/178842/0%20] within Australia, it thrives from northern [[New South Wales]] along the northern coastline around to [[Western Australia]]. Given such a wide range, it is understandable that the species has many common names including: ''Thillai'', milky mangrove, blind-your-eye mangrove and river poison tree. Most of the names refer to its poisonous or blinding nature.

Mangrove swamps form a type of coastal [[wetland]] found in the tropics and subtropics.<ref name="Keddy2010">{{cite book|last=Keddy|first=Paul A.|title=Wetland Ecology : Principles and Conservation|year=2010|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=New York|isbn=978-0521519403|pages=497|url=http://www.drpaulkeddy.com/wetlandecology2.html|edition=2nd}}</ref>  Within a mangrove forest, the most salt-tolerant species occur near the ocean. ''Excoecaria agallocha'', known as a back mangrove, is found at higher elevations back away from the ocean where salinity is lower.<ref>Joshi, H. and  M. Ghose. 2003. Forest structure and species distribution along soil salinity and pH gradient in mangrove swamps of the Sundarbans. Tropical Ecology 44: 197-206.</ref>

This small tree species may grow up to 15 m high.  Trees are either male or female. Male flowers form drooping tassels, while female flowers appear as shorter spikes. Pollinators such as bees commonly visit the flowers.  The fruit is a small dark capsule.[http://www.wildsingapore.com/wildfacts/plants/mangrove/excoecaria/excoecaria.htm]

The plant is well-protected by chemical defenses; these include diterpenoids, triterpenoids and flavonoids.<ref>Zou JH, Dai J, Chen X, and Yuan JQ. 2006. Pentacyclic triterpenoids from leaves of Excoecaria agallocha. Chem. Pharm. Bull. (Tokyo) 54:920-921.</ref>

The milky [[latex]] of ''Excoecaria agallocha'' is very poisonous and powerfully irritant, which is not unusual in milky species of plant in the family Euphorbiaceae. Contact with skin causes irritation and rapid blistering; slight contact with eyes can cause temporary blindness, hence the common names that refer to blindness. Even the generic name is from the Latin for "blinder".

[[William Bligh]] in his book "A Voyage to the South Sea" mentioned that he was already aware of this hazard when he embarked on the voyage that ended in the notorious [[mutiny on the Bounty]], having learned of it in 1777 from Captain [[James Cook]] during the time that he served as Cook's [[Master (naval)|sailing master]]. Several of the men that Cook had sent ashore to cut wood had been blinded for a time. He accordingly instructed his men not to cut that type of tree when he sent them ashore in Tahiti to gather wood and water in 1789.<ref>Bligh, William. A Voyage to the South Sea. 1792 From Project Gutenberg at [http://www.gutenberg.org/files/15411/15411-h/15411-h.htm]</ref> It was just as well that he did so, because even the smoke from the burning wood is poisonous and can harm the eyes, so it would not have been useful as fuel.<ref name="Quattrocchi2012">{{cite book|author=Umberto Quattrocchi|title=CRC World Dictionary of Medicinal and Poisonous Plants: Common Names, Scientific Names, Eponyms, Synonyms, and Etymology (5 Volume Set)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YC_lAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA1709|date=3 May 2012|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=978-1-4200-8044-5|pages=1709–}}</ref>

Even dried and powdered leaves retain the poison and can kill fish very quickly.

Owing to its complex chemistry, the plant may have many new medicinal uses.<ref>Konoshima,T, T. Konishi,  M. Takasaki,  K. Yamazoe, and H. Tokuda. 2001. Anti-tumor-promoting activity of the diterpene from Excoecaria agallocha. II Biological and Pharmaceutical Bulletin 24:1440-1442.</ref>

Mangroves of this plant surround the ancient [[Thillai Chidambaram Temple]] in [[Tamil Nadu]].

'''''Festuca actae''''' is a species of [[Poaceae|grass]] which can be found in [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]].<ref name=kew>{{cite web|url= http://www.kew.org/data/grasses-db/www/imp04364.htm|author1=W.D. Clayton |author2=M. Vorontsova |author3=K.T. Harman |author4=H. Williamson |title=Festuca actae|publisher=GrassBase |work=The Board of Trustees and [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew|Royal Botanic Gardens]]|place=[[Kew]]|date=November 16, 2012|accessdate=December 5, 2013}}</ref>

==Description==

===General description===
The plant is [[perennial plant|perennial]] and caespitose with {{convert|25|–|60|cm}} long [[culm (botany)|culms]]. The [[ligule]] is {{convert|0.4|–|0.7|mm}} long and is going around the eciliate membrane. Leaf-sheaths are ribbed {{convert|5|–|10|cm}} long and have a hairy surface. The leaf-sheaths [[auricle (botany)|auricle]] is identical in size to the membrane but is erect. Leaf-blades are {{convert|20|–|60|cm}} long with the same width as membrane and auricle parts. The [[panicle]] is open [[inflorescence]]d, is {{convert|5|–|25|cm}} long and carries 10–30 fertile [[spikelet]]s.<ref name=kew/>

===Spikelets and palea===
Spikelets are solitary, and carry both scaberulous [[pedicel (botany)|pedicelles]] and 4-7 (sometimes 12) fertile florets. It also have a {{convert|1|–|1.5|mm}} long [[rhachilla]] internodes which are hairy, while the floret [[callus]] is pilose and is {{convert|0.2|–|0.5|mm}} long. The [[palea (botany)|palea]] is {{convert|6|–|8|mm}} long, have scabrous keels and a hairy surface with dentated apex as well.<ref name=kew/>

===Glumes and lemma===
The [[chaff|glumes]] are membranous and keelless with scabrous [[vein (botany)|veins]]. The upper one is {{convert|3|–|4.5|mm}} long and is lanceolate while the other one is ovate and is {{convert|4.5|–|7.5|mm}} long. Fertile [[lemma (botany)|lemma]] is {{convert|6|–|9|mm}} long, is lanceolate just like the upper glume, and is both glaucous, keelless, and membranous as well. Lemma itself have scaberulous surface and muticous with dentated apex.<ref name=kew/>

===Flowers and fruits===
[[Flower]]s carry two ciliate and membranous [[lodicule]]s that are {{convert|0.75|–|1.5|mm}} long. The also have three [[stamen]]s that are {{convert|3.5|–|4.4|mm}} long and are yellow in colour. Their [[ovary (botany)|ovary]] is hairy at the apex. The [[fruit]]s are caryopses and are {{convert|3|–|4.75|mm}} long with an additional [[pericarp]], which just like flowers is hairy at the apex as well. [[Hilum (biology)|Hilum]] is linear and is located {{convert|0.6|mm}} of [[caryopsis]], while the [[embryo]] is {{convert|0.25|–|0.33|mm}} over it.<ref name=kew/>

[[File:Ceratosolen sp. on Ficus septica from South of Taiwan.tif|thumb|right|Pollinating fig wasp (''Ceratosolen'' sp.) collected on ''Ficus septica'' from South of Taiwan]]

'''''Ficus septica''''' (called Hauli tree in the [[Philippines]], 棱果榕 in [[China]]<ref name=wu03>{{cite book| author=Wu, Z., Raven, P.H. & Hong, D.|year=2003| title= Flora of China. Volume 5: Ulmaceae through Basellaceae |chapter=Ulmaceae through Basellaceae|volume=5| isbn= 1-930723-40-7}}</ref> and [[Taiwan]]) is a shrub or tree of the family [[Moraceae]] living at low altitudes from Northeast [[India]] to North [[Australia]] ([[Queensland]]), and throughout [[Malesia]].<ref name=bergcorner05>{{cite book|author1=Berg, C.C.  |author2=Corner E.J.H.|year=2005| title= Flora Malesiana |chapter=Moraceae|series=I|volume=17|issue=6| isbn= 1-930723-40-7}}</ref>
It lives on the edge of the vegetation, often in degraded environments. The seeds of this species are dispersed by numerous species, including fruit bats ([[Megachiroptera]]) when present.<ref name=Shanahan01>{{cite journal|author1=Shanahan, M. |author2=Compton, S. G. |author3=So, S. |author4=Corlett, R. |year=2001 |title=Fig-eating by vertebrate frugivores: a global review |journal=Biological Reviews |volume=76 |issue=4 |pages=529–72 |doi=10.1017/S1464793101005760 |url=http://us.geocities.com/mikeshanahan/figglobalreview.pdf |pmid=11762492 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091026232430/http://us.geocities.com/mikeshanahan/figglobalreview.pdf |archivedate=October 26, 2009 }}</ref>

==Taxonomy==
''Ficus septica'' was described first by the Dutch botanist [[Nicolaas Laurens Burman]] in 1768. Two centuries later, [[E. J. H. Corner]] listed  three varieties for ''Ficus septica'': ''F. septica'' var. ''septica'' distributed all over the range of the species; ''F. septica'' var. ''cauliflora'' limited to [[Queensland]], Australia and the [[Solomon islands]]; and ''F. septica'' var. ''salicifolia'' endemic to the [[Philippines]] Islands.<ref name=Corner-1965>{{Cite journal | last1= Corner | first1= E. J. H. | authorlink1= E. J. H. Corner | year= 1965 | title= Check-list of ''Ficus'' in Asia and Australasia with keys to identification | journal= The Gardens' Bulletin Singapore | volume= 21 | issue= 1 | pages= 1–186 | url= http://biodiversitylibrary.org/page/43581709 | version= (digitised, online, via biodiversitylibrary.org) | accessdate= 5 Feb 2014 }}</ref> Then in the latest [[Flora Malesiana]] edition, [[Cornelis Christiaan Berg]] put all these varieties in synonymy together under the name ''Ficus septica''.<ref name=bergcorner05/>
Within the genus, ''Ficus septica'' belongs to the subgenus ''Sycomorus'' section ''Sycocarpus'' subsection ''Sycocarpus''.

==Description==
Tree or shrub up to 25 meters.<ref name=bergcorner05/> The latex of ''F. septica'' is characteristically yellow. Leaves and petioles are both glabrous. Leaves are symmetric, elliptic to oblong.  Figs grow often in pairs but can be solitary or in groups of up to four. Figs are depressed-globose to ellipsoid, the apex is flat or concave. Seven to twelve ribs towards to ostiole. At maturity, whitish to yellowish dots appear on the fig. The individuals from Philippines have their stems covered by short hairs while those found in Taiwan are glabrous.
{{Multiple image
 | align= left
 | image1= Ficus septica pollinated figs.JPG
 | caption1= ''Ficus septica'' pollinated figs
 | width1= 189
 | image2= Ficus septica female fig at maturity.JPG
 | caption2= ''Ficus septica'' female fig at maturity in [[National Taiwan University]] Campus, [[Taipei]], Taiwan
 | width2= 189
 | image3= Ficus septica branch with unpollinated fig.JPG
 | caption3= ''Ficus septica'' branch with unpollinated fig in [[University of the Philippines]] Diliman campus, [[Philippines]]
 | width3= 189
}} {{Clear|left}}

==Habitat==
''Ficus septica'' trees live up to 1800m in montane forests or secondary growth environments. It can be seen often along rivers. In [[Taiwan]], at the northern limit of its distribution, ''F. septica'' lives up to 500m in secondary growths and along roads and coastlines.

==Ecology==
''Ficus septica'' is pollinated by [[fig wasp]]s from the genus ''[[Ceratosolen]]''. Usually members of the genus ''Ficus'' are pollinated by a single species of pollinating fig wasps specific to each fig species, but recent observations of ''Ficus septica'' have shown there to be three pollinating species in the South of [[Taiwan]] <ref name=Lin11>{{cite journal|author=Lin, R.-C., Yeung, C.K.-L., Fong, J.J., Tzeng, H.-Y. & Li, S.-H.|year=2011|title= The lack of pollinator specificity in a dioecious fig tree: sympatric fig-pollinating wasps of ''Ficus septica'' in southern Taiwan |journal= Biotropica |volume= 43|pages= 200–07|doi=10.1111/j.1744-7429.2010.00686.x}}</ref> and two in [[The Philippines]].<ref name=Conchou14>{{cite journal|author1=L. Conchou |author2=L. Cabioch |author3=L. J. V. Rodriguez |author4=F. Kjellberg |year=2014|title= Daily rhythm of mutualistic pollinator activity and scent emission in ''Ficus septica'': Ecological differentiation between co-occurring pollinators and potential consequences for chemical communication and facilitation of host speciation |journal= PLoS ONE |volume= 9|pages=e103581|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0103581 |pmid=25105796 |pmc=4126690}}</ref>

The figs of ''Ficus septica'' have been reported to be eaten by 22 animal species and among them 14 are bats:<ref name=Shanahan01/>
{{Div col | colwidth= 300px }}
* [[Double-eyed fig parrot]]
* Unspecified [[fruit dove]]
* [[Black-naped oriole]]
* [[Northern common cuscus]]
* [[Stein's cuscus]]
* [[Common spotted cuscus]]
* [[Mantled guereza]]
* [[Black rat]]
* [[Lesser short-nosed fruit bat]]
* [[Horsfield's fruit bat]]
* [[Greater short-nosed fruit bat]]
* [[Indonesian short-nosed fruit bat]]
* [[Bare-backed fruit bat]]
* [[Lesser naked-backed fruit bat]]
* [[Long-tongued nectar bat]]
* [[Long-tongued fruit bat]]
* [[Broad-striped tube-nosed fruit bat]]
* [[Common tube-nosed fruit bat]]
* [[Greater musky fruit bat]]
* [[Geoffroy's rousette]]
* [[Common blossom bat]]
{{Div col end}}

'''''Fimbristylis polytrichoides''''' is a species of [[Fimbristylis|fimbry]] known by the common name '''rusty sedge''', native to east [[Africa]], [[Madagascar]], [[China]], [[Southeast Asia]], [[New Guinea]] and [[Australia]].<ref>[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=245835 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families]</ref><ref>Hoenselaar, K., Verdcourt, B. & Beentje, H. (2010). Cyperaceae. Flora of Tropical East Africa: 1-466. </ref><ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=2&taxon_id=200026805 Flora of China, Vol. 23 Page 213, <big>细叶飘拂草</big> xi ye piao fu cao, ''Fimbristylis polytrichoides'' (Retzius) R. Brown, Prodr. Fl. Nov. Holland. 226. 1810. ]</ref><ref>Govaerts, R. & Simpson, D.A. (2007). World Checklist of Cyperaceae. Sedges: 1-765. The Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew. </ref> The plant is common along the coast line and estuaries of [[Australia]]. The flowers are a distinctive rusty brown color appearing on a single spikelet from May to July.

|species = '''''G. secunda '''''

|synonyms=*''Aizoon contaminatum'' Eckl. & Zeyh. 	
*''Aizoon elongatum'' Eckl. & Zeyh.
*''Aizoon glinoides'' Eckl. & Zeyh.
*''Aizoon propinquum'' Eckl. & Zeyh.

|synonyms_ref=<ref>[http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/kew-2816382 The Plant List]</ref>
|}}
'''''Galenia secunda''''' ('''onesided galenia''') is a plant species native to [[South Africa]] but naturalized in [[Australia]] ([[Western Australia]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], [[Tasmania]] and [[New South Wales]]), [[Spain]], and the United States ([[Florida]] and [[New Jersey]]).<ref>Gibbs Russell, G. E., W. G. M. Welman, E. Retief, K. L. Immelman, G. Germishuizen, B. J. Pienaar, M. Van Wyk & A. Nicholas. 1987. List of species of southern African plants. Memoirs of the Botanical Survey of South Africa 2(1–2): 1–152(pt. 1), 1–270(pt. 2). ''Galenia secunda''</ref><ref>Prescott, A. & J. Venning. 1984. Aizoaceae. Flora of Australia 19–62</ref><ref name="asdlfkasjasjdf0000000000">[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=242415128 Flora of North America, vol 4 p 79, ''Galenia secunda'']</ref><ref>Adamson, R. S. 1956. The South African species of Aizoaceae III. Galenia L. J. S. African Bot. 22: 87-127.</ref><ref>Prescott, A. 1984. Galenia. In: R. Robertson et al., eds. Flora of Australia. 23+ vols. Canberra. Vol. 4, pp. 50-52.</ref> In Spain and Australia, is considered an invasive weed threatening native vegetation.<ref>[http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs10530-008-9278-2#page-1 García-de-Lomas, Juan, Ignacio Hernández, Íñigo Sánchez-García. 2009. Incipient invasion of ''Galenia secunda'' Sond. (Aizoaceae) in southern Spain. Biological Invasions 11:467-472. ]</ref><ref>[http://www.environment.gov.au/cgi-bin/biodiversity/invasive/weeds/weeddetails.pl?taxon_id=4624 Weeds in Australia, Australian Government]</ref>

''Galenia secunda'' is shrub or perennial herb with grayish-white stems that trail along the ground for as much as 60 cm, forming mats. Leaves are grayish-white, folded inward, up to 2.5 cm long. Flowers are small, white to yellowish, up to 2 mm in diameter, often hidden by the leaves. 
<ref name="asdlfkasjasjdf0000000000"/><ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/704441#page/483/mode/1up Sonder, Otto Wilhelm in Harvey, William Henry. 1862. Flora capensis :being a systematic description of the plants of the Cape colony, Caffraria, & Port Natal (and neighbouring territories)  2: 474.].</ref><ref>Clewell, A. F. 1985. Guide to the Vascular Plants of the Florida Panhandle</ref>

114.text:
{{Other uses of|goosegrass|Goosegrass (disambiguation){{!}}Goosegrass}} {{pp-move-indef|small=yes}} {{italic title}} {{taxobox |name =''Galium aparine''
Cleavers |image = Galium aparine b.jpg |regnum = [[Plantae]] |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]] |ordo = [[Gentianales]] |familia = [[Rubiaceae]] |genus = ''[[Galium]]'' |species = '''''G. aparine''''' |binomial = ''Galium aparine'' |binomial_authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]] |synonyms = {{Plainlist | style = margin-left: 1em; text-indent: -1em; | *''Aparine hispida'' Moench nom. illeg. *''Aparine vulgaris'' Hill *''Asperula aparine'' (L.) Besser nom. illeg. *''Asterophyllum aparine'' (L.) Schimp. & Spenn. *''Crucianella purpurea'' Wulff ex Steud. *''Galion aparinum'' (L.) St.-Lag. *''Galium aculeatissimum'' Kit. ex Kanitz *''Galium adhaerens'' Gilib. nom. inval. *''Galium asperum'' Honck. nom. illeg. *''Galium australe'' Reiche nom. illeg. *''Galium charoides'' Rusby *''Galium chilense'' Hook.f. *''Galium chonosense'' Clos nom. illeg. *''Galium hispidum'' Willd. *''Galium horridum'' Eckl. & Zeyh. nom. illeg. *''Galium intermedium'' Mérat nom. illeg. *''Galium lappaceum'' Salisb. nom. illeg. *''Galium larecajense'' Wernham *''Galium parviflorum'' Maxim. nom. illeg. *''Galium pseudoaparine'' Griseb. *''Galium scaberrimum'' Vahl ex Hornem. *''Galium segetum'' K.Koch *''Galium tenerrimum'' Schur *''Galium uliginosum'' Thunb. nom. illeg. *''Galium uncinatum'' Gray *''Rubia aparine'' (L.) Baill. }} |synonyms_ref = {{cite web |url=http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/kew-85676 |title=The Plant List: A Working List of All Plant Species |accessdate=20 June 2015}} }} '''''Galium aparine''''', ('aparine' from Greek 'apairo' - “lay hold of” or “seize”) http://climbers.lsa.umich.edu/?p=461 with many common names including '''cleavers''',{{citation |url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?103276 |title=USDA GRIN Taxonomy |accessdate=20 June 2015}} clivers, goosegrass, catchweed, stickyweed, robin-run-the-hedge, sticky willy, sticky willow, stickyjack, stickeljack, and grip grass, is a herbaceous [[annual plant]] of the family [[Rubiaceae]]. ==Description== Cleavers are annuals with creeping straggling stems which branch and grow along the ground and over other plants. They attach themselves with the small hooked hairs which grow out of the stems and leaves. The stems can reach up to three feet or longer, and are angular or square shaped.{{cite book|author=Duke, James A.|title=Handbook of Edible Weeds|publisher=CRC Press|year=2001|isbn=9780849329463|page=100|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rVrteo-8cI0C&pg=PA100}} The leaves are simple, narrowly oblanceolate to linear, and borne in whorls of six to eight.{{Cite book|author=Rabeler, Richard K.|title=Gleason's Plants of Michigan|publisher=University of Michigan Press|year=2007|isbn=9780472032464|page=299|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6WF1HjsNeqAC&pg=PA299}}Webb, D.A., Parnell, J. and Doogue, D. 1996. ''An Irish Flora.'' Dundalgan Press (W.Tempest) Ltd. Dundalk. 0-85221-131-7 Cleavers have tiny, star-shaped, white to greenish flowers, which emerge from early spring to summer. The flowers are clustered in groups of two or three, and are borne out of the [[leaf axils]].{{cite book|author=Grieve, Maud|chapter=Clivers|title=A Modern Herbal: The Medicinal, Culinary, Cosmetic and Economic Properties, Cultivation and Folk-lore of Herbs, Grasses, Fungi, Shrubs, & Trees with All Their Modern Scientific Uses, Volume 1|publisher=Dover Publications|year=1971|isbn=9780486227986|page=206|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tLWve-VvBLoC&pg=SL26-PA6}} The globular fruits are [[burr (fruit)|burrs]] which grow one to three seeds clustered together; they are covered with hooked hairs which cling to animal fur, aiding in seed dispersal. ==Distribution== The species is native to a wide region of Europe, North Africa and Asia from Britain and the [[Canary Islands]] to Japan. It is now naturalized throughout most of the United States, Canada, Mexico, Central America, South America, Australia, New Zealand, some oceanic islands and scattered locations in Africa. Whether it is native to North America is a question of some debate, but it is considered to be native there in most literature.[http://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/forb/galapa/all.html US Forest Service] It is considered a [[noxious weed]] in many places.[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=85676 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families][http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Galium%20aparine.png Biota of North America Program] == Effects on the body == For some people, skin contact with ''Galium aparine'' causes an unpleasant localized rash{{cite news|author=Evanoff, K. |title=Bedstraw is a weed that bites back |publisher=Tribune Chronicle |year=2013 |url=http://tribune-chronicle.com/page/content.detail/id/589618/Bedstraw-is-a-weed-that-bites-back.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413130250/http://tribune-chronicle.com/page/content.detail/id/589618/Bedstraw-is-a-weed-that-bites-back.htm |archivedate=2014-04-13 |df= }}[Link Evanoff] known as [[contact dermatitis]]. == Chemistry == Chemical constituents of ''Galium aparine'' include: [[iridoid]] [[glycosides]] such as [[asperulosidic acid]] and [[10-deacetylasperulosidic acid]],Iridoids from ''Galium aparine''. D Deliorman, I Çalis, and F Ergun, Pharmaceutical Biology, 2001, Vol. 39, No. 3, Pages 234-235, {{doi|10.1076/phbi.39.3.234.5928}} [[asperuloside]], [[monotropein]] and [[aucubin]], alkaloids such as [[caffeine]], phenolics such as [[phenolic acid]]s, [[anthraquinone]] derivatives such as the aldehyde [[nordamnacanthal]] ([[1,3-dihydroxy-anthraquinone-2-al]]),Antifeedant activity of an anthraquinone aldehyde in ''Galium aparine'' L. against ''Spodoptera litura'' F. Masanori Morimoto, Kumiko Tanimoto, Akiko Sakatani and Koichiro Komai, Phytochemistry, May 2002, Volume 60, Issue 2, Pages 163–166, {{doi|10.1016/S0031-9422(02)00095-X}} [[flavonoid]]s and [[coumarin]]s, organic acids such as [[citric acid]] and a red dye.{{cite book|author=Rahman, Atta-ur|title=Studies in Natural Products Chemistry: Bioactive Natural Products (Part L)|publisher=Gulf Publishing Company|year=2005|isbn=9780444521712|page=291|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BURF2WXdVzEC&pg=PA291}} ==Edibility== ''Galium aparine'' is edible. The leaves and stems of the plant can be cooked as a leaf vegetable if gathered before the fruits appear. However, the numerous small hooks which cover the plant and give it its clinging nature can make it less palatable if eaten raw.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uo4GlfyjgFwC&pg=PA86&lpg=PA86&source=web&ots=Zr5Qf9O97Q&sig=R4i2e_FAnC39ZqDjAAJ6uZnkx6E |title=Edible Wild Plants: A North American Field Guide |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-14}}Tull, Delena. "Edible and Useful Plants of Texas and the Southwest." 1999, p. 145 Geese thoroughly enjoy eating ''G. aparine'', hence one of its other common names, "goosegrass".{{cite book|author=Dukes, James A.|title=The Green Pharmacy Herbal Handbook|publisher=Macmillan|year=2002|isbn=9780312981518|page=102|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AdwG0jCJYcUC&pg=PA102}} Cleavers are in the same [[family (biology)|family]] as coffee. The fruits of cleavers have often been dried and roasted, and then used as a coffee substitute which contains less caffeine.{{cite book|author=Wood, Matthew|chapter=Galium aparine. Cleavers. Lady's Bedstraw. Goosegrass.|title=The Earthwise Herbal: A Complete Guide to Old World Medicinal Plants|publisher=North Atlantic Books|year=2008|isbn=9781556436925|page=267|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RfoJsFHFSnMC&pg=PA267}} == Folk medicine == [[Poultices]] and washes made from cleavers were traditionally used to treat a variety of skin ailments, light wounds and burns. As a pulp, it has been used to relieve poisonous bites and stings.Jones, Pamela. ''Just Weeds: History, Myths, and Uses.'' Prentice Hall Press, New York. 1991. To make a poultice, the entire plant is used, and applied directly to the affected area.{{cite book|authors=Schneider, Anny & Mellichamp, Larry|title=Wild Medicinal Plants: What to Look For, When to Harvest, How to Use|publisher=Stackpole Books|year=2002|isbn=9780811729871|page=73|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SNKWzlTuaT4C&pg=PA73}} Cleavers is also used as a lymphatic system aid, as it assists the lymph nodes in cleaning out toxins. Making a tea with the dried leaves is most common.https://www.achs.edu/blog/2012/05/14/extend-benefits-massage-part-2 == Other uses == [[Dioscorides]] reported that ancient Greek shepherds would use the barbed stems of cleavers to make a "rough sieve", which could be used to strain milk. [[Linnaeus]] later reported the same usage in Sweden, a tradition that is still practiced in modern times.{{cite book|author=Grieve, Maud|chapter=Clivers|title=A Modern Herbal: The Medicinal, Culinary, Cosmetic and Economic Properties, Cultivation and Folk-lore of Herbs, Grasses, Fungi, Shrubs, & Trees with All Their Modern Scientific Uses, Volume 1|publisher=Dover Publications|year=1971|isbn=9780486227986|page=207|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tLWve-VvBLoC&pg=SL26-PA7}}Loudon, John Claudius. "An encyclopædia of plants", 1836, p. 93 In Europe, the dried, matted foliage of the plant was once used to stuff mattresses. Several of the bedstraws were used for this purpose because the clinging hairs cause the branches to stick together, which enables the mattress filling to maintain a uniform thickness.{{cite book|authors=Runkel, Sylvan T. & Roosa, Dean M.|title=Wildflowers of the Tallgrass Prairie: The Upper Midwest|publisher=University of Iowa|year=2009|isbn=9781587297960|page=65|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EyLjHnUap0UC&pg=PA65}} The roots of cleavers can be used to make a permanent red dye.{{Cite book|author=Hutchens, Alma R.|title=A Handbook of Native American Herbs|publisher=Shambala Publications|year=1992|isbn=9780877736998|page=97|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YaSTm6SVCcUC&pg=PT97}} == Ecology == The plant can be found growing in hedges and waste places, limestone scree and as a garden weed.Hackney, P. (Ed)1992. ''Stewart & Corry's Flora of the North-east of Ireland''. Third Edition. Institute of Irish Studies, The Queen's University of Belfast. ISBN 0 85389 446 9Clapham, A.R., Tutin, T.G. and Warburg, E.F. 1968. ''Excursion Flora of the British Isles''. Second Edition. Cambridge University Press. ''G. aparine'' prefers moist soils and can exist in areas with poor drainage. It reportedly flourishes in heavy soils with above-average nitrogen and phosphorus content, and prefers soils with a pH value between 5.5 and 8.0. ''G. aparine'' is often found in post-fire plant communities in the United States, likely developing from onsite seed and therefore rendering controlled burns as an ineffective means of removing ''G. aparine'' in areas where it is considered a noxious weed.{{cite web|last1=Gucker|first1=Corey|title=Galium aparine|url=https://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/forb/galapa/all.html|website=Fire Effects Information System|publisher=United States Department of Agriculture, Forest Service, Rocky Mountain Research Station, Fire Sciences Laboratory|accessdate=14 February 2017}} The [[anthraquinone]] [[aldehyde]] [[nordamnacanthal]] ([[1,3-dihydroxy-anthraquinone-2-al]]) present in ''G. aparine'' has an [[antifeedant]] activity against ''[[Spodoptera litura]]'', the Oriental leafworm moth, a species which is considered an agricultural pest. The Acari ''[[Cecidophyes rouhollahi]]'' can be found on ''G. aparine''.A new species of ''Cecidophyes'' (Acari: Eriophyidae) from ''Galium aparine'' (Rubiaceae) with notes on its biology and potential as a biological control agent for ''Galium spurium''. Charnie Craemer, Rouhollah Sobhian, Alec S. McClay and James W. Amrine Jr., International Journal of Acarology, 1999, Volume 25, Issue 4, pages 255-263, {{doi|10.1080/01647959908684162}} ==Photos== {{Commons category|Galium aparine}} {{gallery |lines=4 |File:Goosegrass (Galium aparine), Loch Clunie - geograph.org.uk - 1505032.jpg|Cleavers, creeping together over the tops of other plants on the forest floor. |File:Galium_aparine.jpg|Leaves and stem of ''G. aperine''. Notice the angular stem and whorled oblong/lanceolate leaves. |File:Flowers February 2008-4.jpg|Flower and fruit of ''G. aperine''. The fruit is an adhesive burr that clings to animals passing by to spread the seed. |File:Galium.aparine.jpg|Galium aparine, closeup with leaves and fruit, from [[Cologne]], Germany |File:Galium aparine 3769.JPG|Closeup of ''G. aparine'' leaf. Note the hooked barbs used to climb over substrate. }} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==Further reading== * ''Edible and Medicinal Plants of the West'', Gregory L. Tilford, ISBN 0-87842-359-1 *[http://luirig.altervista.org/flora/taxa/index1.php?scientific-name=galium+aparine Altervista Flora Italiana] [[Category:Medicinal plants of Asia]] [[Category:Medicinal plants of Europe]] [[Category:Medicinal plants of North America]] [[Category:Galium|aparine]] [[Category:Flora of Canada]] [[Category:Flora of the United States]] [[Category:Flora of Mexico]] [[Category:Flora of Central America]] [[Category:Flora of South America]] [[Category:Flora of the Caribbean]] [[Category:Flora of Australia]] [[Category:Flora of Africa]] [[Category:Flora of the Canary Islands]] [[Category:Flora of Greenland]] [[Category:Flora of Hawaii]] [[Category:Flora of New Zealand]] [[Category:Flora of Asia]] [[Category:Flora of Bermuda]] [[Category:Flora of China]] [[Category:Plants described in 1753]]

116.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name =False cleavers
|image = Galium spurium ssp vaillantii.jpg
|image_caption = ''Galium spurium''
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]]
|ordo = [[Gentianales]]
|familia = [[Rubiaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Galium]]''
|species = '''''G. spurium'''''
|binomial = ''Galium spurium''
|binomial_authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]
}}
'''''Galium spurium''''' or '''false cleavers''' is a plant species of the [[Rubiaceae]]. It is widespread across [[Europe]], [[Asia]], [[Africa]] and [[Canada]], and is naturalized in [[Australia]].<ref name="peggyearnshaw">[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=87547 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families]</ref><ref>[http://luirig.altervista.org/flora/taxa/index1.php?scientific-name=galium+spurium Altervista Flora Italiana]</ref><ref>Moss, E. H. 1983. Flora of Alberta (ed. 2) i–xii, 1–687. University of Toronto Press, Toronto.</ref> It is considered a noxious weed in many places.<ref>[http://www.invasive.org/publications/xsymposium/proceed/01pg117.pdf Wenming Zhang & K. L. Bailey. 2000. Biological Control of Cleavers (''Galium spurium'' and ''G. aparine'') with Pathogenic Fungi - Exploration and Discovery. Proceedings of the X International Symposium on Biological Control of Weeds 4-14 July 1999, Montana State University, Bozeman, Montana USA Neal R. Spencer (ed.). pp. 117-123 ]</ref>

''Galium spurium'' is an erect or reclining herb up to 50 cm tall. Stems are square in cross-section. Leaves are in [[Whorl (botany)|whorls]] of 6-8, narrowly lanceolate. Flowers are in multi-flowered [[Cyme (botany)|cymes]] or [[panicle]]s, white or yellow-green.<ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=2&taxon_id=250090777 Flora of China v 19 p 136, 猪殃殃 zhu yang yang ''Galium spurium'' ]</ref>

==Subspecies==
Many varietal and subspecific names have been proposed, but at present (May 2014) only 3 are recognized:<ref name="peggyearnshaw"/>

*''Galium spurium'' subsp. ''africanum'' <small>Verdc.</small> - mountains of tropical and southern Africa; also [[Saudi Arabia]], [[Yemen]], [[Socotra]]
*''Galium spurium'' subsp. ''ibicinum'' <small>(Boiss. & Hausskn.) Ehrend.</small> - [[Turkey]], [[Iran]], [[Iraq]], [[Afghanistan]], [[Pakistan]], [[Turkmenistan]], [[Tajikistan]]
*''Galium spurium'' subsp. ''spurium'' - widespread

{{taxobox

|image = Galium tricornutum BB-1913.jpg

|synonyms_ref = <ref name="tinathanos"/>
|synonyms = *''Galium spurium'' <small>Huds.</small>
*''Valantia triflora'' <small>Lam.</small>
*''Valantia spuria'' <small>Pers.</small>
*''Galium tricorne'' var. ''microcarpum'' <small>Gren. & Godr.</small>

*''Galium kurramensis'' <small>Nazim.</small>
*''Galium tricornutum'' subsp. ''longipedunculatum'' <small>Nazim.</small>
*''Galium tehranicum'' <small>M.Moussavi, A.Ghahreman & Attar</small>
}}
'''''Galium tricornutum''''' is a species of flowering plant in the [[Rubiaceae|coffee family]] known by the common names '''rough corn bedstraw''', '''roughfruit corn bedstraw''', and '''corn cleavers'''. It is widespread across most of [[Europe]] plus northern [[Africa]] and southern [[Asia]], from [[Norway]], [[Portugal]] and [[Morocco]] to [[China]]. It is also naturalized in [[Australia]], the [[Canary Islands]], [[Mauritius]], [[Madeira]], [[Réunion]], [[Brazil]], [[Argentina]], and scattered locales in [[North America]] (mostly [[California]] and [[Oregon]]).<ref name="tinathanos">[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=87741 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families]</ref><ref>[http://bonap.net/NAPA/TaxonMaps/Genus/County/Galium Biota of North America Program]</ref><ref>[http://luirig.altervista.org/flora/taxa/index1.php?scientific-name=galium+tricornutum Altervista Flora Italiana]</ref><ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=2&taxon_id=250090768 Flora of China v 19 p 138, 麦仁珠 mai ren zhu ]</ref>

''Galium tricornutum'' is an annual herb with trailing or climbing stems up to about 35 centimeters in length. It forms tangled masses or spreads thin. The stems are sometimes nearly square in cross-section. Leaves are arranged in [[Whorl (botany)|whorls]] of 6 to 8 about the stem and are narrow, pointed, and bordered with prickles. Flowers appear in thin clusters of white corollas. The fruits are spherical nutlets hanging in pairs at the leaf axils. This plant is sometimes a weed of grain fields.<ref>Dandy, James Edgar. 1957.  Watsonia 4(1): 47–48</ref><ref>Hickman, J. C. 1993. The Jepson Manual: Higher Plants of California 1–1400. University of California Press, Berkeley. </ref><ref>Bacigalupo, N.M., E. L. Cabral & C.M. Taylor. 2008. Rubiaceae. 107(3): 2871–2920. In F. O. Zuloaga, O. N. Morrone & M. J. Belgrano (eds.) Catálogo de las plantas vasculares del Cono Sur, Monographs in Systematic Botany from Missouri Botanical Garden, Missouri Botanical Garden, St. Louis. </ref>
