118.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2016}}
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = ''Garcinia warrenii''
|image = Garcinia warrenii fruit.JPG
|image_caption = Native mangosteen fruit on tree.
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Malpighiales]]
|familia = [[Clusiaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Garcinia]]''
|species = '''''G. warrenii'''''
|binomial_authority = [[Mueller, F.J.H. von (1891)]]
|binomial = ''Garcinia warrenii''
|}}

'''''Garcinia warrenii''''', a is a fruit-bearing tree, up to 15 metres in height, of the [[mangosteen]] family (Clusiaceae), commonly known as '''native mangosteen''' or '''Warren's mangosteen'''. It is found in the tropical rainforests of northern and north-eastern Australia and [[New Guinea]]. 
The genus ''[[Garcinia]]'', belonging to the family Clusiaceae, includes about 200 species found in the Old World tropics, mostly in Asia and Africa. ''Garcinia warrenii'' is indigenous to [[New Guinea]], the [[Torres Strait Islands]], northeastern [[Queensland]] from [[Cape York Peninsula]] south to [[Babinda]],<ref>[http://keys.trin.org.au/key-server/data/0e0f0504-0103-430d-8004-060d07080d04/media/Html/taxon/Garcinia_warrenii.htm ''Garcinia warrenii'' Factsheet]</ref> and a small, isolated population on [[Melville Island (Australia)|Melville Island]] in the [[Northern Territory]], Australia.<ref>[http://www.lrm.nt.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0020/10946/Garcinia_warrenii_EN.pdf Threatened Species of the Northern Territory]</ref>

''Garcinia warrenii'' is found in rain forest, [[littoral]] rainforest and [[riparian forest]] from 0 to 780 m.<ref>''Fruits of the Australian Tropical Rainforest'', p. 124</ref> 
[[File:Garcinia warrenii fruit and leaf.JPG|thumb|Photo of native mangosteen leaf and fruit]]
[[File:Garcinia warrenii tree.JPG|thumb|Photo of native mangosteen tree]]

==Uses==
There are five species of native ''Garcinia'' in north Queensland forests but ''Garcinia warrenii'' is the only edible one.<ref>http://www.rarefruitaustralia.org/2006/05/25/mangosteen-nutrition-management/</ref> While the fruits are edible, they are not widely sought after.<ref>''Plants of Cape York: the Compact Guide'', p. 154</ref><ref>''Plants of Tropical North Queensland: the Compact Guide'', p. 90.</ref>

==Description==
''Garcinia warrenii'' is a close relative of the mangosteen (''[[Garcinia mangostana]]''). This bushy small tree grows up to 15 metres high, they grow straight up and are often difficult to see in the forest. It has fragrant white flowers and purple sweet edible fruit.
The thick, leathery leaves are often stained with mould or lichens. Broken [[petiole (botany)|petioles]] (leaf stalks) and twigs produce a sticky yellow exudate. Leaf blades are about 10 to 16 x 48 cm. The fruit are eaten by ''[[Pteropus]]'' (fruit bats).

==References==
* ''Fruits of the Australian Tropical Rainforest''. 2004. Wendy Cooper; illustrated by William T. Cooper. Nokomis Editions, Melbourne. 
* ''Plants of Cape York: the Compact Guide''. John Beasley. 2009.
* ''Plants of Tropical North Queensland: the Compact Guide''. John Beasley. Footloose Publications, Kuranda. 2006.

{{Speciesbox
 | taxon = Geitonoplesium cymosum
 | image= Geitonoplesium cymosum flowers.jpg
 | image_caption= Flowers, 26 Dec 2011
 | image2= Scrambling_Lily_fruit.jpg
 | image2_caption= Fruit, Feb 2011 at Paruna Reserve, [[Como, New South Wales|Como, Sydney, NSW]], by John Tann
 | parent_authority = [[Allan Cunningham (botanist)|A.Cunn.]] ex [[Robert Brown (botanist, born 1773)|R.Br.]]<ref name=APNI/>

 | synonyms =
* ''Eustrephus timorensis'' Ridl.
* ''Geitonoplesium asperum'' A.Cunn. ex R.Br.
* ''Geitonoplesium montanum'' (R.Br.) Kunth
* ''Geitonoplesium montanum'' (R. Br.) Hook.
* ''Luzuriaga cymosa'' R.Br.
* ''Luzuriaga laxiflora'' Hallier f.
* ''Luzuriaga montana'' R.Br.
* ''Luzuriaga timorensis'' (Ridl.) Hallier f.
* ''Medeola angustifolia'' Delile nom. illeg.
 | synonyms_ref = <ref>{{ThePlantList | id = kew-307862 | taxon = Geitonoplesium cymosum | authority = (R.Br.) A.Cunn. ex R.Br. | accessdate = 5 Mar 2016}}</ref>
}}
'''''Geitonoplesium''''' is a [[genus]] of a [[monospecific|sole species]] '''''Geitonoplesium cymosum''''', the '''scrambling lily'''. It is a member of the [[Family (biology)|family]] [[Asphodelaceae]], subfamily [[Hemerocallidoideae]].<ref name=APwebH>Stevens, P.F. (2001 onwards). [http://www.mobot.org/MOBOT/research/APweb/orders/asparagalesweb.htm#Hemerocallidaceae "Hemerocallidoideae"]. ''Angiosperm Phylogeny Website''. Retrieved 2016-06-10.</ref> They grow naturally as scrambling vines in rainforests, drier forests and woodlands, of eastern [[Australia]], the [[Philippines]], [[Indonesia]], [[New Guinea]], [[Fiji]], [[New Caledonia]], [[Norfolk Island]] and [[Lord Howe Island]].<ref name=RFK6.1-G.-cymosum/><ref name=Fl-Australia/>

The leaves are variable, usually narrow-lanceolate to linear, usually {{Convert|2|–|10|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} long and {{Convert|3|–|25|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} wide. Both surfaces of leaves are glossy, with the midvein prominent and raised on upper surface. 
The flowers are mauve to white. The globose berries are {{Convert|1|-|2|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} in diameter and contain numerous black seeds.<ref name=RFK6.1-G.-cymosum/><ref name=NSW-PlantNet/><!-- Citations for all 4 sentences of this paragraph. --> The high degree of variation in the shape of the leaves has resulted in the establishment of numerous infraspecific taxa over the years, none of which is recognised by most present-day systematists.<ref name=Laferriere-1995/>

==Uses==
The shoots are harvested and eaten like [[asparagus]] and have a pleasant beany-like flavor.<ref name=Low-1991/> Uncommon in cultivation.{{Citation needed| date= June 2013}}

{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = ''Goodenia''
|image = Goodenia ovata.jpg
|image_caption = ''Goodenia ovata''
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]]
|ordo = [[Asterales]]
|familia = [[Goodeniaceae]]
|genus = '''''Goodenia'''''
|genus_authority = [[James Edward Smith|Sm.]]
|subdivision_ranks = [[Species]]
|subdivision = See [[list of Goodenia species|list of ''Goodenia'' species]]
|}}

'''''Goodenia''''' is a [[genus]] consisting of 179 species of [[flowering plant]]s. The name was published in 1793 by [[James Edward Smith]] in honour of the [[Bishop of Carlisle]] [[Samuel Goodenough]].<ref name="flora-au">{{cite web|url=http://www.anbg.gov.au/abrs/online-resources/flora/stddisplay.xsql?pnid=3960|author=R.C. Carolin|title=Flora of Australia Online (''Goodenia'')|year=1992|work=Flora of Australia Volume 35|publisher=ABRS}}</ref>
Goodenough was also a botanist and member of the [[Linnean Society]].

== Distribution ==
Only ''[[Goodenia konigsbergeri|G. konigsbergeri]]'' doesn't occur in Australia but is [[Endemism|endemic]] to [[Java (island)|Java]]. ''[[Goodenia armstrongiana|G. armstrongiana]]'', ''[[Goodenia purpurascens|G. purpurascens]]'' and ''[[Goodenia pumilio|G. pumilio]]'' extend to [[New Guinea]]. ''[[Goodenia pilosa|G. pilosa]]'' extends to [[Indonesia]], southern [[China]] and the [[Philippines]]. All other species are endemic to Australia. They are found in all states, including in arid and semi-arid areas.<ref>{{FloraBase|name=''Goodenia''|id=22142}}</ref>

==Species==
{{main|List of Goodenia species}}
Species include:
*''[[Goodenia albiflora]]'' – white goodenia
*''[[Goodenia hederacea]]'' – ivy goodenia, forest goodenia
*''[[Goodenia lanata]]'' – trailing goodenia, native primrose
*''[[Goodenia lineata]]''
*''[[Goodenia macmillanii]]'' – pinnate goodenia
*''[[Goodenia ovata]]'' – hop goodenia
*''[[Goodenia stobbsiana]]''
*''[[Goodenia paniculata]]'' – branched goodenia

==References==
{{Reflist}}

==External links==

123.text:
{{taxobox
|image = Hakea leucoptera.jpg
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|ordo = [[Proteales]]
|familia = [[Proteaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Hakea]]''
|species = '''''H. leucoptera'''''
|binomial = ''Hakea leucoptera''
|binomial_authority = [[Robert Brown (botanist, born 1773)|R.Br.]]
|}}

'''''Hakea leucoptera''''' is a plant of the dry regions of [[Australia]]. The species is often referred to as '''silver needlewood''', '''needle hakea''', '''pin bush''', and '''water tree'''.<ref name=Cunningham/> It has several indigenous names; Booldoobah, Uri, Kuluva, and Kuloa. The [[specific name (botany)|specific epithet]], derived from the Latin ''Leucoptera'' (Gk): ''leuco'' means "white"; and ''ptera'' means "winged", referring to the characteristic white-winged seeds of this species.<ref name=FloraBase/>

==Taxonomy and naming==
First described by [[Robert Brown (botanist, born 1773)|Robert Brown]] in 1810 and named in honor of Baron Ludwig von Hake, who was a German patron of botany.<ref name="Flora of South Australia">{{cite web|title=Flora of South Australia|url=http://www.flora.sa.gov.au/efsa/lucid/Hakea/key/Australian%20Hakea%20species/Media/Html/Hakea_leucoptera_ssp._leucoptera.htm|publisher=South Australian Government|accessdate=14 December 2013}}</ref>

==Subspecies==
The two subspecies differ only in the nature of the hairs on the [[rachis]] of the [[inflorescence]], those of ssp. leucoptera being white woolly pubescent (raised), while those of ssp. sericipes are shining white or brown and appressed (not raised).

''Hakea leucoptera'' was treated as part of the Sericea group, a predominantly eastern states group characterised by their simple terete leaves, few-flowered inflorescences, hairy pedicels and solitary, prominently woody fruits, these often markedly verrucose or pusticulate and usually with horns.
Other members of the group are ''H. actites'', ''H. constablei'', ''H. decurrens'', ''H. gibbosa'', ''H. kippistiana'', ''H. lissosperma'', ''H. macraeana'', ''H. macrorrhyncha'', ''H. ochroptera'', ''H. sericea'' and ''H. tephrosperma'', predominantly from the eastern states of Australia.

''Hakea leucoptera'' and ''H. tephrosperma'' are often confused. Initially they can often be distinguished by the mucro, curved in ''H. tephrosperma'' and usually porrect in ''H. leucoptera''. ''H. tephrosperma'' also has a shorter floral rachis with rust-coloured hairs, and the pedicel and perianth are densely appressed-pubescent, while ''H. leucoptera'' has a longer floral rachis. Pubescent flowers in ''H. leucoptera'' seem to be confined to S.A. and N.T.<ref name=FloraBase />

==Classification==
Hakeas are closely related to the genus ''[[Grevillea]]'' and ''[[Finschia]]'', both members of the subfamily '''[[Grevilleoideae]]''' within the family '''Proteaceae'''. Many species have similar [[inflorescences]], but hakeas can be distinguished by their woody seed pods.
Hakeas belong to the family [[Proteaceae]], which includes such well known plants as ''Banksias'', ''Grevilleas'' and ''Waratahs''.

There are around 150 species of ''Hakeas'' and they are only found in Australia. They occur in most areas of Australia in a wide range of habitats. Many are found in [[arid]] areas but they also occur in [[forests]] and heath lands and [[swampy]] areas.

Many ''Hakeas'' have narrow leaves with sharp points which lead to common names such as "needle bush" and "needle points" This is an adaption to avoid drying out as very little leaf area is exposed to the sun and moisture loss from the leaf surface is reduced.

Most ''Hakeas'' are shrubs, some are low ground-hugging plants and others are small trees to about 10 metres. The flowers of most Hakeas resemble those of their close relative, ''Grevilleas'' with auxiliary clusters or [[racemes]].

One of the main distinguishing features between ''Hakeas'' and ''Grevilleas'' is that ''Hakeas'' have woody fruits. The fruits open into two valves to reveal two seeds with a membranous wing. The [[seeds]] fit into cavities in the woody case and many make very attractive designs when the seed is released. Many of the seed cases are decorative. Some are quite large. Many have unusual shapes or they are rough with "bubbly" warts or tubercules which add interest and texture to a garden. Some Hakeas have long [[racemes]] up to 20 centimetres long. ''Hakea bucculenta'' and ''Hakea francisiana'' do not respond well to growing in the open garden on their own rootstock in eastern NSW. Some success has been achieved from [[grafting]]. ''Hakea salicifolia'' is most frequently used as rootstock.

''Hakea victoria'' has been called ‘the world's most beautiful foliage plant’ whereas others think it is grotesque. The leaves are round, stiff, curved upwards and up to 12 centimetres in diameter. They have prickly, toothed, wavy edges and a conspicuous network of veins. Their most unusual feature is the colour. Each leaf has a green rim with the centre of the leaf changing in colours over the years from yellow to orange to red. One of the best known is ''Hakea laurina'', known as the pin-cushion hakea because of its round flower heads, which can adapt more readily to eastern NSW.<ref name=Cunningham />

==Distribution==
It is found in every state of [[Australia]] except [[Tasmania]] and is commonly known as a dry country species particularly [[arid]] and semi arid regions.<ref name=Maiden>{{cite web|last=Maiden|first=J.H.|title=The Forest Flora of New South Wales.|url=http://adc.library.usyd.edu.au/view?docId=ozlit/xml-main-texts/p00108v6.xml)|accessdate=20 October 2013}}</ref>
[[File:H. leucoptera 1.jpg|thumb|Map H. leucoptera]]

==Description==
===Habit and leaf form===
The habit of this plant is highly variable. It can be a small open branched tree to 5 m or a small multi stemmed shrub to 3 m. The habitat is usually course textured soils and associated with a wide variety of species in [[woodland]] communities.<ref name=Cunningham /> It is widespread throughout all mainland states occurring in dense thickets of shrubs, as scattered individual trees or a large parent tree surrounded by offspring. It has a reddish-brown close-grained [[timber]] that is soft but hard and brittle when dry. ''Hakea leucoptera'' resembles an [[oak tree]].<ref name=Cunningham /> They can shoot from roots or by suckering. Many species develop [[lignotubers]] or a swollen rootstock as they grow older. This is a source of regrowth in times of drought or fire. Some attention is required when plants are young to get them established in respect of water requirements. Once actively growing they require very little attention.<ref name=FloraBase>{{cite web|last=Flora Base|title=FloraBase|url=http://florabase.dpaw.wa.gov.au/browse/profile/2173|publisher=Department of Parks and Wildlife Western Australian Herbarium|accessdate=20 October 2013}}</ref>

The leaves are arranged alternatively along the branches. They are rigid and cylindrical in varying length from 8–35 mm long and approximately 1.5 mm wide with a sharp pointed tip. The young leaves are [[wikt:hoary|hoary]] but as they mature they become smooth.<ref name=Cunningham />
[[File:Hakea leucoptera line drawing.jpg|thumb|Line drawing of Hakea leucoptera]]
[[File:Hakea Leucoptera seed pods.jpg|thumb|Seed pods]]

===Inflorescence and floral features===
Creamy white flowers are formed on short hairless stalks about 4 mm long in clusters of 20 or more as auxiliary racemes. ''Hakea leucoptera'' flower from late spring to summer.<ref name=Cunningham />

===Fruit and seed features===
[[Fruit]] comprises a woody follicle about 20–30 mm long which is swollen at the base but tapers to a point. The [[capsule (botany)|capsule]]s open in halves longitudinally revealing 2 [[seeds]] that have an [[Opacity (optics)|opaque]] wing on one side only.<ref name=Cunningham /> The woody seed can persist on the branches until after the following years flowering.<ref name=Urban/> Immature seed will not ripen off the plant and it is best to collect older fruits. Crop size varies from year to year. Once removed the fruits usually dry out and open within 1–2 weeks.<ref name="Ralph 2003"/>  It is easily grown from fresh seed which usually germinates in 3–6 weeks and seed is suitable for direct seeding.<ref name="Ralph 1993"/>

==Uses==
Shrubby forms are palatable to stock but only in times of acute feed shortage.<ref name=Cunningham />

Smoking pipes have been manufactured from the [[root]]s and in 1895 the Australian Needle-wood Pipe Company was formed in Sydney.<ref name=Urban />

This plant was important to the [[Indigenous peoples|Indigenous]] people and inland explorers as they sourced water from the roots.<ref name=Cunningham />  The tree was burnt which forced the [[water]] into the root system, then the roots were dug up. They were stripped, one end placed over a slow fire while the other over a container to force the water out.<ref name=Greig /> This feature also enabled the plant to quickly [[regeneration (biology)|regenerate]] after fire.<ref name=Urban />

A sweet nutritious drink was made by dipping heavily laden blossom into a cup of water or by sucking the flowers directly.<ref name=Hiddens/> ''Hakea leucoptera'' flowers produce a high quality honey favoured by bees.<ref name=Cunningham />

The [[Indigenous peoples|Indigenous]] people of inland [[Australia]] used corkwoods as a medicinal agent. Burns and open sores were directly applied with the burnt bark of the Hakea tree or the burnt bark mixture was combined with animal fat to make a healing ointment.<ref name=Low/>

The seed pods were also used for decoration by Indigenous people. The timber polishes up well and haves a very showy grain and was also used for small tannery articles.<ref name=Greig />

==See also==
*[[Hakea]]
*[[Proteaceae]]

<ref name=Cunningham>{{cite book|last=Cunningham|first=G.M.|title=Plants of Western New South Wales|year=1981|publisher=Soil Conservation Services of NSW|location=Government Printing Office, Sydney |author2=W.E. Mulham |author3=P.L. Milthorpe |author4=J.H.Leigh |accessdate=<!-- 20 October 2013 -->}}</ref>

<ref name=FloraBase>{{cite web|last=Flora Base|title=FloraBase|url=http://florabase.dpaw.wa.gov.au/browse/profile/2173|publisher=Department of Parks and Wildlife Western Australian Herbarium|accessdate=20 October 2013}}</ref>

<ref name=Greig>{{cite book|last=Greig|first=D|title=A photographic guide to Wildflowers of Outback Australia.|year=2002|publisher=A photographic guide to Wildflowers of Outback Australia.|location=Australia}}</ref>

<ref name=Hiddens>{{cite book|last=Hiddens|first=L.|title=Bush Tucker Field Guide.|year=2002|publisher=Explore Australia|location=South Yarra. Vic.}}</ref>

<ref name=Low>{{cite book|last=Low|first=T.|title=Wild food plants of Australia. (R.Ed).|year=1991|publisher=Angus & Robertson|location=Nth Ryde, NSW.}}</ref>

<ref name="Ralph 1993">{{cite book|last=Ralph|first=M.|title=Seed Collection of Australian Native Plants for Revegetation, Tree Planting and Direct Seeding.|year=1993|publisher=Murray Ralph/ Bushland Horticulture|location=Fitzroy. Vic.}}</ref>

<ref name="Ralph 2003">{{cite book|last=Ralph|first=M.|title=Growing Australian Native Plants from Seed - for revegetation, tree planting and direct seeding.|year=2003|publisher=Murray Ralph/ Bushland Horticulture|location=Fitzroy. Vic.}}</ref>

}}

124.text:
{{italic title}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}}
{{Use Australian English|date=September 2011}}
{{taxobox
| name = Mountain needlewood
|image = Hakea lissosperma little.jpg
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|ordo = [[Proteales]]
|familia = [[Proteaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Hakea]]''
|species = '''''H. lissosperma'''''
|binomial = ''Hakea lissosperma''
|binomial_authority = [[R.Br.]]
|synonyms =
* ''Hakea acicularis var. lissosperma (R.Br.) Benth'' <small>Fl. Austral</small>
* ''Hakea tenuifolia var. lissosperma (R.Br.) Domin'' <small>Biblioth. Bot.</small>
* ''Hakea sericea var. lissosperma (R.Br.) Ewart'' <small>Fl.Victoria </small>
}}
'''''Hakea lissosperma''''' is a type of spreading [[shrub]] with almost 4 metres height, needle-shaped leaves and white flowers.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.rhymezone.com/r/d=hakea_lissosperma|title=RhymeZone: hakea_lissosperma definitions |website=www.rhymezone.com |access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> In 1999 it was recognised that it grows commonly in over 1200 m rocky mountains, in [[subalpine]] [[woodland]]. And common names include '''needle bush''' and '''mountain needlewood'''.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Hakea~lissosperma|title=PlantNET - FloraOnline|website=plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> What is more, this species is a favourite of birds due to the dense clusters of flowers and pungent rigid needle-shaped leaves which can be a shelter against [[predator]]s. It is also resistant to wildlife browsing due to its unpalatability but not suitable below powerlines.<ref name=":3" />

== Distribution ==
[[File:Distribution of Hakea lissosperma.jpg|thumb|Distribution of ''Hakea lissosperma''<ref>{{Cite encyclopedia |url=http://bie.ala.org.au/species/urn:lsid:biodiversity.org.au:apni.taxon:247991|title=Hakea lissosperma  : Mountain Needlewood |encyclopedia=Atlas of Living Australia|access-date=2016-03-20}}</ref>]]
This species is easily found in the following areas: [[Break O'Day]], [[Central Highlands (Tasmania)|Central Highlands]], [[Circular Head]], [[Derwent Valley Council|Derwent Valley]], [[Dorset Council|Dorset]], [[Flinders Island]], Glamorgan-Spring Bay, [[Hobart]], [[Huon Valley]], [[Kentish Council|Kentish]], [[Kingborough]], [[Launceston, Tasmania|Launceston]], [[Meander Valley]], [[Northern Midlands]], [[Southern Midlands]], [[Tasman Region|Tasman]], [[Waratah-Wynyard]], [[West Coast, Tasmania|West Coast]].<ref name=":0" />

== Habitat ==
The community is commonly Wet [[Eucalypt]] Forest and it is widespread especially on mountains to 1200m and to [[sea level]] in areas of high [[rainfall]].<ref name=":3" /> The habitat of this species is [[frost]] hardy, [[drought tolerant]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wildseedtasmania.com.au/hakea.php|title=Hakeas|website=www.wildseedtasmania.com.au|access-date=2016-03-20}}</ref> untypical in its narrow and flexible leaves, and in its dry forest habitat at the relatively low altitude of 700 m.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://data.rbg.vic.gov.au/vicflora/flora/taxon/10a54240-0674-41d1-9924-e17a26afb21e|title=Flora of Victoria|website=data.rbg.vic.gov.au|access-date=2016-03-20}}</ref> In addition, it has moist and shady site tolerance as well as fertile, loam, phosphorus intolerant, poor and well-drained [[soil]] tolerance.<ref name=":3" />

==Description==
[[File:Hakea lisso fruit.jpg|thumbnail|Fruit of ''Hakea lissosperma'']]
[[File:Hakea lisso flower.jpg|thumbnail|Flower of ''Hakea lissosperma'']]
The mountain needlewood is an Australian shrub or small tree with commonly spiny leaves and dense clusters of white flowers, growing approximately from 2.0 to 6.0 m tall.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://www.understorey-network.org.au/communities.html?species=Hakea%2520lissosperma|title=Communities|website=www.understorey-network.org.au|access-date=2016-03-20}}</ref> In addition, the bush is a low [[woody plant]] with several main stout [[branch]]es.<ref name=":0" /> Leaves are terete, usually 6–10 cm long, 1.5–2 mm wide, rigidly erect and glabrous with approximately 1 mm long mucro.<ref name=":0" /> What is more, follicles are usually 20–30 mm long, 15–20 mm wide while the mature ones are about 2.3–2.7 cm long, 1.7–2 cm wide, coarsely wrinkled or blistered.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=gn&name=Hakea|title=PlantNET - FloraOnline|website=plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au|access-date=2016-03-20}}</ref>

=== Flowers and Regeneration ===
[[Flowers]] commonly form in October,November and December in alpine areas, earlier at lower altitudes,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.flora.sa.gov.au/efsa/lucid/Hakea/key/Australian%2520Hakea%2520species/Media/Html/Hakea_lissosperma.htm|title=Request Rejected|website=www.flora.sa.gov.au|access-date=2016-03-20}}</ref> which are white or cream clustered in [[leaf axil]]s on [[Peduncle (botany)|stalks]] usually 4–6 mm long. [[Perianth]] is usually glabrous with 5–6 mm length.<ref name=":0" /> Besides, according to Walsh and Entwistle (cited in  Butler et al. 2006), [[seed]] is usually 17–23 mm long, 6.5-10.5 mm wide. And seed body is 6–10 mm long, wrinkled, wing down one side only, and dark blackish-brown in colour. [[Fruit]] commonly becomes hard and brown or grey-brown when it is mature usually in the second year after flowering. Immature fruit will not ripen off the plant and fruit is usually held on the plant for several years. Moreover, each fruit usually includes from 1 to 2 winged seeds (Ralph cited in Butler et al. 2006).<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=2006|title=Hakea decurrens Bushy Needlewood|url=http://www.ccma.vic.gov.au/GLOBAL/uploaded/Speciesnotes-Hakeadecurrens.pdf|journal=Corangamite Seed Supply & Revegetation Network|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> What is more, Ralph (cited in Butler et al. 2006) points out that the seed dispersal is achieve by wind and the [[germination]] time of Hakea lissosperma is about 6 months.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=2006|title=Hakea decurrens Bushy Needlewood|url=http://www.ccma.vic.gov.au/GLOBAL/uploaded/Speciesnotes-Hakeadecurrens.pdf|journal=Corangamite Seed Supply & Revegetation Network|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> Seed is usually not occupying whole [[valve]] face.<ref name=":2" />

== Taxonomy  ==
''Hakea lissosperma'' was first described by [[R. M. Barker|Barker]], [[L. Haegi|Haegi]] and [[W. R. Barker|Barker]] in 1996, and the description was published in [[Flora of Australia]], Volume 17B, [[Proteaceae]] 3 [[Hakea]] to [[Dryandra]] in 1999.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=1999|title=Flora of Australia, Volume 17B, Proteaceae 3 Hakea to Dryandra|url=http://www.environment.gov.au/system/files/pages/6d8c5c3b-8545-437e-b9b3-944ac95ee07a/files/flora-australia-17b-proteaceae-3-hakea-dryandra.pdf|journal=CSIRO|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref>

== Cultivation ==
This tree is not fully hardy and it should only be planted in a [[sheltered]] location. Firstly, collect only the older fruit which is usually grey-brown, and the [[seed]] collection is suitable in the whole year. Secondly, leach the seed, and the dry fruit will usually open in 2–3 weeks or place in a hot oven 80-100 ℃ for 30 mins with the door partially open. Besides, [[leaching (agriculture)|leaching]], [[stratification (botany)|stratification]] or a combination of both improves results, or moist stratify seed for 4 months in fridge for good [[germination]].<ref name=":3" /> Lastly, the direct seeding is also suitable, and the germination time is approximately 6 months.

==References==
{{Portal|Trees}}
{{reflist}}

[[Category:Flora of Australia]]

{{italic title}}{{Taxobox

'''''Halodule wrightii''''' ('''shoalweed''') is a plant species native to seacoasts of some of the warmer oceans of the world. It has been reported from [[California]], [[Texas]], [[Florida]], [[Louisiana]], [[Mississippi]], [[Alabama]], [[North Carolina]], [[Maryland]], [[Yucatán (state)|Yucatán]], [[Quintana Roo]], [[Tabasco]], [[Costa Rica]], [[Belize]], [[Panamá]], [[Cuba]], [[Trinidad & Tobago]], [[Venezuela]], [[Brazil]], [[Australia]], [[Cape Verde]], and [[Madagascar]].<ref name="asdfiuoasdf89999">{{Cite web|url=http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=222000075|title=Halodule wrightii in Flora of North America @ efloras.org|website=www.efloras.org|access-date=2017-02-03}}</ref><ref>Hickman, J. C. 1993. The Jepson Manual: Higher Plants of California 1–1400. University of California Press, Berkeley.</ref><ref>Hammel, B. E. 2003. Cymodoceaceae. In: Manual de Plantas de Costa Rica, B.E. Hammel, M.H. Grayum, C. Herrera & N. Zamora (eds.). Monographs in systematic botany from the Missouri Botanical Garden 92: 456–457.</ref><ref>Novelo R., A. & A. L. H. 1994. 239. Cymodoceaeceae. 6: 15–16. In G. Davidse, M. Sousa Sánchez & A.O. Chater (eds.) Flora Mesoamericana. Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, México, D. F.</ref><ref>Balick, M. J., M. H. Nee & D.E. Atha. 2000. Checklist of the vascular plants of Belize. Memoirs of The New York Botanical Garden 85: i–ix, 1–246.</ref><ref>Correll, D. S. & M. C. Johnston. 1970. Manual of the Vascular Plants of Texas i–xv, 1–1881. The University of Texas at Dallas, Richardson</ref><ref>Cowan, C. P. 1983. Flora de Tabasco. Listados Florísticos de México 1: 1–123.</ref><ref>Sousa Sánchez, M. & E. F. Cabrera Cano. 1983. Flora de Quintana Roo. Listados Florísticos de México 2: 1–100.</ref><ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Halodule%20wrightii.png BONAP (Biota of North America Project) floristic synthesis,  ''Halodule wrightii''] Image</ref><ref>Creed, J. C., Engelen, A. H., D'Oliveira, E. C., Bandeira, S. and Serrão, E. A. 2016. First record of seagrass in Cape Verde, eastern Atlantic. Marine Biodiversity Record 9:57.</ref>

Some publications cite [[United States|US]] specimens by the synonym, ''Halodule beaudettei'',<ref>Hartog, Cornelis den. 1964. Blumea 12: 303.</ref><ref>Hartog, Cornelis den. 1960. Pacific Naturalist 1(15): 4–5, f. 2a–c.</ref> but the two names represent the same species.<ref name="asdfiuoasdf89999"/><ref>Phillips, R. C. 1967. On species of the seagrass, ''Halodule'', in Florida. Bull. Mar. Sci. 17: 672--676.</ref><ref>McMmillan, C. 1991. Isozyme patterning in marine spermatophytes. In: L. Triest, ed. 1988+. Isozymes In Water Plants. Opera Botanica Belgica 1+ vols. Belgium, Meise. Vol. 4,: pp. 193--200.</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tropicos.org/ImageFullView.aspx?imageid=34787|title=Image|website=www.tropicos.org|access-date=2017-02-03}}</ref>

''Halodule wrightii'' is an herb growing in [[salt-water]] [[marshes]] in [[intertidal]] regions, often [[Underwater|submerged]] at [[high tide]] but [[Emergent plant|emergent]] at [[low tide]]. It has flat leaves up to 20 cm long, dark reddish-brown, with a few teeth on the margins. Fruits are spherical to egg-shaped, about 2 mm across.<ref name="asdfiuoasdf89999"/><ref>Novelo, A. & L. Ramos. 2005. Vegetación acuática. Cap. 5: 111–144. In J. Bueno, F Álvarez & S. Santiago, Biodiversidad del Estado de Tabasco. CONABIO-UNAM, México.</ref><ref>Godfrey, R. K. & J. W. Wooten. 1979. Aquatic and Wetland Plants of Southeastern United States Monocotyledons 1–712. The University of Georgia Press, Athens.</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Berlin.|first=Gesellschaft Naturforschender Freunde zu|date=1868-01-01|title=Sitzungsberichte der Gesellschaft Naturforschender Freunde zu Berlin.|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/7914997#page/27/mode/1up|language=en|volume=1868|issn=0433-8731}}</ref><ref>Ascherson, Paul Friedrich August. 1897. Die Natürlichen Pflanzenfamilien 2: 37.</ref>

125.title: Halodule wrightii

126.text:
{{Taxobox
 | image=Helicia cochinchinensis - Miyajima Natural Botanical Garden - DSC02394.JPG
 | image_caption=''Helicia cochinchinensis'' (type species), botanical specimen in the [[Miyajima Natural Botanical Garden]], [[Hatsukaichi, Hiroshima]], Japan.
 | regnum = [[Plantae]]
 | unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
 | unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
 | ordo = [[Proteales]]
 | familia = [[Proteaceae]]
 | genus = '''''Helicia'''''
 | genus_authority = [[João de Loureiro|Lour.]]
 | type_species = ''[[Helicia cochinchinensis]]''
 | type_species_authority = Lour.<ref name=Loureiro-1790-Orig-Publ/><ref name=APNI/>
}} {{Use list-defined references|date=April 2013}}

'''''Helicia''''' is a [[genus]] of around 100 species of trees and shrubs, constituting part of the plant family [[Proteaceae]]. They grow naturally in rainforests in [[New Guinea]], [[Malesia]], southern and eastern Asia and Australia.

==Conservation==
At global, national and regional government scales, many ''Helicia'' species have been threatened with extinction, as officially recognised by the [[International Union for Conservation of Nature]] (IUCN) and by continental, national and local governments. Sixteen species have official IUCN global conservation statuses of either "critically endangered", "endangered", "vulnerable" or "near threatened" (in terms of global extinction).

==Naming and classification==
In 1790, notable pioneer botanist [[João de Loureiro]] described this genus as ''Helicia'' in his publication ''[[Flora Cochinchinensis]]''.<ref name=Loureiro-1790-Orig-Publ/><ref name=APNI/> The [[Type species#In botany|type species]] for the genus was ''Helicia cochinchinensis'', the [[Type specimen#Types in botany|type specimen]] of which was collected in [[Cochinchina]], [[Vietnam]].<ref name=Loureiro-1790-Orig-Publ/><ref name=APNI/> The genus name derives from the [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] word "{{lang|grc|έλιξ}}" (élix), which refers to the petals, now called [[tepals]], spirally revolving or simply rolling or coiling up on themselves, at [[anthesis]] (the flowering time when the [[Stamen|anthers]] open).<ref name=Loureiro-1790-Orig-Publ/><ref name=Foreman-1995/><ref name=Flickr-H.-formosana-flowers-closeup/>

In 1831, botanist [[Nathaniel Wallich]] named ''Helicia robusta'' for a dried specimen of a cultivated plant in India,<ref name=Wallich-1831/> based on the specimen's earlier 1814 name ''Roupala robusta'' by [[William Roxburgh]].<ref name=Roxburgh-1814/> Roxburgh's [[Calcutta]] botanic gardens cultivated the plant.

From the 1850s to the 1860s notable German–Australian botanist [[Ferdinand von Mueller]] formally [[species description|described]] several new Australian species.<ref name=Mueller-1857/><ref name=Mueller-1860/><ref name=Mueller-1862/> In the late 1800s and early 1900s [[Frederick Manson Bailey|Frederick M. Bailey]] concentrated further on additional [[Queensland]] species, writing descriptions of them in numerous scientific papers.<ref name=Bailey-1899/><ref name=Bailey-1901/><ref name=Bailey-1913/>

In 1939, [[Hermann Otto Sleumer|Hermann O. Sleumer]] described many additional [[Malesia]]n species, especially in New Guinea.<ref name=Sleumer-1939/> In 1955, he published a revision of the genus.<ref name=Sleumer-1955/> In 1956, his treatment of the genus in ''[[Flora Malesiana]]'' was published.{{Sfnp|Sleumer|1956|pp=164–190}} From 1969 to the late 1990s botanist [[Don B. Foreman]], who was based in [[Papua New Guinea]] and Australia, collected numerous additional species, which he formally described before he wrote the comprehensive reviews and flora treatments for the two regions;<ref name=Foreman-1984-Australia/><ref name=Foreman-1985-PNG/><ref name=Foreman-1986-Australia/><ref name=Foreman-1988-NG/> notably in the authoritative ''Handbooks of the Flora of Papua New Guinea'' (1978–1995, to date 3 volumes), he wrote the chapters for Proteaceae and other families;{{Sfnp|Foreman|1995|pp=221–270}} and in the authoritative [[Flora of Australia (series)|''Flora of Australia'' (1981–, 60 volume series)]] he wrote the treatment of ''Helicia''.<ref name=Foreman-1995/>

From the 1990s botanist Richard C. K. Chung, based in Malaysia, published new species formal descriptions and a revision of the 13 species occurring in [[Borneo]].<ref name=Chung-2001/><ref name=Chung-1998/> In total, approximately 100 species have been formally scientifically described.<ref name=Weston-2006/><ref name=Angiosperm-Phylogeny-Website/><ref name=Mabberley-2008/>

[[Lawrence Alexander Sidney Johnson|Lawrie Johnson]] and [[Barbara G. Briggs]] grouped ''Helicia'' with ''[[Xylomelum]]'' in the subtribe Heliciinae, tribe Helicieae, and subfamily [[Grevilleoideae]] in their 1975 monograph "[[On the Proteaceae: the evolution and classification of a southern family]]".<ref name=Johnson-Briggs-1975/> However, genetics studies showed these two to be relatively unrelated, instead finding the closest genetic correlations between ''[[Hollandaea]]'' and ''Helicia'', and therefore classifying them both in the subtribe Heliciinae within the tribe Roupaleae.<ref name=Weston-2006/>

==Diversity and Description==
[[File:Helicia glabriflora Coffs Harbour Botanic Gardens.jpg|thumb|left| ''[[Helicia glabriflora]]'' from New South Wales, Australia]]
''Helicia'' plants generally grow naturally as small trees, while some species grow as shrubs and some grow to medium-sized trees up to {{Convert|30|m|ft|-1|abbr=on}}.{{Sfnp|Sleumer|1956|pp=164–190}}{{Sfnp|Foreman|1995|pp=221–270}}<ref name = Wrigley-1991/>

They grow naturally across the Malesia region with the major centre of species diversity of about fifty species in New Guinea. They grow naturally in the south west Pacific ocean region, and in north and eastern Australia. They grow naturally across southern and eastern Asia, including Indonesia, Malaysia and another centre of species diversity of about twenty species in southern China, extending to parts of the Indian subcontinent, the Philippines, Taiwan, and southern Japan.{{Sfnp|Sleumer|1956|pp=164–190}}{{Sfnp|Foreman|1995|pp=221–270}}<ref name=Weston-2006/><!-- Citing prior 3 sentences --> The plant family Proteaceae's 1,700 species (approximate) have their greatest diversity in the southern hemisphere and smaller centres of diversity including some ''Helicia'', in the near northern hemisphere. The species diversity of the plant family Proteaceae decreases further northwards. ''H. cochinchinensis'' has the natural distribution reaching furthest north to Japan where it grows into trees in the mountains of warmer parts and where no other species nor other Proteaceae genera occur. The same Japanese name {{Nihongo3||山もがし|Yama-mogashi}} for this species, also means the whole genus and the entire Proteaceae plant family.<ref name=Oi-1965-Fl.-Japan/><!-- http://4travel.jp/domestic/area/toukai/mie/toba/toba/travelogue/10512269/#pict21112497 --> In the New Guinea and southern China centres of species diversity, many species grow in forests, up to as tall as the sub-canopy, especially diverse in rainforests.{{Sfnp|Foreman|1995|pp=221–270}}<ref name=Weston-2006/> In Australia, they are generally components of rainforests, and prefer richer soils,<ref name = Wrigley-1991/> especially in the farthest south region of ''Helicia'''s global distribution, the [[Illawarra]], [[New South Wales]], south of Sydney, where only one species ''H. glabriflora'' occurs, preferring richer basalt soils.<ref name=NSW-PlantNet-H.-glabriflora/><ref name=Bofeldt-Illawarra-plants-at-risk/>
{{Clear|left}}

==Cultivation==
In India and east Asia Helicias have been cultivated in botanic gardens, from the 1800s.<ref name=Roxburgh-1814/> In Australia they have rarely been cultivated, and were thought to have little horticultural value. The rusty-coloured new growth is attractive on some species.<ref name = Wrigley-1991/><!-- citation for last 2 sentences --> In some of the better known Australian species, the flowers and fruit are generally not prominent, and plants can be slow growing. They are generally propagated by seed, the viability of which drops rapidly with time.<ref name=Elliot-Jones-1992/><!-- citation for last 4 sentences -->

{{Clear|left}}

126.title: Helicia

127.text:
{{italictitle}} {{Taxobox | name = Bat's wing fern | image = Histiopteris incisa pineae.jpg | image_caption = ''
Lobed pinneae of Histiopteria incisa
Photo courtesy of Robert J. Wiltshire'' | regnum = [[Plant]]ae | divisio = [[Fern|Pteridophyta]] | classis = [[Polypodiopsida]] | ordo = [[Polypodiales]] | familia = [[Dennstaedtiaceae]] | genus = ''[[Histiopteris]]'' | species = '''''H. incisa''''' | binomial = ''Histiopteris incisa'' | binomial_authority = ([[Thunb.]]) [[John Smith (botanist)|J.Sm.]] | synonyms = * ''Phegopteris incisa'' ([[Thunb.]]) [[Alexander Keyserling|Keyserl.]] * ''Litobrochia incisa'' ([[Thunb.]]) [[C.Presl]] * ''Pteris incisa'' [[Thunb.]] * ''Histiopteris vespertilionis'' ([[Labill.]]) [[John Smith (botanist)|J.Sm.]] * ''Pteris brunoniana'' [[Endl.]] * ''Litobrochia vespertilionis'' ([[Labill.]]) [[C.Presl]] * ''Pteris australasica'' [[Desv.]] * ''Pteris vespertilionis'' [[Labill.]] * ''Pteris comans'' [[G.Forst.]] }} '''''Histiopteris incisa''''', the '''bat's wing fern''', '''water fern''' or '''fern mata''', is a common plant found in [[Australia]], [[New Zealand]] and other islands in the south Pacific region. Usually found in moist areas, where it may form large colonies. The lowermost lobes of each [[pinnae]] have a bat wing like appearance, giving the fern it's common name. ==Description== [[File:Histiopteris incisa sori.jpg|thumb|left|
Sori of Histiopteris incisa
Photo courtesy of Robert J. Wiltshire]] ''Histiopteris incisa'' is a medium sized [[fern]], usually producing [[fronds]] of approximately 60-200cm in length. Fronds are widely spaced, distinct, and slightly dimorphic with fertile lobes slightly narrower than the infertile lobes. Fertile lobes have the [[sorus|sori]] continuous, linear and exindusiate (without an [[indusium]]) but protected by relaxed leaf margins.{{Cite book|title=Australian Ferns and Fern Allies 2nd. Ed|last=Jones|first=D.L.|last2=Clemesha|first2=S.C.|publisher=A.H. & A.W. Reed PTY LTD.|isbn=|location=}} Young fronds have a thick and whitish blue-green succulent stipe. Mature fronds are thin, long with red-brown stipes. Pinnae are pale greyish-green, almost a glaucous colour, they are paired and opposite and set at a wide angle and very lobed. The two lowermost lobes of each pinnae result in a bat’s wing like appearance giving the fern its common name. {{Cite book|title=Ferns of Victoria and Tasmania.|last=Wakefield|first=N.A.||publisher=Field Naturalists Club of Victoria.|year=1955|isbn=|}}This species has a robust creeping [[rhizome]] of 5-10mm length and is covered in brown or reddish scales. {{Cite book|title=Flora of Australia Volume 49, Oceanic islands 1|publisher=Australian Government Publishing Service|year=1994|isbn=|location=Canberra}} ==Habitat and Distribution== [[File:Histiopteris incisa Distribution Map of Tasmania.jpg|thumb|left|Distribution Map of Histiopteris incisa of Tasmania]] The bat’s wing fern is widely distributed and abundant across most of the southern hemisphere including Tasmania. However, it is less common in exposed highland situations and mostly absent from low rainfall regions. {{Cite book|title=The Ferns of Tasmania: Their Ecology and Distribution.|last=Garret|first=M.|publisher=Tasmanian Forest Research Council|year=1996|isbn=|location=}} This fern is a ‘weedy’ opportunistic species, freely colonising disturbed sites on the margins of, or within, wet forest, and often forming extensive colonies. It mainly inhabits high rainfall forests with poorly drained soils. Found mainly in shaded areas as shade is necessary for pinnae survival although it can grow in less shaded areas with sufficient water availability. Bat’s wing fern is commonly found growing on the margins of wet forests, along more open scrubby creeks and gullies and at the base of cliffs. In rare situations with optimal growing conditions, the fronds can reach lengths of 7m {{Cite book|title=Ferns and Allied Plants of Victoria, Tasmania and South Australia.|last=Duncan|first=B.D.|publisher=National Library of Australia Cataloguing in Publication Data|year=1986|isbn=}} ==Uses== The bat’s wing fern is found in many Tasmanian nurseries and is popular as both an indoor or outdoor plant, as it requires little sunlight and is very aesthetic. It is a popular pot plant, easily grown in a pot or open ground and is fast spreading in cool, moist environments. [[File:Deeply lobed fern with opposite fronds Dee Why.jpg|thumb|315px|left|Fronds with deeply lobed segments, [[Dee Why]], [[Australia]]]] ==References== {{Reflist}} * Kramer, K.U., Green, P.S. (eds.) The Families and Genera of Vascular Plants Volume 1, Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg (1990) *[http://www.home.aone.net.au/~byzantium/ferns/descriptions/histiopteris/histiopt.html ''Histiopteris incisa - Bat's wing fern''] [[Category:Dennstaedtiaceae]] [[Category:Fern species]] [[Category:Flora of Australia]] [[Category:Flora of New Zealand]] [[Category:Flora of Norfolk Island]] [[Category:Flora of Lord Howe Island]] [[Category:Flora of New Caledonia]] [[Category:Flora of the Pacific]] [[Category:Flora of the Auckland Islands]]
127.title: Histiopteris incisa

| genus = ''[[Huperzia]]''
| species = '''''H. varia'''''
| binomial = ''Huperzia varia''
| binomial_authority = ([[R. Br.]]) [[Trevis.]]
}}

'''''Huperzia varia''''', also called '''clubmoss''' is a firm [[moss]] found in areas of [[Australia]], [[New Zealand]] and [[subantarctic islands]].

''H. varia'' can grow on the ground and as a [[lithophyte]] or [[epiphyte]]. It can have one or many branches that are spirally arranged with slender leaves that narrow to a point. The plant varies from green to green-yellow and is sometimes orange in appearance.<ref name=nzpcn>{{cite web|title=Huperzia varia|url=http://nzpcn.org.nz/flora_details.asp?ID=2156|publisher=New Zealand Plant Conservation Network|accessdate=2012-05-15}}</ref>

Mémoires du Muséum d'Histoire Naturelle 1: 368] |type_species= ''Hydrocleys commersonii'' (syn of ''H. nymphoides'') |type_species_authority=Rich. |synonyms = |subdivision_ranks = Species |subdivision = See text }} '''''Hydrocleys''''' is a genus of [[aquatic plant]]s in the [[Alismataceae]], native to the [[Western Hemisphere]], though one is naturalized elsewhere and sold as an ornamental for decorative ponds and artificial aquatic habitats.{{Cite web|url=http://idtools.org/id/aquariumplants/Aquarium_&_Pond_Plants_of_the_World/key/Aquarium_&_Pond_Plants/Media/Html/Fact_sheets/hydrocleys.html|title=Hydrocleys|website=idtools.org|access-date=2017-01-30}} At present (May 2014), five species are recognized:{{Cite web|url=http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=278713|title=World Checklist of Selected Plant Families: Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew|website=apps.kew.org|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-01-30}} *''[[Hydrocleys martii]]'' Seub. in C.F.P.von Martius - [[Brazil]], [[Argentina]], [[Uruguay]] *''[[Hydrocleys mattogrossensis]]'' (Kuntze) Holm-Niels. & R.R.Haynes - [[Brazil]], [[Bolivia]] *''[[Hydrocleys modesta]]'' Pedersen - [[Brazil]], [[Argentina]], [[Paraguay]] *''[[Hydrocleys nymphoides]]'' (Humb. & Bonpl. ex Willd.) Buchenau - widespread across [[South America]], [[Central America]], [[Puerto Rico]], [[Trinidad]] and the [[Netherlands Antilles]]. Also naturalized in [[Australia]], [[New Zealand]], [[South Africa]], [[Fiji]], [[New Caledonia]], [[French Polynesia]], [[Florida]], [[Louisiana]] and [[Texas]][http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Hydrocleys%20nymphoides.png Biota of North America Program] Image{{Cite web|url=http://bie.ala.org.au/species/HYDROCLEYS+NYMPHOIDES|title=Hydrocleys nymphoides {{!}} Atlas of Living Australia|last=Australia|first=Atlas of Living|website=bie.ala.org.au|language=en-AU|access-date=2017-01-30}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.sanbi.org/information/infobases/invasive-alien-plant-alert/hydrocleys-nymphoides|title=Hydrocleys nymphoides {{!}} SANBI|website=www.sanbi.org|language=en|access-date=2017-01-30}} *''[[Hydrocleys parviflora]]'' Seub. in C.F.P.von Martius - [[Mexico]], [[Central America]], [[Venezuela]], [[Colombia]], [[Bolivia]], [[Brazil]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == *[https://plants.usda.gov/core/profile?symbol=HYNY US Department of Agriculture plants profile] *[http://www.missouribotanicalgarden.org/PlantFinder/PlantFinderDetails.aspx?kempercode=b812 Missouri Botanical Garden, Plant Finder, Gardening Help, water poppy] [[File:Hydrocleys nymphoides (3) 1200.jpg|thumb|right|''[[Hydrocleys nymphoides]]'']] [[Category:Alismataceae]] [[Category:Alismataceae genera]] [[Category:Freshwater plants]] [[Category:Flora of Australia]] [[Category:Flora of New Zealand]] [[Category:Flora of the Caribbean]] [[Category:Flora of Mexico]] [[Category:Flora of Central America]] [[Category:Flora of South Africa]] [[Category:Flora of South America]]

'''''Hypericum gramineum''''', commonly known as '''small St. John's wort''' or '''grassy St. Johnswort''', is an erect herb with a height of 10-40 cm.<ref name = HG>{{cite web|title=Hypericum gramineum G.Forst.|work=PlantNet|publisher=National Herbarium of NSW, Royal Botanic Garden|date=1990|accessdate=9 August 2014|url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Hypericum~gramineum|author=Miller, C}}</ref> Its flowers are 5-12 mm in diameter.<ref name = HG/> It is native to [[Australia]] (wherein it is found in every state and territory), [[New Caledonia]], [[New Zealand]], [[Papua New Guinea]] and parts of South–East Asia.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Willis|first1=AJ|last2=Groves|first2=RH|last3=Ash|first3=JE|title=Seed Ecology of Hypericum gramineum, an Australian Forb|journal=Australian Journal of Botany|date=1997|volume=45|issue=6|pages=1009-1022|doi=10.1071/BT96074}}</ref>

|image_caption=''Ichnocarpus frutescens'' <ref>illustration circa 1880, from Francisco Manuel Blanco (O.S.A.) - Flora de Filipinas</ref>
|regnum = [[Plantae]]

|ordo = [[Gentianales]]
|familia = [[Apocynaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Ichnocarpus]]''
|species = '''''I. frutescens'''''
|name=black creeper
|binomial = ''Ichnocarpus frutescens''
|binomial_authority = ([[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]) [[William Townsend Aiton|W.T.Aiton]]<ref name=Fl.China>{{cite web |url=http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=2&taxon_id=200018399 |last1 = Li |first1 = Bingtao |last2 = Leeuwenberg |first2 = Antony J. M. |last3= Middleton |first3= David J. |others = [http://www.efloras.org/ eFloras.org] |year=2008 |origyear= 1995 |title= ''Ichnocarpus frutescens'', Apocynaceae, Vol. 16 |editor1-last= Wu |editor1-first= Z. Y. |editor2-last= Raven |editor2-first= P. H. |work= [http://www.efloras.org/flora_page.aspx?flora_id=2 Flora of China] |version= Online access |publisher=Missouri Botanical Garden Press and Harvard University Herbaria |location=St. Louis, MO & Cambridge, MA. |accessdate=9 Mar 2013}}</ref><ref name=AustTRFPK6.1>{{AustTRFPK6.1 |url= http://keys.trin.org.au:8080/key-server/data/0e0f0504-0103-430d-8004-060d07080d04/media/Html/taxon/Ichnocarpus_frutescens.htm |name= Ichnocarpus frutescens |accessdate= 13 Mar 2013 }}</ref>
}}
[[File:Ichnocarpus frutescens 12.JPG|thumb|left|Black Creeper, in [[Thrissur]], [[Kerala]], [[India]]]]
[[File:Ichnocarpus frutescens11.JPG|thumb|left|Flower]]

'''''Ichnocarpus frutescens''''' is a species of flowering plant in the [[Apocynaceae|dogbane family]] known by the [[English language|English]] common name '''black creeper'''. It is native to much of [[China]], [[India]], [[Southeast Asia]], and northern [[Australia]].<ref name=Fl.China/><ref name=AustTRFPK6.1/> In [[Uttarakhand]] it is known as '''''kali-dudhi''''',<ref name=adhi>Adhikari, B. S., et al. (2010). [http://ethnoleaflets.com/leaflets/dehradun.htm Medicinal Plants Diversity and their Conservation Status in Wildlife Institute of India (WII) Campus, Dehradun.] ''Ethnobotanical Leaflets'' 14 46-83.</ref> and as '''''botilai'''''<ref name=dash>Dash, D. K., et al. (2007). [http://www.tjpr.org/vol6_no3/634Maity.pdf Evaluation of hepatoprotective and antioxidant activity of ''Ichnocarpus frutescens'' (Linn.) R.Br. on paracetamol-induced hepatotoxicity in rats.] ''Tropical Journal of Pharmaceutical Research'' 6:3 755-65.</ref> and '''''shyamlata''''' in [[Orissa, India|Orissa]],<ref name=ashu>Ashutosh, M, et al. (2009). [http://www.ijps.info/journal/Old%20files/09.pdf Analgesic and anti-inflammatory effect of ''Ichnocarpus frutescens'' plant parts.] ''Int J Ph Sci'' 1:2 280-83.</ref> '''''dudhilata''''' in [[Madhya Pradesh]],<ref name=barik>Barik, R., et al. (2008). [http://medind.nic.in/ibi/t08/i1/ibit08i1p19.pdf Antidiabetic activity of aqueous root extract of ''Ichnocarpus frutescens'' in streptozotocin-nicotinamide induced type II diabetes in rats.] ''Indian Journal of Pharmacology'' 40:1 19.</ref> '''''palvalli''''' in [[Tamil Nadu]],<ref name=kali>Kalidass, C., et al. (2009). [http://hmtjournals.com/vol3_2/004.pdf Pharmacognostic studies on ''Ichnocarpus frutescens'' (L.) R.Br.] ''Journal of Herbal Medicine & Toxicology'' 3:2 23-29.</ref> and '''''siamlata''''' in [[Uttar Pradesh]].<ref name=pandu>Pandurangan, A., et al. (2009). [http://www.sid.ir/En/VEWSSID/J_pdf/101020090108.pdf Evaluation of antipyretic potential of ''Ichnocarpus frutescens'' roots.] ''Iranian Journal of Pharmacology & Therapeutics'' 8:1 47-50.</ref>

It is a woody [[shrub]] with [[liana]]s sprawling to 10 meters in maximum length and 6 centimeters in diameter. The bark produces a creamy white [[sap]]. The leaves are up to 11 centimeters long by 4.5 wide. The [[inflorescence]] is a head of several flowers. Each flower has a calyx of densely hairy [[sepal]]s and a five lobed corolla just under a centimeter long. The fruit is a [[Follicle (fruit)|follicle]] which may be over 14 centimeters long. The roots may be reddish or purple. The plant is sold in markets in some areas in India.<ref name=barik/>

== Uses ==
The plant has a large number of [[Herbalism|traditional medicinal]] uses, including treatment for [[rheumatism]], [[asthma]], [[cholera]], and [[fever]].<ref name=adhi/> Some ''[[in vitro]]'' and [[animal testing on rodents|rodent studies]] have suggested that extracts of the plant inhibit [[tumor]]s,<ref name=kuma>{{cite journal |author=Kumarappan CT, Mandal SC |title=Antitumor activity of polyphenolic extract of Ichnocarpus frutescens |journal=Exp. Oncol. |volume=29 |issue=2 |pages=94–101 |date=June 2007 |pmid=17704739 |doi= |url=http://www.exp-oncology.com.ua/en/archives/31/609.html}}</ref> protect [[liver|liver cells]] from damage in [[acetaminophen]] overdose,<ref name=dash/> and reduces complications of [[hyperlipidemia]] in diabetic rats.<ref name=kuma2>{{cite journal |author=Kumarappan CT, Mandal SC |title=Polyphenolic extract of Ichnocarpus frutescens attenuates diabetic complications in streptozotocin-treated diabetic rats |journal=Ren Fail |volume=30 |issue=3 |pages=307–22 |year=2008 |pmid=18350451 |doi=10.1080/08860220701857449 |url=http://informahealthcare.com/doi/abs/10.1080/08860220701857449}}</ref> There have been no published studies testing any of these effects in humans.

The fibrous bark is used to make [[rope]].<ref name=Fl.China/>

133.text:
{{Speciesbox
|taxon = Ipheion uniflorum
|image = Ipheion uniflorum1.jpg
|authority = ([[Raf.]]) [[Traub]]
|synonyms = *''[[Triteleia]] uniflora'' <small>Lindl.</small>
*''[[Brodiaea]] uniflora'' <small>(Lindl.) [[Engl.]]</small>
*''[[Tristagma]] uniflorum'' <small>([[John Lindley|Lindl.]]) [[Traub]]</small>
*''[[Milla]] uniflora'' <small>(Lindl.) [[Robert Graham (botanist)|Graham]]</small>
|}}
'''''Ipheion uniflorum''''' is a species of flowering plant, related to the onions, so is placed in the allium subfamily (Allioideae) of the [[Amaryllidaceae]].<ref>{{Citation |last=Stevens |first=Peter F. |year=2001–2010 |work=Angiosperm Phylogeny Website, Version 10 |title=Amaryllidaceae |url=http://www.mobot.org/MOBOT/Research/APweb/orders/asparagalesweb.htm#Amaryllidaceae |accessdate=2010-11-30 }}</ref> It is known by the common name '''springstar''',<ref>{{PLANTS|id=TRUN6|taxon=Tristagma uniflorum|accessdate=15 December 2015}}</ref> or '''spring starflower'''. Along with all the species of the genus ''Ipheion'', some sources place it in the genus ''[[Tristagma]]'',<ref name="WCSP">{{Citation |contribution=''Ipheion''|title=World Checklist of Selected Plant Families |publisher=[[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]] |url=http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=279339 |accessdate=2012-12-17}}</ref> but research published in 2010 suggested that this is not correct.<ref>{{Citation |last=Souza |first=L.G.R |last2=Crosa |first2=O. |last3=Guerra |first3=M. |year=2010 |title=Karyological circumscription of ''Ipheion'' Rafinesque (Gilliesioideae, Alliaceae) |journal=Plant Systematics and Evolution |volume=287 |pages=119–27 |url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/u156056815398651/fulltext.pdf |accessdate=2010-11-30 |lastauthoramp=yes |doi=10.1007/s00606-010-0304-3}}</ref> It is [[native plant|native]]  to [[Argentina]] and Uruguay, but is widely cultivated as an ornamental and reportedly naturalized in [[Great Britain]], [[France]], [[Australia]], and [[New Zealand]].<ref>[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=290463 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families, as ''Tristagma uniflorum'' ]</ref>

==Description==
This is a small [[herbaceous plant|herbaceous]] [[Perennial plant|perennial]] growing from a [[bulb]] and producing flat, shiny, green, hairless, grasslike leaves up to {{convert|30|cm|0|abbr=on}} long. The foliage has an [[onion]]like scent when crushed. The stem grows up to {{convert|20|cm|0|abbr=on}} tall and bears a solitary showy flower in spring (hence the Latin name ''uniflorum'' - "single flower"). Each honey-scented, star-shaped flower has six pointed lobes up to 3 centimeters long in shades of very pale to deep purple-blue.

==Cultivation==
''Ipheion uniflorum'' has been grown in the UK since 1820, when bulbs collected from near Buenos Aires arrived in the country. It is recommended for growing in a well-drained position outside or as long-flowering pot plant in an unheated greenhouse. Various named forms are in cultivation, some of which may be hybrids. 'Wisley Blue' is a clear lilac blue; 'Froyle Mill' is a deeper violet blue; 'Album' is white. The cultivar 'Alberto Castillo', also white, has larger flowers and was collected in the 1980s by Alberto Castillo, the owner of Ezeiza Botanical Garden, from an abandoned Buenos Aires garden.<ref>{{Citation |year=1993 |editor-last=Beckett |editor-first=K. |title=Encyclopedia of Alpines, Vol. 1 |publication-place=Pershore, UK |publisher=AGS Publications |isbn=978-0-900048-61-6 }}, p.675</ref><ref>{{Citation |last=Rolfe |first=R. |year=2001 |title=Plant Awards 2000-2001 |journal=Bulletin of the Alpine Garden Society |volume=69 |pages=482–550 }}, p.488</ref> In the USA, the species is stated to be hardy to [[USDA Hardiness Zone|USDA Zone]] 5, and is recommended for massing in borders, alpine gardens and other areas, or it can be naturalized in lawns.<ref>{{Citation |last=Kemper Center for Home Gardening |title=Ipheion uniflorum |url=http://www.mobot.org/gardeninghelp/plantfinder/Plant.asp?code=Q760#lbl_culture |accessdate=2010-12-01 }}</ref>

The [[cultivars]] 'Rolf Fiedler',<ref>{{cite web|title=RHS Plant Selector - ''Ipheion uniflorum'' 'Rolf Fiedler'|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=1030|publisher=Royal Horticultural Society|accessdate=2013-05-20}}</ref> 'Froyle Mill'<ref>{{cite web|title=RHS Plant Selector - ''Ipheion uniflorum'' 'Froyle Mill'|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=3139|publisher=Royal Horticultural Society|accessdate=2013-05-20}}</ref> and '[[RHS Garden, Wisley|Wisley]] Blue'<ref>{{cite web|title=RHS Plant Selector - ''Ipheion uniflorum'' 'Wisley Blue'|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=1031|publisher=Royal Horticultural Society|accessdate=2013-05-20}}</ref> have gained the [[Royal Horticultural Society]]'s [[Award of Garden Merit]].

{{taxobox
| status = LC
| status_system = iucn3.1
| status_ref =  <ref name="IUCN"/>
| image = Doesn't look like other Isolepis (4243401389).jpg
| regnum = [[Plantae]]
| unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
| unranked_classis = [[Monocots]]
| unranked_ordo = [[Commelinids]]
| ordo = [[Poales]]
| familia = [[Cyperaceae]]
| genus = ''[[Isolepis]]''
| species = '''''I. prolifera'''''
| binomial = ''Isolepis prolifera''
| binomial_authority = ([[Christen Friis Rottbøll|Rottb.]]) [[Robert Brown (botanist, born 1773)|R.Br.]] <ref name="IUCN"/>
| synonyms = 
*''Cyperus aitonii'' <small>Spreng.</small>
*''Cyperus punctatus'' <small>Lam.</small>
*''Isolepis erythronegma'' <small>Steud.</small>
*''Isolepis globosa'' <small>Buchanan</small>
*''Isolepis prolifer'' <small>(Rottb.) R.Br.</small> (orth. var.)
*''Scirpus prolifer'' <small>Rottb.</small>
| synonyms_ref =  <ref name="eMonocot">{{cite web |url=http://e-monocot.org/taxon/urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:250475 |title=''Isolepis prolifera'' (Rottb.) R.Br. |work=eMonocot |accessdate=22 January 2016}}</ref>
}}

'''''Isolepis prolifera''''' is a species of [[flowering plant]] in the family [[Cyperaceae]] that grows in temperate regions of the Southern Hemisphere. It has leafless stems up to {{convert|90|cm|abbr=on}} tall, and clusters of flowers that often proliferate into branches.

==Description==
''Isolepis prolifera'' has a caespitose (tufted) growth form, with round stems up to {{convert|90|cm}} tall and {{convert|4|mm}} wide.<ref name="Moore">{{cite book |authors=L. B. Moore & E. Edgar |year=1970 |series=Flora of New Zealand |volume=II |title=Indigenous Tracheophyta: Monocotyledones except Gramineae |location=Wellington, New Zealand |chapter=''Scirpus prolifer'' Rottb.}} Cited in [[#NZFlora|Flora of New Zealand]].</ref> Its leaves are reduced to red or brown sheaths around the stem, sometimes with a small free lobe up to {{convert|3|mm|abbr=on}} long.<ref name="Muasya">{{cite journal |authors=A. Muthama  Muasya & David A. Simpson |year=2002 |title=A monograph of the genus ''Isolepis'' R. Br. (''Cyperaceae'') |journal=[[Kew Bulletin]] |volume=57 |issue=2 |pages=257–362 |jstor=4111111}}</ref>

Its flowers are arranged in a cluster of [[spikelet]]s, {{convert|2|-|10|mm|2|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|1|-|2|mm|2|abbr=on}} wide. Many of the spikelets are, however, replaced by branchlets, each {{convert|2|-|7|cm|1|abbr=on}} long, and terminating in a further head of spikelets.<ref name="Moore"/> This proliferation into branches gives the species its scientific name ''{{lang|la|prolifera}}''. Each spikelet consists of up to 30 flowers, and the fruit is a nutlet with fine reticulations on its surface.<ref name="Muasya"/>

''Isolepis prolifera'' varies considerably in size, and smaller specimens may resemble the Australasian species ''[[Isolepis inundata]]'', although ''I. inundata'' normally has some true leaves, and is not always proliferating.<ref name="NZPCN"/><ref name="NSW"/>

==Distribution==
''Isolepis prolifera'' is found in a number of countries around the world, although it is not clear where it is native, and where it is an [[introduced species]]. The [[International Union for Conservation of Nature]] considers it to be native only to [[South Africa]],<ref name="IUCN">{{Cite web |url=http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/185403/0 |title=''Isolepis prolifera'' |year=2005 |authors=W. Foden & L. Potter |accessdate=22 January 2016 |work=The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species 2010 |at=e.T185403A8404497 |doi=10.2305/IUCN.UK.2010-3.RLTS.T185403A8404497.en}}</ref> where it grows in the [[Eastern Cape]], [[KwaZulu-Natal]] and [[Western Cape]] provinces.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://redlist.sanbi.org/species.php?species=2478-20 |title=''Isolepis prolifera'' (Rottb.) R.Br. |work=Red List of South African Plants |year=2005 |authors=W. Foden & L. Potter |accessdate=22 January 2016}}</ref> It is also widespread in [[New Zealand]], occurring on the [[South Island]], [[North Island]], and on the [[Chatham Islands]], and may be native there.<ref name="NZPCN">{{cite web |url=http://www.nzpcn.org.nz/flora_details.aspx?ID=2035 |title=''Isolepis prolifera'' |date=30 May 2015 |publisher=New Zealand Plant Conservation Network |accessdate=22 January 2016}}</ref> In Australia, ''I. prolifera'' occurs in [[New South Wales]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] and [[Tasmania]], as well as in the Mediterranean-climate region of [[Western Australia]].<ref name="ALA">{{cite web |url=http://bie.ala.org.au/species/urn:lsid:biodiversity.org.au:apni.taxon:740058 |title=''Isolepis prolifera'' (Rottb.) R.Br., Budding Club-rush |work=Atlas of Living Australia |accessdate=22 January 2016}}</ref> It is also potentially native to [[Tristan da Cunha]] and [[Saint Helena]],<ref name="eMonocot"/> and has been introduced to France<ref name="eMonocot"/> and California.<ref name="PLANTS">{{cite web |url=http://plants.usda.gov/core/profile?symbol=ISPR2 |title=''Isolepis prolifera'' (Rottb.) R.Br., proliferating bulrush |work=PLANTS Database |publisher=[[United States Department of Agriculture]] |accessdate=22 January 2016}}</ref>

==Ecology==
''Isolepis prolifera'' is a [[perennial plant]] that grows as a [[helophyte]] (marsh plant).<ref name="IUCN"/> It thrives in both [[eutrophic]] and [[oligotrophic]] [[wetland]]s, and can be a weed of drainages on farmland.<ref name="NZPCN"/>

==Naming==
''Isolepis prolifera'' was [[species description|first described]] by [[Christen Friis Rottbøll]], a pupil of [[Carl Linnaeus]], in his 1772 work ''{{lang|la|Descriptiones plantarum rariorum}}'', as "''Scirpus prolifer''". It was transferred to the genus ''[[Isolepis]]'' in 1810 by [[Robert Brown (botanist, born 1773)|Robert Brown]], although it is different from other ''Isolepis'' species, and may be better placed in a different genus, such as ''[[Scirpoides]]''.<ref name="NSW">{{cite web |url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Isolepis~prolifera |title=''Isolepis prolifera'' (Rottb.) R.Br. |work=New South Wales Flora Online |publisher=[[Royal Botanic Gardens, Sydney]] |accessdate=22 January 2016}}</ref>

''Isolepis prolifera'' has different common names in different parts of its range. In South Africa, it is known as ''{{lang|af|vleigras}}'' in [[Afrikaans]] or ''{{lang|zu|incapha}}'' in [[Zulu language|Zulu]], in Australia as "budding club-rush",<ref name="ALA"/> and in the United States as "proliferating bulrush".<ref name="PLANTS"/> In New Zealand, it either has no common name<ref name="NZPCN"/> or is known as "three-square".<ref name="NZflora">{{cite web |url=http://www.nzflora.info/factsheet/Taxon/Isolepis_prolifera.html |publisher=[[Landcare Research]] |title=''Isolepis prolifera'' (Rottb.) R.Br. |work=Flora of New Zealand |ref=NZFlora |accessdate=22 January 2016}}</ref>

136.text:
{{italic title}}
{{Taxobox
|image= Isophysis tasmanica.jpg
|image_caption = ''Isophysis tasmanica'', Mount Eliza, [[Southwest National Park]]
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
| unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
| unranked_classis = [[Monocots]]
|ordo = [[Asparagales]]
|familia = [[Iridaceae]]
|subfamilia ='''Isophysidoideae'''
|genus = '''''Isophysis''''' 
|genus_authority = [[Thomas Moore (botanist)|T.Moore]]<ref>Proc. Linn. Soc. London 2: 212 (1853).</ref>
|type_species = ''Isophysis tasmanica''
|type_species_authority = ([[William Jackson Hooker|Hook.]]) T.Moore<ref>Bot. Not. 127: 107 (1974).</ref> 
|synonyms =
*''Hewardia tasmanica'' <small>Hook.</small>
}}
'''''Isophysis'''''  is a  [[genus]] of [[herbaceous]], [[perennial]] and [[rhizomatous]] plants in the Iris family ([[Iridaceae]]). A [[monotypic]] genus formerly known as ''Hewardia'', it contains a single species,<ref>Royal Horticultural Society, Kew.  [http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/reportbuilder.do A detailed checklist for genus ''Isophysis''.]</ref> '' Isophysis tasmanica '', [[endemism|endemic]] to the mountains of [[Western Tasmania]] growing in heathland on sandy soils. It has grass-like foliage and star-like dark red-purple or yellow flowers with reflexed [[tepal]]s. A characteristic feature of this species is its [[superior ovary]], which distinguishes it from any other member of Iridaceae. The genus name is derived from the [[Greek language|Greek]] words ''iso'', meaning "equal", and ''physis'', meaning "bladder".<ref name=Goldblatt2008>{{cite book |author1=Manning, John |author2=Goldblatt, Peter |title=The Iris Family: Natural History & Classification |publisher=Timber Press |location=Portland, Oregon|pages=91–93 |year=2008|isbn=0-88192-897-6}}</ref>

The former genus name ''Hewardia'' is used as a landmark name in Tasmania's [[Southwest National Park|southwest wilderness]] such as Hewardia Ridge on Mt Picton located near Pineapple flats, named after the [[Astelia alpina|Pineapple Grass]].

137.text:
{{taxobox
| image = Jasminum didymum subsp racemosum, Queensland.jpg
| image_caption = ''Jasminum didymum'' subsp. ''racemosum''.
| regnum = [[Plant]]ae
| unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
| unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
| unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]]
| ordo = [[Lamiales]]
| familia = [[Oleaceae]]
| genus = ''[[Jasminum]]''
| species = '''''J. didymum'''''
| binomial = ''Jasminum didymum''
| binomial_authority = [[Georg Forster|G.Forst.]]
}}

'''''Jasminum didymum''''' is a species of scrambling vine or low shrub. It is native to insular Southeast Asia from [[Java]] to the [[Philippines]], as well as [[Australia]] ([[Northern Territory]], [[Norfolk Island]], and all states except [[Tasmania]]), as well as some islands in the Pacific ([[New Guinea]], [[Solomon Islands]], [[Fiji]], [[Niue]], [[New Caledonia]] and the [[Society Islands]]).<ref name="hisakodrury">[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=352134 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families, ''Jasminum didymum'']</ref>  ''Jasminum didymum'' occurs naturally in habitats from [[rainforest]]s to arid and semi-arid [[shrubland]]s.<ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/11162909#page/11/mode/1up Forster, Johann Georg Adam. 1786.  Florulae Insularum Australium Prodromus 3, ''Jasminum didymum''].</ref>

==Subspecies==
''Jasminum didymum'' is highly variable in leaf shape and habit and is subdivided into 3 subspecies based on these characteristics:<ref name="hisakodrury"/>

*''Jasminum didymum'' subsp. ''didymum'' -  wide natural distribution
*''Jasminum didymum'' subsp. ''lineare'' <small>(R.Br.) P.S.Green</small><ref name="peggyearnshaw">Green, Peter Shaw. 1984.  Allertonia 3: 411-412.</ref>  - Mainland Australia
*''Jasminum didymum'' subsp. ''racemosum'' <small>(F.Muell.) P.S.Green</small><ref name="peggyearnshaw"/> - [[Queensland]] only
