138.text:
{{taxobox |image = |image_caption = |regnum = [[Plantae]] |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]] |ordo = [[Malvales]] |familia = [[Thymelaeaceae]] |tribus = [[Linostomateae]]
[[Karl Wilhelm Supprian|Supprian]]{{ cite web |url=http://www.biologie.uni-hamburg.de/b-online/library/revfam/www.inform.umd.edu/PBIO/fam/inspv6.html |author=[[James L. Reveal]] |title=''Jaborosa'' through ''Myxopyrum'' |work=Indices Nominum Supragenericorum Plantarum Vascularium |publisher=[[University of Maryland]]; Norton-Brown Herbarium |location=[[College Park, Maryland]] |date=27 September 2000 |accessdate=13 November 2011}} |subtribus = [[Linostomatinae]]
[[Ernest Friedrich Gilg|Gilg]] in [[Adolf Engler|Engl.]] & [[Karl Anton Eugen Prantl|Prantl]] |genus = '''''Jedda''''' |genus_authority = [[John Richard Clarkson|J.R.Clarkson]]The genus ''Jedda'' was first described and published in ''Austrobaileya'' 2(3): 203. 1986. {{ cite web |url=http://www.tropicos.org/Name/50286076 |title=Name - ''Jedda'' J.R.Clarkson |work=Tropicos |publisher=[[Missouri Botanical Garden]] |location=[[Saint Louis, Missouri]] |accessdate=13 November 2011}} |species = '''''J. multicaulis''''' |binomial = ''Jedda multicaulis'' |binomial_authority = J.R.Clarkson ''Jedda multicaulis'' was originally described and published in ''Austrobaileya'' 2(3): 203. 1986. {{ cite web |url=http://www.tropicos.org/Name/50286077 |title=Name - ''Jedda multicaulis'' J.R.Clarkson |quote=Type-Protologue: Locality: "Queensland, Cook District: between Jedda Creek and the Kennedy River. 15º37'S, 143º57'E. 18 October 1982" |work=Tropicos |publisher=Missouri Botanical Garden |location=Saint Louis, Missouri |accessdate=13 November 2011}} }} '''''Jedda''''' is a monotypic plant genus in the [[Thymelaeaceae]] family, its only species being ''J. multicaulis''. The species is an upright, evergreen bush [[indigenous (ecology)|indigenous]] to tropical [[Australia]], discovered in the early 1980s on the [[Cape York Peninsula]] in northern [[Queensland]], in an area of grassy forest land.{{ cite web |url=http://www.anbg.gov.au/anpc/apc/9-1_clarkson.html |title=Threatened Plant Conservation in Cape York Forges Ahead |author=John Clarkson, Principal Botanist, Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service |location=[[Mareeba, Queensland]], Australia |publisher=Australian National Botanic Gardens; Centre for Australian National Biodiversity Research |date=14 January 2011 |accessdate=13 November 2011}} The full extent of its distribution is unknown. The name ''Jedda'' is a [[toponymy|toponym]] from Jedda Creek, which is close to where the [[type (biology)|type specimen]] was collected from. ==Description== ''Jedda multicaulis'' is a multi-stemmed, upright, evergreen bush (1.5–2.5 m tall). [[plant stem|Stem]]s, which are smooth, reddish-brown, and cylindrical when young, and woody as they age, arise from a central [[corm]]. Glabrous, coriaceous, point-tipped, oval-shaped leaves (2.5–7 mm long × 8–25 mm wide), are arranged oppositely, or nearly oppositely, along the stems. [[Inflorescence]]s (2–4 mm long) are clusters of usually three, occasionally up to five flowers, set in [[bract]]s. [[Flower]] base is tubular (7–9 mm long), extending into [[sepal]]s and white [[corolla (flower)|corolla]] lobes (3.8–5 mm long). Flowers come out in October.{{ cite web |url=http://www.environment.gov.au/biodiversity/threatened/species/pubs/4079-conservation-advice.pdf |title=''Jedda multicaulis'' Conservation Advice |publisher=Australian Government; Department of Sustainability, Environment, Water, Population and Communities |date=16 December 2008 |accessdate=13 November 2011}} [[Fruit]]s (6–8 cm long × 4–6 cm wide) which are sometimes [[vivipary#In plants|viviparous]]{{ cite web |url=http://www.anbg.gov.au/abrs/online-resources/flora/stddisplay.xsql?pnid=46837 |title=''Jedda multicaulis'' |work=Flora of Australia Online |publisher=Australian National Botanic Gardens |accessdate=13 November 2011}} and exhibit [[cryptogeal]] (i.e. plant burrows under the soil) [[germination]],{{ cite journal |url=http://www.publish.csiro.au/paper/BT9870715.htm |author1=JR Clarkson |author2=HT Clifford |title=Germination of ''Jedda multicaulis'' Clarkson,J.r. (Thymelaeaceae). An Example of Cryptogeal Germination in the Australian Flora |journal=Australian Journal of Botany |year=1987 |volume=35 |issue=6 |pages=715–720 |doi=10.1071/BT9870715 |accessdate=13 November 2011}} are green leathery [[berry (botany)|berries]] or [[achene]]s. {{clear}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.tropicos.org/ImageFullView.aspx?imageid=54140 Type specimen photo] from the Missouri Botanic Garden * [http://www.anbg.gov.au/anpc/apc/images/jedda.jpg Fruit photo] from the Australian National Botanic Gardens * [http://www.anbg.gov.au/abrs/online-resources/flora/image.xsql?pnid=46837&volume=18&imgurl=v18_m167.jpg&maptext=Jedda%20multicaulis Distributional map] from Australian National Botanic Gardens [[Category:Plants described in 1986]] [[Category:Flora of Australia]] [[Category:Flora of Queensland]] {{Malvales-stub}}
138.title: Jedda multicaulis

139.text:
{{italic title}} {{taxobox |image = Juncus kraussii subsp. australiensis 11.JPG |image_caption = ''Juncus kraussii'' subsp. ''australiensis'' |regnum = [[Plantae]] |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Monocots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Commelinids]] |ordo = [[Poales]] |familia = [[Juncaceae]] |genus = ''[[Juncus]]'' |species = '''''J. kraussii''''' |binomial = ''Juncus kraussii'' |binomial_authority = [[Christian Ferdinand Friedrich Hochstetter|Hochst.]] |subdivision_ranks = Subspecies |subdivision = '''''Juncus kraussii'' subsp. ''austerus''''' {{au|(Buchenau) Snogerup}}
'''''Juncus kraussii'' subsp. ''australiensis''''' {{au|(Buchenau) Snogerup}}
'''''Juncus kraussii'' subsp. ''kraussii''''' }} '''''Juncus kraussii''''' commonly known as '''salt marsh rush''', '''sea rush''', '''jointed rush''', '''matting rush''' or '''dune slack rush''', is of the [[monocot]] family [[Juncaceae]] and genus [[Juncus]]. It grows in [[Salt marsh]]es, [[estuary|estuarine]] and coastal areas.{{cite web|url=http://www.birdsinbackyards.net/spaces/display.cfm?id=167|title=Birds in Backyards - Juncus kraussii |year=2007|accessdate=2008-10-28}} This species is ideal as a stabilizer in estuary banks and [[riparian]] zones that adjoin developed areas{{cite web|url=http://www.lhccrems.nsw.gov.au/CPR/CPR/plant_profiles/j.kraussii.htm |title=CPR Coastal Plant Regeneration - Juncus kraussii subsp. australiensis |year=2008 |accessdate=2008-10-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080904164945/http://www.lhccrems.nsw.gov.au/CPR/CPR/plant_profiles/j.kraussii.htm |archivedate=September 4, 2008 }} it prevents erosion and provides an excellent fibre for weaving.{{cite web|url=http://www.plantzafrica.com/planthij/juncuskraus.htm|title=Plantzafrica - Juncus kraussii Hochst. |year=2006|accessdate=2008-10-28}} The plant is named after a German [[naturalist]] and museum curator, [[Christian Krauss]], who travelled to [[South Africa]]. == Description == This species is a [[tussock (grass)|tussock]] shaped [[perennial]] with many [[rhizome]]s.{{cite web|url=http://florabase.calm.wa.gov.au/browse/profile/1185|title=Florabase - Juncus kraussii Hochst. |year=2008|accessdate=2008-10-28}} The [[leaf|leaves]] are tough, straw shaped and spine-tipped that grow to be {{convert|40|cm|in}} - {{convert|150|cm|in}} in length with a golden brown or shiny black sheath. The inflorescences or flowers of ''J. kraussii'' are reddish brown to purplish brown in colour, {{convert|4|cm|in}} - {{convert|20|cm|in}} in length and are clustered toward the end of the stem. The flowers occur clusters of three to six and flowering occurs in Summer between October and January. == Distribution and habitat == The species occurs in all states of [[Australia]],{{cite web|url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Juncus~kraussii|title=PlantNET - New South Wales Flora Online- ''Juncus kraussii'' Hochst.|year=2008|accessdate=2008-10-28}} Southern [[Africa]] and [[South America]].{{cite web|url=http://www.kznwildlife.com/site/ecotourism/activities/flora/Wetlands/Juncus_kraussii_.html|title=Ezemvelo KZM Wildlife - Juncus Kraussii - Wetlands|year=2008|accessdate=2008-10-28}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} ''J. kraussii'' is salt tolerant and favours a damp environment and is most often found in areas such as [[swamp]]s and [[brackish]] [[estuary|estuaries]]. The plant is able to grow in a range of soils from [[sand]]s to [[alluvium]]. == Uses == ''J. kraussii'' is harvested and weaved to produce traditional sleeping mats, baskets, beer strainers, and other craftwork items in many [[Zulu people|Zulu]] areas of [[South Africa]]. The plant is in great demand because of its economic value and has been extensively [[harvest]]ed in the wild. It is now [[Agriculture|cultivate]]d in many areas and is harvested yearly for a period of seven years in total. == References == {{reflist|45em}} [[Category:Juncus|kraussii]] [[Category:Plants described in 1845]] [[Category:Flora of Australia]] [[Category:Flora of Southern Africa]] [[Category:Flora of South America]]
139.title: Juncus kraussii

140.text:
{{taxobox
|image = Juncus planifolius 11.JPG
|image_caption = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Monocots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Commelinids]]
|ordo = [[Poales]]
|familia = [[Juncaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Juncus]]''
|species = '''''J. planifolius'''''
|binomial = ''Juncus planifolius''
|binomial_authority = [[R.Br.]]
}}
'''''Juncus planifolius''''' is a species of [[juncus|rush]], commonly known as '''broadleaf rush''',<ref>{{PLANTS|id=JUPL|taxon=Juncus planifolius|accessdate=22 January 2016}}</ref> '''broad-leaved rush''',<ref name=BSBI07>{{cite web|title=BSBI List 2007 |publisher=Botanical Society of Britain and Ireland |url=http://www.bsbi.org.uk/BSBIList2007.xls |format=xls |archive-url=http://www.webcitation.org/6VqJ46atN?url=http://www.bsbi.org.uk/BSBIList2007.xls |archive-date=2015-01-25 |accessdate=2014-10-17 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> or '''grass-leaved rush'''. It naturally occurs in [[Australia]], [[New Zealand]], [[Hawaii]] and [[South America]].

In New Zealand ''J. planifolius'' is found in open, wet ground, and can be typically found on exposed clay, beside tracks or drains.<ref name=nzpcn>{{cite web|title=Juncus planifolius|url=http://www.nzpcn.org.nz/flora_details.asp?ID=2175|publisher=New Zealand Plant Conservation Network|accessdate=2 October 2012}}</ref>

Recently ''J. planifolius'' has been introduced to the northern hemisphere.  It was found in Hawai'i in 1930 and has spread to most of the islands.<ref>Wester L, 1992. Origin and distribution of adventives alien flowering plants in Hawai'i. In: Alien plant invasions in native ecosystems of Hawaii: Management and research [ed. by Stone, C. P. \Smith, C. W. \Tunison, J. T.]. Honolulu, Hawaii, USA: University of Hawaii Cooperative National Park Resources Studies Unit, 99-154 pp.</ref>  The species arrived in Ireland by 1973.<ref>Scannell, Mary J. P.  1973.  Juncus planifolius R. Br. in Ireland.  The Irish Naturalists’ Journal 17(9): 308-309.</ref>  It is now well established on Pacific coast of North America, where the plant was first collected in Oregon in 1980.<ref>Balslev Henrik, 1980. Juncus planifolius (Juncaceae) in North America. Brittonia, 32(1):51-54.</ref>  The first California record was in 2008,<ref>Zika PF, 2009. Noteworthy Collections. California. Madrono, 56:130.</ref> but populations were probably well established before then.  ''Juncus planifolius'' may have arrived as a contaminant in vines planted in commercial cranberry bogs, but is now spreading in native coastal bogs, where it may displace native plants.

In North America, it is recognized by its unbranched stems, basal leaves with no sharp demarcation of sheath and blade, and blackish tepals.

142.text:
{{taxobox
|image = Lawrencella davenportii habit.jpg 
|image_width = 
|image_caption = ''Lawrencella davenportii''
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]]
|ordo = [[Asterales]]
|familia = [[Asteraceae]]
|genus = '''''Lawrencella'''''
|genus_authority = J. Lindley
|type_species = ''Lawrencella rosea''
|type_species_authority = J. Lindley
|subdivision_ranks = Species
|subdivision = 
|}}
'''''Lawrencella''''' is a [[genus]] of flowering plants in the [[Asteraceae|daisy family]] endemic to [[Australia]].

The genus comprises two species: ''[[Lawrencella davenportii]]'' with a distribution in arid regions of [[Western Australia]], [[The Northern Territory]], and [[South Australia]] and ''[[Lawrencella rosea]]'' which is restricted to Southern [[Western Australia]].<ref>Wilson, P.G. 1998 “The  Lawrencella complex (Asteraceae: Gnaphalieae: Angianthinae) of Australia” Nuytsia 8:3</ref>

Both species are annual herbs growing to approximately 40 cm in height. The strap-shaped leaves up to 10 cm in length are covered with short hairs.  Flower heads are produced on stalks well above the main leaves, and have yellow centres with pink or occasionally white [[bracts]]. Flowering usually occurs in spring or summer in years with good cool season rain.<ref>Corrick, M.G., Alexander, B. 2002. “Wildflowers of Southern Western Australia” Five Mile Press, Noble Park.</ref><ref>http://asgap.org.au/l-ros.html</ref>

Both species have horticultural potential for their colourful flower displays and their drought hardiness. However, difficulties in germination of seed have restricted their widespread cultivation to date<ref>http://asgap.org.au/l-ros.html</ref><ref>http://www.ngia.com.au/files/nurserypapers/NP_1996_06.pdf</ref>

The genus Lawrencella is closely related to two other Australian genera, ''[[Schoenia]]'' and ''[[Bellida]]''.

147.text:
{{taxobox
|image = FloweringLigustrumLucidumTree.jpg
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]]
|ordo = [[Lamiales]]
|familia = [[Oleaceae]]
|tribus = [[Oleeae]]
|genus = ''[[Ligustrum]]''
|species = '''''L. lucidum'''''
|binomial = ''Ligustrum lucidum''
|binomial_authority = [[William Aiton|W.T.Aiton]]
}}
'''''Ligustrum lucidum''''' ('''broad-leaf privet''',<ref name="weed">[http://www.dpi.nsw.gov.au/agriculture/pests-weeds/weeds/profiles/privet Weed profile: Privet], New South Wales Department of Primary Industries</ref> '''Chinese privet'''<ref name=RHS/> '''glossy privet''',<ref>{{PLANTS|id=LILU2|taxon=Ligustrum lucidum|accessdate=24 January 2016}}</ref> '''tree privet'''<ref name=BSBI07>{{cite web |title=BSBI List 2007 |publisher=Botanical Society of Britain and Ireland |url=http://www.bsbi.org.uk/BSBIList2007.xls |format=xls |archive-url=http://www.webcitation.org/6VqJ46atN |archive-date=2015-02-25 |accessdate=2014-10-17}}</ref> or '''wax-leaf privet''') is a [[species]] of [[privet]] (''Ligustrum'' genus), a [[flowering plant]] in the olive [[family (biology)|family]], Oleaceae, [[native plant|native]] to the southern half of China and naturalized in many places: [[Spain]], [[Italy]], [[Algeria]], [[Canary Islands]], [[New Zealand]], [[Lesotho]], [[South Africa]], [[Japan]], [[Korea]], [[Australia]], [[Norfolk Island]], [[Chiapas]], [[Central America]], [[Argentina]], and the southern [[United States]] ([[California]], [[Arizona]], [[Maryland]], and the southeast from [[Texas]] to [[North Carolina]]).<ref>[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=354188 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families, ''Ligustrum lucidum'']</ref><ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Ligustrum%20lucidum.png Biota of North America Program, ''Ligustrum lucidum'']</ref><ref>Gavier-Pizarro, Gregorio I.; Kuemmerle, Tobias; Hoyos, Laura E.; Stewart, Susan I.; Huebner, Cynthia D.; Keuler, Nicholas S.; Radeloff, Volker C. 2012. "[http://www.nrs.fs.fed.us/pubs/42495 Monitoring the invasion of an exotic tree (''Ligustrum lucidum'') from 1983 to 2006 with Landsat TM/ETM+ satellite data and support vector machines in Cordoba, Argentina]". ''Remote Sensing of Environment''. 122: 134-145.</ref> The name "Chinese privet" is more frequently used for ''[[Ligustrum sinense]]''.

The Latin ''lucidum'' means bright or shiny, and refers to the glossy leaves.

==Description==
''Ligustrum lucidum'' is an [[evergreen]] [[tree]] growing to {{convert|10|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} tall and broad''.'' The [[leaf|leaves]] are opposite, glossy dark green, {{convert|6|-|17|cm}} long and {{convert|3|-|8|cm}} broad. The [[flower]]s are similar to other privets, [[white]] or near white, borne in panicles, and unpleasantly pungent.<ref name=RHSAZ>{{cite book|title=RHS A-Z encyclopedia of garden plants|year=2008|publisher=Dorling Kindersley|location=United Kingdom|isbn=1405332964|pages=1136}}</ref>

''Ligustrum lucidum''<ref name=RHS>{{cite web|title=RHS Plant Selector - ''Ligustrum lucidum'' |url= http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=3382 |accessdate=21 May 2013}}</ref> and the [[variegation|variegated]] [[cultivar]] 'Excelsum Superbum'<ref>{{cite web|title=RHS Plant Selector - ''Ligustrum lucidum'' 'Excelsum Superbum' |url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=1157 |accessdate=21 May 2013}}</ref> have gained the [[Royal Horticultural Society]]'s [[Award of Garden Merit]].

==Uses==
''Ligustrum lucidum'' is often used as an ornamental tree, sometimes in variegated forms. However, it has become an invasive species in some areas where it has been introduced, such as urban areas in the southeastern United States. It is classed as a noxious weed in [[New South Wales]], [[Australia]],<ref name="weed"/> and is similarly listed in New Zealand's [[National Pest Plant Accord]].

''Ligustrum lucidum'' is also known to the West as the "wax tree privet".

===Ethnomedical uses===
The seeds are known as ''nu zhen zi'' (female chastity seed) in [[traditional Chinese medicine]] and are believed to nourish liver and kidney [[Yin and yang|yin]] and [[Jing (Chinese medicine)|jing]] in the treatment of [[tinnitus]] (ringing in the ears), [[vertigo]] (dizziness), premature graying of the hair, and soreness/weakness of the lower back and knees.{{citation needed|date=February 2016}} Due to the belief in the seeds' ability to nourish the liver, they are also used in the treatment of disorders of the eye involving red or dry eyes, blurred vision, and pain.{{citation needed|date=February 2016}}

==Chemical constituents==
Chemical constituents of the seeds include [[oleanolic acid]], [[nuzhenide]], and [[ligustroside]].

148.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = ''Ligustrum vulgare''
|image = Wilde liguster (Ligustrum vulgare).jpg
|image_caption = Mature shrub in summer
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]]
|ordo = [[Lamiales]]
|familia = [[Oleaceae]]
|tribus = [[Oleeae]]
|genus = ''[[Ligustrum]]''
|species = '''''L. vulgare'''''
|binomial = ''Ligustrum vulgare''
|binomial_authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]
}}

'''''Ligustrum vulgare''''' ('''wild privet''', also sometimes known as '''common privet''' or '''European privet'''), is a [[species]] of ''[[Ligustrum]]'' native to central and southern [[Europe]], [[north Africa]] and southwestern [[Asia]], from [[Ireland]] and southwestern [[Sweden]] south to [[Morocco]], and east to [[Poland]] and northwestern [[Iran]].<ref name=fe>Flora Europaea: [http://rbg-web2.rbge.org.uk/cgi-bin/nph-readbtree.pl/feout?FAMILY_XREF=&GENUS_XREF=Ligustrum+&SPECIES_XREF=vulgare&TAXON_NAME_XREF=&RANK= ''Ligustrum vulgare'']</ref><ref>[[Plants for a Future]]: [http://www.pfaf.org/database/plants.php?Ligustrum+vulgare ''Ligustrum vulgare'']</ref><ref>Germplasm Resources Information Network: [http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?22101 ''Ligustrum vulgare'']</ref><ref name=blamey>Blamey, M. & Grey-Wilson, C. (1989). ''Flora of Britain and Northern Europe''. ISBN 0-340-40170-2</ref><ref name=bean>Bean, W. J. (1978). ''Trees and Shrubs Hardy in the British Isles'' vol. 2: 576-577. ISBN 0-7195-2256-0.</ref>

[[Image:- Ligustrum vulgare - Berries -.jpg|thumb|Berries]]
It is a [[evergreen|semi-evergreen]] or [[deciduous]] [[shrub]], growing to 3 m (rarely up to 5 m) tall. The stems are stiff, erect, with grey-brown [[bark]] spotted with small brown [[lenticel]]s. The [[leaf|leaves]] are borne in decussate opposite pairs, sub-shiny green, narrow oval to lanceolate, 2–6 cm long and 0.5–1.5 cm broad. The [[flower]]s are produced in mid summer in [[panicle]]s 3–6 cm long, each flower creamy-white, with a tubular base and a four-lobed [[Corolla (flower)|corolla]] ('petals') 4–6 mm diameter.  The flowers produce a strong, pungent fragrance that many people find unpleasant. The [[fruit]] is a small glossy black [[berry (botany)|berry]] 6–8 mm diameter, containing one to four [[seed]]s. The berries are [[poison]]ous to humans but readily eaten by [[thrush (bird)|thrushes]], which disperse the seeds in their droppings.<ref name=blamey/><ref name=bean/><ref name=fnwe>Flora of Northwest Europe: [http://ip30.eti.uva.nl/BIS/flora.php?selected=beschrijving&menuentry=soorten&id=3568 ''Ligustrum vulgare'']</ref>

Plants from the warmer parts of the range show a stronger tendency to be fully evergreen; these have sometimes been treated as a separate [[variety (biology)|variety]] ''Ligustrum vulgare'' var. ''italicum'' (Mill.) Vahl,<ref name=bean/> but others do not regard it as distinct.<ref name=fe/>

In the [[British Isles]] it is the only [[native plant|native]] privet, common in [[hedge (barrier)|hedge]]rows and woodlands in southern [[England]] and [[Wales]], especially in chalk areas; it is less common in northern England, [[Scotland]], and [[Northern Ireland]], where it only occurs as an escape from cultivation.<ref name=bean/><ref name="multiple">The [[Reader's Digest]] Field Guide to the Trees and Shrubs of Britain ''p.52''.</ref><ref name=fni>Flora of Northern Ireland: [http://www.habitas.org.uk/flora/species.asp?item=3951 ''Ligustrum vulgare'']</ref>

==Cultivation and uses==
The species was used for hedging in [[Elizabethan gardens]] in England, but was superseded by the more reliably evergreen introduction ''[[Ligustrum ovalifolium|L. ovalifolium]]'' from Japan.<ref name="multiple"/>

A number of [[cultivar]]s have been selected, including:<ref name=bean/>
*'Aureum' – yellow leaves.
*'Buxifolium' – small, oval leaves not over 2.5 cm long.
*'Cheyenne' – cold-tolerant clone selected in North America.
*'Chlorocarpum' - berries green.
*'Insulense' – long, narrow leaves 5–11 cm long and 1-2.5 cm broad.
*'Leucocarpum' – berries greenish-white.
*'Lodense' – dense, dwarf shrub (the name is a [[portmanteau]] of 'low' and 'dense').
*'Pyramidale' – fastigiate.
*'Xanthocarpum' – berries yellow.

==Invasiveness==
The species is listed as [[invasive plant|invasive]] as an introduced plant in [[Australia]],<ref>Potential Environmental Weeds in Australia: [http://www.environment.gov.au/biodiversity/invasive/publications/weeds-potential/appendix-c-l.html Appendix C]</ref> [[Canada]],<ref>Canadian Botanical Conservation Network: [http://www.rbg.ca/cbcn/en/projects/invasives/i_shrub2.html Information on Invasive Shrub and Vine Species]</ref> [[New Zealand]],<ref>Protecting and Restoring our Natural Heritage: [http://www.doc.govt.nz/publications/conservation/protecting-and-restoring-our-natural-heritage-a-practical-guide/appendix-one-invasive-weeds/ Appendix one: Invasive weeds]</ref> and the [[United States]].<ref>{{cite book |url=http://www.nps.gov/plants/alien/pubs/midatlantic/midatlantic.pdf | title=Plant Invaders of Mid-Atlantic Natural Areas, 4th Edition |last1=Swearingen |first1=Jil |last2=Reshetiloff |first2=K. |last3=Slattery |first3=B |last4=Zwicker |first4=S. | year=2010 |publisher=National Park Service and U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service |page=71}}</ref><ref>Invasive species: [http://www.invasive.org/browse/subject.cfm?sub=3036 European privet]</ref> It is also fully naturalised in [[Mexico]]'s highlands<ref>Plantas medicinales. Virtudes insospechadas de plantas conocidas. 1987. Reader's Digest México S.A. de C.V. Printed by Gráficas Monte Albán S.A. de C.V. Querétaro, Mexico. ISBN 968-28-0099-4</ref> and [[Argentina]].<ref>[http://www.nrs.fs.fed.us/pubs/42495 Gavier-Pizarro, Gregorio I.; Kuemmerle, Tobias; Hoyos, Laura E.; Stewart, Susan I.; Huebner, Cynthia D.; Keuler, Nicholas S.; Radeloff, Volker C. 2012. Monitoring the invasion of an exotic tree (''Ligustrum lucidum'') from 1983 to 2006 with Landsat TM/ETM+ satellite data and support vector machines in Cordoba, Argentina. Remote Sensing of Environment. 122: 134-145.]</ref>

148.title: Ligustrum vulgare

149.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=April 2017}}
{{taxobox
|image = 
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Malpighiales]]
|familia = [[Linaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Linum]]''
|species = '''''L. marginale'''''
|binomial = ''Linum marginale''
|binomial_authority = [[Carolus Linnaeus|L.]]
|}}
'''''Linum marginale''''', known by the common name of ''''native flax'''' or ''''Australian flax'''', is a short lived perennial flowering herb, native to [[Australia]]. A slender, wispy, upright plant, growing to around 1 metre high, Native Flax is often overlooked when not in flower. It should not be confused with species of [[Wahlenbergia]], which occurs in the same area and can appear similarly. Like most species of [[Linum]], Linum marginale can be used to produce useful [[Linen|fibre]], but is not grown on a commercial level for this purpose.
Native flax has small linear blue green leaves, often pushed quite close to the stem. To the untrained eye from a distance, in may appear to have no leaves.
Unlike most other species of [[flax]] which have yellow flowers, Linum marginale beaks into sprays of large, electric blue flowers in spring and early summer.  The flowers (around 3 cm across) have five petals and form at the top of each wiry stem of the plant. Flowers are replaced in summer by small, globular, papery capsules, about 3 mm across, containing a cluster of buff coloured, [[sesame]]-like seeds. Like many southern [[Australian]] flowers, the plant dies back in [[summer]], but reshoots the following [[autumn]] when the rains return.

[[Category:Linum|marginale]]
[[Category:Flora of Australia]]


{{Malpighiales-stub}}
149.title: Linum marginale

150.text:
The '''list of seaweeds and marine flowering plants of Australia (temperate waters)''' is a list of marine species that form a part of the flora of [[Australia]].

The geographical range is from [[Perth, Western Australia]] to [[New South Wales]], and those tropical species which are also found in this range may also be listed here.

The listed organisms are generally identifiable to the naked eye. Many microscopic algae also inhabit this region.

Ranges are generally given relating to Australian waters. If listed as [[endemic]], they have been found only in the listed range. Others may have much greater ranges.

==Phylum (Division) Heterokontophyta==
(Brown algae, brown seaweeds)

Family [[Leathesiacae]]
*Leatherweed ''[[Leathesia difformis]]'' (Linnaeus) Areschoug (Point Westall, South Australia, to Ulladulla, New South Wales, and around Tasmania. Also widely distributed overseas.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />

Family [[Chordariaceae]]
*Brown spaghetti weed ''[[Cladosiphon filum]]'' (Harvey) Kylin (Safety Bay, Western Australia, to Nowra, New South Wales, and around Tasmania. Also widely distributed overseas.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />

Family [[Splachnidiaceae]]
*Neptune’s fingers ''[[Splachnidium rugosum]]'' (Linnaeus) Greville (Point Sinclair, South Australia, to Sydney, New South Wales, and around Tasmania. Also South Africa, New Zealand and several subantarctic islands.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />

Family [[Stypocaulaceae]]
*Twisted filament weed ''[[Halopteris paniculata]]'' (Suhr) Prud’homme van Reine (Port Willunga, South Australia, to Newcastle, New South Wales, and around Tasmania. Also New Zealand, Chile and several subantarctic Islands.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />

Family [[Cladostephaceae]]
*Bushy brown alga ''[[Cladostephus spongiosus]]'' (Hudson) C. Agardh (Yanchep, Western Australia, to Keppel Bay, Queensland, and around Tasmania. Also widespread overseas.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />

Family [[Dictyotaceae]]

*Crinkleweed ''[[Dilophus marginatus]]'' J. Agardh (Port Stanvac, South Australia, to Noosa, Queensland, and northern Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Eastern forkweed ''[[Dilophus intermedius]]'' (Zanardini) Allender & Kraft (Jervis Bay, New South Wales, to Caloundra, Queensland. Also Lord Howe Island.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Mueller’s forkweed ''[[Dictyopteris muelleri]]'' (Sonder) Reinbold (Port Gregory, Western Australia, to Walkerville, Victoria, and around Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Agardh’s forkweed ''[[Dictyopteris acrostichoides]]'' (J. Agardh) Boergesen  (Warrnambool, Victoria, to Rockingham, Queensland, and northern Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Southern forkweed ''[[Dictyopteris australis]]'' (Sonder) Askenasy (Dampier, Western Australia, to Port Noarlunga, South Australia. Also Queensland, Lord Howe Island, and widespread overseas.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Stringy forkweed ''[[Pachydictyon paniculatum]]'' (J. Agardh) J. Agardh (Geraldton, Western Australia, to Sydney, New South Wales, and around Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Spiralled forkweed ''[[Lobospira bicuspidata]]'' Areschoug (Nickol Bay, Western Australia, to Eden, New South Wales, and northern Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Elegant padina ''[[Padina elegans]]'' Koh ex Womersley (Dongara, Western Australia, to Pearson Island, South Australia.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Thickened padina ''[[Padina crassa]]'' Yamada (Tropical Australia south to Narooma, New South Wales. Also Lord Howe Island and widespread in the Indo-West Pacific region.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Thin-leaf fanweed ''[[Zonaria angustata]]'' (Kützing) Papenfuss (Elliston, South Australia, to Eden, New South Wales, and around Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Fanweed ''[[Zonaria turneriana]]'' J. Agardh (Geraldton, Western Australia, to Port Phillip Heads, Victoria, and around Tasmania. Also New Zealand.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Spiral fanweed ''[[Zonaria spiralis]]'' (J. Agardh) Papenfuss (Rottnest Island, Western Australia, to Flinders, Victoria.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Sydney fanweed ''[[Zonaria diesingiana]]'' J. Agardh (Green Cape to Coffs Harbour, New South Wales.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Peacockweed ''[[Lobophora variegata]]'' (Lamouroux) Womersley (Around Australia. Also widespread overseas.)
*Southern peacockweed ''[[Distromium flabellatum]]'' Womersley (Houtman Abrolhos, Western Australia, to Sydney, New South Wales, and northern and eastern Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Banded fanweed ''[[Stypopodium flabelliforme]]'' Weber-van Bosse (Tropical Australia south to Rottnest Island, Western Australia, and Jervis Bay, New South Wales. Also Lord Howe Island, and widespread in the Indo-West Pacific region.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Split fanweed ''[[Taonia australasica]]'' J. Agardh (Kangaroo Island, South Australia, to Coffs Harbour, New South Wales. Also Lord Howe Island.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />

Family [[Sporochnaceae]]
*Stackhouse’s seaweed ''[[Carpomitra costata]]'' (Stackhouse) Batters (Kangaroo Island, South Australia, to Port Stephens (New South Wales), and around Tasmania. Also widely distributed overseas.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />

*Open tuftweed ''[[Sporochnus radiciformis]]'' Turner (C. Agardh) (Rottnest Island, Western Australia, to Botany Bay, New South Wales, and around Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Spiky tuftweed ''[[Perithalia caudata]]'' (Labillardière) Womersley (West Bay, Kangaroo Island, South Australia, to Wilsons Promontory, Victoria, and around Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Clifton’s tuftweed ''[[Encyothalia cliftonii]]'' Harvey (Kalbarri, Western Australia, to Walkerville, Victoria.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Chimney-brush seaweed ''[[Bellotia eriophorum]]'' Harvey (Ceduna, South Australia, to Walkerville, Victoria, and around Tasmania. Also Noosa, Queensland.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />

Family [[Scytosiphonaceae]]

*Sinuous ballweed ''[[Colpomenia sinuosa]]'' (Mertens ex Roth) Derbes & Solier (Widespread around Australia and overseas.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Smooth ballweed ''[[Colpomenia peregrina]]'' (Sauvageau) Hamel (Albany, Western Australia, to Heron Island, Queensland, and around Tasmania. Also widely distributed overseas.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />

Family [[Punctariaceae]]
*Bulbous ballweed ''[[Asperococcus bullosus]]'' Lamouroux (Rottnest Island, Western Australia, to Port Stephens (New South Wales), and around Tasmania. Also widely distributed overseas.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />

Family [[Lessoniaceae]]

*Giant kelp ''[[Macrocystis pyrifera]]'' (Linnaeus) C. Agardh (Eastern, southern and western Tasmania. Also New Zealand, subantarctic islands, South America and the Pacific coast of North America.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Northern giant kelp, string kelp ''[[Macrocystis angustifolia]]'' Bory ([[Cape Jaffa]], South Australia, to Walkerville, Victoria, and northern Tasmania. Also South Africa.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />

Family [[Alariaceae]]

*Japanese kelp ''[[Undaria pinnatifida]]'' (Harvey) Suringar (Port Phillip Bay, Victoria, and D’Entrecasteaux Channel to Coles Bay, Tasmania. Also Japan, China, New Zealand and France.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />

Family [[Notheiaceae]]
*Neptune’s string ''[[Notheia anomala]]'' Harvey & Bailey (Albany, Western Australia, to Port Stephens (New South Wales), and around Tasmania. Also New Zealand.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />

Family [[Durvillaeaceae]]
*Bull kelp ''[[Durvillaea potatorum]]'' (Labillardière) Areschoug (Cape Jaffa, South Australia, to Bermagui, New South Wales, and western, southern and eastern Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />

Family [[Hormosiraceae]]

*Branched daggerweed ''[[Xiphophora chondrophylla]]'' (R. Brown ex Turner) Montagne ex Harvey  (Kangaroo Island, South Australia, to Walkerville, Victoria, and northern Tasmania. Also New Zealand.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Daggerweed ''[[Xiphophora gladiata]]'' (Labillardière) Montagne ex Kjellman (Western Port, Victoria, and eastern, western and southern Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />

Family [[Seirococcaceae]]
*Crayweed ''[[Phyllospora comosa]]'' (Labillardière) C. Agardh (Robe, South Australia, to Port Macquarie, New South Wales, and around Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Bristled crayweed ''[[Seirococcus axillaris]]'' (R. Brown ex Turner) Greville  (Fishery Bay, South Australia, to Walkerville, Victoria, and around Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Western crayweed ''[[Scytothalia dorycarpa]]'' (Turner) Greville (Geraldton, Western Australia, to Point Lonsdale, Victoria, and Georgetown, Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />

Family [[Cystoseiraceae]]

*Sawtooth seaweed ''[[Platythalia quercifolia]]'' (R. Brown ex Turner) Sonder  (Geraldton to Recherche Archipelago, Western Australia.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Three-node seaweed ''[[Cystoseira trinodis]]'' (Forsskål) C. Agardh  (Tropical Australia south to Victor Harbor, South Australia, and to Lake Conjola, New South Wales. Also Dunalley, Tasmania, and widespread overseas.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Three corners ''[[Hormophysa cuneiformis]]'' (Gmelin) Silva (Tropical Australia south to Mandurah, Western Australia, and Port Stephens (New South Wales), and northern Spencer Gulf, South Australia. Also widespread in the Indo-West Pacific region.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Serrated myriodesma ''[[Myriodesma serrulatum]]'' (Lamouroux) Decaisne (Dongara to Cape Riche, Western Australia.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Oak-leaf myriodesma ''[[Myriodesma quercifolium]]'' (Bory) J. Agardh (Geraldton, Western Australia, to Port Elliott, South Australia.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Brown fingerweed ''[[Scaberia agardhii]]'' Greville (Houtman Abrolhos, Western Australia, to Sydney, New South Wales, and northern Tasmania. Also Lord Howe Island.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Succulent seaweed ''[[Carpoglossum confluens]]'' (R. Brown ex Turner) Kützing (Elliston, South Australia, to Walkerville, Victoria, and around Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Flat-lobed cystophora ''[[Cystophora platylobium]]'' (Mertens) J. Agardh (Eucla, South Australia, to Sydney, New South Wales, and around Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />

*Shore cystophora ''[[Cystophora intermedia]]'' J. Agardh (Point Sinclair, South Australia, to Portland, Victoria, and Hogan Island, Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Greville’s cystophora ''[[Cystophora grevillei]]'' (C. Agardh ex Sonder) J. Agardh (Dongara, Western Australia, to Wilsons Promontory, Victoria, and around Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Tasmanian cystophora ''[[Cystophora xiphocarpa]]'' Harvey (Cape Otway, Victoria, and around Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Leafy cystophora ''[[Cystophora racemosa]]'' (Harvey ex Kützing) J. Agardh (Geographe Bay, Western Australia, to Queenscliff, Victoria.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Fishbone cystophora ''[[Cystophora pectinata]]'' (Greville & C. Agardh ex Sonder) J. Agardh (Perth, Western Australia, to Walkerville, Victoria.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />

*Brown’s cystophora ''[[Cystophora brownii]]'' (Turner) J. Agardh (Dongara, Western Australia, to Victor Harbor, South Australia, and Waterhouse Point, Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Womersley’s cystophora ''[[Cystophora gracilis]]'' Womersley (Cowaramup Bay, Western Australia, to Kangaroo Island, South Australia.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Western cystophora ''[[Cystophora harveyi]]'' Womersley (Geographe Bay to Walpole, Western Australia.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Club-leafed cystophora ''[[Cystophora torulosa]]'' (R. Brown ex Turner) J. Agardh (Apollo Bay to Wilsons Promontory, Victoria, and around Tasmania. Also New Zealand.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Open-branched cystophora ''[[Cystophora retorta]]'' (Mertens) J. Agardh (Nickol Bay, Western Australia, to Crookhaven Heads, New South Wales, and south to Spring Bay, Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Slender cystophora ''[[Cystophora siliquosa]]'' J. Agardh (Geographe Bay, Western Australia, to Wilsons Promontory, Victoria, and northern Tasmania.<ref name="Edgar 2008" />)
*Congested cystophora ''[[Cystophora congesta]]'' Womersley & Nizamuddin (Elliston, South Australia, to Wilsons Promontory, Victoria, and around Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Labillardière’s cystophora ''[[Cystophora retroflexa]]'' (Labillardière) J. Agardh  (Kangaroo Island, South Australia, to Sydney, New South Wales, and around Tasmania. Also New Zealand.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Bushy cystophora ''[[Cystophora subfarcinata]]'' (Mertens) J. Agardh (Nickol Bay, Western Australia, to Wilsons Promontory, Victoria, and around Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Awled cystophora ''[[Cystophora cuspidata]]'' J. Agardh (Point Sinclair, South Australia, to Port Phillip, Victoria, and northern Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Narrow grapeweed ''[[Caulocystis cephalornithos]]'' (Labillardière) Areschoug  (Cape Naturaliste, Western Australia, to Sydney, New South Wales, and around Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Grapeweed ''[[Caulocystis uvifera]]'' (C. Agardh) Areschoug (Shark Bay, Western Australia, to Sydney, New South Wales, and northern and eastern Tasmania. Also Norfolk Island.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Bushy tangleweed ''[[Acrocarpia paniculata]]'' (Turner) Areschoug (Ceduna, South Australia, to Port Stephens (New South Wales), and around Tasmania. Also Lord Howe Island.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />

Family [[Sargassaceae]]

*Lacerated sargassum ''[[Sargassum lacerifolium]]'' (Turner) C. Agardh (Pearson Island, South Australia, to Jervis Bay, New South Wales, and around Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />

==Phylum (Division) Rhodophyta==
(Red algae, red seaweeds)

Family [[Bangiaceae]]

*Red leatherstraps ''[[Gelinaria ulvoidea]]'' Sonder (Houtman Abrolhos, Western Australia, to Walkerville, Victoria, and northern Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Constricted wireweed ''[[Polyopes constrictus]]'' (Turner) J. Agardh (Sleaford Bay, South Australia, to Twofold Bay, New South Wales, and around Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Branched spongeweed ''[[Thamnoclonium dichotomum]]'' (J. Agardh) J. Agardh (Nickol Bay, Western Australia, to Ballina, New South Wales, and around Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />

Family [[Kallymeniaceae]]
*Pitted red lettuce ''[[Kallymenia cribrosa]]'' Harvey (Houtman Abrolhos, Western Australia, to Flinders, Victoria, and around Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Red lettuce ''[[Kallymenia tasmanica]]'' Harvey (Gulf St Vincent, South Australia, to Western Port, Victoria, and around Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />

*Tubular seagrass ''[[Syringodium isoetifolium]]'' (Ascherson) Dandy (Tropical Australia south to Garden Island, Western Australia, and to Moreton Bay, Queensland. Also widespread in the Indo-Pacific region.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Reef seagrass ''[[Thalassodendron pachyrhizum]]'' den Hartog (Geraldton to Bremer Bay, Western Australia.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Sea nymph, wireweed ''[[Amphibolis antarctica]]'' (Labillardière) Sonder & Ascherson ex Ascherson (Carnarvon, Western Australia, to Wilsons Promontory, Victoria, and south to Maria Island, Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Griffith’s sea nymph ''[[Amphibolis griffithii]]'' (J. Black) den Hartog (Champion Bay, Western Australia, to Victor Harbor, South Australia.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />

Family [[Zosteraceae]]
*Tasmanian eelgrass ''[[Heterozostera tasmanica]]'' (Martens ex Ascherson) den Hartog (Younghusband Peninsula, South Australia, to Wilsons Promontory, Victoria, and around Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Black-stemmed eelgrass ''[[Heterozostera nigricaulis]]'' Kuo (Dongara, Western Australia, to Port Stephens (New South Wales), and around Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*Mueller’s eelgrass ''[[Zostera muelleri]]'' Irmisch ex Ascherson (Perth, Western Australia, to southern Queensland and around Tasmania. Also New Zealand.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />

===Mangroves===
*Grey mangrove ''[[Avicennia marina]]'' (Forsskål) Vierhapper (Around mainland Australia. Also Lord Howe Island.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />
*River mangrove ''[[Aegiceras corniculatum]]'' (Linnaeus) Blanco (Tropical Australia south to Shark Bay, Western Australia, and to Merimbula, New South Wales. Also Lord Howe Island.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />

===Saltmarsh plants===
*Beaded glasswort ''[[Sarcocornia quinqueflora]]'' (Bunge ex Ungern-Sternberg) A.J. Scott (Around the Australian mainland and Tasmania.)<ref name="Edgar 2008" />

151.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2011}}
{{Use Australian English|date=October 2011}}
{{italic title}}
{{Taxobox
|name = Bushy clubmoss
| image = Lycopodium deuterodensum Gloucester Tops.jpg
|image_caption = Bushy Clubmoss near the [[Gloucester River]], [[Barrington Tops]], [[Australia]]
| regnum = [[Plant]]ae
| divisio = [[Lycopodiophyta]]
| classis = [[Lycopodiopsida]]
| ordo = [[Lycopodiales]]
| familia = [[Lycopodiaceae]]
| genus = ''[[Lycopodium]]''
| species = '''''L. deuterodensum'''''
| binomial = ''Lycopodium deuterodensum''
| binomial_authority = [[Wilhelm Gustav Franz Herter|Herter]]
|synonyms_ref=<ref name=r>[http://homepages.caverock.net.nz/~bj/fern/lycopodium.htm Family Lycopodiaceae, genus ''Lycopodium''; world species list]</ref><ref>[http://www.tropicos.org/Name/50050906 Tropicos, ''Lycopodium densum'' Labill.]</ref>
| synonyms =*''Lycopodium densum'' <small>Labill. 1806, illegitimate homonym not Lam. 1779</small>
*''Selaginella densa'' <small>(Labill.) Veitch 1873 not Sim. 1859</small> 
*''Lepidotis densa'' <small>Rothm.</small>
*''Lycopodium densum'' <small>Labill.</small>
*''Pseudolycopodium densu]'' <small>(Rothm.) Holub</small>
}}
'''''Lycopodium deuterodensum''''' known as the '''bushy clubmoss''' is an ancient plant occurring in [[Australia]] (all 6 states plus [[Northern Territory]]), [[New Caledonia]] and [[New Zealand]] ([[North Island of New Zealand|North Island]] and [[Chatham Island]]. It is a spore-bearing vascular plant and grows up to a metre high. It is found in a wide variety of situations, often in high rainfall areas on sandy soils.<ref>[http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Lycopodium~deuterodensum Plant Net New South Wales Flora Online, retrieved 24 September 2009]</ref><ref>[http://bie.ala.org.au/species/urn:lsid:biodiversity.org.au:apni.taxon:308094 Atlas of Living Australia]</ref>

|''Lycopodium curvifolium'' <small>Col. 1888 not Kunze (1835)</small>  
|''Lycopodium decurrens'' <small>Col. 1896 not R. Br (1810)</small>  
|''Austrolycopodium fastigiatum'' <small>(R. Br.) Holub</small>
|''Lycopodium scopulosum'' <small>Col.</small>
}}}}
'''''Lycopodium fastigiatum''''', commonly known as '''alpine club moss''' or '''mountain club moss''', is a species of [[club moss]] native to [[New Zealand]] and [[Australia]].<ref name=nzpcn>[http://www.nzpcn.org.nz/flora_details.aspx?ID=2194 New Zealand Plant Conservation Network: ''Lycopodium fastigiatum'']</ref><ref>[http://bie.ala.org.au/species/urn:lsid:biodiversity.org.au:apni.taxon:268881# Atlas of Living Australia]</ref> It has an upright, much branched and [[Pinophyta|conifer]]-like appearance, and can grow up to {{Convert|10|cm|0|abbr=on}} high.

''Lycopodium fastigiatum'' is widespread across New Zealand including [[Stewart Island|Stewart]], [[Chatham Islands|Chatham]], [[Adams Island, New Zealand|Adams]], [[Auckland Islands|Auckland]], and [[Campbell Islands]]. It has also been found in the Australian States of [[Tasmania]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], and [[New South Wales]]. It grows in mountainous, alpine areas to scrubland. In cold conditions it can have a bright orange appearance.<ref name=TERRAIN>{{cite web|title=Lycopodium fastigiatum|url=http://www.terrain.net.nz/friends-of-te-henui-group/club-mosses/lycopodium-fastigiatum.html|publisher=Taranaki Educational Resource: Research, Analysis and Information Network|accessdate=2012-05-13}}</ref>

'''''Lycopodium scariosum''''', commonly known as '''spreading clubmoss''' or '''creeping club moss''' is a native [[club moss]] of [[Australia]], [[New Zealand]] and [[Borneo]].<ref>[http://bie.ala.org.au/species/urn:lsid:biodiversity.org.au:apni.taxon:308095# Atlas of Living Australia, ''Lycopodium scariosum'' G.Forst., Spreading Clubmoss]</ref><ref>T.E.R:R.A.I.N - Taranaki Educational Resource: Research, Analysis and Information Network (New Zealand), ''Lycopodium scariosum'' (Creeping club moss)</ref><ref name=j>[http://homepages.caverock.net.nz/~bj/fern/lycopodium.htm Family Lycopodiaceae, genus ''Lycopodium''; world species list by Michael Hassler and Brian Swale]</ref>

''Lycopodium scariosum'' has stems that lie on the ground, are multi branched and can grow to 2 metres long. The leaves are flat and can be up to 4 millimetres long.<ref name=terrain>{{cite web|title=Creeping club moss (Lycopodium scariosum)|url=http://www.terrain.net.nz/friends-of-te-henui-group/club-mosses/creeping-club-moss-lycopodium-scariosum.html|publisher=Taranaki Educational Resource: Research, Analysis and Information Network|accessdate=2012-05-19}}</ref>

154.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Taxobox | image = Lysiana_exocarpi_flower.jpg | image_caption = | image_alt = Lysiana exocarpi | regnum = [[Plant]]ae | unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] | unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] | ordo = [[Santalales]] | familia = [[Loranthaceae]] | genus = ''[[Lysiana]]'' | genus_authority = [[Tiegh.]] | species = '''''L. exocarpi''''' | binomial = ''Lysiana exocarpi'' | binomial_authority = ([[Hans Hermann Behr|Behr]]) [[Philippe Édouard Léon Van Tieghem|Tiegh.]] | subdivision_ranks = Subspecies | subdivision = ''L. exocarpi'' subsp. ''exocarpi''
''L. exocarpi'' subsp. ''tenuis'' | synonyms = *''Elytranthe exocarpi'' [[Hans Hermann Behr|Behr]] *''Loranthus angustifolius'' [[Robert Brown (botanist, born 1773)|R.Br.]]Blakely, W.F. (1922). The Loranthaceae of Australia. Part i. From the Proceedings of the Linnean Society of New South Wales, 1922, Vol. xlvii., Part 1, 29 March 1922. *''Loranthus exocarpi'' [[Hans Hermann Behr|Behr]]Danser, B.H. (1929) On the Taxonomy and the nomenclature of the Loranthaceae of Asia and Australia. Bulletin du Jardin Botanique de Buitenzorg, Serie III. Vol. X. Livr 3. Nov. 1929. p.342 }} '''''Lysiana exocarpi''''', commonly known as '''harlequin mistletoe''', is a species of [[Parasitic plant|hemiparasitic]] shrub, [[Endemism|endemic]] to Australia. It is in the [[Gondwana]]n family [[Loranthaceae]] and is probably the most [[Derived trait|derived]] genus of that family with 12 pairs of chromosomes.Barlow, B.A. (1984). Loranthaceae. In Flora of Australia and New Zealand. (Ed. A.S. George) Australian Government Publishing Service: Canberra. Vol 22, p.80. The Loranthaceae is the most diverse family in the [[Mistletoes|mistletoe]] group with over 900 species worldwide and including the best known species in Australia.Watson, D. (2011). ''Mistletoes of Southern Australia'',ISBN 9780643095939, CSIRO Publishing, p.9. Mistletoes are notable for their relationships with other species. In an early reference to the group in Australia [[Allan Cunningham (botanist)|Allan Cunningham]] explorer and first Director{{cite web|url=http://www.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/welcome/quick_links/our_history|title=Royal Botanic Garden - History and Facts|work=Royal Botanic Garden}} of the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Sydney]], wrote in 1817: "The Bastard Box{{cite web|url=http://bastardboxwine.wordpress.com/about|title=About|work=Bastardboxwine's Blog}} is frequently much encumbered with the twining adhering ''Loranthus aurantiacus''http://plants.jstor.org/specimen/bm001015700history=true (box mistletoe) which 'Scorning the soil, aloft she springs, Shakes her red plumes and claps her golden wings'."Robinson, L.(1994). Field Guide to the Native Plants of Sydney, 2nd Edition, Kangaroo Press, p.345. == Description == Spreading to shrub, [[Glabrousness|glabrous]]; no external runners. Leaves flat or compressed when very narrow, linear to narrow-oblong, [[Sessility (zoology)|sessile]] or the wider leaves shortly [[Petiole (botany)|petiolate]], 3–15 cm long, 1–10 mm wide, apex is usually rounded, base [[attenuate]] - contracted, [[Leaf#Venation (arrangement of the veins)|venation]] is obscure; shortly petiolate. [[Inflorescence]] pedunculate usually a 2-flowered [[umbel]]; peduncle usually 0.5–2 mm in length; pedicels 2–5 mm long; bracts 1–1.5 mm long. Corolla 25–50 mm long,is usually red, rarely yellow, can also be tipped with green or black. Fruit [[ellipsoidal]] to [[ovoid]], 6–10 mm long, red or black.{{cite web|url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Lysiana~exocarpi|title=PlantNET - FloraOnline|publisher=}} === Subspecies === ==== ''L. exocarpi'' subsp. ''exocarpi'' ==== Leaves are linear to narrow-oblong or narrow-elliptic and occasionally [[obcordate]], 3–10 mm wide, often thick or leathery at maturity. Plant spreading to pendent. Mostly [[parasitic]] on species of ''[[Acacia]]'', [[Alectryon (plant)|''Alectryon'']], ''[[Amyema]]'', [[Cassia (legume)|''Cassia'']], [[Casuarinaceae]], [[Eremophila (plant)|''Eremophila'']], ''[[Exocarpos]]'', and exotic trees, west from [[Moree, New South Wales|Moree]] district.{{cite web|url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=in&name=Lysiana~exocarpi~subsp.+exocarpi|title=PlantNET - FloraOnline|publisher=}} Synonym: ''L. exocarpi'' subsp. ''diamantinensis''Barlow, B.A. (1966). A revision of the Loranthaceae of Australia and New Zealand. Australian Journal of Botany, 1966,p.443. ==== ''L. exocarpi'' subsp. ''tenuis'' ==== Leaves linear, 1–3 mm wide, not terete but sometimes compresses. Plant is pendent. It is found in open woodland and forest, usually on species of Casuarinaceae, north from the [[Hunter Valley]]{{cite web|url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=in&name=Lysiana~exocarpi~subsp.+tenuis|title=PlantNET - FloraOnline|publisher=}} First described by Blakely and revised by Barlow.Blakely, W.F.(1925) Proceedings of the Linnean Society, New South Wales 50:8,t.5a. === Habitat and distribution === [[File:Lysiana exocarpi on Pittosporum angustifolium.jpg|thumbnail|left|''Lysiana exocarpi'' on ''Pittosporum angustifolium'' Mungo Walls of China]] ''Lysiana'' species can be broadly grouped into those that have 80-90 units of DNA and those that have greater than 100 units. ''L. exocarpi'' is the only species that extends its range into temperate non-arid regions, with DNA values predominantly above 100, the average being 117 units.Martin, N.(1983) Nuclear DNA Variation in the Australasian Loranthaceae in ''The Biology of Mistletoes'', eg. Calder, M. & Bernhardt, P., Academic Press Australia, North Ryde. p.286 [[File:Lysiana exocarpi and subspecies distribution.jpg|thumbnail|L-R Occurrences of ''L. exocarpi''; ''L. exocarpi'' subsp. ''exocarpi''; ''L. exocarpi'' subsp. ''tenuis''[http://www.ala.org.au An amalgam of maps from ''Atlas of Living Australia'']]] Open woodland and forest, extending into [[semi-arid]] woodlands dominated by acacia.Watson, D. (2011). ''Mistletoes of Southern Australia'', CSIRO Publishing, p.82. ''L. exocarpi:'' Occurs in arid and temperate regions of all mainland States, from Lake Carnegie, W.A, to the Hunter Valley, NSW, in open forest and woodland on many different hosts but frequently on other Loranthaceae. ''L. exocarpi'' subsp. ''exocarpi'': Occurs in arid and temperate Australia from Lake Carnegie, Q.A., to western Qld and central Vic; on many host species, most frequently on ''[[Acacia]]'', ''[[Amyema]]'', ''[[Cassia (legume)|Cassia]]'', [[Casuarinaceae]], ''[[Eremophila (plant)|Eremophila]]'', ''[[Exocarpos]]'', ''[[Alectryon (plant)|Alectryon]]'' and exotic trees. A [[Polymorphism (biology)|polymorphic]] subspecies, with a cline towards wider and thicker leaves from temperate to arid habitats. ''L. exocarpi'' subsp. ''tenuis:'' Occurs in Qld and NSW from the [[Darling Downs]] to the Hunter Valley and inland to the Western Plains, in open woodland and forest, usually on [[Casuarinaceae]].Barlow, B.A. Loranthaceae. In Flora of Australia, ed. A.S. George. Australian Government Publications Service. Vol 22, pp 67-130. == Life Cycle == [[File:Lysiana exocarpi red and black berries.jpg|thumbnail|right|''Lysiana exocarpi'' fruit]] [[File:Lysiana exocarpi on Box Mistletoe Kinchega National Park.jpg|thumbnail|left|''Lysiana exocarpi'' on ''Amyema miquelii'' (box mistletoe), Kinchega National Park]][[File:Lysiana exocarpi germinating seed.jpg|thumbnail|right|''Lysiana exocarpi'' germinating seed dispersed by mistletoe bird]] [[File:Dicaeum hirundinaceum -near Lake Ginninderra, Canberra, Australia -male-8 (1).jpg|thumbnail|left|Mistletoe bird]] === Flowering and germination === Flowering occurs mainly in summer. Charles Brittlebank (1908) noted that germination "usually takes place in one to two days, but may be delayed in some cases for a period of 50 days".Lamont, B.(1983). Germination of Mistletoes in The Biology of Mistletoes, ed. Calder, M. & Bernhardt, P. Academic Press Australia, North Ryde, p.134. === Fire responses === Life span - 4 to 20 years. First seeds - 2 to 3 years. Adult fire response - greater than a 70% mortality when subject to total leaf scorch. Resprouting - none.{{cite web|url=http://www.landmanager.org.au/#sort=sort_title%20asc&nid=526150|title=Land Manager - Northern Land Manager|publisher=}} === Parasitism === Mistletoes generally have green or green-yellow coloured leaves and stems and [[photosynthesise]]. However, they use the water supply of the host plant and the water-soluble nutrients in the water (sap). For this reason, they are considered to be semi-parasites. Attachment to the host plant is by means of one or more woody absorbing organs ([[haustoria]]). This organ effectively replaces the root system of a normal plant, and extends through the bark layers of the host and into the young wood zone, where most of the water transport occurs.{{cite web|last=Bishop|first= G. |year=2010|title= Briefing note on the importance of mistletoe and its effect of on regional biodiversity conservation|work= Department of Environment and Heritage South Australia|url= http://www.nynrm.sa.gov.au/portals/7/pdf/reports/briefing_paper-mistletoe.pdf|format=PDF}} Mistletoes often have foliage that [[Mimicry in plants|mimics]] the host plant.{{cite web|work=Southern New England Landcare |year=2008|title= Methods to Manage Mistletoe|url= http://brg.cma.nsw.gov.au/uploads/Books/MethodsManageMistletoe.pdf|format=PDF}} ''Lysiana exocarpi'' is known to ''epiparastise''{{cite web|url=http://www.anbg.gov.au/mistletoe/epiparasitism.html|title=Epiparasitism - Mistletoes|publisher=}} other mistletoes, namely ''[[Amyema]]'' species: ''A. maidenii'', ''A. miquelii'' (box mistletoe), ''A. quandang''Downey, P. (1998). An inventory of host species for each aerial mistletoe species (Loranthaceae and Viscaceae) in Australia. Cunninghamia Vol. 5(3): 685-720. === Host plants === In New South Wales the most common hosts are species of ''Eucalyptus'' and ''Acacia'' and also ''Flindersia'', ''Pittosporum'', ''Santalum''May, V. (1941). A Survey of the Mistletoe of New South Wales. from the Proceedings of the Linnean Society of New South Wales, Vol. lxvi, Partrs 1-2, 1941: pp, 77-87. In a comprehensive study of Australian herbaria specimens, Paul Downey found that the host plants for Australian mistletoes were mostly [[dicotyledonous]] angiosperms with a small number of [[gymnosperms]] in the genera ''[[Araucaria]]'', ''[[Callitris]]'' and ''[[Pinus]]''. No host species were herbaceous. Every host family and genus recorded contained species which were not documented as mistletoe host species. The two major genera of host species were ''Eucalyptus'' and ''Acacia'' with 2084, and 2559 records respectively. There were 187 species of ''Eucalyptus'' and 150 species of ''Acacia''. Seven mistletoe species commonly parasitised exotic host species including ''L. exocarpi''. The commonly recorded exotic host species included ''[[Nerium oleander]]'', ''[[Citrus]]'' spp., ''[[Prunus]]'' spp., ''[[Schinus molle]]'' and ''[[Quercus]]'' spp. ''L. exocarpi'' was found in 901 records and 109 species. The host families were [[Apocynaceae]], [[Caesalpiniaceae]], [[Capparaceae]], [[Casuarinaceae]], [[Chenopodiaceae]], [[Fabaceae]], [[Fagaceae]], [[Loranthaceae]], [[Malvaceae]], [[Meliaceae]], [[Mimosaceae]], [[Moraceae]], [[Myoporaceae]], [[Myrtaceae]], [[Oleaceae]], [[Pittosporaceae]], [[Polygonaceae]], [[Proteaceae]], [[Rhamnaceae]], [[Rutaceae]], [[Santalaceae]], [[Sapindaceae]], [[Solanaceae]] and [[Zygophyllaceae]]. In a 1990 study of ''L. exocarpi'' subsp. ''exocarpi'' in Southern South Australia, Yan found that this species showed a specific preference for ''[[Alectryon oleifolius]]'' and ''[[Myoporum platycarpum]]'' supporting Barlow's view that all Australian mistletoes of open forest and woodland are host specific to some extent. He also found that rainfall was a determining factor in regulating the distribution.Yan, Z. (1990). Host Specificity of Lysiana exocarpi subsp. exocarpi and Other Mistletoes in Southern South Australia. Australian Journal of Botany, 1990. 38:475-86. === Insect and animal associations === Interactions between mistletoes and animals have long been noted and were used by [[Charles Darwin]] as early exemplars of evolutionary adaptation with [[Carl Linnaeus]] credited as the first to describe the mistletoe life cycle. [[Pliny the Elder]] had recorded similar observations some 1600 years earlier. Most species of mistletoe are dispersed by animals, chiefly birds and this close relationship has been treated as a model system in the study of fruit dispersal generally. Many insects pollinate mistletoes primarily in the [[Coleoptera]], [[Diptera]], [[Hymenoptera]] and [[Lepidoptera]].Watson, D.(2001). Mistletoe - A Keystone Resource in Forests and Woodlands Worldwide. Annual Review of Ecology and Systematics 32:219–49 At least 27 species of Australian butterflies use mistletoes as their host plant. The two groups are the jezebels ([[Pieridae]]) and azures ([[Lycaenidae]]). Upon hatching, the caterpillars subsist and grow entirely on the foliage. Although some species drop off to pupate in the ground beneath, most remain in the clump attaching their chrysalis to the tips of denuded twigs or burrowing into the junction between mistletoe and the host tree to evade predators. ''L. exocarpi'' is a host plant for ''Ogyris aenone''{{cite web|url=http://lepidoptera.butterflyhouse.com.au/lyca/aenone.html|title=Ogyris aenone|publisher=}} and is a popular food plant for nectar feeding birds when in full flower.Watson, D. (2011). ''Mistletoes of Southern Australia'', CSIRO Publishing The mistletoe fruit is a single-seeded berry, often brightly coloured, with striking adaptations for bird dispersal, germination and attachment. Under the outer coat of the fruit is a sticky layer of viscin, which is rich in glucose, and which envelops the seed. Birds which feed on the fruits often have specialized feeding behaviour, swallowing the seed whole after squeezing it from the fruit coat. Birds have been reported nipping the end off the fruit, as though removing a cap, prior to squeezing out the seed. Notable dispersal agents are the mistletoebird (''[[Mistletoebird|Dicaeum hirundinaceum]]''),{{cite web|url=http://www.anbg.gov.au/mistletoe|work=Australian National Herbarium|title= Exploring the World of Mistletoes}} and some honeyeaters in Australia (''[[painted honeyeater|Grantiella]]'', ''[[spiny-cheeked honeyeater|Acanthagenys]]'', ''[[striped honeyeater|Plectorhyncha]]'') == Ethnobotany == === Bushfood === According to [[Les Hiddins]], Aboriginal people would eat the fruit without chewing so they wouldn't stick to the tongue.Hiddins, L. (1999). Explore Wild Australia with the Bush Tucker Man. ABC Books. p.151 The ripeness of the berry is indicated not only by its softness, but often also by a slight translucence. When quite ripe the sticky, gelatinous, sweet pulp surrounding the single seed is pleasant to eat, but its great stickiness often make the seed almost impossible to spit out. Birds have the same difficulty and may sometimes be seen wiping their beaks free of seeds against the branch of a tree.Cribb, A.B. & J.W. (1976). Wild Food in Australia. Fontana Books. p. 43 Jennifer Isaacs lists berries of ''L. exocarpi'' and ''L.spathulata'' as being eaten in the Central desertIsaacs, J.(1987). Bushfood: Aboriginal food and herbal medicine. Lansdowne Publishing, Sydney. p.225 Peter Latz notes that the calories obtained would be rather low. Aborigines often pluck whole branches from the tree and pick off the berries at their leisure. These berries are particularly favored by children. Although all Aboriginal groups have two or more names for mistletoes, it appears that they do not give separate names to each species. The [[Warlpiri language|Walpiri]] word for both ''L. murrayi'' and ''L. spathulata'' is ''pawurlirri''.Latz, P. (1995). Bushfire and Bush Tucker.IAD Press, Alice Springs. p.127 The [[Antakirinja]] people around [[Coober Pedy]] call the berries of ''L. exocarpi'' Ngantja.{{cite web|url=http://bush-tucker.tripod.com/html/parka-parka.html|title=Parka-Parka and Nyinkini|publisher=}} Reference to the fruit was first contained in a letter written by [[Governor Gawler]] during an ill-fated expedition in 1839 led by [[Charles Sturt]]. Gawler to his brother-in-law, Henry Cox, 20 December 1839: "The poor boy (Henry Bryan) accompanied me most cheerfully, he had been resting all day and did not appear to suffer from the subsequent exertion. He brought me the pulpy but bitter fruit of the mesembryantheumum and the little berries of the exocarpi - and ate plenty of them himself - he made many observations about our course, appearing to recollect its striking features well, and calculated our distances with much precision".[http://www.murrayriver.com.au/pdf/Mt_Bryan_Booklet_PrintFile.pdf Charles Sturt Museum Disappearance of Henry Bryan Trail booklet] === Medicinal === [[File:Lysianadioic acid structure.jpg|thumbnail|left|Lysianadioic acid structure]] In Europe mistletoe leaves and young twigs are used by herbalists, especially in Germany, for treating circulatory and respiratory system problems. Mistletoe extract is sold as Iscador, Helixor, and several other trade names. Use of mistletoe extract in the treatment of cancer originated with Rudolf Steiner, the founder of Anthroposophy. He compared the parasitic nature of the mistletoe plant to that of cancer, and believed that cancer represents a faltering of the body's spiritual defenses. Public interest in the United States was spurred in 2001 following actress Suzanne Somers' decision to use Iscador in lieu of chemotherapy following her treatment for breast cancer. Available clinical evidence, however, does not support claims of anti-cancer effect, quality of life, or other outcomes from the use of mistletoe extract.[[Mistletoe]] In 2007 researchers from [[Griffith University]] in Queensland found that a new natural product, lysianadioic acid, isolated from ''Lysiana subfalcata''(in the same genusOther species in the genus were not tested (''personal communication'')) was a carboxypeptidase B (CPB) inhibitor. It is a potent inhibitor of CPB with an IC50 of 0.36 lM. This is the ﬁrst known example of a small molecule CPB inhibitor isolated from plant origin.Buchanan, M.S.et al. Lysianadioic acid, a carboxypeptidase B inhibitor from Lysiana subfalcata ''Bio-organic & Medicinal Chemistry'' Letters 18 (2008) 1495–1497 == History == [[File:Lysiana exocarpi Olive Pink sketch.jpg|thumbnail|[[Olive Pink]] sketch 1930]] [[File:Loranthus exocarpi Behr.jpeg|thumbnail|Specimen type collected by Hans Herman Behr in Barossa 1844-45, published in Proceedings of the Linnean Society, NSW, 1925]] ''L. exocarpi'' was first collected from Spencer's Gulf in 1802 by [[Robert Brown (botanist, born 1773)|Robert Brown]].{{cite web|url=http://plants.jstor.org/specimen/bm001015703?history=true|title=Edit History: Type of Loranthus angustifolius R.Br. ex Benth. [family LORANTHACEAE] on JSTOR|publisher=}} It was first described as ''Loranthus exocarpi'' by [[Hans Hermann Behr]] in 1847Linnaea (1847),20, p. 647 after his first visit to Australia 1844-45. Behr was the first botanist to systematically collect and study the flora of the [[Barossa Ranges|Barossa Range]], mallee scrubs towards the River Marne and areas adjacent to the [[River Murray]] at Moorundie. [[Dietrich von Schlechtendal|Dietrich von Schlechtendahl]] treated 200 plants collected by Behr, of which he described 62 as being new species: a further five, including ''Loranthus exocarpi'' were described by Behr.Kraehenbuehl, D.(1981). Dr H.H. Behr's two visits to South Australia in 1844-45 and 1848-49. Journal of the Adelaide Botanic Gardens, 3(1): page 107. In 1894 [[Philippe Édouard Léon Van Tieghem]] published a revision of ''Loranthus'' and created a new genus ''Lysiana''. The name is based on the Greek ''lyo'' - "I set free" - referring to the separation of the genus from ''Loranthus''.Bulletin Société botanique de France 41: 1894. p.599. ==Notes== {{Reflist|group="note"}} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{commonscatinline}} {{taxonbar}} [[Category:Loranthaceae]] [[Category:Flora of Australia]] [[Category:Parasitic plants]] [[Category:Plants described in 1847]]
154.title: Lysiana exocarpi

155.text:
[[File:Eucalyptus stricta - Woodford.jpg|thumb|upright=1.4|Typical form of a mallee, ''[[Eucalyptus stricta]]'']]
'''Mallee''' is the growth [[Habit (biology)|habit]] of certain [[eucalypt]] species that grow with multiple stems springing from an underground [[lignotuber]], usually to a height of no more than {{convert|10|m}}.<ref name="ANBG">{{cite web | title = Habit of Eucalypts | work = Euclid | url = http://www.anbg.gov.au/cpbr/cd-keys/Euclid/sample/html/habit.htm | accessdate = 2007-05-06 | publisher = [[Australian National Botanic Gardens]]}}</ref> It is most common in plants of the [[genus]] ''[[Eucalyptus]]'', many of which naturally grow in a mallee habit, and some of which grow as single-stemmed [[tree]]s initially but recover in mallee form if burnt to the ground by [[bushfire]]. It also occurs in the closely related genera ''[[Corymbia]]'' and ''[[Angophora]]''. The word ''mallee'' may also be used as a [[noun]] in reference to species or individual plants with a mallee habit.

Mallees are the dominant vegetation throughout semi-arid areas of [[Australia]] with reliable winter rainfall. Within this area, they form extensive woodlands and shrublands covering over {{convert|250000|km2}}.<ref name="ANRA">{{cite web | title = Mallee woodlands and shrublands | work = Australian National Resources Atlas | url = http://audit.ea.gov.au/anra/vegetation/docs/Native_vegetation/vegfsheet-mvg14_low.pdf |accessdate=6 May 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20031001070540/http://audit.ea.gov.au/anra/vegetation/docs/Native_vegetation/vegfsheet-mvg14_low.pdf |archivedate=1 October 2003}}</ref> Thus [[mallee woodlands and shrublands]] are considered one of Australia's [[Major Vegetation Group]]s.<ref name="ANRA"/>

Widespread mallee species include:
* ''[[Eucalyptus dumosa|E. dumosa]]'' (white mallee)
* ''[[Eucalyptus socialis|E. socialis]]'' (red mallee)
* ''[[Eucalyptus gracilis|E. gracilis]]'' (yorrell)
* ''[[Eucalyptus oleosa|E. oleosa]]'' (red mallee)
* ''[[Eucalyptus incrassata|E. incrassata]]'' (ridge-fruited mallee)
* ''[[Eucalyptus diversifolia|E. diversifolia]]'' (soap mallee)

The [[malleefowl]] is a [[bird]] characteristic of this habitat.

An example of a mallee in a high-rainfall area is the rare yellow-top mallee ash, ''[[Eucalyptus luehmanniana]]''.

==See also==

The '''Resinous Kamala ''',<ref>http://www.flowersofindia.net/catalog/slides/Buckthorn-Leaved%20Kamala.html</ref> ('''''Mallotus resinosus''''') is a species of 12m tall shrub, evergreen [[plant]] in the [[Euphorbiaceae]] family. It is native to [[India]], [[Sri Lanka]]  to [[New Guinea]] and [[Australia]].<ref>http://www.biotik.org/india/species/m/mallrham/mallrham_en.html</ref> The plant is known as "கருவாளிச்சீ / karuvalichchi" by Tamil people.

==Leaves==
elliptic to obovate; base attenuate; margin serrate.<ref>http://indiabiodiversity.org/species/show/263250</ref>

==Flowers==
Inflorescence - present, where male flowers are clustered and unbranched. Female flowers are also unbrnanched, but with 3 locules and few short spines.<ref>http://www.flowersofindia.net/catalog/slides/Resinous%20Kamala.html</ref>

==Fruits==
globose seeded capsule.<ref>http://keys.trin.org.au/key-server/data/0e0f0504-0103-430d-8004-060d07080d04/media/Html/taxon/Mallotus_resinosus.htm</ref>

==Chemistry==
Scientists found a simple [[coumarin]], called [[Scopoletin]] from the root extraction of resinous kamala. It was identified as the active principle responsible for DNA cleavage activity during the extraction process. The chemical was once thought that only found within plants of genus ''[[Scolopia]]''<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=15387675 | doi=10.1021/np040129c | volume=67 | title=A coumarin from Mallotus resinosus that mediates DNA cleavage. | date=Sep 2004 | journal=J Nat Prod | pages=1614–6}}</ref>

159.text:
{{italictitle}}
{{taxobox
|name= Prickly bottlebrush
|status =
|status_system = 
|image = Melaleuca brachyandra.jpg
|image caption = ''M. brachyandra'' growing in [[Morgan, South Australia|Morgan]]
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. brachyandra'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca brachyandra''
|binomial_authority = ([[John Lindley|Lindl.]]) [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
|synonyms = ''[[Callistemon brachyandrus]]'' {{small|[[John Lindley|Lindl.]] }}{{br}}
}}

'''''Melaleuca brachyandra''''' commonly known as '''prickly bottlebrush''' or '''scarlet bottlebrush''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to  [[New South Wales]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] and [[South Australia]] in [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state herbaria continue to use the name ''Callistemon brachyandrus''.)<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> It is a shrub or small tree with narrow leaves and showy red and green flowers making it an ideal ornamental plant in temperate areas.

==Description==
''Melaleuca brachyandra'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|1.5-8|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with hard bark and a rigid habit. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|18-61|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|0.5-1.7|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, linear in shape, kidney-shaped in cross section and with the end tapering to a sharp point.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=93}}</ref><ref name=plantnet>{{cite web|title=''Callistemon brachyandrus''|url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Callistemon~brachyandrus|publisher=Royal Botanic Garden Sydney: PlantNet|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref>

The flowers are arranged in spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering. The spikes are up to {{convert|35|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with 7 to 36 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|2.8-4.9|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages. There are 50 to 84 [[stamen]]s in each flower, with their "stalks" (the filaments) rich crimson and "tips" (the anthers) green. Flowering occurs from September to January and is followed by fruits which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|9-12.4|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name="plantnet"/>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca brachyandra'' was first formally described in 2006 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Novon]]''.<ref name=APNI(1)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca brachyandra''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/613685|publisher=APNI|accessdate=1 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=Novon>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=New Combinations in Melaleuca for Australian Species of Callistemon (Myrtaceae)|journal=Novon|date=2006|volume=16|issue=4|pages=468–475|url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.3417/1055-3177%282006%2916%5B468%3ANCIMFA%5D2.0.CO%3B2|accessdate=11 June 2015|doi=10.3417/1055-3177(2006)16[468:ncimfa]2.0.co;2}}</ref> It had previously been known as ''Callistemon brachyandrus'' since [[John Lindley]] described it in 1849 in ''[[Journal of the Horticultural Society of London]]''.<ref name=lindley>{{cite journal|last1=Lindley|first1=John|title=New Plants etc. from the Society's Garden|journal=Journal of the Horticultural Society of London|date=1849|volume=4|pages=112–113|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/37849#page/122/mode/1up|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=APNI(2)>{{cite web|title=''Callistemon brachyandrus''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/521877|publisher=APNI|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''brachyandra'') is from the [[Ancient Greek]]  ''brachys'' meaning “short”<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref>{{rp|161}} and ''andros'' meaning "male"<ref name="RWB" />{{rp|509}} referring to the length of the stamens being shorter than the styles.<ref name="Brophy" />

''Callistemon brachyandrus'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca brachyandra'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref name '"WCSP">{{WCSP | 31412 | ''Callistemon brachyandrus'' }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca brachyandra'' occurs in scattered inland areas of New South Wales, mostly commonly in the [[Cobar]] district.<ref name="plantnet" /> It also occurs in the lower [[Murray River]] districts of north-western Victoria and south-eastern South Australia.

==Use in horticulture==
Although it has prickly leaves, the attractive flower spikes of ''M. brachyandra'' make it a suitable ornamental for temperate gardens.<ref name="Brophy" /> It is usually more resistant to pests than other species of the former ''Callistemon''.<ref name=anbg>{{cite web|title=''Callistemon brachyandrus''|url=https://www.anbg.gov.au/gnp/gnp5/cal-brac.html|publisher=Australian National Botanic Garden|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> It prefers well-drained soil in a sunny situation.<ref name=Wrigley>{{cite book|last1=Wrigley|first1=John W.|last2=Fagg|first2=Murray|title=Australian native plants : a manual for their propagation, cultivation and use in landscaping|date=1983|publisher=Collins|location=Sydney|isbn=0002165759|page=191|edition=2nd}}</ref>

==References==
