160.text:
{{Speciesbox
|name=Mallee honey-myrtle
|image=Melaleuca brevifolia.jpg
|image_caption= ''M. brevifolia'' growing near the [[Coorong, South Australia|Coorong]]
|taxon=Melaleuca brevifolia
|authority=[[Nikolai Turczaninow|Turcz.]]<ref name="APNI" />
}}
'''''Melaleuca brevifolia''''', commonly known as '''mallee honey-myrtle''', '''short-leaf honey-myrtle''', or '''d'Alton's melaleuca''' is a shrub or tree in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]], and is [[Indigenous (ecology)|native]] to western [[Victoria, Australia|Victoria]], south-eastern [[South Australia]] and the south-west of [[Western Australia]]. It is a shrub with rough, corky bark and a large number of heads of white to yellowish flowers on the previous season's growth. It is a moderately hardy garden plant.

==Description==
''Melaleuca brevifolia'' is a [[shrub]], rarely a [[tree]], growing to a height of {{convert|4|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} with rough, corky [[bark]]. Its branches and [[Leaf|leaves]] are [[Glabrousness|glabrous]] except when young. Its leaves are [[Phyllotaxis|arranged]] in pairs, sometimes in threes and are {{convert|2.4-8|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|0.7-1.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, linear to lance-shaped with the thinner end at the base and have blunt tips. On their lower surface there are two rows of raised oil glands.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|page=97|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517}}</ref>

The [[flower]]s are white to yellowish and are arranged in heads on the previous season's growth. Each head is up to {{convert|18|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and contains up to six individual flowers. The stamens are arranged in five bundles around the flowers with 10 to 12 stamens in each bundle. The main flowering season is in spring and the fruits that follow are wrinkled, cup-shaped [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]] {{convert|3.3-4.2|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and wide.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas: a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=34–35|edition=2nd}}</ref><ref name=Victoria>{{cite web|title=Mallee Honey-myrtle|url=http://vro.depi.vic.gov.au/dpi/vro/vrosite.nsf/pages/water_sss_mallee_honeymyrtle|publisher=State Government of Victoria, Department of Environment and Primary Industries|accessdate=1 May 2015}}</ref>

==Taxonomy==
''Melaleuca brevifolia'' was first formally described in 1852 by [[Nikolai Turczaninow]] in ''Repertorium Botanices Systematicae''.<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca brevifolia''|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/509209|publisher=APNI|accessdate=1 March 2015}}</ref><ref name=Bulletin>{{cite journal|last1=Turczaninow|first1=Nikolai|title=Myrtaceae Xerocarpicae in Nova Hollandia|journal=Bulletin de la classe physico-mathematique de l'Academie Imperiale des sciences de Saint-Petersburg|date=1852|volume=10|page=342|url=http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?q1=brevifolia;id=hvd.32044106338122;view=image;start=1;sz=10;page=root;size=100;seq=183;num=191|accessdate=1 May 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''brevifolia'') from the [[Latin]] ''brevis'' meaning "short"<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.|page = 708}}</ref> and ''folia'' meaning "leaves"<ref name="RWB" />{{rp|466}} referring to the small leaves.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in the [[Mallee (Victoria)|Mallee]], [[Shire of Loddon|Loddon]] and [[Wimmera]] regions of Victoria,<ref name=Victoria/> the south-east of South Australia<ref name=environment.sa>{{cite web|last1=Foulkes|first1=J.N.|last2=Heard|first2=L.M.B.|title=South East Biological Survey:  Conclusions and conservation recommendations|url=http://www.environment.sa.gov.au/files/5abc287c-3f26-457b-be24-9e3001189c41/southeast_pt1.pdf|publisher=Government of South Australia:Department of Environment, Water and Natural Resources|accessdate=1 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=Forestry>{{cite web|last1=Horn|first1=Troy|title=Draft revised management plant:Deadmans Swamp Native Forest Reerve|url=https://www.forestry.sa.gov.au/portals/0/publications/nfrmgtplans/gt/nfr004_deadmansswamp.pdf|publisher=Government of South Australia:Forestry|accessdate=1 May 2015}}</ref> and the south-west of Western Australia in the [[Avon Wheatbelt]], [[Esperance Plains]], [[Geraldton Sandplains]], [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]] and [[Swan Coastal Plain]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca brevifolia''|id = 5881}}</ref> The species is found in swampy areas, near salt lakes<ref name=FloraBase/> in heathlands and shrublands.<ref name=Victoria />

==Conservation==
This species is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name=FloraBase/>

==Use in horticulture==
''Melaleuca brevifolia'' is a moderately hardy garden plant requiring good drainage and a sunny position.<ref name=Wrigley>{{cite book|last1=Wrigley|first1=John W.|last2=Fagg|first2=Murray|title=Australian native plants : a manual for their propagation, cultivation and use in landscaping|date=1983|publisher=Collins|location=Sydney|isbn=0002165759|page=261|edition=2nd}}</ref> It is useful for harsh conditions, including salty soils or those containing limestone.<ref name=Holliday/>

161.text:
{{taxobox
|status = 
|status_system = 
|image = Melaleuca brophyi (habit).JPG
|image caption = ''M. brophyi'' near [[Salmon Gums, Western Australia|Salmon Gums]]
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]

|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''<ref>Craven. "New combinations in Melaleuca for Australian species of Callistemon (Myrtaceae)." 2006, vol. 16, no4, pp. 468-475.</ref>
|species = '''''M. brophyi'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca brophyi''
|binomial_authority = ([[K.J.Cowley]]) [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca brophyi''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It is a small to medium-sized shrub with small, fleshy leaves and clusters of fruit that resemble soccer balls.

==Description==
''Melaleuca brophyi'' is a shrub which grows to a height of between {{convert|0.3 and 3|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}}. Its leaves are crowded, spirally arranged, fleshy, warty, almost circular in cross-section and have prominent oil glands. The leaves are {{convert|5-16|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name="Brophy">{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=101}}</ref><ref name="Holliday" />

Small, yellow, almost spherical groups of flowers about {{convert|14|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter appear on the ends of the branches between June and November. As with other melaleucas, the stamens are in groups of five and in this species there are about three to six stamens per bundle. The fruit are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]] in small, spherical clusters with a diameter of about {{convert|10|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}}.<ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=38–39|edition=2nd}}</ref>[[File:Melaleuca brophyi (leaves, flowers, fruits).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. brophyi'' leaves, flowers and fruit]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca brophyi'' was first described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] from a specimen found "about {{convert|1.8|km|m|abbr=on}} south of [[Lockhart River, Western Australia|Lake Biddy]] on the road to [[Newdegate, Western Australia|Newdegate]]".<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca brophyi''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561654|publisher=APNI|accessdate=16 March 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''brophy'') is in recognition of the work of Joseph J. Brophy for his work on essential oils in the families [[Myrtaceae]] and [[Rutaceae]].<ref name=UNSW>{{cite web|title=School of chemistry: Dr Joe Brophy|url=http://www.chemistry.unsw.edu.au/our-school/emeritus-and-adjunct-staff/dr-joe-brophy|publisher=University of New South Wales|accessdate=4 March 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyndley|last2=Lepschi|first2=B.J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|pages=819–928|url=http://www.publish.csiro.au/paper/SB98019.htm|accessdate=4 March 2015|doi=10.1071/sb98019}}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs between [[Southern Cross, Western Australia|Southern Cross]], [[Norseman, Western Australia|Norseman]] and [[Esperance, Western Australia|Esperance]]<ref name="Holliday" /> in the [[Avon Wheatbelt]], [[Esperance Plains]] and [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]] in Western Australia.<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca brophyi''|id=18527}}</ref> It grows in black clay in saline, low-lying areas.<ref name=Flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=392}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca brophyi'' is classified as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name=FloraBase/>

==References==

162.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = Cajuput
|image = Melaleuca cajuputi.jpg
|image_caption = ''M. cajuputi'' flowers and leaves
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. cajuputi'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca cajuputi''
|binomial_authority = [[Thomas Powell (botanist)|Powell]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca cajuputi''''', commonly known as '''cajuput''' or '''white samet''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is widespread in [[Australia]], [[Southeast Asia]], [[New Guinea]] and the [[Torres Strait]] islands. It is a medium to tall tree with papery bark, silvery new growth and white or greenish flower spikes. It has important uses as a source of [[cajuput oil]].

==Description==
''Melaleuca cajuputi'' is usually a medium to large tree, often growing to {{convert|35|m|ft|sigfig=1}} and sometimes to {{convert|46|m|ft|sigfig=1}} with grey, brownish or whitish papery bark. The new growth is silky-hairy, becoming [[Glabrousness|glabrous]] as it matures.  The leaves are arranged alternately {{convert|40–140|mm|in|sigfig=1}} long and {{convert|7.5–60|mm|in|sigfig=1}} wide, tapering at both ends. The flower are white, cream or greenish-yellow mostly in dense spikes at the ends of the branches which continue to grow after flowering but also often in the [[Leaf|axils]] of the upper leaves. The spikes contain 8 to 20 groups of flowers, each group with three flowers. The stamens are grouped in five bundles around the flower, each bundle containing 6 to 18 stamens. Timing of flowering varies with subspecies. The fruits are woody, cup-shaped capsules clustered loosely along the branches, each fruit {{convert|2-2.8|mm|in|sigfig=1}} long.
<ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=38–39|edition=2nd}}</ref><ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|pages=104–105}}</ref>[[File:Melaleuca cajuputi (habit).jpg|thumb|225px|''M. cajuputi'' habit]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca cajuputi'' was first formally described in 1809 by [[Thomas Powell (botanist)|Thomas Powell]] in ''Pharmacopoeia of the Royal College of Physicians of London'' with a reference to an earlier (1747) description by [[Georg Eberhard Rumphius|Rumphius]] in ''Herbarium Amboinense''.<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca cajuputi''|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/509268|publisher=APNI}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''cajuputi'') is "probably a corruption of the Indonesian name for the plant, kayu putih".<ref name="Brophy" />

===Subspecies===
There are 3 subspecies:
*''Melaleuca cajuputi'' Powell subsp. ''cajuputi'':<ref name=APNI(1)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca cajuputi'' subsp. ''cajuputi''|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/name/apni/153642|publisher=APNI|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref> The nominate subspecies has leaves {{convert|7-26|mm|in|sigfig=1}} wide, 7 to 10 stamens per bundle and flowers from March to November.<ref name="Holliday" /><ref name="Brophy" />
*''Melaleuca cajuputi'' subsp. ''cumingiana'' ([[Nikolai Turczaninow|Turcz.]]) Barlow:<ref name=APNI(2)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca cajuputi'' subsp. ''cumingiana''|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/589500|publisher=APNI|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref> This subspecies flowers from February to December and has leaves {{convert|40-200|mm|in|sigfig=1}} long and {{convert|10-20|mm|in|sigfig=1}}wide and there are 7 to 9 stamens per bundle.<ref name=eFloras>{{cite web|title=Flora of China|url=http://flora.huh.harvard.edu/china/PDF/PDF13/Melaleuca.pdf|website=eFloras.org|publisher=eFloras.org|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref>
*''Melaleuca cajuputi'' subsp. ''platyphylla'' Barlow:<ref name=APNI(3)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca cajuputi'' subsp. ''platyphylla''|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561657|publisher=APNI|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref> This subspecies has leaves ({{convert|15-60|mm|in|sigfig=1}} wide), more stamens (8-13 per bundle) and flowers from January to May and August to September.<ref name="Holliday" /><ref name="Brophy" /> The name ''platyphylla'' is from the [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] ''platys'' meaning "flat", "broad", "wide" or "level"<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref>{{rp|167}} and ''phyllon'' meaning “leaf”.<ref name="RWB" />{{rp|605}}

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca cajuputi'' Powell subsp. ''cajuputi'' occurs in the [[Dampier Peninsula]], [[Calder River (Western Australia)|Calder River]],  [[Fitzroy Crossing, Western Australia|Fitzroy Crossing]] district in the [[Central Kimberley]] biogeographic zone in [[Western Australia]],<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca cajuputi''|id = 5883}}</ref> the northern part of the [[Northern Territory]], and [[East Timor]]. It grows in woodland, vine forest, gallery forest and savannah forest, on clayey and peaty loam.<ref name="Brophy" />

''Melaleuca cajuputi'' subsp. ''cumingiana'' ([[Nikolai Turczaninow|Turcz.]]) Barlow occurs in [[Burma|Myanmar]], [[Thailand]], [[Vietnam]], [[Malaysia]] and [[Indonesia]] ([[Sumatra]], [[West Java]] and south-west [[Kalimantan]]). The name ''cumingiana'' is "in honour of [[Hugh Cuming]]". It grows in coastal swamp forest.<ref name="Brophy" /> In Thailand, the species is known as ''White Samet''.<ref name=Nuyim>{{cite web|last1=Nuyim|first1=Tanit|title=Potentiality of ''Melaleuca cajuputi'' Powell cultivation to develop for economic plantation purpose|url=http://www.researchgate.net/publication/266000009_Potentiality_of_Melaleuca_cajuputi_Powell_Cultivation_to_Develop_for_Economic_Plantation_Purpose|publisher=Forest management and forest products research office|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref>

''Melaleuca cajuputi'' subsp. ''platyphylla'' Barlow occurs in New Guinea, the Torres Strait islands and north-western [[Queensland]] as far south as [[Cairns]]. It grows in similar habitats to subsp. ''cajuputi''.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Uses==

===Timber===
In Southeast Asia, ''Melaleuca cajuputi'' is used as a fuel and for making charcoal. It is used on a small scale for supporting columns, frames and floorboards in house construction and for fences. The bark has been used as roofing material and a sealant in boat construction including as a caulking material for boats in Indonesia.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="Nuyim" />

===Essential oils===
[[Aboriginal Australians|Indigenous Australian people]] used the leaves of this species to treat aches and pains and inhaled vapours from the crushed leaves to treat respiratory infections.<ref name=Doran>{{cite book|last1=Doran|first1=John C.|editor-last1=Southwell|editor-first1=Ian|editor-last2=Lowe|editor-first2=Robert|title=Tea tree : the genus melaleuca|date=1999|publisher=Harwood Academic|location=Amsterdam|isbn=9057024179|pages=221–224}}</ref> In Thailand the leaves are used to make a herbal tea as a treatment for a range of medical problems. In many parts of Asia, the oil which gives the tree its name - [[cajuput oil]] is used as a liniment and inhalant.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="Nuyim" />

Commercial cajuput oil is mostly obtained from ''Melaleuca cajuputi'' subsp. ''cajuputi''. This oil is a pale yellow liquid and contains up to 60% [[Eucalyptol|1,8-cineole]], the main antimicrobial component of the oil . Cajuput oil has been classified as non-toxic and non-sensitizing, although skin irritation may occur at high concentrations. It has been reported to be useful as an insect repellant, as a sedative and relaxant and is useful in treating roundworms and urino-genital infections. It is used to flavour foods and to add to the fragrance of soaps and cosmetics.<ref name="Doran" />

==References==
<references/>

163.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = ''Melaleuca camptoclada''
|image = Melaleuca camptoclada (habit).JPG
|image caption = ''M. camptoclada'' in the [[Stirling Range National Park]] 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. camptoclada'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca camptoclada''
|binomial_authority = F.C.Quinn
}}

'''''Melaleuca camptoclada''''' is a shrub in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It was first described in 1990 in a review of the genus ''Melaleuca'' when the species ''[[Melaleuca laxiflora]]'' at that time was found to comprise ten species. Two of those species were new - ''M. camptoclada'' and ''[[Melaleuca ctenoides|M. ctenoides]]''.<ref name=CSIRO>{{cite journal|last1=Cowley|first1=KJ|last2=Quinn|first2=FC|last3=Barlow|first3=BA|last4=Craven|first4=LA|title=Contributions to a revision of (Myrtaceae): 7–10|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1990|volume=3|issue=2|pages=165|doi=10.1071/SB9900165|url=http://www.publish.csiro.au/paper/SB9900165.htm|accessdate=21 March 2015}}</ref> 

==Description==
''Melaleuca camptoclada'' is a shrub growing to a height of about {{convert|3|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}}. Its leaves and branches are [[Glabrousness|glabrous]] or almost so. The leaves are {{convert|2.9–5.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|1.5–1.8|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide and elliptical in shape.<ref name="Brophy" />

The flowers are mauve and are arranged in heads or spikes to {{convert|16|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter, with 5 to 15 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|1.5-2.4|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flowers open. The stamens are arranged in five bundles around the flower with 9 to 16 stamens in each bundle. Flowering occurs from September to November and the fruit are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|2.5-3.5|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=111}}</ref>
[[File:Melaleuca camptoclada (leaves and flowers).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. camptoclada'' leaves and flowers]]
[[File:Melaleuca camptoclada (fruits).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. camptoclada'' fruit]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca camptoclada'' was first formally described in 1990 by [[F.C.Quinn]] from a specimen found near the [[Stirling Ranges]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca camptoclada''|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/552349|publisher=APNI|accessdate=21 March 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''camptoclada'') is from the [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] ''kamptos'' meaning "to bend"<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref>{{rp|181}} and ''κλάδος (kládos)'' meaning "shoot" or "branch"<ref name="RWB" />{{rp|162}} "in reference to the habit of this species".<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in the [[Esperance Plains]], [[Jarrah Forest]] and [[Warren (biogeographic region)|Warren]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca camptoclada''|id = 12386}} </ref> It grows in gravelly sand and clay loam.<ref name=Flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=392}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca camptoclada'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

==References==
{{reflist|30em}}

164.text:
{{italictitle}}
{{taxobox
|name = Burra bottlebrush 
|status =
|status_system = 
|image =
|image caption = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. chisholmii'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca chisholmii''
|binomial_authority = ([[Edwin Cheel|Cheel]]) [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
|synonyms = ''Callistemon chisholmi'' {{small|[[Edwin Cheel|Cheel]] }}{{br}}
}}

'''''Melaleuca chisholmii''''' commonly known as '''Burra bottlebrush''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to  [[Queensland]] in [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state herbaria continue to use the name ''Callistemon chisholmii''.)<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> It is a shrub with rough bark, an open habit and spiky foliage but in winter has bright red flower spikes tipped with yellow.

==Description==
''Melaleuca chisholmii'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|3-4|m|ft|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} tall with rough, dark grey or fibrous brown bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|25-100|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|1-7|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, flat, linear to narrow egg-shaped with the narrower end near the base and with the end tapering to a sharp point.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=117}}</ref><ref name=sgap>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca chisholmii''|url=http://sgaptownsville.org.au/Melaleuca-chisholmii.html|publisher=Society for Growing Australian Plants - Townsville Branch|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref>

The flowers are arranged in spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering. The spikes are up to {{convert|40-50|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} in diameter and {{convert|60-80|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long with 10 to 30 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|3.1-5.6|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages. There are 25 to 57 [[stamen]]s in each flower, with their "stalks" (the filaments) red and "tips" (the anthers) yellow. Flowering occurs from May to August and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|3.7-6.1|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long in cylindrical spikes which remain on the stem for a lengthy period.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name="sgap"/>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca chisholmii'' was first formally described in 2006 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Novon]]''.<ref name=APNI(1)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca chisholmii''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/613686|publisher=APNI|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> It had previously been known as ''[[Callistemon chisholmii]]'' since [[Edwin Cheel]] described it in 1925 in ''[[Proceedings of the Linnean Society of New South Wales]]'' from a specimen collected on the "western watershed, [[Thomson River (Queensland)|Thompson River]] Fall, North Queensland".<ref name=Cheel>{{cite journal|last1=Cheel|first1=Edwin|title=Two new species of ''Callistemon'', with notes on certain other species|journal=Proceedings of the Linnean Society of New South Wales|date=1925|volume=50|issue=4|page=260|url=http://biodiversitylibrary.org/item/108646#page/306/mode/1up|accessdate=12 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=APNI(2)>{{cite web|title=''Callistemon chisholmii''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/662407|publisher=APNI|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> (Cheel gave the incorrect spelling ''Callistemon chisholmi''.)<ref name=APNI(3)>{{cite web|title=''Callistemon chisholmi''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/662406|publisher=APNI|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''chisholmii'') honours J.R. Chisholm (1855-1927), a botanical collector<ref name=CHAH>{{cite web|title=Australian Plant Collectors and Illustrators (C)|url=http://www.anbg.gov.au/bot-biog/bot-biog-C.html|publisher=Council of the Heads of Australian Herbaria|accessdate=12 June 2015}}</ref> including of the [[Type (biology)|type]] of this species.<ref name="Brophy" />

''Callistemon chisholmii'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca chisholmii'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref name '"WCSP">{{WCSP | 31418 | ''Callistemon chisholmii'' }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in higher areas of central Queensland in woodland and forest near watercourses.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Use in horticulture==
''Melaleuca chisholmii'' is a hardy plant from dry inland areas but has been grown successfully in [[Townsville]].<ref name="sgap" />

165.text:
{{italic title}} {{taxobox |name = Crimson bottlebrush |status = |status_system = |image = Callistemon citrinus-0878.jpg |image caption = ''Melaleuca citrina'' flowers, fruit and foliage |regnum = [[Plantae]] |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s |unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s |unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s |ordo = [[Myrtales]] |familia = [[Myrtaceae]] |genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]'' |species = '''''M. citrina''''' |binomial = ''Melaleuca citrina'' |binomial_authority = ([[William Curtis|Curtis]]) [[Georges Louis Marie Dumont de Courset|Dum.Cours.]] |synonyms = ''Metrosideros citrina'' Curtis
''Callistemon lanceolatus'' ([[Sm.]]) [[DC.]]
''Callistemon citrinus'' (Curtis) [[Skeels]] }} '''''Melaleuca citrina''''', commonly known as '''common red''', '''crimson''' or '''lemon bottlebrush''',{{cite web|title=''Callistemon citrinus''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/521947|publisher=APNI|accessdate=30 August 2015}} is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to [[New South Wales]] and [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] in Australia. (Some Australian state herbaria continue to use the name ''Callistemon citrinus''.{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=11 June 2015}} ''Callistemon lanceolatus'' is an older name.){{cite web|title=Callistemon citrinus|url=http://anpsa.org.au/c-cit.html|publisher=Australian Native Plants Society Australia|accessdate=20 July 2015}} It is a hardy and adaptable species, common in its natural habitat. It is widely cultivated, not only in Australia, often as a species of ''Callistemon''. It was one of the first Australian plants to be grown outside the country, having been taken to England in 1770 by [[Joseph Banks]]. Its showy red flower spikes, present over most of the year in an ideal situation, account for its popularity. ==Description== ''Melaleuca citrina'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|5|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall but more usually in the range {{convert|1-3|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} high and wide. It has hard, fibrous or papery bark and its young growth is usually covered with soft, silky hairs. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|26-99|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|4-25|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, hard, flat, narrow egg-shaped with the narrower end near the base and with a pointed but not sharp end. There are between 7 and 26 branching veins clearly visible on both ides of the leaves and a large number of distinct oil glands visible on both surfaces of the leaves.{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=119}}{{cite web|title=''Callistemon citrinus''|url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Callistemon~citrinus|publisher=Royal Botanic Garden Sydney: PlantNet|accessdate=12 June 2015}} The flowers are red and arranged in spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and sometimes also in the upper leaf axils. The spikes are up to {{convert|45-70|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and {{convert|60-100|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long with up to 80 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|3.9-5.8|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages. There are 30 to 45 [[stamen]]s in each flower, with their "stalks" (the filaments) red and "tips" (the anthers) purple. Flowering occurs in most months of the year but mainly in November and December. Flowering is followed by fruit which are woody, cup-shaped [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|4.4-7|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and about {{convert|7|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide in cylindrical clusters along the stem. The fruiting capsules remain unopened until the plant, or the part bearing them dies. ==Taxonomy and naming== ''Melaleuca citrina'' was first formally described in 1802 by the French botanist [[Georges Louis Marie Dumont de Courset]] in ''[[Le Botaniste Cultivateur]]''.{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca citrina''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/509658|publisher=APNI|accessdate=12 June 2015}} The species had previously been known as ''Metrosideros citrina'', in turn named by [[William Curtis]] in the ''[[The Botanical Magazine]]'' in 1794, based on a flowering plant growing at [[Thomas Dawson, 1st Viscount Cremorne|Lord Cremorne]]'s estate. That plant had grown from a root collected in 1770 at [[Botany Bay]] by [[Joseph Banks]] during the [[first voyage of James Cook]] to Australia. Curtis noted that the leaves "when bruised give forth an agreeable fragrance."{{cite book|last1=Curtis|first1=William|title=The Botanical Magazine (Volume 8)|date=1794|location=London|page=260|edition=1|url=http://www.gutenberg.org/files/24670/24670-h/24670-h.htm#Metrosideros_Citrina_Harsh-Leavd_Metrosideros|accessdate=12 June 2015}}{{cite web|title=''Metrosideros citrina''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/541790|publisher=APNI|accessdate=12 June 2015}} The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''citrina'') alludes to the similarity of the aromatic property of leaves of this species and those of [[citrus]] plants. ''Callistemon citrinus'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca citrina'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].{{WCSP | 31419 | ''Callistemon citrinus'' }} ==Distribution and habitat== ''Melaleuca citrina'' occurs in near coastal areas of New South Wales, including the [[Blue Mountains (New South Wales)|Blue Mountains]] and extends as far west as the Central Western Slopes. It also occurs in the east coast areas of Victoria and grows in swamps and along creeks and rivers. ==Ecology== Birds have been observed using the species as a source of food. Those seeking nectar from the flowers include [[eastern spinebill]]s, [[New Holland honeyeater]]s, [[noisy miner]]s, [[red wattlebird]]s and [[silvereye]]s, while [[crimson rosella]]s eat the seeds.{{cite journal|author=Lepschi, B.J.|title=Food of some birds in eastern New South Wales"Additions to Barker & Vestjens|journal=Emu|volume=93|pages=195–199|year=1993|url=http://www.publish.csiro.au/?act=view_file&file_id=MU9930195.pdf|doi=10.1071/MU9930195|issue=3}} ==Uses== ===Agriculture=== The herbicide [[Mesotrione]] was developed as a synthetic analogue of [[leptospermone]], a natural herbicide produced by the roots of ''Callistemon citrinus''.{{cite web|last1=Cornes|first1=Derek|title=Fourth World Congress on Allelopathy |url=http://www.regional.org.au/au/allelopathy/2005/2/7/2636_cornesd.htm|publisher=The Regional Institute Ltd.|accessdate=18 July 2015}} ===Horticulture=== ''M. citrina'', as ''Callistemon citrinus'' had become established in cultivation in England by 1794 when flowering plants that were more than five years old had been observed at both [[Kew Gardens]] and [[Syon House]] and younger plants had become available in nurseries. It is widely cultivated, often as ''Callistemon citrinus'' and sometimes as ''Callistemon lanceolatus''. It is easily propagated from seed or [[Cutting (plant)|cuttings]] and grows in most soils, preferring a sunny location. It is frost hardy and responds well to watering and the application of fertiliser but is tolerant of drought and frost.{{cite web|title=''Callistemon citrinus''|url=http://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Callistemon+citrinus|publisher=Plants for a Future|accessdate=12 June 2015}}{{cite web|title=''Callistemon citrinus''|url=http://anpsa.org.au/c-cit.html|publisher=Australian Native Plants Society (Australia)|accessdate=12 June 2015}}{{cite web|title=''Callistemon citrinus''|url=https://www.anbg.gov.au/gnp/gnp2/callistemon-citrinus.html|publisher=Australian National Botanic Garden|accessdate=12 June 2015}} A number of cultivars have been developed (as cultivars of ''Callistemon citrinus'') including:{{cite web|title=List of Registered Cultivars derived from Australian native flora|url=http://www.anbg.gov.au/acra/acra-list-2009.html|publisher=Australian Cultivar Registration Authority Inc.|accessdate=18 July 2015}} * ''Demesne Rowena'' - A cross between 'Splendens' and 'White Anzac' growing to 1.5 x 1.5 metres. The flowers are red upon opening, fading to deep pink.{{cite web|title=Callistemon 'Firebrand'|url=http://www.anbg.gov.au/acra/descriptions/acc288.html|publisher=Australian Cultivar Registration Authority|accessdate=18 July 2015}} * ''Firebrand'', a seedling of uncertain origin first planted at Austraflora Nursery in 1973. Plants are about 60 cm high and 2.5 metres wide and have deep crimson-pink flowers.{{cite web|title=Callistemon 'Firebrand'|url=http://www.anbg.gov.au/acra/descriptions/acc191.html|publisher=Australian Cultivar Registration Authority|accessdate=18 July 2015}} * [[Callistemon 'Splendens'|''Splendens'']], a form with a compact and rounded habit, growing to about 2 metres high and wide. It is sold under the trade name "Endeavour".{{cite web|title=Callistemon 'Splendens'|url=http://www.anbg.gov.au/acra/descriptions/acc459.html|publisher=Australian Cultivar Registration Authority|accessdate=18 July 2015}} * ''White Anzac'', a low, spreading white-flowering form selected from a natural population in New South Wales.{{cite web|title=Callistemon 'White Anzac'|url=http://www.anbg.gov.au/acra/descriptions/acc239.html|publisher=Australian Cultivar Registration Authority|accessdate=18 July 2015}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} [[Category:Melaleuca|citrina]] [[Category:Flora of Australia]] [[Category:Flora of New South Wales]] [[Category:Flora of Victoria (Australia)]] [[Category:Plants described in 1802]]
165.title: Melaleuca citrina

166.text:
{{italictitle}}
{{taxobox
|name = Cliff bottlebrush
|status =
|status_system = 
|image = Melelauca comboynensis flowers.jpg
|image caption = ''M. comboynensis'' flowers
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. comboynensis'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca comboynensis''
|binomial_authority = ([[Edwin Cheel|Cheel]]) [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
|synonyms = ''Callistemon comboynensis'' {{small|[[Edwin Cheel|Cheel]]}}{{br}}
}}

'''''Melaleuca comboynensis''''', commonly known as '''cliff bottlebrush''', is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to  [[New South Wales]] and [[Queensland]] in [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state herbaria continue to use the name ''Callistemon comboynensis''.)<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> It is usually a shrub, similar to ''[[Melaleuca citrina]]'' with its hard leaves, spikes of red flowers and clusters of cup-shaped fruits but differs in that its leaves are generally wider and its habitat is usually rocky outcrops rather than along watercourses.[[File:Melaleuca comboynensis (Gibraltar Ra.).jpg|thumb|225px|''M. comboynensis'' near The Granites lookout in the [[Gibraltar Range National Park]]]]

==Description==
''Melaleuca comboynensis'' is a small shrub or tree growing to {{convert|0.3-5|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with hard bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|27-95|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|7-17|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide,flat, narrow egg-shaped with the narrower end near the base and with the end tapering to a point.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=125}}</ref><ref name=plantnet>{{cite web|title=''Callistemon comboynensis''|url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Callistemon~comboynensis|publisher=Royal Botanic Garden Sydney: PlantNet|accessdate=12 June 2015}}</ref>

The flowers are arranged in spikes usually near the end of the branches. The spikes are up to {{convert|65|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and wide with 15 to 50 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|3.0-6.1|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages. There are 31 to 41 [[stamen]]s in each flower, with their "stalks" (the filaments) red to crimson and "tips" (the anthers) a dark purple. Flowering occurs from March to December and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|4.1-7|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name="plantnet"/>


==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca comboynensis'' was first named in 2006 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Novon]]''.<ref name=APNI(1)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca comboynensis''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/613687|publisher=APNI|accessdate=12 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=Novon>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=New Combinations in Melaleuca for Australian Species of Callistemon (Myrtaceae)|journal=Novon|date=2006|volume=16|issue=4|pages=468–475|url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.3417/1055-3177%282006%2916%5B468%3ANCIMFA%5D2.0.CO%3B2|accessdate=12 June 2015|doi=10.3417/1055-3177(2006)16[468:ncimfa]2.0.co;2}}</ref> It was first formally described in 1943 as ''Callistemon comboynensis'' by [[Edwin Cheel]] in ''[[Proceedings of the Linnean Society of New South Wales]]''. His specimen was collected in the "[[Comboyne, New South Wales|Comboyne Ranges]] in crevices of rocks".<ref name=cheel>{{cite journal|last1=Cheel|first1=Edwin|title=Description of new species of ''Callistemon''|journal=Proceedings of the Linnean Society of New South Wales|date=1943|volume=68|page=184|url=http://biodiversitylibrary.org/item/108561#page/217/mode/1up|accessdate=12 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=APNI(2)>{{cite web|title=''Callistemon comboynensis''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/522009|publisher=APNI|accessdate=12 June 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''comboynensis'') refers to the location where the [[Type (biology)|type]] specimen was found; the suffix ''-ensis'' means "place for" or "where" in [[Latin]].<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.|page =45}}</ref>

''Callistemon comboynensis'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca comboynensis'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref name '"WCSP">{{WCSP | 31423 | ''Callistemon comboynensis'' }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in the high country in and between the [[Border Ranges National Park|Border Ranges]] in southern Queensland and the [[Gibraltar Range]] in northern New South Wales. It also occurs in the lower [[Murray River]] districts of north-western Victoria and south-eastern South Australia.<ref name="Brophy" /> It mostly grows on rocky hilltops and crevices above {{convert|500|m|ft|sigfig=1}}.<ref name="plantnet" />

==Use in horticulture==
''Melaleuca comboynensis'' is well known in cultivation as an attractive and hardy shrub for temperate areas.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name=Wrigley>{{cite book|last1=Wrigley|first1=John W.|last2=Fagg|first2=Murray|title=Australian native plants : a manual for their propagation, cultivation and use in landscaping|date=1983|publisher=Collins|location=Sydney|isbn=0002165759|page=191|edition=2nd}}</ref>

<gallery>
Image:Callistemon comboynensis HRM1.jpg|''M. comboynensis'' in the [[Real Jardín Botánico de Madrid|Royal Botanic Garden in Madrid]] arboretum
Image:Callistemon comboynensis.jpg|thumb|''M. comboynensis'' in Royal Botanical Garden of Madrid
Image:Melaleuca comboynensis flowers.jpg|thumb|225px|''M. comboynensis'' in the [[Australian Botanic Garden Mount Annan]]
Image:Melaleuca comboynensis habit.jpg|thumb|225px|''M. comboynensis'' on Waratah Trig in the  [[Gibraltar Range National Park]]
</gallery>

167.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = ''Melaleuca condylosa''
|image =Melaleuca condylosa (leaves, flowers, fruits).JPG
|image caption = ''M. condylosa'' leaves, flowers and fruit
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. condylosa'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca condylosa''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca condylosa''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It is similar to ''[[Melaleuca brophyi]]'' except that its fruiting clusters are often knobbly and the flower heads and leaves are slightly larger.

==Description==
''Melaleuca condylosa'' is a shrub growing to a height of about {{convert|3|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} with papery bark. Its leaves are alternately arranged, {{convert|9.5-32|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|1.3-2.1|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, more or less linear in shape, almost circular in cross-section and have a pointed, although not sharp end.<ref name="Holliday" /><ref name="Brophy" />

The flowers are in heads at the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering. Each head is composed of 6 to 11 groups of flowers with three flowers in each group. The petals are {{convert|1.2-2.0|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower opens. There are five bundles of stamens around the flower, each with 5 to 7 pale yellow stamens giving the flower its colour. Flowering occurs mainly in October and November and is followed by almost spherical, knobbly clusters of woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], each {{convert|2.0-2.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=38–39|edition=2nd}}</ref><ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=129}}</ref>
[[File:Melaleuca condylosa (habit).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. condylosa'' at the type location near [[Bendering, Western Australia|Bendering]]]]
[[File:Melaleuca condylosa (bark).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. condylosa'' bark]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca condylosa'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] from a specimen found "{{convert|40.5|km|mi|sigfig=1}} east along [[Bendering, Western Australia|Bendering]] Reserve Road from the Bendering wheat bin".<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca condylosa''|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561672|publisher=APNI|accessdate=23 March 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=869|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''condylosa'') is from the [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] ''κόνδυλος (kóndulos)'' meaning "knuckle", "knob" or "prominence"<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.|page =633}}</ref> referring to the knobbly fruit.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in the [[Narembeen, Western Australia|Narembeen]], [[Kondinin, Western Australia|Kondinin]] and [[Hyden, Western Australia|Hyden]] districts<ref name="Brophy" /> in the [[Avon Wheatbelt]], [[Coolgardie (biogeographic region)|Coolgardie]] and [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]]. It grows in melaleuca-[[Mallee (habit)|mallee]] shrubland in sandy loam on undulating sandplains and slopes.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca condylosa''|id = 19289}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca condylosa'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

==References==
{{reflist|30em}}

[[Category:Flora of Western Australia]]
[[Category:Plants described in 1999]]
[[Category:Endemic flora of Western Australia]]

168.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = ''Melaleuca croxfordiae''
|image = Melaleuca croxfordiae.jpg
|image caption = ''M. croxfordiae'' leaves and flowers
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. croxfordiae'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca croxfordiae''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca croxfordiae''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the far south-west of corner [[Western Australia]]. It is a paperbark, usually growing in winter-wet places, with long, narrow leaves and a few small creamy coloured flower heads in early summer .

==Description==
''Melaleuca croxfordiae'' is a large shrub or small tree, sometimes {{convert|8|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} high, with papery bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately, {{convert|14-60|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|1.5-5.2|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, linear to narrow oval in shape, tapering to a point. They are also flat and soft and have a very short stalk.<ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=72–73|edition=2nd}}</ref><ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=133}}</ref>

This species has a few heads of flowers, white to creamy-yellow, borne at the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering, sometimes also in the upper leaf axils. Each head is up to {{convert|22|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and composed of 5 to 12 groups of flowers with three flowers in each group. The petals are {{convert|1.3-1.7|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages. There are five bundles of stamens around the flower, each with 5 to 8 stamens. Flowering occurs mainly in October to December and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]] {{convert|3-4|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long in tightly packed, almost spherical clusters {{convert|12-15|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter.<ref name=Holliday/><ref name=Brophy/>
[[File:Melaleuca croxfordiae (habit).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. croxfordiae'' in the [[West Cape Howe National Park]] ]]
[[File:Melaleuca croxfordiae (fruits).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. croxfordiae'' fruit]]
[[File:Melaleuca croxfordiae (bark).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. croxfordiae'' bark]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca croxfordiae'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] from a specimen found near [[Albany, Western Australia|Albany]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca croxfordiae''|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561677|publisher=APNI|accessdate=2 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=869|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''croxfordiae'') honours Eileen Jessie Croxford who helped professional biologists in understanding the flora of the Albany district.<ref name=Brophy />

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca croxfordiae'' occurs in the near the coast between [[Manjimup, Western Australia|Manjimup]] and Albany<ref name=Brophy/> in the [[Esperance Plains]], [[Jarrah Forest]], [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]] and [[Warren (biogeographic region)|Warren]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca croxfordiae''|id = 18184}}</ref> It grows in sandy soils, often over granite in swamps and coastal heath.<ref name=Brophy /><ref name=FloraBase/>

==Conservation==
This melaleuca is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

==References==
{{reflist|30em}}

[[Category:Flora of Western Australia]]

168.title: Melaleuca croxfordiae

{{taxobox
|image = 
|status = 
|status_system = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]

|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s

|ordo = [[Myrtales]]

|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. ctenoides'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca ctenoides''
|binomial_authority = F.C.Quinn
}}

'''''Melaleuca ctenoides''''' is a shrub in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It was first described in 1990 in a review of the genus ''Melaleuca'' when the species ''[[Melaleuca laxiflora|M. laxiflora]]'' at that time was found to comprise ten species. Two of those species were new - ''[[Melaleuca camptoclada|M. camptoclada]]'' and ''M. ctenoides''.<ref name=CSIRO>{{cite journal|last1=Cowley|first1=KJ|last2=Quinn|first2=FC|last3=Barlow|first3=BA|last4=Craven|first4=LA|title=Contributions to a revision of (Myrtaceae): 7–10|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1990|volume=3|issue=2|pages=165|doi=10.1071/SB9900165|url=http://www.publish.csiro.au/paper/SB9900165.htm|accessdate=21 March 2015}}</ref> It similar to ''Melaleuca laxiflora'' but distinguished from it by its comb-like leaves and attractive mauve or violet flowers in spring.

==Description==
''Melaleuca ctenoides'' is a spreading shrub growing to a height of about {{convert|3|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}}. Its leaves and branches are [[Glabrousness|glabrous]] or almost so. The leaves are {{convert|10-35|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|0.9-1.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}}, wide linear in shape and almost circular in cross-section.

Mauve flowers occur in spikes on side branches which continue to grow after flowering. Each spike has up to 20 individual flowers and is about {{convert|20-30|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|25|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter. The petals are pale pink, {{convert|3-3.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long but fall off soon after the flower opens. The stamens are arranged in five bundles around the flower with 14 to 18 stamens in each bundle. Flowering occurs mainly from October to November and the fruit that follow are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|3.5-5.0|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=134}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=74–75|edition=2nd}}</ref>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca ctenoides'' was first formally described in 1990 by [[F.C.Quinn]] from a specimen found {{convert|6.5|km|mi|sigfig=1}} by road north of [[Wongan Hills, Western Australia|Wongan Hills]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca ctenoides''|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/552345|publisher=APNI|accessdate=25 March 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''ctenoides'') is from the [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] ''kteis'' or ''ktenos'' meaning "comb"<ref name=Quattrochi>{{cite book|last1=Quattrocchi|first1=Umberto|title=CRC world dictionary of plants names: common names, scientific names, eponyms, synonyms and etymology|date=2000|publisher=CRC Press|location=Boca Raton, FL|isbn=0849326761|page=657|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=A68qyOyhOdkC&pg=PA657&lpg=PA657&dq=kteno+greek&source=bl&ots=BQLJdzVCnS&sig=WD4RRwQwdC4wz5vVAvm6_-ZNeEY&hl=en&sa=X&ei=OWcSVeJilrnyBcHngdAC&ved=0CBwQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=kteno%20greek&f=false|accessdate=25 March 2015}}</ref><ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.|page =220}}</ref> referring to the appearance of new growth with young leaves projecting like the teeth of a comb.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs between the [[Maya, Western Australia|Maya]], [[Narembeen, Western Australia|Narembeen]] and [[Hyden, Western Australia|Hyden]] districts in the [[Avon Wheatbelt]], [[Coolgardie (biogeographic region)|Coolgardie]] and [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca cteoides''|id = 12387}}</ref> It grows in sandy or clay soils on hillsides and granite outcrops.<ref name=Flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=392}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca ctenoides'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

170.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = ''Melaleuca delta''
|image = Melaleuca delta (habit).JPG
|image caption = ''Melaleuca delta'' in Fowlers Gully Nature Reserve near [[Wongan Hills]].
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. delta'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca delta''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca delta''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It is an erect shrub resembling ''[[Melaleuca marginata]]'' with its heads of white flowers in late spring but is distinguished from that species by the length of its [[Stigma (botany)|style]]. Its species name is derived from the name for a computer software application.

==Description==
''Melaleuca delta'' is a shrub often growing to {{convert|2.5|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} high with the young branches covered with soft, silky hairs. Its leaves are arranged alternately, {{convert|5-12.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|1.5-2.8|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, narrow elliptic or narrow egg-shaped with the end tapering to a point.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=142}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|page=70|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are white and arranged in heads on the sides of the branches. The heads are up to {{convert|15|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and composed of 1 to 7 individual flowers. The style is {{convert|2-4|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long (compared to {{convert|7-11|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in ''[[Melaleuca marginata]]''). The petals are {{convert|2-3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages. There are five bundles of stamens around the flower, each with 15 to 40 stamens. Flowering occurs mainly in November and December and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]] {{convert|3-4|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>
[[File:Melaleuca delta (foliage).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. delta'' leaves]]
[[File:Melaleuca delta (fruits).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. delta'' fruit]]
[[File:Melaleuca delta (bark).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. delta'' bark]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca delta'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] from a specimen collected in the [[Wongan Hills]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca delta''|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561685|publisher=APNI|accessdate=3 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=872|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''delta'') refers to a computer software package called DEscription Language for TAxonomy used by biologists.<ref name=Brophy />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in three disjunct areas in the [[Kalbarri, Western Australia|Kalbarri]], Wongan Hills and [[Jurien Bay, Western Australia|Jurien Bay]] districts<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/> in the [[Avon Wheatbelt]] and [[Geraldton Sandplains]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca delta''|id = 18125}}</ref> where it grows in gravelly loam in swampy areas, including those that are affected by salt.<ref name=Brophy /><ref name=FloraBase/>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca delta'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

|status = P3

|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s

|binomial = ''Melaleuca dempta''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca dempta''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It is an erect shrub resembling ''[[Melaleuca calycina]]'' with its heads of white flowers and egg-shaped to heart-shaped leaves. It was formerly considered a subspecies of ''Melaleuca calycina'' subsp. ''dempta'' but it lacks the star-like fruits of that species and its leaves have a blunt rather than a pointed tip.

==Description==
''Melaleuca dempta'' is a shrub often growing to about {{convert|2.2|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} high with the branches [[Glabrousness|glabrous]] except when very young. Its leaves are arranged in alternating pairs at right angles to the leaves above and below so that the leaves are in four rows along the stems. The leaves are {{convert|4.2-8|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|2.5-6.2|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, broadly elliptic, egg-shaped or heart-shaped with the end tapering to a rounded point.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=143}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|page=44|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are white and arranged in heads on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering. The heads are up to {{convert|18|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with up to 4 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|2.6-2.9|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages. There are five bundles of stamens around the flower, each with 22 to 29 stamens. Flowering occurs mainly in September but may continue to February and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]] {{convert|4.6-6.2|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long with five blunt teeth persisting around the edge. (These teeth are long in ''Melaleuca calycina'' giving its fruit a star shape when viewed end-on.)<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>
[[File:Melaleuca dempta (habit).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. dempta'' at the [[Type (biology)|type]] location near [[Scaddan, Western Australia|Scaddan]]]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
This species was first formally described in 1988 as ''Melaleuca calycina'' subsp. ''dempta'' <small> Barlow</small> by B.A.Barow and K.J. Cowley.<ref name=APNI(1)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca calycina subsp. dempta''|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/509373|publisher=APNI|accessdate=2 September 2015}}</ref> It was raised to species status in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]].<ref name=APNI(2)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca dempta''|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561686|publisher=APNI|accessdate=3 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=872|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''dempta'') is a [[Latin]] word meaning "removed" or "taken away"<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.|page=258}}</ref> referring to the lack of long, curved teeth around the fruit.<ref name=Brophy />

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca dempta'' occurs in and between the [[Scaddan, Western Australia|Scaddan]], [[Gibson, Western Australia|Gibson]] and [[Dalyup River]] districts<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/> in the [[Esperance Plains]] and [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name = ''Melaleuca dempta’'|id = 15693}}</ref> It grows in dense scrub in sandy soil in swampy areas and on the edges of clay pans.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca dempta'' is listed as "[[Declared Rare and Priority Flora List|Priority Three]]" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]]<ref name="FloraBase" /> meaning that it is known from only a few locations but is not currently in imminent danger.<ref name=dpaw>{{cite web|title=Conservation codes for flora and fauna|url=http://www.dpaw.wa.gov.au/images/documents/plants-animals/threatened-species/Listings/conservation_code_definitions.pdf|publisher=Government of Western Australia department of parks and wildlife|accessdate=1 May 2015}}</ref>

{{taxobox

}}

'''''Melaleuca eulobata''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the west coast of [[Western Australia]]. It is a shrub resembling ''[[Melaleuca campanae]]'' with its heads of pink flowers in late spring but is distinguished from that species by its [[sepal]]s - in ''M. campane'' these are reduced to a ring of tissue but ''M. eulobata'' has distinct [[sepal|calyx]] lobes.

==Description==
''Melaleuca eulobata'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|2|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with the young branches covered with short, silky hairs. Its leaves are arranged alternately, {{convert|10-18|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|3-6|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, flat, narrow egg-shaped with the end tapering to a point and three parallel veins.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=156}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=46–47|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are purple and arranged in heads on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering, sometimes also in the upper leaf axils. The heads are up to {{convert|22|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and composed of 4 to 7 groups of flowers in threes. The petals are {{convert|1-1.7|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower opens. There are five bundles of stamens around the flower, each with 9 or 10 stamens. Flowering occurs mainly in September and October and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]] {{convert|2.5-3.5|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long, in almost spherical clusters around the stem.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca eulobata'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected on the road to [[Monkey Mia]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca eulobata''|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561697|publisher=APNI|accessdate=4 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=875|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''eulobata'') is from the [[Ancient Greek]] ''εὖ (eû)'' meaning “well" or "good”<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref>{{rp|131}} and ''λοβός (lobós)'' meaning “capsule” or "pod"<ref name="RWB" />{{rp|118}} referring to the presence of calyx lobes, unlike the similar ''[[Melaleuca campanae]]''.<ref name=Brophy />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs near [[Shark Bay]]<ref name=Holliday/> in the [[Carnarvon (biogeographic region)|Carnarvon]] and [[Yalgoo (biogeographic region)|Yalgoo]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]]<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca eulobata''|id = 19452}}</ref> where it grows in scrubland in pebbly sand.<ref name =FloraBase/>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca eulobata'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

173.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = ''Melaleuca eurystoma''
|image = Melaleuca eurystoma (habit).JPG
|image caption = ''M. eurystoma'' growing near [[Tarin Rock, Western Australia|Tarin Rock]]
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. eurystoma'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca eurystoma''
|binomial_authority = [[Bryan A. Barlow|Barlow]] ex [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca eurystoma''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the south of [[Western Australia]]. It is a small shrub with pale lemon to greenish flowers and egg-shaped to almost oval leaves.

==Description==
''Melaleuca eurystoma'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|1.5|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with mostly [[Glabrousness|glabrous]] branches, leaves and flower parts. Its leaves are arranged alternately, {{convert|4.2-8.7|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|3-6.1|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, egg-shaped to almost oval with a wedge-shaped base and a rounded end.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=157}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|page=160|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are yellow or greenish-yellow and arranged in heads or spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering, sometimes also on the sides of the branches. The heads are up to {{convert|25|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and composed of 5 to 20 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|2.5-3.5|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages. There are five bundles of stamens around the flower, each with 7 to 15 stamens. Flowering occurs mainly in early spring and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]] {{convert|3.5-5|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>
[[File:Melaleuca eurystoma (foliage).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. eurystoma'' foliage]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca eurystoma'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected near [[Tarin Rock, Western Australia|Tarin Rock]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca eurystoma''|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561698|publisher=APNI|accessdate=4 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=875|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''eurystoma'') is from the [[Ancient Greek]] ''εὐρύς (eurús)'' meaning “wide”<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref>{{rp|166}} and ''στόμα (stóma)'' meaning “mouth”<ref name="RWB" />{{rp|538}} referring to the unusually wide opening of the fruits.<ref name=Brophy/>

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in and between the [[Lake King, Western Australia|Lake King]], [[Corrigin, Western Australia|Corrigin]] and [[Condingup]] districts<ref name=Brophy/> in the [[Avon Wheatbelt]], [[Esperance Plains]] and [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]]<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca eurystoma''|id = 15749}}</ref> where it grows gravelly sand and [[laterite]].<ref name=flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=393}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca eurystoma'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />
