174.text:
{{taxobox
|image = 
|status = P2
|status_system = DECF
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. eximia'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca eximia''
|binomial_authority = (K.J.Cowley)  [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
|synonyms = ''Melaleuca coccinea'' subsp. ''eximia'' <small>K.J.Cowley</small>  {{br}}
}}

'''''Melaleuca eximia''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the south of [[Western Australia]]. It is distinguished by its leaf arrangement, its large, showy red [[inflorescence]]s and the large, furry [[bract]]s under the flowers.

==Description==
''Melaleuca eximia'' is a woody shrub growing to {{convert|3|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with short, silky hairs covering the young branches. Its leaves are crowded and arranged in alternating pairs at right angles to the ones above and below so that there are four rows of leaves along the stems. The leaves are linear, taper to a point, crescent moon-shaped in cross section, {{convert|8-20|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|1.2-2|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=158}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=106–107|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are bright red and arranged in spikes on the sides of the branches. The heads are up to {{convert|60|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and composed of 7 to 13 groups of flowers in threes. At the base of each group of flowers there is a furry, heart-shaped  [[bract]]. The petals are {{convert|2.2-3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower opens. There are five bundles of stamens around the flower, each with 11 to 14 stamens. Flowering occurs mainly in October and November and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]] {{convert|4.5-5|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long, crowded in cylindrical clusters around the stems.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>

==Taxonomy and naming==
The first formal description of this plant was made in 1990 by Kirsten Cowley in  ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' as ''Melaleuca coccinea'' subsp. ''eximia'' from a specimen collected near [[Esperance, Western Australia|Esperance]].<ref name=Cowley>{{cite journal|last1=Cowley|first1=KJ|last2=Quinn|first2=FC|last3=Barlow|first3=BA|last4=Craven|first4=LA|title=Contributions to a revision of ''Melaleuca'' (Myrtaceae): 7–10|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1990|volume=3|issue=2|page=179|doi=10.1071/SB9900165|url=http://www.publish.csiro.au/paper/SB9900165.htm|accessdate=4 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=APNI(1)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca coccinea'' subsp. ''eximia''|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/552316|publisher=APNI|accessdate=4 May 2015}}</ref> It was raised to species status as ''Meleleuca eximia'' in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]''.<ref name=APNI(2)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca eximia''|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561699|publisher=APNI|accessdate=4 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=876|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''eximia'') is from the [[Latin]]  ''eximius'' meaning "exceptional", "uncommon" or "extraordinary",<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.|page=311}}</ref> referring to the appearance of the plant in flower.<ref name=Brophy/>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca eximia'' occurs in a small area near Esperance<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/> in the [[Esperance Plains]] and [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]],<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca eximia''|id = 15781}}</ref> growing in gravelly sand or clay near granite outcrops.<ref name=flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=393}}</ref>

==Conservation==
This melaleuca is listed as "[[Declared Rare and Priority Flora List|Priority Two]]" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]], meaning that it is known from only a few locations but is not currently in imminent danger.<ref name=FloraBase /><ref name=dpaw>{{cite web|title=Conservation codes for flora and fauna|url=http://www.dpaw.wa.gov.au/images/documents/plants-animals/threatened-species/Listings/conservation_code_definitions.pdf|publisher=Government of Western Australia department of parks and wildlife|accessdate=4 May 2015}}</ref>

==Use in horticulture==
The leaves and flowers of this species make this an attractive plant for the garden. It has been grown in [[South Australia]] and proven to be hardy in drier climates when grown in soil that is slightly acid.<ref name=Holliday/>

==References==
{{reflist|30em}}

174.title: Melaleuca eximia

175.text:
{{taxobox
|image = 
|status = 
|status_system = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. fabri'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca fabri''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca fabri''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It features strap-like leaves with distinct veins and spikes of pinkish flowers, the buds of which are covered with short, soft, silky hairs.

==Description==
''Melaleuca fabri'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|1.5|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with leathery, strap-like leaves that are arranged alternately, {{convert|35-110|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|6.5-15|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide. The leaves are flat but slightly wavy, with the end tapering to a sharp point and there are 3 or 5 (sometimes 7) distinct parallel veins.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=161}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=108–109|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are a shade of pink to purple and are arranged in spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering, often also on the sides of the branches. The spikes are up to {{convert|35|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and composed of 12 to 18 groups of flowers in threes. The outer edge of [[Hypanthium|floral cup]] and the parts of the flowers covering the buds are covered with short, soft, silky white hairs. The petals are {{convert|2.3-4|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages. There are five bundles of stamens around the flower, each with 9 to 13 stamens. Flowering occurs in spring and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]] {{convert|3-4.5|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long, in tight clusters along the stem.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca fabri'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected south of [[Morawa, Western Australia|Morawa]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca fabri''|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561700|publisher=APNI|accessdate=5 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=876|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''fabri'') is from the [[Latin]] ''faber'' meaning “artisan" or "workman”<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.|page =313}}</ref> in honour of the Smith family who have helped botanists studying the flora of the [[Wongan Hills]] and [[Manmanning, Western Australia|Manmanning]] districts.<ref name=Brophy />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in and between the Morawa, [[Perenjori, Western Australia|Perenjori]], [[Wubin, Western Australia|Wubin]] and [[Mount Gibson, Western Australia|Mount Gibson]] districts<ref name=Brophy /> in the [[Avon Wheatbelt]], [[Geraldton Sandplains]] and [[Yalgoo (biogeographic region)|Yalgoo]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]]<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca fabri''|id = 18528}}</ref> where it grows in shrubland, [[Mallee (habit)|mallee]] and on roadsides in sand or sandy loam.<ref name=Flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=393}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca fabri'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

==References==

[[Category:Endemic flora of Western Australia]]
175.title: Melaleuca fabri

176.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = Desert bottlebrush
|status =
|status_system =

|image caption = ''M. faucicola'' in [[Geelong Botanic Gardens]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], [[Australia]]
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. faucicola'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca faucicola''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
|synonyms = ''[[Callistemon pauciflorus]]'' {{small|[[Roger David Spencer|R.D.Spencer]] & Lumley }}{{br}}
}}

'''''Melaleuca faucicola''''' commonly known as '''desert bottlebrush''', is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Northern Territory]] in [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state herbaria continue to use the name ''Callistemon pauciflorus''.)<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> It is a shrub or small tree growing only in protected gorges in the ranges of [[Central Australia]] such as the [[Petermann Ranges (Australia)|Petermann Ranges]] and has red, cream or white spikes of flowers.

==Description==
''Melaleuca faucicola'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|1.515|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with hard, fissured bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|25-89|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|3.5-16|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, flat, linear to lance-shaped, with a mid-vein, 16 to 20 lateral veins and distinct oil glands.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=162}}</ref>

The flowers red, pink, cream or white. They are arranged in spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and also on the sides of the branches. The spikes are up to {{convert|27|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with 7 to 17 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|2.5-4.4|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages. There are 52 to 71 [[stamen]]s in each flower, some of which are joined in bundles. Flowering occurs at unpredictable times throughout the year and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|2.8-4.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name=Brophy/>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca faucicola'' was named in 2006 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Novon]]''.<ref name=APNI(1)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca faucicola''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/613688|publisher=APNI|accessdate=12 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=Novon>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=New Combinations in Melaleuca for Australian Species of Callistemon (Myrtaceae)|journal=Novon|date=2006|volume=16|issue=4|page=471|url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.3417/1055-3177%282006%2916%5B468%3ANCIMFA%5D2.0.CO%3B2|accessdate=11 June 2015|doi=10.3417/1055-3177(2006)16[468:NCIMFA]2.0.CO;2}}</ref> It had previously been known as ''Callistemon pauciflorus'' since [[Roger David Spencer]] and Peter F. Lumley first formally described it in 1986 in ''[[Muelleria (journal)|Muelleria]]'' from a specimen collected from the "[[Serpentine Gorge]] in the Heavitree Range".<ref name=APNI(2)>{{cite web|title=''Callistemon pauciflorus''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/662631|publisher=APNI|accessdate=12 June 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''faucicola'') is from the [[Latin]]  ''faux'' meaning “throat” or "pharynx"<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref>{{rp|799}} and ''-cola'' meaning "dweller in"<ref name="RWB" />{{rp|48}} referring to the habitat of this species, being in gorge country.<ref name="Brophy" />

''Callistemon pauciflorus'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca faucicola'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref name '"WCSP">{{WCSP | 31470 | ''Callistemon pauciflorus'' }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in the [[Central Ranges]], [[MacDonnell Ranges]] and [[Petermann Ranges (Australia)|Petermann Ranges]] in the Northern Territory<ref name=nt>{{cite web|title=Petermann Ranges and surrounds|url=http://www.lrm.nt.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0003/13881/60_petermann.pdf|publisher=Northern Territory Government Department of Natural Resources, Environment, the Arts and Sport|accessdate=12 June 2015}}</ref> where it grows near waterholes in protected sandstone gorges.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca faucicola'' is classified as "near threatened" in terms of the Northern Territory Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act.<ref name="eflorant">{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca faucicola''|url=http://eflora.nt.gov.au/factsheet?id=27076|publisher=Northern Territory Flora Online|accessdate=3 May 2016}}</ref>

==References==
{{reflist|30em}}

[[Category:Flora of Australia]]
[[Category:Flora of Queensland]]
[[Category:Plants described in 1986]]
176.title: Melaleuca faucicola

{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = Tapering-leaved bottlebrush
|status =

|image caption = ''M. flammea'' leaves and flowers
|regnum = [[Plantae]]

|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. flammea'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca flammea''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
|synonyms = ''[[Callistemon acuminatus]]'' {{small|[[Edwin Cheel|Cheel]] }}{{br}}
}}

'''''Melaleuca flammea''''', commonly known as '''tapering-leaved bottlebrush''',  is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to [[New South Wales]] and [[Queensland]] in [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state [[Herbarium|herbaria]] continue to use the name ''Callistemon acuminatus''.)<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> It is a shrub with broad, lance-shaped leaves which have wavy edges and taper gradually to a fine point. In spring it has typical bottlebrush flowers whose fiery colour gives the species its name.

==Description==
''Melaleuca flammea'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|1-5|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with hard, fibrous bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|36-151|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|6-31|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, broad to narrow lance-shaped and gradually taper to a fine point. They are also distinguished by their broad v-shape, wavy margin with scattered fine teeth and 12 to 33 distinct lateral veins.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=167}}</ref><ref name=plantnet>{{cite web|title=''Callistemon acuminatus''|url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Callistemon~acuminatus|publisher=Royal Botanic Garden Sydney: PlantNet|accessdate=12 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=ANBG>{{cite web|last1=Williams|first1=Mark|title=''Callistemon acuminatus''|url=https://www.anbg.gov.au/gnp/interns-2003/callistemon-acuminatus.html|publisher=Australian National Botanic Garden|accessdate=12 June 2015}}</ref>

The flowers are deep red to crimson and arranged in spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering. The spikes are up to {{convert|70|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with 25 to 120 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|3-5.4|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages. There are 20 to 32 bright red [[stamen]]s in each flower. Flowering occurs mainly in spring but often at other times of the year and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|3.9-5.5|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name="plantnet"/>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca flammea'' was first named in 2006 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Novon]]''.<ref name=APNI(1)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca flammea''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/613689|publisher=APNI|accessdate=12 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=Novon>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=New Combinations in Melaleuca for Australian Species of Callistemon (Myrtaceae)|journal=Novon|date=2006|volume=16|issue=4|page=471|url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.3417/1055-3177%282006%2916%5B468%3ANCIMFA%5D2.0.CO%3B2|accessdate=12 June 2015|doi=10.3417/1055-3177(2006)16[468:NCIMFA]2.0.CO;2}}</ref> It had first been formally described as ''Callistemon acuminatus'' by [[Edwin Cheel]] in 1911 in ''[[Illustrations of New South Wales Plants]]'' from a specimen collected "''on slopes of rocky mountains, Crawford River, 7 miles'' (10km) ''from [[Bulahdelah, New South Wales|Bullahdelah]].''"<ref name=APNI(2)>{{cite web|title=''Callistemon acuminatus''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/521824|publisher=APNI|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''flammea'') is from the [[Latin]] word ''flammeus'' meaning “flaming” or "fiery-red"<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.|page=330}}</ref> referring to the fiery colour of the stamens.<ref name="Brophy" />[[File:Melaleuca flammea (habit).jpg|thumb|225px|''M. flammea'' growing in [[Sherwood Nature Reserve]]]]

''Callistemon acuminatus'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca flammea'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref name '"WCSP">{{WCSP | 31409 | ''Callistemon acuminatus'' }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca flammea'' occurs near [[Nambour, Queensland|Nambour]] in Queensland and in coastal areas of New South Wales from [[Port Stephens (New South Wales)|Port Stephens]] to the [[Clarence River (New South Wales)|Clarence River]] district. It usually grows in woodland or forest on dry, rocky hilltops<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="plantnet" />

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca flammea'', as ''Callistemon acuminatus'', is a classified in New South Wales as a "[[ROTAP|Rare or Threatened Australian Plant]]".<ref name="ANBG" />

==Use in horticulture==
Although not common in cultivation, this species is hardy, frost and drought tolerant and its distinctive leaves and large, brightly coloured flowers give it horticultural potential.<ref name="ANBG" />

178.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = Green bottlebrush
|status =
|status_system = 
|image = Melaleuca flavovirens leaves and flowers.jpg
|image caption = ''Melaleuca flavovirens'' leaves and flowers
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. flavovirens'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca flavovirens''
|binomial_authority = ([[Edwin Cheel|Cheel]]) [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
|synonyms_ref =  <ref name ="APNI(3)" />
| synonyms = 
*''Callistemon flavovirens'' <small> ([[Edwin Cheel|Cheel]]) Cheel
}}
'''''Melaleuca flavovirens''''', commonly known as '''green bottlebrush''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to a small area near the [[New South Wales]] - [[Queensland]] border in [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state [[Herbarium|herbaria]] continue to use the name ''Callistemon flavovirens''.)<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> It is a stiff shrub, distinguished by its silvery new growth and spikes of greenish flowers with yellow tips.

==Description==
''Melaleuca flavovirens'' is a spreading shrub growing to {{convert|1-3|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with hard, corrugated bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|36-102|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|4-11|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, narrow egg-shaped with the narrower end towards the base, and a short, blunt tip on the end. They are also distinguished by their broad v-shape, distinct oil glands on both surfaces, a mid-rib and 8 to 16 distinct lateral veins.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=168}}</ref><ref name=plantnet>{{cite web|title=''Callistemon flavovirens''|url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Callistemon~flavovirens|publisher=Royal Botanic Garden Sydney: PlantNet|accessdate=13 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=Harden>{{cite book|last1=Harden|first1=Gwen J.|title=Flora of New South Wales. Volume 2|date=2002|publisher=New South Wales University Press|location=Sydney|isbn=0868406090|page=195|edition=Revised|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=MtKLQQlu0qkC&pg=PR7&lpg=PR7&dq=Callistemon+flavovirens&source=bl&ots=QEeAo56euf&sig=JKdfaZ3jwx_0aZ2-Y7yei97U-xE&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAzgKahUKEwj-kNeOvYzGAhVBnLwKHThVAKQ#v=onepage&q=Callistemon%20flavovirens&f=false|accessdate=13 June 2015}}</ref>

The flowers are whitish through cream to green and arranged in spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering as well as on the sides of the branches. The spikes are up to {{convert|55|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with 15 to 40 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|3.9-6.1|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages. There are 34 to 38 [[stamen]]s in each flower, tipped with yellow. Flowering occurs between May and December and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|5.7-8.2|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name="plantnet" /><ref name="Harden"/>[[File:Melaleuca flavovirens habit.jpg|thumb|225px|''Melaleuca flavovirens'' in [[Boonoo Boonoo National Park]]]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
The species was first formally described in 1925 by  [[Edwin Cheel]] who gave it the name ''Callistemon rugulosus'' var. ''flavo-virens''. The description was published in ''Illustrations of New South Wales Plants''.<ref name=APNI(1)>{{cite web|title=''Callistemon rugulosus'' var ''flavo-virens''|url=  http://id.biodiversity.org.au/instance/apni/522794|publisher=APNI|accessdate=4 March 2016}}</ref> In 1925, Cheel raised the variety to species level and gave it the name ''Callistemon flavovirens'', publishing the change in ''[[Proceedings of the Linnean Society of New South Wales]]''.<ref name=APNI(2)>{{cite web|title=''Callistemon flavovirens''|url=  http://id.biodiversity.org.au/instance/apni/522102|publisher=APNI|accessdate=4 March 2016}}</ref><ref name=Cheel>{{cite journal|last1=Cheel|first1=Edwin|title=Two new species of ''Callistemon'' with notes on certain other species|journal=Proceedings of the Linnean Society of New South Wales|date=1925|volume=50|page=263|url=http://biodiversitylibrary.org/item/108646#page/309/mode/1up|accessdate=4 March 2016}}</ref> In 2006, [[Lyndley Craven]] changed the name to ''Melaleuca flavovirens'', publishing the change in ''[[Novon]]''.<ref name=APNI(3)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca flavovirens''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/613690|publisher=APNI|accessdate=13 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=Novon>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=New Combinations in Melaleuca for Australian Species of Callistemon (Myrtaceae)|journal=Novon|date=2006|volume=16|issue=4|page=471|url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.3417/1055-3177%282006%2916%5B468%3ANCIMFA%5D2.0.CO%3B2|accessdate=13 June 2015|doi=10.3417/1055-3177(2006)16[468:NCIMFA]2.0.CO;2}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''flavovirens'') is from the [[Latin]] words ''flavus'' meaning “golden-yellow” or "yellow"<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref>{{rp|872}} and ''virens'' meaning "green",<ref name="RWB" />{{rp|383}} referring to the colour of the stamens.<ref name="Brophy" />

''Callistemon flavovirens'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca flavovirens'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref name '"WCSP">{{WCSP | 31426 | ''Callistemon flavovirens'' }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca flavovirens'' occurs in the mountains and tablelands from the [[Stanthorpe, Queensland|Stanthorpe]] and [[Wallangarra, Queensland|Wallangarra]] districts in Queensland south to [[Torrington, New South Wales|Torrington]] and the [[Guy Fawkes River National Park]] in northern New South Wales. It grows in scrubland, heath and forest along watercourses and amongst boulders on hilltops.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="plantnet" />

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca flavovirens'', as ''Callistemon flavovirens'', is classified in New South Wales as a "[[ROTAP|Rare or Threatened Australian Plant]]".<ref name="plantnet" />

==Use in horticulture==
''Melaleuca flavovirens'' is a drought resistant species but will tolerate wet situations and is tolerant of frosts. It can be propagated from seed or from [[Cutting (plant)|cuttings]].<ref name="APS">{{cite web|title=''Callistemon flavovirens''|url=http://austplants.com.au/plant-profiles-base/from-our-cold-climate-garden-sorted/135-callistemon-flavovirens.html|publisher=Australian Plants Society - NSW|accessdate=14 November 2016}}</ref>

179.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = Kingaroy bottlebrush
|status =
|status_system = 
|image = Melaleuca formosa.jpg
|image caption = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. formosa'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca formosa''
|binomial_authority = ([[Stanley Thatcher Blake|S.T.Blake]]) [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
|synonyms = <small> ''[[Callistemon formosus]]'' [[Stanley Thatcher Blake|S.T.Blake]] </small>
}}

'''''Melaleuca formosa''''', commonly known as '''Kingaroy bottlebrush''' or '''cliff bottlebrush''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to a small area in [[Queensland]], Australia. (Some Australian state [[Herbarium|herbaria]] continue to use the name ''Callistemon formosus''.)<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> It is a shrub with weeping branches and spikes of lemon-coloured flowers in spring.

==Description==
''Melaleuca formosa'' is a spreading shrub growing to {{convert|2-6|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|35-86|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|3-9|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, flat, narrow egg-shaped or narrow elliptical with a mid-vein and have distinct oil glands and 11 to 24 branching veins.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=171}}</ref>

The flowers are whitish through cream to lime-green and arranged in spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering as well as on the sides of the branches. The spikes are up to {{convert|45|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with 20 to 40 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|3.5-4.5|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages. There are 57 to 63 [[stamen]]s in each flower, tipped with yellow. Flowering occurs throughout the year but mainly in spring and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|3.8-5.4|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=ANBG>{{cite web|title=Bottlebrush - genus ''Callistemon''|url=http://www.anbg.gov.au/callistemon/|publisher=Australian National Botanic Garden|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca formosa'' was named in 2006 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Novon]]''.<ref name=APNI(1)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca formosa''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/613691|publisher=APNI|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=Novon>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=New Combinations in Melaleuca for Australian Species of Callistemon (Myrtaceae)|journal=Novon|date=2006|volume=16|issue=4|page=472|url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.3417/1055-3177%282006%2916%5B468%3ANCIMFA%5D2.0.CO%3B2|accessdate=14 June 2015|doi=10.3417/1055-3177(2006)16[468:NCIMFA]2.0.CO;2}}</ref> It had previously been known as ''Callistemon formosus'' having first been formally described in 1958 by [[Stanley Thatcher Blake|S.T.Blake]] in ''[[Proceedings of the Royal Society of Queensland]]'' from a specimen found "near [[Kingaroy]] (near Edenvale Rwy. Stn.), low plateau, remnant of mixed low forest on red loam."<ref name=APNI(2)>{{cite web|title=''Callistemon formosus''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/522133|publisher=APNI|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''formosa'') is a [[Latin]] word meaning “beautifully formed” or "handsome"<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.|page =346}}</ref> referring to the appearance of the plant.<ref name="Brophy" />

''Callistemon formosus'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca formosa'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref name '"WCSP">{{WCSP | 31427 | ''Callistemon formosus'' }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in near coastal districts in south eastern Queensland where it grows in vine forest or as an understorey plant beneath eucalypts in [[loam]] or sandy soil over [[trachyte]].<ref name="Brophy" />

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca formosa'' is classified as "near threatened" under the Government of Queensland Nature Conservation Act (1992).<ref name=nprsr>{{cite web|title=Mount Walsh National Park Management Statement|url=http://www.nprsr.qld.gov.au/managing/plans-strategies/statements/pdf/mount-walsh.pdf|publisher=Queensland Government Department of National Parks, Recreation, Sport and Racing|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref>

==Use in horticulture==
''Melaleuca formosa'' is grown as a street tree in Kingaroy.<ref name="ANBG" /> It is recommended as a shrub to be grown under powerlines<ref name=ergon>{{cite web|title=Think smart, plant smart|url=https://www.ergon.com.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0004/48892/Gympie-RC_PS-Brochure-Approved.pdf|publisher=Ergon Energy|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref> and has been found to be relatively tolerant to the fungal disease, myrtle rust (''[[Uredo rangelii]]'').<ref name=ngiq>{{cite web|title=Myrtle Rust Management Plan (2012)|url=http://www.ngiq.asn.au/wp-content/uploads/Myrtle-Rust-Management-Plan-2012-Final.pdf|publisher=Nursey and Garden Industry|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref>

180.text:
{{italic title}} {{taxobox |name = Albany bottlebrush |image = Melaleuca glauca (habit).JPG |image_caption = ''M. glauca'' in [[Gull Rock National Park]]. |status = |status_system = |regnum = [[Plantae]] |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s |unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s |unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s |ordo = [[Myrtales]] |familia = [[Myrtaceae]] |genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]'' |species = '''''M. glauca''''' |binomial = ''Melaleuca glauca'' |binomial_authority = ([[Robert Sweet (botanist)|Sweet]]) [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]] |synonyms = ''Callistemon glaucus'' ([[Augustin Pyramus de Candolle|DC.]]) [[Robert Sweet (botanist)|Sweet]]
''Callistemon speciosus'' ([[John Sims (taxonomist)|Sims]]) [[Robert Sweet (botanist)|Sweet]]
''Callistemon citrinus'' (Curtis) [[Skeels]] }} '''''Melaleuca glauca''''', commonly known as '''Albany bottlebrush''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. (Some Australian state [[Herbarium|herbaria]] continue to use the name ''Callistemon glaucus''. Craven claims that there is no [[Type (biology)|type material]] for ''Callistemon speciosus'' and includes it here as a synonym.){{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=11 June 2015}}{{cite web|title=Callistemon speciosus|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/nsl/services/search?product=apc&tree.id=1133571&name=Callistemon+speciosus&max=100&display=apc&search=true|publisher=Australian Plant Census|accessdate=22 July 2015}} It is a tall shrub with [[glaucous]] leaves and spikes of red flowers in spring. ==Description== ''Melaleuca glauca'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|3.5|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with hard, fibrous bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|40-128|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|3-18|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, flat, mostly narrow egg-shaped with a mid-vein and 11 to 20 branching veins.{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|pages=177–178}} The flowers are bright red and arranged in spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering. The spikes are up to {{convert|75|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with 20 to 120 or more individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|4.5-7.2|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages. The stamens are arranged in five bundles around the flower and there are between 6 and 15 stamens per bundle. Flowering occurs from October to December and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|5.7-8.8|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long. [[File:Melaleuca glauca (leaves, flowers, fruits).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. glauca'' leaves, flowers and fruit]] ==Taxonomy and naming== ''Melaleuca glauca'' was named in 2013 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses''. It was first formally described in 1815 by [[Aimé Bonpland]] as ''Metrosideros glauca'' however the description was not validly published. In 1830, the [[English people|English]] botanist [[Robert Sweet (botanist)|Robert Sweet]] gave it the name ''[[Callistemon glaucus]]''.{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca glauca''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/773227|publisher=APNI|accessdate=5 August 2015}}{{cite book|last1=Sweet|first1=Robert|title=Hortus Britannicus|date=1830|publisher=James Ridgway|location=London|page=209|edition=2nd|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/41438#page/224/mode/1up|accessdate=13 July 2015}} The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''glauca'') is from the [[Latin]] word ''glaucus'' meaning “blue-grey” or "blue-green"{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.|page=369}} referring to the glaucous leaves. ''Callistemon glaucus'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca glauca'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].{{WCSP | 31430 | ''Callistemon glaucus'' }} ==Distribution and habitat== ''Melaleuca glauca'' occurs in the south and south-western coastal districts of Western Australia between [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]] and [[Albany, Western Australia|Albany]] in the [[Jarrah Forest]], [[Swan Coastal Plain]] and [[Warren (biogeographic region)|Warren]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]], where it grows in swampy ground in sandy or clayey soils.{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=350}}{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca glauca''|id = 5394}} ==Conservation== ''Melaleuca glauca'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]]. ==Use in horticulture== ''Melaleuca glauca'' is widely grown as an ornamental (as ''Callistemon glaucus'') in temperate parts of Australia. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} [[Category:Melaleuca|glauca]] [[Category:Flora of Australia]] [[Category:Flora of Western Australia]] [[Category:Plants described in 1815]] [[Category:Endemic flora of Western Australia]]
180.title: Melaleuca glauca

181.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|status = 
|status_system = 
|image = Melaleuca glena (leaves, flowers, fruits).JPG
|image caption = ''M. glena'' leaves, flowers and fruit
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. glena'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca glena''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca glena''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the south of [[Western Australia]]. It is similar to the commonly cultivated ''[[Melaleuca nesophila]]'' with its purple "[[pom-pom]]" flower heads but is a smaller shrub with the [[inflorescence]]s much more often on the sides of the branches and only occasionally on the ends.

==Description==
''Melaleuca glena'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|2|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with papery bark and [[Glabrousness|glabrous]] young stems. Its leaves are flat, narrow egg-shaped, {{convert|24-46|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|6.5-10.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide with rounded ends and 5 to 7 longitudinal veins.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=179}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=200–201|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are a shade of pink to purple and are arranged in heads or spikes usually only on the sides of the branches. The spikes are up to {{convert|15|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and composed of 5 to 12 groups of flowers in threes. The outer edge of the [[Hypanthium|floral cup]] and the parts of the flowers covering the buds are covered with short, soft, silky white hairs. The petals are {{convert|1.2-1.8|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages. There are five bundles of stamens around the flower, each with 4 to 7 stamens. Flowering occurs in spring and early summer and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]] {{convert|2.5-3.5|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long, in almost spherical clusters along the stem.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>
[[File:Melaleuca glena (habit).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. glena'' at the [[Type (biology)|type]] location in the Mount Burdett Nature Reserve]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca glena'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected near [[Scaddan, Western Australia|Scaddan]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca glena''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561711|publisher=APNI|accessdate=6 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=878|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''glena'') is from the [[Ancient Greek]] ''glenos'' meaning “a thing to stare at" or "a thing to wonder at” <ref name=glenos>{{cite journal|last1=Saul|first1=L.R.|last2=Squires|first2=R.L.|title=Pacific slope Cretaceous gastropods|journal=Journal of Palaeontology|date=2001|volume=75|issue=1|page=57|url=http://research.nhm.org/pdfs/33637/33637-004.pdf|accessdate=6 May 2015}}</ref><ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.|page=312}}</ref> referring to the lateral flower heads of this species.<ref name=Brophy />

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca glena'' occurs in the [[Wittenoom Hills]] and [[Fitzgerald River]] districts near [[Esperance, Western Australia|Esperance]]<ref name=Brophy /> in the [[Esperance Plains]] and [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]]<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca glena''|id = 18277}}</ref> where it grows in shrubland and [[Mallee (habit)|mallee]] in clay soil over granite or [[laterite]]<ref name=Brophy/> or a fossil bearing rock called [[spongolite]].<ref name=Flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=393}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca glena'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

==References==
{{reflist|30em}}

[[Category:Flora of Australia]]
[[Category:Melaleuca|glena]]
[[Category:Flora of Western Australia]]
[[Category:Plants described in 1999]]
[[Category:Endemic flora of Western Australia]]
181.title: Melaleuca glena

182.text:
{{taxobox
|status = P1
|status_system = DECF
|image = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. grieveana'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca grieveana''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca grieveana''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It is similar to ''[[Melaleuca brophyi]]'' with its heads of yellow flowers and almost cylindrical leaves. The main difference is that the leaves of this species, but not those of ''Melaleuca brophyi'' are covered with soft hairs.

==Description==
''Melaleuca grieveana'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|1.2|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with young stems that are usually covered with soft hairs. Its leaves are linear to very narrow egg-shaped, almost cylindrical in cross-section, {{convert|5-19.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|0.8-1.6|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide and usually covered with soft, silky, woolly hairs.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=184}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|page=38|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are creamy-white to yellow and are arranged in heads on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering, sometimes also in the upper leaf axils. The heads are up to {{convert|14|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and composed of 4 to 8 groups of flowers in threes. The petals are {{convert|1.4-1.6|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages. There are five bundles of stamens around the flower, each with 3 to 6 stamens. Flowering occurs in spring and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]] {{convert|2.0-2.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca grieveana'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected near [[Wyalkatchem, Western Australia|Wyalkatchem]] in 1937.<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca grieveana''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561714|publisher=APNI|accessdate=6 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=878|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''grieveana'') is in honour of the Australian botanist, [[Brian Grieve]] who wrote books on the identification of Western Australian flora.<ref name=Brophy />

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca grieveana'' occurs in the [[Cowcowing, Western Australia|Cowcowing]], [[Narembeen, Western Australia|Narembeen]] and [[Moorine Rock, Western Australia|Moorine Rock]] districts<ref name=Brophy /> in the [[Avon Wheatbelt]] and [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]] where it grows in sandplain vegetation or [[Mallee Woodlands and Shrublands|mallee]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca grieveana''|id = 19450}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca grieveana'' is listed as "[[Declared Rare and Priority Flora List|Priority One]]" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]]<ref name="FloraBase" /> meaning that it is "known from one or a few locations (generally five or less) which are potentially at risk".<ref name=dpaw>{{cite web|title=Conservation codes for flora and fauna|url=http://www.dpaw.wa.gov.au/images/documents/plants-animals/threatened-species/Listings/conservation_code_definitions.pdf|publisher=Government of Western Australia department of parks and wildlife|accessdate=1 May 2015}}</ref>

{{taxobox
|status =

|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s

|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]

}}

'''''Melaleuca halophila''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the south of [[Western Australia]]. It is a prickly shrub, similar to ''[[Melaleuca thapsina]]'' but its flowers are white and the leaves are shorter and hairier.

==Description==
''Melaleuca halophila'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|3|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall. Its leaves are arranged alternately, linear to very narrow elliptic, roughly oval in cross-section, {{convert|11-30.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|1.7-2.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide with a short, prickly point on the end. The leaves are covered with short, soft hairs.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=187}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|page=284|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are white and arranged in heads on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and in the upper leaf axils. The heads are up to {{convert|15|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and composed of 5 to 11 groups of flowers in threes. The petals are {{convert|1.0-1.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages. There are five bundles of stamens around the flower, each with 3 to 7 stamens. Flowering occurs in October and November and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]] {{convert|1.8-3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>
[[File:Melaleuca halophila (leaves, flowers, fruits).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. halophila'' leaves, flowers and fruit]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca halophila'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected near [[Salmon Gums, Western Australia|Salmon Gums]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca halophila''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561716|publisher=APNI|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=880|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''halophila'') is from the [[Ancient Greek]] words ''halos'' meaning "salt” or "sea"<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref>{{rp|678}} and ''philia'' meaning “beloved" or "dear",<ref name="RWB" />{{rp|498}}  referring to the apparent preference of this species for salty situations.<ref name=Brophy />

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca halophila'' occurs in the [[Fitzgerald River National Park|Fitzgerald Peaks]] and [[Salmon Gums, Western Australia|Salmon Gums]] districts in the [[Esperance Plains]] and [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca halophila''|id = 18166}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca halophila'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = Mount Wheeler bottlebrush
|image = 
|image_caption =
|status =

|regnum = [[Plantae]]

|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. hemisticta'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca hemisticta''
|binomial_authority = ([[Stanley Thatcher Blake|S.T.Blake]]) ex [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
|synonyms = <small> ''[[Callistemon hemistictus]]'' (S.T.Blake ex Craven) Udovicic & [[R.D.Spencer]] </small>
}}

'''''Melaleuca hemisticta''''', commonly known as '''Mount Wheeler bottlebrush''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to coastal areas of [[Queensland]]. (Some Australian state [[Herbarium|herbaria]] continue to use the name ''Callistemon hemistictus''.)<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> It is a tall, bushy shrub with dark green leaves and red flowers spikes tipped with yellow.

==Description==
''Melaleuca hemisticta'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|6|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with grey, papery or fibrous bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|42-102|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|6-28|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, flat, mostly narrow egg-shaped with a mid-vein and 15 to 30 branching veins.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|pages=192–193}}</ref><ref name=SGAP>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca hemisticta''|url=http://sgaptownsville.org.au/Melaleuca-hemisticta.html|publisher=Society for Growing Australian Plants, Townsville branch|accessdate=13 July 2015}}</ref>

The flowers are arranged in spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and sometimes on the sides of the branches. The spikes are {{convert|30-45|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with 10 to 50 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|3.4-5.4|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages. There are 35-53 stamens in each flower with red [[stamen|filaments]] and yellow anthers. Flowering occurs from March to September and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|4-5.2|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long.<ref name=Brophy/>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca hemisticta'' was first formally described in 2006 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Novon]]''.<ref name=APNI(1)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca hemisticta''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/653264|publisher=APNI|accessdate=14 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Novon>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=New Combinations in Melaleuca for Australian Species of Callistemon (Myrtaceae)|journal=Novon|date=2006|volume=16|issue=4|pages=444–445|url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.3417/1055-3177%282006%2916%5B468%3ANCIMFA%5D2.0.CO%3B2|accessdate=14 July 2015|doi=10.3417/1055-3177(2006)16[468:NCIMFA]2.0.CO;2}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''hemisticta'') is from the [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] prefix ''ἡμι- (hemi-)'' meaning “half”<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref>{{rp|392}} and ''stiktos'' meaning "spotted"<ref name="RWB" />{{rp|743}} referring to the oil glands in the leaves being only in the lower half of the leaf.<ref name="Brophy" />

''Callistemon hemistictus'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca hemisticta'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref name '"WCSP">{{WCSP | 472786 | ''Callistemon hemistictus'' }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca hemisticta'' occurs in coastal Queensland in and between the [[Bowen, Queensland|Bowen]] and [[Bundaberg]] regions, on nearby islands and on Mount Stewart near [[Townsville]], where it grows in a range of habitats but often on the sides of cliffs.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="SGAP" />

[[Category:Flora of Queensland]]

184.title: Melaleuca hemisticta

|image caption = ''M. hnatiukii'' growing at the [[Type (biology)|type]] location near Wittenoom Hill.
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]

|species = '''''M. hnatiukii'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca hnatiukii''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca hnatiukii''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the south of [[Western Australia]]. It is a medium to large shrub with arching branches, prickly tipped leaves and creamy-white heads of flowers in spring or early summer.

==Description==
''Melaleuca hnatiukii'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|2.5|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with whitish, papery bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately, elliptic to narrow egg-shaped, flat, {{convert|12-24|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|4-8|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide with a short, prickly point on the end.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=194}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|page=126|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are white or cream-coloured and arranged in heads or short spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and sometimes in the upper leaf axils. The heads are up to {{convert|23|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and composed of 2 to 12 groups of flowers in threes. The petals are {{convert|2-3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages. There are five bundles of stamens around the flower, each with 5 to 8 stamens. Flowering occurs between September and January and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], usually {{convert|3-4|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long, in oval-shaped clusters around the stem.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>
[[File:Melaleuca hnatiukii (leaves, flowers, fruits).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. hnatiukii'' leaves, flowers and fruit]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca hnatiukii'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected near [[Scaddan, Western Australia|Scaddan]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca hnatiukii''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561719|publisher=APNI|accessdate=6 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=880|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''hnatiukii'') honours [[Roger Hnatiuk]], a [[Canadians|Canadian]]-[[Australians|Australian botanist]].<ref name=Brophy />

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca hnatiukii'' occurs in the [[Scaddan, Western Australia|Scaddan]] and [[Esperance, Western Australia|Esperance]] districts in the [[Esperance Plains]] and [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca hnatiukii''|id = 18274}}</ref> It grows in sandy soils in heath near salt lakes.<ref name=flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=394}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca hnatiukii'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

==References==

[[Category:Flora of Western Australia]]
[[Category:Plants described in 1999]]

{{taxobox
|status =

|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. hollidayi'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca hollidayi''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca hollidayi''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], Myrtaceae and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the south of [[Western Australia]]. It is a small shrub with fine hairs like [[spider web]] on its leaves, and bright pink flowers.

==Description==
''Melaleuca hollidayi'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|1.3|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}}, usually less but often spreading to more than {{convert|1|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide and which has papery bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately, linear in shape, oval in cross section, {{convert|5-12|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|0.5-0.8|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide with a rounded end and a covering of fine hairs like [[spider silk]].<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=195}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=138–139|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are a shade of deep pink to purple, arranged in heads on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and sometimes in the upper leaf axils. The heads are up to {{convert|22|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and composed of 2 to 9 groups of flowers in threes. The petals are {{convert|1.5-2.6|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower opens. There are five bundles of stamens around the flower, each with 5 to 10 stamens. Flowering occurs between August and November and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], usually {{convert|3-4|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long, in small, loose clusters around the stem.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca hollidayi'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected near [[Scaddan, Western Australia|Scaddan]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca hollidayi''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561720|publisher=APNI|accessdate=6 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=881|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''hollidayi'') honours [[Ivan Holliday]], an [[Australian]] author of books about native plants who did much to promote the use of indigenous plants in cultivation, including ''Melaleuca'' species.<ref name=Brophy />

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca hollidayi'' occurs in the [[Kalbarri, Western Australia|Kalbarri]] and [[Mullewa, Western Australia|Mullewa]]<ref name=Brophy /> districts in the [[Esperance Plains]] and [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca hollidayi''|id = 18527}}</ref> It grows in sandy soils on sandplains<ref name=flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=394}}</ref> in heath, often with ''[[Banksia]]'' species.<ref name=Brophy />

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca hollidayi'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

|image caption = ''M. huttensis'' growing on the road to Coronation Beach.
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. huttensis'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca huttensis''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca huttensis''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It is a small, woody shrub with elliptic leaves, mostly crowded near the ends of the branches which are tipped with heads of white or yellow flowes during spring and early summer. It is a threatened species, potentially endangered by the construction of the [[Oakajee Port]] near [[Geraldton]].

==Description==
''Melaleuca huttensis'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|2.5|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall, with its lower branches lacking leaves. Its leaves are near the ends of the branches, arranged alternately, broad oval to almost circular in shape, flat and fleshy, {{convert|3.5-6.6|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|3.2-5.8|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide with a rounded end.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=200}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=142–143|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are white to a shade of yellow and fade to pink. They are arranged in heads on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering. The heads are up to {{convert|22|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and composed of up to 14 groups of flowers in threes. The petals are {{convert|2-2.7|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower opens. There are five bundles of stamens around the flower, each with 10 to 12 stamens. Flowering occurs between August and November and is followed by fruit which are woody, urn-shaped [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]] usually {{convert|4-5|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long, in small clusters around the stem.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>
[[File:Melaleuca huttensis (flowers).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. huttensis'' flowers]]
[[File:Melaleuca huttensis (leaves, fruit).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. huttensis'' leaves and fruit]]
[[File:Melaleuca huttensis (bark).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. huttensis'' bark]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca huttensis'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected on the road to Coronation Beach near Geraldton.<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca huttensis''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561724|publisher=APNI|accessdate=11 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=881|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''huttensis'') is derived from the name of the hearby [[Hutt River (Western Australia)|Hutt River]].<ref name=Brophy />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in the [[Hutt River (Western Australia)|Hutt River]] district<ref name=Holliday /> in the [[Geraldton Sandplains]] [[IBRA|biogeographic region]] where it grows in heath on sandplains.<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca huttensis''|id = 19451}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca huttensis'' is listed as "[[Declared Rare and Priority Flora List|Priority One]]" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]]<ref name="FloraBase" /> meaning that it is known from a few locations which are potentially at risk and all occurrences are on lands not managed for conservation.<ref name=dpaw>{{cite web|title=Conservation codes for flora and fauna|url=http://www.dpaw.wa.gov.au/images/documents/plants-animals/threatened-species/Listings/conservation_code_definitions.pdf|publisher=Government of Western Australia department of parks and wildlife|accessdate=11 May 2015}}</ref> A targeted flora survey was undertaken for the Oakajee Rail and Port development, although the development has so far not proceeded.<ref name=survey>{{cite web|title=Oakajee Port and Rail targeted flora survey, ''Melaleuca huttensis''|url=http://www.epa.wa.gov.au/EIA/EPAReports/Documents/1387%20-%20Ecologia%20Melaleuca%20huttensis%20targeted%20search.pdf|publisher=Government of Western Australia, Environmental Protection Authority|accessdate=11 May 2015}}</ref>

|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca idana''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]], and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It is a small shrub with fine, silky hairs covering the new foliage and heads of pink to deep purple flowers in early spring. It is similar to ''[[Melaleuca sapientes]]'', differing mainly in the shape of the leaves in cross-section and the length of its [[Stigma (botany)|style]]s.

==Description==
''M. idana'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|1|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|6-22|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|0.7-1.0|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, linear in shape and roughly oblong in cross-section.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=202}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|page=250|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are a shade of pink to deep purple, arranged in heads on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering. The heads are up to {{convert|33|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and composed of three to six groups of flowers in threes. The petals are {{convert|1.5-2.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages. Five bundles of stamens are around the flower, each with six to 10 stamens and the styles are {{convert|11-13|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long. Flowering occurs between August and October and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|3.5-5|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca idana'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected on the northern boundary of [[Kalbarri National Park]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca idana''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561726|publisher=APNI|accessdate=6 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=882|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''idana'') is from the [[Ancient Greek]]  ἰδᾰνός (''idanós'') meaning "fair" or "comely"<ref name=LSJ>{{cite web|title=ἰδανός|url=http://lsj.translatum.gr/wiki/ἰδανός|publisher=Liddell, Scott, Jones Ancient Greek lexicon:online version|accessdate=12 May 2015}}</ref> referring to the attractive flowers.<ref name=Brophy />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in the [[Wannoo, Western Australia|Wannoo]] and [[Kalbarri, Western Australia|Kalbarri]]<ref name=Brophy /> districts in the [[Geraldton Sandplains]] and [[Yalgoo (biogeographic region)|Yalgoo]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca idana''|id = 19049}}</ref> It grows in dry yellow sand on sandplains.<ref name=flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=394}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca idana'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

==References==
