[[Category:Flora of Western Australia]]
[[Category:Plants described in 1999]]
[[Category:Endemic flora of Western Australia]]
188.title: Melaleuca idana

189.text:
{{taxobox
|status =
|status_system = 
|image = Melaleuca interioris (habit).jpg
|image caption = ''M. interioris'' growing near Lake Raeside
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. interioris'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca interioris''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]] & Lepschi
}}

'''''Melaleuca interioris''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to [[Western Australia]], [[South Australia]], [[Queensland]], [[New South Wales]] and the [[Northern Territory]]. It was formerly included in ''[[Melaleuca uncinata]]'' and is similar to that species with its cylinder-shaped leaves and small heads of yellow flowers, but with smaller, less compressed fruiting capsules.

==Description==
''Melaleuca interioris'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|3|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with papery bark. Its leaves are spreading or erect and are {{convert|6-56|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|06-1.2|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, linear in shape, roughly circular to oblong in cross-section and end in a sharp point.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=205}}</ref>

The flowers are yellow and are arranged in heads which are composed of 4 to 9 groups of flowers in threes. The petals are {{convert|1.1-1.3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, circular to egg-shaped and fall off as the flower opens. There are five bundles of stamens around the flower, each with 4 to 9 stamens. Flowering occurs between August and November and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|3.8-8|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, about the same length as width. The capsules remain separate from each other (whereas in ''[[Melaleuca uncinata]]'' they tend to become compressed together so that they look like a single fruit).<ref name=Brophy/>[[File:Melaleuca interioris (leaves and flowers).jpg|thumb|225px|''M. interioris'' leaves and flowers]]
[[File:Melaleuca interioris (fruit).jpg|thumb|225px|''M. interioris'' fruit]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca interioris'' was first formally described in 2004 by [[Lyndley Craven]] and Brendan Lepschi in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]''<ref name=CSIRO>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=Brendan J.|last3=Broadhurst|first3=Linda|last4=Byrne|first4=Margaret|title=Taxonomic revision of the broombush complex in Western Australia (Myrtaceae, Melaleuca uncinata s.l.)|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=2004|volume=17|issue=3|page=263|doi=10.1071/SB04001}}</ref> from a specimen collected {{convert|134|km|mi|sigfig=1}} north of [[Leinster, Western Australia|Leinster]] in Western Australia.<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca interioris''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/589519|publisher=APNI|accessdate=12 May 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''interioris'') refers to the interior of Australia, where this species is found.<ref name=Brophy />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in the central parts of Western Australia,<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca interioris''|id = 20288}}</ref> the central parts of South Australia, the southern half of the Northern Territory, far west of New South Wales<ref name=plantnet>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca interioris''|url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Melaleuca~interioris|publisher=Royal Botanic Garden Sydney:PlantNet|accessdate=12 May 2015}}</ref> and the far south-west corner of Queensland.<ref name=Brophy /> It grows in shrubland in red sand on the edges of salt lakes, and near ephemeral creeks, claypans and floodplains.<ref name=Brophy /><ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca interioris''|id = 20288}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca interioris'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

==Uses in agriculture==
''Melaleuca interioris'' and related species of melaleucas such as ''[[Melaleuca uncinata|M. uncinata]]'' and ''[[Melaleuca atroviridis|M. atroviridis]]'' can be used to protect property from wind and water erosion, reduce salinity and waterlogging, provide wildlife habitat and provide income by harvesting for brushwood fencing.<ref name=avongrow>{{cite web|title=Integrated brushwood plantings for natural resource management benefits to farming systems|url=http://www.avongro.com.au/Webpages/documents/BrushwoodandNRMfinal.pdf|publisher=Avongrow Wheatbelt Tree Croppping|accessdate=12 May 2015}}</ref>

189.title: Melaleuca interioris

190.text:
{{taxobox
|status =
|status_system = 
|image = Melaleuca johnsonii (habit).JPG
|image caption = ''M. johnsonii'' growing 10 km east of [[Hyden, Western Australia|Hyden]].
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. johnsonii'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca johnsonii''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca johnsonii''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the south of [[Western Australia]]. It is similar to ''[[Melaleuca thapsina]]'' with its cylindrical leaves with prickly tips and usually yellow heads of flowers but is distinguished from it by its shorter leaves and papery [[sepal]]s.

==Description==
''Melaleuca johnsonii'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|3|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with fibrous bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|7-16.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|0.9 - 17.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, linear in shape and roughly oblong in cross-section narrowing to a sharp, straight tip.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=207}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|page=284|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are usually yellow, sometimes creamy-white and occasionally pink. They are arranged in heads on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and sometimes also in the upper leaf axils. The heads are up to {{convert|13|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and composed of 4 to 7 groups of flowers in threes. The sepals are {{convert|0.1-0.3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and papery. The petals are {{convert|1.0-1.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages. There are five bundles of stamens around the flower, each with 3 to 5 stamens. Flowering occurs between August and November and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|1.5-3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long in spherical clusters around the stem.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>[[File:Melaleuca johnsonii (leaves, flowers, fruits).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. johnsonii'' leaves, flowers and fruit]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca johnsonii'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected {{convert|80|km|mi|sigfig=1}} west of [[Esperance, Western Australia|Esperance]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca johnsonii''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561731|publisher=APNI|accessdate=12 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=883|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''johnsonii'') honours [[Lawrence Alexander Sidney Johnson]], an [[Australian]] [[Taxonomy (biology)|taxonomist]].<ref name=Brophy />

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca johnsonii'' occurs in and between the [[Hyden, Western Australia|Hyden]], [[Marvel Loch, Western Australia|Marvel Loch]], [[Norseman, Western Australia|Norseman]], [[Newdegate, Western Australia|Newdegate]] and [[Esperance, Western Australia|Esperance]] districts<ref name=Brophy /> in the [[Avon Wheatbelt]], [[Coolgardie (biogeographic region)|Coolgardie]], [[Esperance Plains]] and [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca johnsonii''|id = 19081}}</ref> It grows in gravelly sand and claypans.<ref name=flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=394}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca johnsonii'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

==References==
{{reflist|30em}}

[[Category:Flora of Western Australia]]
[[Category:Plants described in 1999]]
[[Category:Endemic flora of Western Australia]]
190.title: Melaleuca johnsonii

{{taxobox
|status =
|status_system = 
|image = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]

|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. keigheryi'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca keigheryi''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca keigheryi''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the west coast of [[Western Australia]]. It is a shrub with white, papery bark and in spring, heads of pink flowers which fade to white.

==Description==
''Melaleuca keigheryi'' is a shrub with papery bark growing to {{convert|2.5|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|12-23|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|2.4-5.2|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, flat, egg-shaped and with a sort, blunt tip. They are also unusual for the genus in that they have [[Pinnation|pinnate]] rather than longitudinal veins.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=208}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|page=304|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are a shade of pink to purple and fade to white. They are arranged in heads on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and sometimes also in the upper leaf axils. The heads are up to {{convert|25|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and composed of 4 to 9 groups of flowers in threes. The petals are {{convert|1.5-2.3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower opens. There are five bundles of stamens around the flower, each with 6 to 10 stamens. Flowering occurs between August and October and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|3-4|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long in roughly spherical clusters around the stem.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca keigheryi'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected near [[Shark Bay]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca keigheryi''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561732|publisher=APNI|accessdate=12 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=883|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''keigheryi'') honours [[Gregory John Keighery|Greg Keighery]], an [[Australian]] [[botany|botanist]].<ref name=Brophy />

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca keigheryi'' occurs in the Shark Bay district<ref name=Brophy /> in the [[Carnarvon (biogeographic region)|Carnarvon]] and [[Yalgoo (biogeographic region)|Yalgoo]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]] where it grows in sand and clay on flats and near roads.<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca keigheryi''|id = 19525}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca keigheryi'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

==References==
{{Reflist|30em}}

[[Category:Flora of Western Australia]]
[[Category:Plants described in 1999]]
[[Category:Endemic flora of Western Australia]]
191.title: Melaleuca keigheryi

192.text:
{{taxobox
|status =
|status_system = 
|image = 
|image caption = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. laetifica'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca laetifica''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca laetifica''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the west coast of [[Western Australia]]. It has unusual warty, hairy leaves and heads of bright yellow flowers in spring. It is one of the brightest yellow flowering melaleucas and deserves a place in gardens in semi-dry to temperate areas.

==Description==
''Melaleuca laetifica'' is a bushy shrub growing to {{convert|1|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall in ideal conditions. Its branchlets are covered with soft, silky hairs when young but become [[Glabrousness|glabrous]] as they mature. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|5.5-12|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|0.5-1.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, roughly linear in shape and circular in cross section. They also have distinct, raised oil glands, giving the leaf a warty appearance and often there are long, white hairs, especially on the younger leaves.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=210}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|page=152|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are usually bright yellow, sometimes creamy-white and ageing to white. They are arranged in heads on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering. The heads are up to {{convert|23|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and composed of 4 to 10 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|2.5-4|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages. There are five bundles of stamens around the flower, each with 12 to 20 stamens. Flowering occurs between August and February, but mostly in spring and is followed by fruit which are woody capsules, {{convert|4-6|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long in loose clusters along the stem.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca laetifica'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected on the road to [[Geraldton]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca laetifica''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561734|publisher=APNI|accessdate=12 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=883|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''laetifica'') is derived from the [[Latin]] word ''laetus'' meaning "joyful", "glad" or "pleasant"<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref>{{rp|448}} and the suffix ''-fex'' meaning "to make"<ref name="RWB" />{{rp|44}} referring to the bright, pleasing flowers of this plant species.<ref name=Brophy />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in and between the [[Kalbarri, Western Australia|Kalbarri]] and [[Hutt River (Western Australia)|Hutt River]] districts<ref name=Brophy /> in the [[Geraldton Sandplains]] biogeographic region.<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca laetifica''|id = 18452}}</ref> It mostly grows in sand in low heath.<ref name=Holliday />

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca laetifica'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

==Use in horticulture==
''Melaleuca laetifica'' is probably the brightest yellow-flowering melaleuca and its low, ground-hugging habit makes it an ideal groundcover or fore-ground plant. It grows best in semi-dry to temperate areas and may not be suited to the humid east coast of Australia.<ref name=Holliday />

==References==

[[Category:Flora of Western Australia]]
[[Category:Plants described in 1999]]
[[Category:Endemic flora of Western Australia]]
192.title: Melaleuca laetifica

{{taxobox
|status =
|status_system =

|species = '''''M. lara'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca lara''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca lara''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to a small area on the west coast of [[Western Australia]]. It is similar to ''[[Melaleuca ciliosa]]'' with its hairy young leaves and heads of yellow flowers ageing to red but there are fewer flowers in each head and the leaves are generally smaller.

==Description==
''Melaleuca lara'' is a shrub sometimes growing to {{convert|1.5|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall and wide with branchlets that have soft hairs at first but become [[Glabrousness|glabrous]] with age. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|4.5-8.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|2.8-3.8|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} wide, flat, elliptical or egg-shaped and covered with short, soft hairs, especially when young. The oil glands are distinct.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=213}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|page=54|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are bright yellow fading to red, arranged in heads on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and sometimes also in the upper leaf axils. The heads are up to {{convert|25|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with 2 to 5 groups of flowers in threes. The petals are {{convert|1.9-3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages. There are five bundles of stamens around the flower, each with 9 to 13 stamens. Flowering occurs in early spring and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|4-5.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long in loose clusters along the stem.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca lara'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen near the [[Z Bend]] lookout on the [[Murchison River (Western Australia)|Murchison River]] in the [[Kalbarri National Park]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca lara''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561736|publisher=APNI|accessdate=13 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=885|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''lara'') is derived from the [[Ancient Greek]] word ''laros'' meaning "agreeable", "pleasant" or "lovely"<ref name=Brown>{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland|title=Composition of scientific words; a manual of methods and a lexicon of materials for the practice of logotechnics|date=1954|publisher=Brown|location=Washington|page=75|url=https://archive.org/stream/compositionofsci00brow/compositionofsci00brow_djvu.txt|accessdate=13 May 2015}}</ref> referring to the flowers of this plant species.<ref name=Brophy />

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca lara'' occurs in the [[Kalbarri, Western Australia|Kalbarri]] district<ref name=Brophy /> in the [[Geraldton Sandplains]] [[IBRA|biogeographic region]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca lara''|id = 19522}}</ref> It grows in sand in heath on sandplains near river gorges.<ref name=Brophy />

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca lara'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

194.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = Gorada
|image = Melaleuca lateriflora (habit).JPG
|image caption = ''M. lateriflora'' growing near [[Wagin, Western Australia|Wagin]]
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. lateriflora'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca lateriflora''
|binomial_authority = [[George Bentham|Benth]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca lateriflora''''', commonly known as '''gorada''', is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It is usually an erect shrub with oval leaves and small clusters of white flowers mainly along the older branches.

==Description==
''Melaleuca lateriflora'' is a branching shrub with rough, grey-brown bark, usually growing to about {{convert|4|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall or sometimes higher with [[Glabrousness|glabrous]] foliage except on the youngest leaves and branchlets. Its leaves are arranged alternately, are {{convert|4-12|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|3-6|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide and variable in shape from linear to oval with a short pointed tip.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|page=216|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517}}</ref><ref name=water>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca lateriflora'' subsp ''lateriflora''|url=http://www.water.wa.gov.au/PublicationStore/first/84839.pdf|publisher=Government of Western Australia, department of water|accessdate=9 April 2015}}</ref>

The flowers are white or pale cream, arranged in heads up to {{convert|90|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|12|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with up to 15 flowers in each head. The heads occur on the previous year's wood but also at or near the ends of branches.  The petals are {{convert|1.2-2.3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off soon after the flower opens. The stamens are in five bundles around the flower, each bundle containing 6 to 13 stamens. The flowers mainly appear between September and January and are followed by the fruit which are woody capsules {{convert|3-5.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|4-5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with the [[sepal]]s remaining as teeth on the capsules.<ref name ="Brophy" /><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=160–161|edition=2nd}}</ref>
[[File:Melaleuca lateriflora (leaves, flowers, fruits).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. lateriflora'' leaves, flowers and fruit]]
[[File:Melaleuca lateriflora (bark).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. lateriflora'' bark]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca lateriflora'' was first formally described in 1867 by [[George Bentham]] in ''[[Flora Australiensis]]''.<ref name=tropicos>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca lateriflora''|url=http://www.tropicos.org/Name/100221039|publisher=tropicos|accessdate=9 April 2015}}</ref><ref name=Mueller>{{cite book|last1=Mueller|first1=Ferdinand|title=Flora Australiensis, volume 3|date=1866|location=London|page=136|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/41807#page/144/mode/1up|accessdate=9 April 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''lateriflora'') is "in reference to the inflorescences being inserted on the branchlets and branches below the leaves".<ref name="Brophy" /> Until 2010  there were two subspecies - ''Melaleuca lateriflora'' subsp. ''lateriflora''  and ''Melaleuca lateriflora'' subsp. ''acutifolia'' but in 2010 the latter subspecies was raised to species status as ''[[Melaleuca acutifolia]]''.<ref name=Nuytsia>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyndley|last2=Lepschi|first2=Brendan|last3=Cowley|first3=Kirsten|title=Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) of Western Australia: five new species, three new combinations, one new name and a new state record|journal=Nuytsia|volume=20|pages=27–36|accessdate=7 April 2015}}</ref><ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca lateriflora''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/513100|publisher=APNI|accessdate=23 July 2015}}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca lateriflora'' occurs from the [[Yuna, Western Australia|Yuna]]  and [[Mullewa, Western Australia|Mullewa]] districts east to the [[Coolgardie, Western Australia|Coolgardie]] district and south to the [[Stirling Range]]<ref name="Brophy" /> in the [[Avon Wheatbelt]], [[Coolgardie (biogeographic region)|Coolgardie]], [[Esperance Plains]], [[Geraldton Sandplains]], [[Jarrah Forest]], [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]], [[Murchison (Western Australia)|Murchison]] and [[Yalgoo (biogeographic region)|Yalgoo]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca lateriflora''|id = 5925}}</ref> It grows in sandy and clayey soils on flats, floodplains and swampy areas.<ref name=Flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=394}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca lateriflora'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

|synonyms = <small> ''Callistemon lazaridis'' (Craven) Udovicic & [[R.D.Spencer]] </small>

'''''Melaleuca lazaridis''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Blackdown Tableland National Park]] in [[Queensland]]. (Some Australian state [[Herbarium|herbaria]] use the name ''Callistemon lazaridis'').<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> It is a shrub with dark green leaves and red flowers spikes tipped with yellow.

==Description==
''Melaleuca lazaridis'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|4|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with hard, fibrous bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|43-119|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|4.5-17|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, flat, mostly narrow egg-shaped with a mid-vein and 9 to 29 branching veins.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=219}}</ref>

The flowers are arranged in spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and also on the sides of the branches. The spikes are {{convert|35-60|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with 25 to 60 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|4.5-6.5|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages. There are 48-59 stamens in each flower with red to deep pink [[stamen|filaments]] and yellow anthers. Flowering occurs from June to September and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|4.5-5.7|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long.<ref name=Brophy/>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca lazaridis'' was first formally described in 2006 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Novon]]''.<ref name=APNI(1)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca lazaridis''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/653265|publisher=APNI|accessdate=14 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Novon>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=New Combinations in Melaleuca for Australian Species of Callistemon (Myrtaceae)|journal=Novon|date=2006|volume=16|issue=4|pages=445–446|url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.3417/1055-3177%282006%2916%5B468%3ANCIMFA%5D2.0.CO%3B2|accessdate=14 July 2015|doi=10.3417/1055-3177(2006)16[468:NCIMFA]2.0.CO;2}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''lazaridis'') honours Michael Lazaridis, an [[Australian]] [[Plant collecting|botanical collector]], [[Agrostology|agrostologist]] and co-collector of the [[Type (biology)|type specimen]].<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name=CHAH>{{cite web|title=Australian Plant Collectors and Illustrators|url=https://www.anbg.gov.au/bot-biog/bot-biog-L.html|publisher=Council of Heads of Australian herbaria|accessdate=14 July 2015}}</ref>

''Callistemon lazaridis'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca lazaridis'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref name '"WCSP">{{WCSP | 472787 | ''Callistemon lazaridis'' }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca only occurs in the Blackdown Tableland National Park, where it grows in a range of habitats but often near sandstone in open forest and along creeks.<ref name="Brophy" />

196.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = ''Melaleuca leiopyxis''
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. leiopyxis'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca leiopyxis''
|binomial_authority = [[George Bentham|Benth]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca leiopyxis''''' is a shrub in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to an area near the west coast of [[Western Australia]]. It has bright yellow flowers and is very similar to ''[[Melaleuca depressa]]''. The ranges of the two species overlap making it difficult to distinguish between them.

==Description==
''Melaleuca leiopyxis'' is a low, dense, ground hugging shrub to about {{convert|50|cm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} or sometimes a much more erect shrub to {{convert|3|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}}.  Its leaves are arranged alternately, have a thin covering of soft hairs and are narrow oval to elliptical in shape, with a blunt to slightly pointed tip.<ref name="Holliday" /><ref name="Brophy" />

The flowers are arranged in heads up to {{convert|25|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter at or near the ends of the branches, with 3 to 4 groups of flowers, 3 flowers in each group. The flowers mainly appear during September and October and are bright yellow, turning brown with age.  The stamens are arranged in bundles of five around the flower, with 8 to 14 stamens in each bundle. The cup-shaped base of the flower, the [[hypanthium]] is {{convert|2-3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and covered with silky hairs. The fruit are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]] arranged in irregular groups, each capsule {{convert|4-7|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and cup-shaped.<ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=168–169|edition=2nd}}</ref><ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|page=222|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517}}</ref>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca leiopyxis'' was first formally described in 1867 by [[George Bentham]] in ''[[Flora Australiensis]]''.<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca leiopyxis''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/513386|publisher=APNI|accessdate=16 March 2015}}</ref><ref name=Mueller>{{cite book|last1=Mueller|first1=Ferdinand|title=Flora Australiensis, volume 3|date=1866|location=London|page=160|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/41807#page/168/mode/1up|accessdate=16 March 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''leiopyxis'') is derived from the [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] words ''λεῖος (leîos)'' meaning "smooth" or "bald"<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref>{{rp|722}} and ''πυξίς (puxís)'' meaning "box"<ref name="RWB" />{{rp|160}} referring to the smooth fruit.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca leiopyxis'' occurs in the [[Kalbarri, Western Australia|Kalbarri]] - [[Shire of Shark Bay|Shark Bay]] area<ref name="Holliday" /> in the  [[Carnarvon (biogeographic region)|Carnarvon]], [[Geraldton Sandplains]] and [[Yalgoo (biogeographic region)|Yalgoo]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca leiopyxis''|id = 5930}}</ref> It grows in red sand on sand dunes and limestone hills.<ref name=Flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=395}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca leiopyxis'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

==Use in horticulture==
This melaleuca is rarely cultivated although it has grown successfully in [[Adelaide]]. It would probably be an excellent plant to trial in exposed coastal gardens.<ref name="Holliday" />

|species = '''''M. leuropoma'''''

|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca leuropoma''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It is a small to medium-sized shrub which flowers over an extended period with flower colour varying from purple to yellow or white. The glossy, often brown petals covering the flower buds are also an unusual characteristic of this species.

==Description==
''Melaleuca leuropoma'' is a shrub sometimes growing to {{convert|1.5|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|4-17|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|0.6-1.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, linear to very narrow egg-shaped and elliptic to almost circular in cross section. They are also glossy and often have short, silky hairs.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=226}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=172–173|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers colour is variable, from pink or purple to yellow or white and shades in between. The flowers are arranged in heads or short spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and sometimes also in the upper leaf axils. The heads are up to {{convert|22|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with 3 to 12 groups of flowers in threes. The petals are glossy brown in bud, {{convert|1.5-3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off soon after the flower opens. The outer surface of the floral cup (the [[hypanthium]]) is hairy and there are five bundles of stamens around the flower, each with 7 to 11 stamens. Flowering occurs mainly in spring but often extends into March, and is followed by fruit which are woody, cup-shaped [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|2.5-4.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, usually in tight, almost spherical clusters along the stem.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca leuropoma'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected {{convert|11|km|mi|sigfig=1}} north of [[Eneabba, Western Australia|Eneabba]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca leuropoma''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561767|publisher=APNI|accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=888|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''leuropoma'') is derived from the [[Ancient Greek]] words ''λευρός (leuros)'' meaning "smooth"<ref name=perseus>{{cite web|last1=Liddell|first1=Henry George|last2=Scott|first2=Robert|title=λευρός|url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0057%3Aentry%3D%2362783&redirect=true|publisher=A Greek-English Lexicon|accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref> and ''poma'' meaning "a lid" or "a cover"<ref name=Quattrocchi>{{cite book|last1=Quattrocchi|first1=Umberto|title=CRC world dictionary of plant names : common names, scientific names, eponyms, synonyms, and etymology|date=1999|publisher=CRC Press|location=Boca Raton, FL|isbn=0-8493-2673-7|page=2147}}</ref> referring to the unusual, glossy petals covering the flower buds.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca leuropoma'' occurs in and between the [[Kalbarri, Western Australia|Kalbarri]], [[Gairdner Range]] and [[Moora, Western Australia|Moora]] districts<ref name=Brophy /> in the [[Avon Wheatbelt]], [[Geraldton Sandplains]] and [[Swan Coastal Plain]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca leuropoma''|id = 18112}}</ref> It grows in a range of vegetation associations in sand over sandstone and limestone.<ref name=Brophy />

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca leuropoma'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

'''''Melaleuca linearifolia''''', commonly known as '''netted bottlebrush''', is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to [[New South Wales]] in [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state [[Herbarium|herbaria]] continue to use the name ''Callistemon linearifolius'').<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> It is a shrub with narrow, pointed leaves and red flower spikes in spring or summer.

==Description==
''Melaleuca linearifolia'' is a shrub or small tree growing to {{convert|4|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with grey, hard, flaking bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|29-152|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|4-13|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, flat but thickened at the edges, linear to lance-shaped, pointed at the tip, with a mid-vein and 17 to 35 branching veins.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=229}}</ref><ref name=RBGS>{{cite web|last1=Spencer|first1=Roger|last2=Lumley|first2=Peter F.|title=''Callistemon linearifolius''|url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Callistemon~linearifolius|publisher=Royal Botanic Garden Sydney: Plantnet|accessdate=14 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Environment>{{cite web|title=Netted Bottle Brush - profile|url=http://www.environment.nsw.gov.au/threatenedspeciesapp/profile.aspx?id=10129|publisher=NSW Government: Office of Environment and Heritage|accessdate=14 July 2015}}</ref>

The flowers are red to dark crimson and arranged in spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and also on the sides of the branches. The spikes are {{convert|35-55|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and {{convert|9-10|cm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long with 30 to 90 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|3.2-6.6|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages and there are 21-23 stamens in each flower. Flowering occurs from spring to summer and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|4.8-6|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="RBGS" /><ref name="Environment" />[[File:Melaleuca linearifolia leaves and fruit.jpg|thumb|225px|''M. linearifolia'' leaves and fruit]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca linearifolia'' was first formally described in 2006 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Novon]]''.<ref name=APNI(1)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca linearifolia''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/613692|publisher=APNI|accessdate=14 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Novon>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=New Combinations in Melaleuca for Australian Species of Callistemon (Myrtaceae)|journal=Novon|date=2006|volume=16|issue=4|page=472|url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.3417/1055-3177%282006%2916%5B468%3ANCIMFA%5D2.0.CO%3B2|accessdate=14 July 2015|doi=10.3417/1055-3177(2006)16[468:NCIMFA]2.0.CO;2}}</ref>  The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''linearifolia'') is from the [[Latin]] words ''linearis'' meaning "linear"<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref>{{rp|485}} and ''folium'' meaning "a leaf"<ref name="RWB" />{{rp|340}} in reference to the shape of the leaves of this species.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca linearifolia'' occurs on the coast of New South Wales from [[Nelson Bay, New South Wales|Nelson Bay]] to the [[Georges River]], where it grows in dry sclerophyll forest near sandstone.<ref name="RBGS" /><ref name="Environment" />

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca linearifolia'' has been classified as "vulnerable" by the New South Wales Government.<ref name=Office>{{cite web|title=Callistemon linearifolius (a shrub) - vulnerable species listing|url=http://www.environment.nsw.gov.au/determinations/CallistemonLinearifoliusVulSpListing.htm|publisher=NSW Government: Office of Environment and Heritage|accessdate=14 July 2015}}</ref>

</gallery>

199.text:
{{italic title}} {{taxobox |name= Narrow-leaved bottlebrush |image = Narrow-leaved Bottlebrush flower (8349172340).jpg |image_caption = ''Melaleuca linearis'' in the [[Royal National Park]] |status = |status_system = |regnum = [[Plantae]] |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s |unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s |unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s |ordo = [[Myrtales]] |familia = [[Myrtaceae]] |genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]'' |species = '''''M. linearis''''' |binomial = ''Melaleuca linearis'' |binomial_authority = [[Heinrich Schrader (botanist)|Schrad.]] & [[Johann Christoph Wendland|J.C.Wendl.]] |synonyms = ''Callistemon linearis'' [[Heinrich Schrader (botanist)|Schrad.]] & [[Johann Christoph Wendland|J.C.Wendl.]]
''Callistemon rigidus'' [[Robert Brown (botanist, born 1773)|R.Br.]]
''Metrosideros pinifolia'' [[Johann Christoph Wendland|J.C.Wendl.]]
''Callistemon pinifolius'' ([[Johann Christoph Wendland|J.C.Wendl.]]) [[Robert Sweet (botanist)|Sweet]] }} '''''Melaleuca linearis''''', commonly known as '''narrow-leaved bottlebrush''', is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to [[New South Wales]] and [[Queensland]] in [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state [[Herbarium|herbaria]] continue to use the names ''Callistemon linearis'', ''Callistemon pinifolius'' and ''Callistemon rigidus''.){{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=11 June 2015}} It is a medium-sized shrub with narrow leaves which have a rigid point, and red flower spikes in late spring or early summer. ==Description== ''Melaleuca linearis'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|3|m|ft|sigfig=1}} tall with grey, hard, fibrous bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|35-115|mm|in|sigfig=1}} long, {{convert|0.7-2.7|mm|in|sigfig=1}} wide, narrow linear in shape and flat to channelled or semi-circular in cross section. There is a mid-vein but the lateral veins are inconspicuous.{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|pages=230–231}}{{cite web|last1=Spencer|first1=Roger|last2=Lumley|first2=Peter F.|title=''Callistemon linearis''|url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Callistemon~linearis|publisher=Royal Botanic Garden Sydney: Plantnet|accessdate=14 July 2015}}{{cite web|title=Callistemon linearis|url=http://anpsa.org.au/c-lin.html|publisher=Australian Native Plants Society Australia|accessdate=14 July 2015}} The flowers are a shade of red, rarely green and arranged in spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and also on the sides of the branches. The spikes are {{convert|40-65|mm|in|sigfig=1}} in diameter and {{convert|5-10|cm|in|sigfig=2}} long with 20 to 90 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|3.2-7|mm|in|sigfig=1}} long and fall off as the flower ages and there are 23-73 stamens in each flower. Flowering occurs from late spring to early summer and is followed by fruits which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|3.8-8.2|mm|in|sigfig=1}} long. [[File:Callistemon linearis capsules old and new (8349175974).jpg|thumb|225px|Mature and immature capsules]] [[File:Narrow-leaved Bottlebrush habit (8349169000).jpg|thumb|225px|Growth habit]] ==Taxonomy and naming== ''Melaleuca linearis'' was first formally described in 1796 by [[Heinrich Schrader (botanist)|Heinrich Schrader]] and [[Johann Christoph Wendland]] in ''[[Sertum Hannoveranum]]''.{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca linearis''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/514319|publisher=APNI|accessdate=14 July 2015}}{{cite book|last1=Schrader|first1=Heinrich|last2=Wendland|first2=Johann Christoph|title=Sertum Hannoveranum 2|date=1796|page=19|url=http://bibdigital.rjb.csic.es/ing/Libro.php?Libro=3957&Pagina=7|accessdate=14 July 2015}} The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''linearis'') is a [[Latin]] word ''linearis'' meaning "linear"{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.|page=485}} in reference to the shape of the leaves of this species. There are two varieties: ''Melaleuca linearis'' var. ''linearis''{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca linearis'' var. ''linearis''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/217277|publisher=APNI|accessdate=20 July 2015}} has leaves which are more than {{convert|1.3|mm|in|sigfig=1}} wide, usually 23-33 stamens per flower and occurs in Queensland south to the [[Coonabarabran]] and [[Narrabri]] districts in New South Wales and also in and between the [[Central Coast (New South Wales)|Central Coast]] and [[Nowra, New South Wales|Nowra]] districts in New South Wales. ''Melaleuca linearis'' var. ''pinifolia''{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca linearis'' var. ''pinifolia''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/613693|publisher=APNI|accessdate=20 July 2015}} has leaves which are less than {{convert|1.3|mm|in|sigfig=1}} wide, 34-73 stamens per flower and occurs in the [[Gilgandra, New South Wales|Gilgandra]], [[Kandos, New South Wales|Kandos]] and [[Sydney]] districts in New South Wales. ''Callistemon linearis'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca linearis'',{{WCSP | 31452 | ''Callistemon linearis'' }} ''Callistemon pinifolius'' as a synonym of ''Melaleuca linearis'' var. ''acerosa'' (although this variety, named by [[Ignaz Friedrich Tausch|Tausch]] has not been formally described){{WCSP | 31477 | ''Callistemon pinifolius'' }} and ''Callistemon rigidus'' as a synonym of ''Melaleuca linearis'' var. ''linearis'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].{{WCSP | 31482 | ''Callistemon rigidus'' }} The [[National Herbarium of New South Wales]] retains the names ''Callistemon linearis'' ('''narrow-leaved bottlebrush'''),{{cite web|title=Callistemon linearis|url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Callistemon~linearis|publisher=Royal Botanic Gardens Sydney:Plantnet|accessdate=21 July 2015}} ''Callistemon pinifolius'' ('''pine-leaved bottlebrush'''){{cite web|title=Callistemon pinifolius|url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Callistemon~pinifolius|publisher=Royal Botanic Gardens Sydney:Plantnet|accessdate=21 July 2015}} and ''Callistemon rigidus'' ('''stiff bottlebrush''').{{cite web|title=Callistemon rigidus|url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Callistemon~rigidus|publisher=Royal Botanic Gardens Sydney:Plantnet|accessdate=21 July 2015}} ==Distribution and habitat== ''Melaleuca linearis'' occurs in and between the south-east corner of Queensland, [[Nowra, New South Wales|Nowra]] on the south coast of New South Wales and inland as far as [[Gilgandra, New South Wales|Gilgandra]]. It grows in damp situations in a range of vegetation associations. ==Use in horticulture== ''Melaleuca linearis'' has long been in cultivation (as ''Callistemon linearis'', ''C. pinifolius'' and ''C. rigidus''). Although not common in gardens, it is a hardy plant, thriving in most soils but preferring full sun. It is more resistant to pests such as [[sawfly]] than other melaleucas.{{cite book|last1=Wrigley|first1=John W.|last2=Fagg|first2=Murray|title=Australian native plants : a manual for their propagation, cultivation and use in landscaping|date=1983|publisher=Collins|location=Sydney|isbn=0002165759|pages=192–193|edition=2nd}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} [[Category:Melaleuca|linearis]] [[Category:Flora of Australia]] [[Category:Flora of New South Wales]] [[Category:Plants described in 1796]]
199.title: Melaleuca linearis

200.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|status =
|status_system = 
|image = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]

|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]

|species = '''''M. linguiformis'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca linguiformis''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca linguiformis''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the south of [[Western Australia]]. It is a shrub with hairy new growth, small leaves and heads of white flowers similar to ''[[Melaleuca teuthidoides]]'' shorter [[sepal]]s and more stamens in each flower.

==Description==
''Melaleuca linguiformis'' is a shrub sometimes growing to {{convert|5|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with hard, rough bark and very hairy new growth. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|3.3-6.3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|1.3-2.3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, elliptic to narrow egg-shaped and semi-circular in cross section.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=232}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|page=294|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are white to cream-coloured and arranged in heads or short spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering. The spikes are up to {{convert|22|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with 3 to 28 individual flowers. The sepals are thin, papery, {{convert|1.0-1.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and the petals are {{convert|2.3-3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off soon as the flower matures. The stamens are arranged in five bundles around the flower and there are13 to 22 stamens in each bundle.  Flowering occurs mainly in spring and is followed by fruit which are woody, cup-shaped [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|4.3-5.6|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, in clusters along the stem.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca linguiformis'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected in the [[Salmon Gums, Western Australia|Salmon Gums]] Nature Reserve.<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca linguiformis''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561769|publisher=APNI|accessdate=4 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=888|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''linguiformis'') is derived from the [[Latin]] words ''lingua'' meaning "tongue"<ref name=Wiktionary(1)>{{cite web|title=lingua|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/lingua#Latin|publisher=Wiktionary|accessdate=4 June 2015}}</ref> and ''forma'' meaning "shape" or "form",<ref name=Wiktionary(2)>{{cite web|title=forma|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/forma#Latin|publisher=Wiktionary|accessdate=4 June 2015}}</ref> referring to the tongue-like shape of the leaves.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca linguiformis'' occurs in the Salmon Gums and [[Wittenoom Hills]] districts in the [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]] [[IBRA|biogeographic region]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca linguiformis''|id = 19080}}</ref> It usually grows in dense shrub or heath over sand or loam, often in saline soils.<ref name=Brophy /><ref name=flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=395}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca linguiformis'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

|image caption = ''M. longistaminea'' growing at Red Bluff near [[Kalbarri, Western Australia|Kalbarri]].
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. longistaminea'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca longistaminea''
|binomial_authority = ([[Ferdinand von Mueller|F.Muell.]]) Barlow ex [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca longistaminea''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It is a shrub with small, prickly, heart-shaped leaves and heads of yellow to green flowers on the sides of the stems in winter and spring. It is similar to ''[[Melaleuca spectabilis]]'' which was formerly included in this species but has smaller flowerheads and narrower leaves.

==Description==
''Melaleuca longistaminea'' is a prickly, sprawling, many-branched, woody shrub growing to {{convert|2|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with [[glabrousness|glabrous]] branches and leaves. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|4.5-13.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|3-11.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, egg-shaped to heart-shaped and tapering to a sharp point. They have 11 to 19 parallel veins, giving the leaf the appearance of having fine striations.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=234}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|page=178|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are a shade of lime-green to yellow and are arranged in heads on the sides of the branches. The heads are up to {{convert|45|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and composed of 5 to 15 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|3-3.7|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages. There are five bundles of stamens around the flower, each with 9 to 24 stamens. Flowering occurs between June and October and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|3.5-6.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long in clusters of 7 to 15 along the branches.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/><ref name=Corrick>{{cite book|last1=Corrick|first1=Margaret G.|last2=Fuhrer|first2=Bruce A.|title=Wildflowers of southern Western Australia|date=2009|publisher=Rosenberg Publishing|location=Kenthurst, N.S.W.|isbn=9781877058844|page=132|edition=3|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=gzgsXMXxAd0C&pg=PA132&lpg=PA132&dq=Melaleuca+longistaminea&source=bl&ots=408s_5yR93&sig=bq3U_lW36SRdPdYUl1PztAKNkkM&hl=en&sa=X&ei=IepvVeHKIYqB8QWW84KYCw&ved=0CDMQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=Melaleuca%20longistaminea&f=false|accessdate=4 June 2015}}</ref>
[[File:Melaleuca longistaminea (leaves, flowers).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. longistaminea'' leaves and flowers]]
[[File:Melaleuca longistaminea (fruits).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. longistaminea'' fruit]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca longistaminea'' was first named in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]''.<ref name=APNI(1)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca longistaminea''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561771|publisher=APNI|accessdate=4 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=883|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> It was first formally described in 1863 by [[Ferdinand von Mueller]] who gave it the name ''[[Melaleuca cardiophylla]]'' subsp. ''longistaminea'' from a specimen collected near the Murchison River.<ref name=APNI(2)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca cardiophylla'' subsp. ''longistaminea''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/509519|publisher=APNI|accessdate=4 June 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''longistaminea'') is derived from the [[Latin]] words ''longus'' meaning "long"<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref>{{rp|494}} and ''stamen''<ref name="RWB" />{{rp|798}} referring to the relatively long stamens of this species.<ref name=Brophy />

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca longistaminea'' occurs in and between the [[Murchison River (Western Australia)|Murchison River]], [[Carnamah, Western Australia|Carnamah]] and [[Wongan Hills]] districts<ref name=Brophy /> in the [[Avon Wheatbelt]] and [[Geraldton Sandplains]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca longistaminea''|id = 18435}}</ref> It is found in heath, shrubland, scrub and sandplain growing in sand over sandstone and granite.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="FloraBase" /><ref name=flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=395}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca longistaminea'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

|regnum = [[Plantae]]

|species = '''''M. lophocoracorum'''''

|binomial_authority = A.J.Ford, [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]& [[Brophy]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca lophocoracorum''''' is a plant in the myrtle family [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to a small area in the Ravenshoe State Forest, near [[Ravenshoe, Queensland|Ravenshoe]] in [[Queensland]]. It is a newly described (2013) species of shrub or small tree with twisted leaves and spikes of cream-coloured flowers in summer. It is similar to ''[[Melaleuca squamophloia]]'' and ''[[Melaleuca styphelioides]]''.  

== Description ==
''Melaleuca lophocoracorum'' is a shrub or small tree growing to a height of {{convert|10|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}}. Its leaves are arranged alternately, {{convert|2.8-8.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|2.7–3.8|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} wide, egg-shaped, twisted, tapering to a sharp but not prickly point.<ref name=Ford>{{cite journal|last1=Ford|first1=Andrew J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Brophy|first3=Joseph J.|title=A new species of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) from north-east Queensland.|journal=Telopea|date=8 November 2013|volume=15|pages=185–189|doi=10.7751/telopea2013021|url=http://openjournals.library.usyd.edu.au/index.php/TEL/article/view/7187|accessdate=1 June 2015}}</ref>

The flowers are cream-coloured and arranged in spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and also on the sides of the branches. The spikes are up to {{convert|18|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter, {{convert|25|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and contain 3 to 9 groups of flowers in threes. The [[stamen]]s are arranged in five bundles around the flower with 15 to 25 stamens per bundle. Flowers appear in December and January and are followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]] {{convert|2.6-3.1|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long. The fruit retain the seeds for more than 3 years or until the plant is burned or the part bearing the fruit dies. The [[sepal]]s remain as teeth around the edge of the fruit, usually for more than a year.<ref name="Ford" />

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca lophocoracorum'' was discovered in 2012<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=337}}</ref> and first formally described in 2013 by Andrew Ford, [[Lyndley Craven|Lyn Craven]] and Joe Brophy in ''[[Telopea (journal)|Telopea]]''<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca lophocoracorum''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/773572|publisher=APNI|accessdate=1 June 2015}}</ref> from a specimen collected on the walking track to Bally Knob near Ravenshoe.  The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''lophocoracorum'') is from the [[Ancient Greek]] word ''lophos'' meaning “crest”<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref>{{rp|238}} and ''korax'' meaning "raven",<ref name="RWB" />{{rp|231}} because "hoe" in "Ravenshoe" originally meant "ridge" or "crest of a hill", so that ''lophocoracorum'' is equivalent to ''Ravenshoe''.<ref name="Ford" />
[[File:Melaleuca lophocoracorum 02.JPG|thumb|225px|''M.lophocoracorum'' fruit]]
[[File:Melaleuca lophocoracorum 03.JPG|thumb|225px|''M.lophocoracorum'' foliage]]

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca is only known from an area of less than {{convert|1|km2|mi2|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} near Ravenshoe, where there are thought to be no more than 600 individual plants. It grows in forest, generally in poorly-drained or swampy soil on [[rhyolite]] rock near creeks. There seems to be a correlation between the size of the plants and the depth of the soil in which they grow.<ref name="Ford" />

==Ecology==

===Response to fire===
After fire, ''M. lophocoracorum'' resprouts at the stem base and along stems from [[Epicormic shoot|epicormic buds]].<ref name="Ford" />

203.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = Megalong Valley bottlebrush
|image =
|image_caption = 
|status =
|status_system = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. megalongensis'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca megalongensis''
|binomial_authority = [[Heinrich Schrader (botanist)|Schrad.]] & [[Johann Christoph Wendland|J.C.Wendl.]] 
|synonyms = 
''Callistemon megalongensis'' <small> ([[Lyndley Craven|Craven]] & S.M.Douglas) Udovicic & [[R.D.Spencer]] </small>
}}

'''''Melaleuca megalongensis''''', commonly known as '''Megalong Valley bottlebrush''', is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to [[New South Wales]] in [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state [[Herbarium|herbaria]] use the name ''Callistemon megalongensis'').<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> It is a shrub similar to ''[[Melaleuca citrina]]'' (''[[Callistemon citrinus]]'') which occurs in the same area and is difficult to distinguish from it, except when in flower.

==Description==
''Melaleuca megalongensis'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|5|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with soft, flaking or peeling bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|35-55|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|3.5-5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, flat, narrow elliptic to narrow egg-shaped with the narrow end towards the base. There is a mid-vein and 15 to 24 lateral veins. The leaves usually have some thickening at the mid-vein and margins.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=241}}</ref><ref name=RBGS>{{cite web|last1=Wilson|first1=Pete |title=''Callistemon megalongensis''|url=http://pngplants.org/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Callistemon~megalongensis|publisher=Royal Botanic Garden Sydney: Plantnet|accessdate=14 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=OEH(1)>{{cite web|title=Callistemon megalongensis - proposed critically endangered species listing|url=http://www.environment.nsw.gov.au/determinations/callistemonmegalongensispd.htm|publisher=NSW Government Office of Environment and Heritage|accessdate=14 July 2015}}</ref>

The flowers are arranged in spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and are {{convert|30-40|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with 25 to 60 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|3.0-3.7|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages and there are 45-50 stamens in each flower. The filaments of the [[stamens]] are pink with a dark red anther. Flowering occurs in November and December and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|6|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="RBGS" /><ref name="OEH(1)" />

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca megalongensis'' was first formally described in 2009 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in [[Novon]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca megalongensis''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/653268|publisher=APNI|accessdate=14 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=''Melaleuca'' (Myrtaceae) from Australia|journal=Novon|date=2009|volume=19|page=446|doi=10.3417/2007008|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/40330691#page/454/mode/1up|accessdate=14 July 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''megalongensis'') refers to the locality where the species is found.<ref name="Brophy" />

''Callistemon megalongensis'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca megalongensis'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]],<ref name ="WCSP1">{{WCSP | 472788 | ''Callistemon megalongensis'' }}</ref>


==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in the [[Megalong Valley]] in the [[Blue Mountains (New South Wales)|Blue Mountains]]. It grows in damp situations near streams.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="RBGS" />

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca megalongensis'' has been classified as "critically endangered" by the Scientific Committee of the NSW Government Department of Environment and Heritage.<ref name="OEH(1)" />

204.text:
{{taxobox
|status =
|status_system = 
|image = Melaleuca monantha.JPG
|image caption = ''M. monantha'' 5km south of the [[Palmer River (Queensland)|Palmer River]].
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. monantha'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca monantha''
|binomial_authority = (Barlow) [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca monantha''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to an area in [[Queensland]], [[Australia]]. It is a shrub, similar to ''[[Melaleuca minutifolia]]'' with very small leaves but the leaves lack oil glands and its flowers occur singly, rather than in pairs. It is also similar to ''[[Melaleuca sylvana]]'' but is usually multi-stemmed and has a more dense crown than that species.

==Description==
''Melaleuca monantha'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|7|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall. Its leaves are arranged in alternating pairs, ([[Phyllotaxy|decussate]]) so that they are in four rows along the stems. Each leaf is oval to egg-shaped, {{convert|0.9-3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|0.5-1|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide tapering to a point on the end.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=245}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|page=192|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are white and arranged in small heads on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering or in the upper leaf axils. The heads are up to {{convert|12|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and composed of up to 8 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|1.2-1.6|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages. There are five bundles of stamens around the flower, each with 6 to 14 stamens. Flowering occurs from October to February and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]] {{convert|2-3.2|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long in small, loose clusters.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>
[[File:Melaleuca monantha 02.JPG|thumb|225px|''M.monantha'' foliage and fruiting capsules.]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
The species was first formally described in 1987 by [[Bryan Barlow]] as a subspecies of ''[[Melaleuca minutifolia]]''. The [[Type (biology)|type]] specimen was collected near Granite Creek, near [[Mareeba]] in [[Far North Queensland]] and the description was published in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]''.<ref name=APNI(2)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca minutifolia'' subsp. ''monantha''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/514158|publisher=APNI|accessdate=25 March 2016}}</ref><ref name=Barlow>{{cite journal|last1=Barlow|first1=Bryan A.|title=Contributions to a revisin of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae): 1-3|journal=Brunonia|date=1986|volume=9|issue=2|page=176|doi=10.1071/BRU9860163|url=http://www.publish.csiro.au/paper/BRU9860163.htm|accessdate=25 March 2016}}</ref> It was raised to species status in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]].<ref name=APNI(1)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca monantha''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/572813|publisher=APNI|accessdate=25 March 2016}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=891|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''monantha'') is from the [[Ancient Greek]] words ''μόνος (mónos)'' meaning “alone", or "single”<ref name=Wiktionary(1)>{{cite web|title=mono-|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mono-|publisher=Wiktionary|accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref> and ''ἄνθος (ánthos)'' meaning “flower",<ref name=Wiktionary(2)>{{cite web|title=ἄνθος|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ἄνθος#Ancient_Greek|publisher=Wiktionary|accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref> referring to the arrangement of the flowers individually rather than in pairs.<ref name=Brophy />

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca monantha'' occurs in Queensland, mainly between the [[Palmer River (Queensland)|Palmer River]] and [[Mount Sturgeon, Queensland|Mount Sturgeon]] (near [[Hughenden, Queensland|Hughenden]]) districts.<ref name= "Brophy" /><ref name="Holliday" /><ref name=Muelleria>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyndley A.|last2=Ford|first2=A.J.|title=A new species of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) from northern Queensland, Australia|journal=Muelleria|date=2004|volume=20|pages=4–8|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_20,_p3-8,_Craven__Ford,_new_Melaleuca.pdf|accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref>

[[Category:Flora of Queensland]]
