205.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = Mountain bottlebrush
|image = Callistemon montanus.jpg
|image_caption = ''M. montana'' in the [[Maranoa Gardens]]
|status =
|status_system = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. montana'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca montana''
|binomial_authority = ([[Stanley Thatcher Blake|S.T.Blake]]) [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]] 
|synonyms = 
<small> ''Callistemon montanus'' [[Stanley Thatcher Blake|S.T.Blake]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca montana''''', commonly known as '''mountain bottlebrush''', is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Border Ranges National Park|Border Ranges]] area of [[New South Wales]] and [[Queensland]] in [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state [[Herbarium|herbaria]] continue to use the name ''Callistemon montanus'').<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> It is a shrub or small tree distinguished from most other red bottlebrushes by its hairy petals.

==Description==
''Melaleuca montana'' is a shrub or small tree growing to {{convert|8|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|37-112|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|5-12|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, flat, narrow elliptic to narrow egg-shaped often with one side straighter than the other. There is a mid-vein and 11 to 21 lateral veins.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=246}}</ref><ref name=RBGS>{{cite web|last1=Spencer|first1=Roger|last2=Lumley|first2=Peter F.|title=''Callistemon montanus''|url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Callistemon~montanus|publisher=Royal Botanic Garden Sydney: Plantnet|accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref>

The flowers are a shade of red to crimson and arranged in spikes on the sides of the branches. The spikes are {{convert|15-65|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with 15 to 30 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|4.2-6.2|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long, densely hairy on the outer surface and fall off as the flower ages. There are 27 to 47 stamens in each flower. Flowering occurs in spring and summer but sometimes at other times of the year. Flowering is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|6.2-8.6|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="RBGS" />

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca montana'' was first formally described in 2006 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Novon]]''.<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca montana''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/613692|publisher=APNI|accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Novon>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=New Combinations in Melaleuca for Australian Species of Callistemon (Myrtaceae)|journal=Novon|date=2006|volume=16|issue=4|page=472|url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.3417/1055-3177%282006%2916%5B468%3ANCIMFA%5D2.0.CO%3B2|accessdate=15 July 2015|doi=10.3417/1055-3177(2006)16[468:NCIMFA]2.0.CO;2}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''montana'') is from the [[Latin]] word ''mons'' meaning "a mountain"<ref name="Wiktionary">{{cite web|title=mons|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mons|publisher=Wiktionary|accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref> in reference to the habitat of this species.<ref name="Brophy" />

''Callistemon montanus'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca montana'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]],<ref name ="WCSP1">{{WCSP | 31460 | ''Callistemon montanus'' }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in the Border Ranges area near the New South Wales - Queensland border. It grows in forest and heath in shallow soils on cliff tops and edges.<ref name="RBGS" /><ref name="Brophy" />

==Use in horticulture==
''Melaleuca montana'' has long been in cultivation (as ''[[Callistemon montanus]]''). Whilst the flowers may not be as attractive as those of ''[[Melaleuca citrina]]'', it is more likely to flower in shady situations.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name=Wrigley>{{cite book|last1=Wrigley|first1=John W.|last2=Fagg|first2=Murray|title=Australian native plants : a manual for their propagation, cultivation and use in landscaping|date=1983|publisher=Collins|location=Sydney|isbn=0002165759|page=193|edition=2nd}}</ref>

[[Category:Plants described in 2006]]

206.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|image = 
|image_caption = 
|status =
|status_system = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. montis-zamia'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca montis-zamia''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]] 
|synonyms = 
<small> ''Callistemon montis-zamiae'' ([[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]) Udovicic and [[R.D.Spencer]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca montis-zamia''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Springsure, Queensland|Springsure]] district in [[Queensland]], [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state [[Herbarium|herbaria]] use the name ''Callistemon montis-zamiae''.)<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> It is a shrub with red bottlebrush flowers.

==Description==
''Melaleuca montis-zamia'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|4|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|37-92|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|2.5-9|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, flat, narrow elliptic to narrow egg-shaped with a mid-vein and 18 to 27 lateral veins.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=247}}</ref>

The flowers are a shade of red with the [[stamen]]s tipped with yellow. They are arranged in spikes on the ends of the branches which continue to grow after flowering and also on the sides of the branches. The spikes are {{convert|30-45|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with 10 to 40 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|3.1-4.7|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, hairy on the outer surface and fall off as the flower ages. There are 40 to 58 stamens in each flower. Flowering occurs in August and September and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|3.4-4.9|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca montis-zamiae'' was first formally described in 2009 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Novon]]'',<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca montis-zamia''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/653269|publisher=APNI|accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=''Melaleuca'' (Myrtaceae) from Australia|journal=Novon|date=2009|volume=19|page=447|doi=10.3417/2007008|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/40330691#page/454/mode/1up|accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref> but the spelling was in error, later corrected to ''M. montis-zamia''.<ref name="Brophy" /> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''montis-zamia'') is from the [[Latin]] word ''mons'' meaning "a mountain"<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.|page =536}}</ref> and Zamia, in reference to the habitat of this species at Mt. Zamia in the [[Minerva Hills National Park]], Queensland.<ref name="Brophy" />

''Callistemon montis-zamiae'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca montis-zamia'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref name ="WCSP1">{{WCSP | 472789 | ''Callistemon montis-zamiae'' }}</ref> Craven noted that the spelling ''Melaleuca montis-zamiae'' in the Novon article is an error which was not detected at the proof stage.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca montis-zamia'' occurs in the Springsure district. It grows in scrub near watercourses.<ref name="Brophy" />

206.title: Melaleuca montis-zamia

207.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|status =
|status_system = 
|image = Melaleuca orbicularis foliage, flowers and fruit.jpg
|image caption = ''Melaleuca orbicularis'' foliage, flowers and fruit
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. orbicularis'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca orbicularis''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca orbicularis''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It is similar to ''[[Melaleuca cordata]]'' with its pinkish "[[pom-pom]]" heads of flowers but its leaves are smaller, almost circular compared to the heart shaped leaves of the other species.

==Description==
''Melaleuca orbicularis'' is an erect shrub growing to {{convert|2.5|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|3.5-8|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|2-10.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, heart-shaped to almost circular.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=257}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=66–67|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are a shade of pink to purple and are arranged in heads on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and sometimes also in the upper leaf axils. The heads are up to {{convert|30|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with 2 to 8 groups of flowers in threes. The petals are {{convert|2-3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off soon after the flower opens. The outer surface of the floral cup (the [[hypanthium]]) is hairy and there are five bundles of stamens around the flower, each with 5 to 12 stamens. Flowering occurs from July to January and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|3-5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, usually in tight, oval-shaped clusters along the stem.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>[[File:Melaleuca orbicularis habit.jpg|thumb|225px|''Melaleuca orbicularis'' growing near [[Bindi Bindi, Western Australia|Bindi Bindi]]]][[File:Melaleuca orbicularis flower detail.jpg|thumb|225px|''M. orbicularis'' flower detail]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca orbicularis'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected near [[Bindi Bindi, Western Australia|Bindi Bindi]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca orbicularis''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561806|publisher=APNI|accessdate=5 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=893|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''orbicularis'') is derived from the [[Latin]] word ''orbis'' meaning "circle" or "disc"<ref name=Wiktionary>{{cite web|title=orbis|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/orbis|publisher=Wiktionary|accessdate=5 June 2015}}</ref> referring to the circular leaves.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca orbicularis'' occurs in and between the [[Coorow, Western Australia|Coorong]], [[Wongan Hills]] and [[Cowcowing, Western Australia|Cowcowing]] districts<ref name="Brophy" /> in the [[Avon Wheatbelt]], [[Geraldton Sandplains]], [[Jarrah Forest]] and [[Warren (biogeographic region)|Warren]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca orbicularis''|id = 17981}}</ref> It grows in a range of vegetation associations in sand over sandstone and [[laterite]].<ref name=Brophy /><ref name=flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=396}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca orbicularis'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

==References==
{{reflist|30em}}

[[Category:Flora of Western Australia]]
[[Category:Plants described in 1999]]
[[Category:Endemic flora of Western Australia]]
207.title: Melaleuca orbicularis

208.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = Needle bottlebrush
|image = Callistemon teretifolius.jpg
|image_caption = ''M. orophila'' in the [[Peter Francis Points Arboretum]], [[Coleraine, Victoria]]
|status =
|status_system = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]

|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. orophila'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca orophila''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]] 
|synonyms = 
<small> ''Callistemon teretifolius'' [[Ferdinand von Mueller|F.Muell.]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca orophila''''', commonly known as '''needle bottlebrush''' or '''Flinders Ranges bottlebrush''', is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the eastern part of [[South Australia]]. (Some Australian state [[Herbarium|herbaria]] continue to use the name ''[[Callistemon teretifolius]]'').<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> It is a medium-sized shrub with sharp-pointed, needle-like leaves and bright red bottlebrush flower spikes.

==Description==
''Melaleuca orophila'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|2|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with hard, fissured bark and rigid branches. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|44-143|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|0.8-1.7|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, linear in shape and circular or almost so in cross section.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=260}}</ref><ref name=DEH>{{cite web|title=Callistemon teretifolius|url=http://www.naturalresources.sa.gov.au/files/sharedassets/public/plants_and_animals/threatened_plants/pa-fact-pafactcallistemonteretifolius.pdf|publisher=Government of South Australia Department for Environment and Heritage|accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref>

The flowers are bright red or orange-green and arranged in spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and also on the sides of the branches. The spikes are {{convert|40-55|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} in diameter with 12 to 55 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|3.5-7.4|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages and there are 25-42 stamens in each flower. Flowering occurs in spring and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|5.5-7.1|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="DEH" />

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca orophila'' was first named in 2006 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in [[Novon]] when he transferred the species from ''[[Callistemon]]''.<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca orophila''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/613695|publisher=APNI|accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Novon>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=New Combinations in Melaleuca for Australian Species of Callistemon (Myrtaceae)|journal=Novon|date=2006|volume=16|issue=4|page=472|url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.3417/1055-3177%282006%2916%5B468%3ANCIMFA%5D2.0.CO%3B2|accessdate=15 July 2015|doi=10.3417/1055-3177(2006)16[468:NCIMFA]2.0.CO;2}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''orophila'') is from the [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] words ''ὄρος (óros)'' meaning "a mountain"<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref>{{rp|537}} and ''φίλος (phílos)'' meaning “dear one" or "friend"<ref name="RWB" />{{rp|355}} in reference to the preferred habitat of this species.<ref name="Brophy" />

''Callistemon teretifolius'' was first formally described in 1853 by botanist [[Ferdinand von Mueller]] in the journal ''Linnaea''.<ref name=APNI(2)>{{cite web|title=''Callistemon teretifolius''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/523157|publisher=APNI|accessdate=21 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Mueller>{{cite journal|last1=von Mueller|first1=Ferdinand|title=Diagnoses et descriptiones plantarum novarum, quas in Nova Hollandia|journal=Linnaea|date=1853|volume=25|pages=387–388|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/109556#page/393/mode/1up|accessdate=21 July 2015}}</ref>

''Callistemon teretifolius'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca orophila'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref name '"WCSP">{{WCSP | 31512 | ''Callistemon teretifolius'' }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca orophila'' occurs mainly in the [[Flinders Ranges]], especially between [[Williamstown, South Australia|Williamstown]] and [[Mount Crawford (South Australia)|Mount Crawford]].<ref name="DEH" /> It grows in [[Mallee (habit)|mallee]] and [[woodland]] in rocky situations.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca orophila'' is classified as "vulnerable" by the Government of South Australia Department for Environment and Heritage.<ref name="DEH" />

[[Category:Flora of Australia]]

208.title: Melaleuca orophila

209.text:
{{italictitle}}
{{taxobox
|status =
|status_system = 
|image = Melaleuca osullivani (habit).JPG
|image caption = ''M. osullivani'' growing at the [[Type (biology)|type]] location near [[Busselton]]
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. osullivanii'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca osullivanii''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]] & Lepschi
}}

'''''Melaleuca osullivanii''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It was first formally described in 2004 after a review of the broombush group, ''[[Melaleuca uncinata]]''. It differs from others in the group by having leaves that are fine and circular in cross section. The closest other broombrush is ''[[Melaleuca hamata]]'' whose leaves are {{convert|0.8-1.6|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter compared to {{convert|0.7-0.9|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} for this species.

==Description==
''Melaleuca osullivanii'' is shrub growing to {{convert|3|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with flaky, papery bark. Its leaves are {{convert|28-73|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|0.7-0.9|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, linear in shape and oval to almost circular in cross section tapering to a point or with a bristle on the end.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=261}}</ref><ref name=DPAW>{{cite web|last1=Byrne|first1=Margaret|title=Broombush complex|url=http://www.dpaw.wa.gov.au/images/documents/conservation-management/wetlands/issue_13.pdf|publisher=Western Australian Government Department of Parks and Wildlife|accessdate=5 June 2015}}</ref>

The flowers are creamy white and are arranged in heads containing 4 to 9 groups of flowers in threes. The petals are oval to almost circular, {{convert|0.7-1.2|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off soon after the flower opens. The stamens are arranged in five bundles around the flower, each bundle with 3 to 5 stamens. Flowering occurs in November and December and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]] tightly packed together so that they appear like a single oval-shaped fruit {{convert|6.5-8|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} in diameter.<ref name=Brophy/>
[[File:Melaleuca osullivani (leaves, flowers).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. osullivani'' foliage and flowers]]
[[File:Melaleuca osullivani (fruits).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. osullivani'' fruit]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca osullivanii'' was first formally described in 2004 by [[Lyndley Craven]] and Brendan Lepschi in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]''.<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca osullivanii''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/589520|publisher=APNI|accessdate=5 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=CSIRO>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=Brendan J.|last3=Broadhurst|first3=Linda|last4=Byrne|first4=Margaret|title=Taxonomic revision of the broombush complex in Western Australia (Myrtaceae, Melaleuca uncinata s.l.)|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=2004|volume=17|issue=3|pages=265–266|doi=10.1071/SB04001|url=http://www.publish.csiro.au/paper/SB04001.htm|accessdate=5 June 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''osullivanii'') is a reference to Wayne O'Sullivan who has contributed to studies of ''[[Melaleuca]]'' species in the field.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in and between the [[Perth]], and [[Busselton]] districts<ref name="Brophy" /> in the [[Jarrah Forest]] and [[Swan Coastal Plain]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca osullivanii''|id = 20297}}</ref> It often grows in sand in association with other heathy species of ''Melaleuca'', ''Hakea'', ''Grevillea'' and introduced grasses in areas close to the coast that are wet in winter.<ref name=Brophy /><ref name="FloraBase" />

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca osullivanii'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

==References==

[[Category:Flora of Western Australia]]

|status =

|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. pachyphylla'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca pachyphylla''
|binomial_authority = ([[Edwin Cheel|Cheel]]) [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]] 
|synonyms = 
<small> ''Callistemon pachyphyllus'' [[Edwin Cheel|Cheel]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca pachyphylla''''', commonly known as '''wallum bottlebrush''', is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to near-coastal regions of [[New South Wales]] and [[Queensland]] in [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state [[Herbarium|herbaria]] use the name ''Callistemon pachyphyllus''.<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref>) It is a medium-sized shrub with a straggling habit and red, or sometimes greenish bottlebrush flowers in summer.

==Description==
''Melaleuca pachyphylla'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|3|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|25-119|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|3-15|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, flat, narrow elliptic to narrow egg-shaped with the narrower end towards the base and a small point at the end. There is a distinct mid-vein and 11-22 side veins.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=264}}</ref><ref name=RBGS>{{cite web|last1=Spencer|first1=Roger|last2=Lumley|first2=Peter F.|title=''Callistemon pachyphyllus''|url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Callistemon~pachyphyllus|publisher=Royal Botanic Garden Sydney: Plantnet|accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref>

The flowers are usually crimson but sometimes greenish-yellow. They are arranged in spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and also on the sides of the branches. The spikes are {{convert|45-65|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with 30 to 90 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|3.5-6.9|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages and there are 27-45 stamens in each flower. Flowering occurs in summer and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|3.9-7.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="RBGS" />

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca pachyphylla'' was first formally described in 2006 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in [[Novon]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca pachyphylla''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/613696|publisher=APNI|accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Novon>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=New Combinations in Melaleuca for Australian Species of Callistemon (Myrtaceae)|journal=Novon|date=2006|volume=16|issue=4|page=472|url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.3417/1055-3177%282006%2916%5B468%3ANCIMFA%5D2.0.CO%3B2|accessdate=15 July 2015|doi=10.3417/1055-3177(2006)16[468:NCIMFA]2.0.CO;2}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''pachyphylla'') is from the [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] words ''pakhús'' meaning “thick”<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref>{{rp|583}} and ''phýllon'' meaning “leaf”<ref name="RWB" />{{rp|466}} in reference to the thick leaves of this species.<ref name="Brophy" />

''Callistemon pachyphyllus'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca pachyphylla'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref name '"WCSP">{{WCSP | 31462 | ''Callistemon pachyphyllus'' }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca pachyphylla'' occurs in coastal areas from [[Port Stephens (New South Wales)|Port Stephens]] in New South Wales to [[Hervey Bay]] in Queensland.<ref name="Brophy" /> It grows in moist ground in [[wallum]].<ref name="RBGS" />

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca pachyphylla'' is sometimes cultivated as ''[[Callistemon pachyphyllus]]''. It is a hardy plant which grows well in poorly drained soil in full sun.<ref name=Wrigley>{{cite book|last1=Wrigley|first1=John W.|last2=Fagg|first2=Murray|title=Australian native plants : a manual for their propagation, cultivation and use in landscaping|date=1983|publisher=Collins|location=Sydney|isbn=0002165759|page=193|edition=2nd}}</ref>

[[Category:Flora of New South Wales]]
[[Category:Flora of Queensland]]
[[Category:Plants described in 2006]]

211.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = Lemon bottlebrush
|image = Melaleuca pallida leaves and flowers.jpg
|image_caption = ''Melaleuca pallida'' leaves and flowers
|status =
|status_system = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. pallida'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca pallida''
|binomial_authority = ([[Aimé Bonpland|Bonpl.]]) [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]] 
|synonyms = 
''Callistemon pallidus'' <small> ([[Aimé Bonpland|Bonpl.]]) [[Augustin Pyramus de Candolle|DC.]]  </small>
}}

'''''Melaleuca pallida''''', commonly known as '''lemon bottlebrush''', is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to eastern [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state [[Herbarium|herbaria]] use the name ''Callistemon pallidus''.)<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> It is an upright shrub with thin, spreading branches, silvery new growth and pale yellow, sometimes pinkish bottlebrush flowers.

==Description==
''Melaleuca pallida'' is a shrub or tree growing to {{convert|8|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall, with fibrous or papery bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|20-79|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|4-17|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, flat or broadly v-shaped, narrow elliptic to egg-shaped with the narrow end towards the base and with a small point at the end. There is a distinct mid-vein, 6-16 indistinct side veins and many distinct oil glands.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=266}}</ref><ref name=RBGS>{{cite web|last1=Spencer|first1=Roger|last2=Lumley|first2=Peter F.|title=''Callistemon pallidus''|url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Callistemon~pallidus|publisher=Royal Botanic Garden Sydney: Plantnet|accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=ANBG>{{cite web|last1=Mullins|first1=Effie|title=Callistemon pallidus|url=https://www.anbg.gov.au/gnp/gnp14/callistemon-pallidus.html|publisher=Australian National Botanic Garden|accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref>

The flowers are a shade of cream to yellow, occasionally pinkish-red and are arranged in spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and sometimes also on the sides of the branches. The spikes are {{convert|20-45|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with 15 to 50 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|2.9-6|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages and there are 34-70 stamens in each flower. Flowering occurs from October to February and is followed by fruit which are woody, cup-shaped [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|3.9-6.6|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="RBGS" /><ref name="ANBG" />[[File:Melaleuca pallida habit(1).jpg|thumb|225px|''M. pallida'' in the [[Gibraltar Range National Park]] ]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca pallida'' was first formally described in 2006 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in [[Novon]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca pallida''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/613697|publisher=APNI|accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Novon>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=New Combinations in Melaleuca for Australian Species of Callistemon (Myrtaceae)|journal=Novon|date=2006|volume=16|issue=4|page=472|url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.3417/1055-3177%282006%2916%5B468%3ANCIMFA%5D2.0.CO%3B2|accessdate=15 July 2015|doi=10.3417/1055-3177(2006)16[468:NCIMFA]2.0.CO;2}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''pallida'') is a [[Latin]] word meaning “pale”<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.|page = 584}}</ref> referring to the pale flower colour.<ref name="Brophy" />

''Callistemon pallidus'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca pallida'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref name '"WCSP">{{WCSP | 31467 | ''Callistemon pallidus'' }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca pallida'' occurs from the [[Border Ranges National Park|Border Ranges]] area in far south eastern [[Queensland]], through the ranges and slopes of [[New South Wales]] to eastern [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]].  It is also present in all but the far west of [[Tasmania]] and on some [[Bass Strait]] islands.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="RBGS" /> It grows in streams and wet, rocky slopes.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="RBGS" />

==Use in horticulture==
''Melaleuca pallida'' is sometimes cultivated as ''[[Callistemon pallidus]]''. It is a hardy plant, adaptable to many soils but needs full sun.<ref name=Wrigley>{{cite book|last1=Wrigley|first1=John W.|last2=Fagg|first2=Murray|title=Australian native plants : a manual for their propagation, cultivation and use in landscaping|date=1983|publisher=Collins|location=Sydney|isbn=0002165759|page=193|edition=2nd}}</ref>

==Gallery==

Image:Callistemon pallidus, Jardín Botánico, Múnich, Alemania 2012-04-21, DD 01.JPG|''M. pallida'' in the [[Botanischer Garten München-Nymphenburg|Munich Botanic Garden]] as ''Callistemon pallidus''
Image:Melaleuca pallida leaves, flowers and fruit.jpg|''M. pallida'' leaves and fruit
Image:Melaleuca pallida habit(2).jpg|''M. pallida'' growing near wet heath in the [[Gibraltar Range National Park|Gibraltar Range]]
</gallery>

212.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = River bottlebrush
|image = Melaleuca paludicola flowers.jpg
|image_caption = ''Melaleuca paludicola'' leaves and flowers
|status =
|status_system =

|species = '''''M. paludicola'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca paludicola''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]] 
|synonyms = 
''Callistemon sieberi'' <small>  [[Augustin Pyramus de Candolle|DC.]] </small><ref name="APNI(2)" />
''Callistemon salignus'' var. ''sieberi'' ([[Augustin Pyramus de Candolle|DC.]]) [[Ferdinand von Mueller|F.Muell.]] <ref name=APNI(3)>{{cite web|title=''Callistemon salignus'' var. ''sieberi''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/522973|publisher=APNI|accessdate=15 August 2015}}</ref>
}}

'''''Melaleuca paludicola''''', commonly known as '''river bottlebrush''', is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to eastern [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state [[Herbarium|herbaria]] continue to use the names ''Callistemon sieberi'' or ''Callistemon paludosus''.)<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> It is a shrub or small tree with flexible, often drooping branches, pinkish new growth and spikes of cream, pale yellow, or sometimes pink flowers in summer.

==Description==
''Melaleuca paludicola'' is a shrub or tree growing to {{convert|8|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall, with fibrous bark, or hard, fissured bark on older plants. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|20-68|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|1.3-8|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, flat, linear to narrow lance-shaped and have a small point at the end. There is a distinct mid-vein and 11-18 indistinct side veins.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=267}}</ref><ref name=RBGS>{{cite web|last1=Spencer|first1=Roger|last2=Lumley|first2=Peter F.|title=''Callistemon sieberi''|url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Callistemon~sieberi|publisher=Royal Botanic Garden Sydney: Plantnet|accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=florabank>{{cite web|title=Callistemon sieberi|url=https://www.florabank.org.au/files/documents/provenance/20070810-01.pdf|publisher=Corangamite Seed Supply and Revegetation Network|accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref>

The flowers are a shade of cream to yellow, occasionally pink and are arranged in spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and also on the sides of the branches. The spikes are {{convert|20-30|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with 10 to 40 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|2.6-4.2|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages and there are 48-67 stamens in each flower. Flowering occurs mainly from October to January and is followed by fruit which are woody, cup-shaped [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|3-4.3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="RBGS" /><ref name="florabank" />[[File:Melaleuca paludicola habit.jpg|thumb|225px|''M. paludicola'' in the [[Gibraltar Range National Park]] ]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca paludicola'' was named in 2006 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in [[Novon]] when he transferred ''Callistemon sieberi'' to the present [[genus]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca paludicola''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/613698|publisher=APNI|accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Novon>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=New Combinations in Melaleuca for Australian Species of Callistemon (Myrtaceae)|journal=Novon|date=2006|volume=16|issue=4|page=472|url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.3417/1055-3177%282006%2916%5B468%3ANCIMFA%5D2.0.CO%3B2|accessdate=15 July 2015|doi=10.3417/1055-3177(2006)16[468:NCIMFA]2.0.CO;2}}</ref> ''Callistemon sieberi'' was first formally described by botanist [[Augustin Pyramus de Candolle]] in 1828 in ''[[Prodromus Systematis Naturalis Regni Vegetabilis]]''.<ref name=APNI(2)>{{cite web|title=''Callistemon sieberi''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/22075|publisher=APNI|accessdate=21 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Prodromus>{{cite book|last1=de Candolle|first1=Augustin Pyramus|title=Prodromus Systematis Naturalis, Volume 3Regni Vegetabilis|date=1828|location=Paris|page=223|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/7152#page/234/mode/1up|accessdate=21 July 2015}}</ref>
The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''paludicola'') is from the [[Latin]] word ''palus'' meaning “swamp”, "marsh", "bog" or "fen"<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref>{{rp|514}} and the suffix ''-cola'' meaning “inhabitant”.<ref name="RWB" />{{rp|217}} An earlier, alternative name ([[Synonym (taxonomy)|taxonomic synonym]]) for the species was ''Callistemon paludosus'' and the present name was chosen to link with the earlier one.<ref name="Brophy" />

''Callistemon paludosus'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca paludicola'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref name '"WCSP">{{WCSP | 31468 | ''Callistemon paludosus'' }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca paludicola'' occurs from [[Warwick, Queensland|Warwick]] in the far south east of [[Queensland]], through [[New South Wales]] as far inland as the eastern part of the [[North West Plains]] to the eastern half of [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]].  There is a [[Disjunct distribution|disjunct]] population in the [[Mount Lofty Ranges]] and [[Adelaide]] districts of [[South Australia]].<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="RBGS" /> It grows in and near rivers, in dry, rocky riverbeds and in flood channels subject to periodic inundation.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="florabank" />

==Use in horticulture==
''Melaleuca paludicola'' is sometimes cultivated as ''Callistemon sieberi''. An alpine form is a smaller, denser, rounded shrub suitable as a more formal plant.<ref name=Wrigley>{{cite book|last1=Wrigley|first1=John W.|last2=Fagg|first2=Murray|title=Australian native plants : a manual for their propagation, cultivation and use in landscaping|date=1983|publisher=Collins|location=Sydney|isbn=0002165759|page=193|edition=2nd}}</ref>

==Gallery==
<gallery>
Image:Callistemon sieberi.jpg|''M. paludicola'' in the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Melbourne]] as ''Callistemon sieberi''
Image:Melaleuca paludicola leaves and fruit.jpg|''M. paludicola'' leaves and fruit
Image:Melaleuca paludicola leaves and flowers.jpg|''M. paludicola'' leaves and flowers
</gallery>

213.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|status =
|status_system = 
|image = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. papillosa'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca papillosa''
|binomial_authority = [[Nikolai Turczaninow|Turcz.]] ex [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca papillosa''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It is one of the smallest species of ''[[Melaleuca]]'', distinguished by its narrow, usually hairy, pimply leaves, small heads of pink to purple flowers surrounded by silky hairs and scattered rather than clustered fruits.

==Description==
''Melaleuca papillosa'' is a shrub sometimes growing to {{convert|1.2|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|6.5-14.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|1.0-1.7|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, linear to very narrow egg-shaped and semi-circular in cross section. The leaves are more or less curved, usually covered with short, matted, silky hairs and have small, pimply projections.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=269}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|page=252|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are a shade of pink to purple and arranged in heads on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and sometimes also in the upper leaf axils. The heads are up to {{convert|18|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with up to 3 groups of flowers in threes. The petals are {{convert|1.0-1.2|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower matures. The outer surface of the floral cup (the [[hypanthium]]) is usually hairy and there are five bundles of stamens around the flower, each with 4 to 7 stamens. Flowering occurs mainly in September and October, and is followed by fruit which are woody, cup-shaped [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|3.8-5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, scattered along the stem.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca papillosa'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected in the [[Fitzgerald River National Park]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca papillosa''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561813|publisher=APNI|accessdate=6 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=894|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''papillosa'') is derived from the [[Latin]] word ''papilla'' meaning "nipple"<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.|page = 634}}</ref> referring to the pimply surface of the leaves.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca papillosa'' occurs in the Fitzgerald River district<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="Holliday" /> in the [[Esperance Plains]] [[IBRA|biogeographic region]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca papillosa''|id = 18350}}</ref> It grows in [[Mallee (habit)|mallee]] [[heath]] in rocky clay [[loam]].<ref name=flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=396}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca papillosa'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

214.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox

|image = Callistemon pearsonii.jpg

|status =

|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. pearsonii'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca pearsonii''
|binomial_authority = ([[R.D.Spencer]] & Lumley) [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]] 
|synonyms = 
''Callistemon pearsonii'' <small> [[R.D.Spencer]] & Lumley </small>
}}

'''''Melaleuca pearsonii''''', commonly known as '''Blackdown bottlebrush''', is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to [[Queensland]] in [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state [[Herbarium|herbaria]] continue to use the name ''Callistemon pearsonii''.)<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> It is a small, spreading but compact shrub with hard bark, soft foliage and profuse spikes of bottlebrush flowers in spring and summer.

==Description==
''Melaleuca pearsonii'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|2|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} high and wide, with hard, fibrous bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|14-38|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|1.5-5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, flat, linear to narrow egg-shaped with the narrower end towards the base. The leaf veins are indistinct but there are many distinct oil glands.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=276}}</ref><ref name=Randwick>{{cite web|title=Street Tree Identification Manual|url=https://www.randwick.nsw.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0015/23028/Volume-2-Tree-Species-C-D.pdf|publisher=Randwick City Council|accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref>

The flowers are red, tipped with yellow and are arranged in short spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and also on the sides of the branches. The spikes are {{convert|45-65|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with 20 to 40 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|3.7-5.7|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages and there are 25-39 stamens in each flower. Flowering occurs mainly in spring and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|3.8-5.2|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="Randwick" /><ref name=ABC>{{cite web|last1=Campbell|first1=Colin|title=Fact Sheet: Bomb-Proof Beauties|url=http://www.abc.net.au/gardening/stories/s3547433.htm|publisher=ABC Gardening Australia factsheet|accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca pearsonii'' was first named in 2006 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in [[Novon]] when ''Callistemon pearsonii'' was moved to the present [[genus]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca pearsonii''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/613699|publisher=APNI|accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Novon>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=New Combinations in Melaleuca for Australian Species of Callistemon (Myrtaceae)|journal=Novon|date=2006|volume=16|issue=4|page=473|url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.3417/1055-3177%282006%2916%5B468%3ANCIMFA%5D2.0.CO%3B2|accessdate=15 July 2015|doi=10.3417/1055-3177(2006)16[468:NCIMFA]2.0.CO;2}}</ref> It had previously been known as ''Callistemon pearsonii'', formally described by [[Roger David Spencer|Roger Spencer]] and Peter Lumley in 1986 in [[Muelleria (journal)|Muelleria]], based on plant material collected from the [[Blackdown Tableland National Park|Blackdown Tabeland]]. The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''pearsonii'') honours Steven Pearson, a park ranger in the [[Blackdown Tableland National Park]].<ref name="Brophy" />

''Callistemon pearsonii'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca pearsonii'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref name '"WCSP">{{WCSP | 31471 | ''Callistemon pearsonii'' }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca pearsonii'' occurs on the Blackdown Tableland in [[Queensland]]. It grows near rivers, in rocky gullies and in [[wallum]] vegetation in creek beds.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Use in horticulture==
''Melaleuca pearsonii'' is sometimes cultivated as ''[[Callistemon pearsonii]]'' including the cultivar "Rocky Rambler".

215.text:
{{taxobox
|image = 
|status = P4
|status_system = DECF
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''<ref>Craven. "New combinations in Melaleuca for Australian species of Callistemon (Myrtaceae)." 2006, vol. 16, no4, pp. 468-475.</ref>
|species = '''''M. penicula'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca penicula''
|binomial_authority = ([[K.J.Cowley]]) [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca penicula''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the south of [[Western Australia]]. It is a rare species only known from the [[Fitzgerald River National Park]] and resembles ''[[Melaleuca eximia]]'' with its spikes of red flowers but its leaves and stamen bundles are different.

==Description==
''Melaleuca penicula'' is an erect, woody shrub growing to {{convert|2.5|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall. Its leaves are arranged in alternating pairs ([[Phyllotaxy|decussate]]) so that there are four rows of leaves along the stem. The leaves are
{{convert|5.5-10.3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|2-3.3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, narrow egg-shaped and tapering to a point. Young leaves are covered with soft, silky hairs. The stalk of the leaf is attached to the underside of the leaf and the upper surface of the leaf faces the stem. The oil glands are distinct.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=277}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=106–107|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are red to scarlet and arranged in spikes up to {{convert|60|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide and contain about 40 groups of flowers in threes. The petals are {{convert|3-3.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower opens. The outer surface of the floral cup (the [[hypanthium]]) is usually hairy and there are five bundles of [[stamen]]s around the flower, each with 10 to 14 stamens. Flowering over a long period from October to February and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|4.5-5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long in tight cylindrical clusters.<ref name="Brophy"/><ref name="Holliday"/>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca penicula'' was first formally described as a [[subspecies]] of ''[[Melaleuca coccinea]]'' by [[Kirsten Cowley]] in 1990 from a specimen collected in the North Fitzgerald River National Park<ref name=APNI(1)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca coccinea'' subsp. ''penicula''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/552314|publisher=APNI|accessdate=6 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=CSIRO(2)>{{cite journal|last1=Cowley|first1=KJ|last2=Quinn|first2=FC|last3=Barlow|first3=BA|last4=Craven|first4=LA|title=Contributions to a revision of (Myrtaceae): 7–10|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1990|volume=3|issue=2|pages=17–179|doi=10.1071/SB9900165|url=http://www.publish.csiro.au/paper/SB9900165.htm|accessdate=6 June 2015}}</ref> but later elevated to species rank by [[Lyndley Craven]] and [[Brendan Lepschi]] in 1999.<ref name=APNI(2)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca penicula''|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561825|publisher=APNI|accessdate=6 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=894|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''penicula'') is derived from the [[Latin]] word ''penicillum'' meaning "a painter's brush"<ref name=Wiktiionary>{{cite web|title=penicillum|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/penicillum|publisher=Wiktionary|accessdate=6 June 2015}}</ref> referring to the brush-like stamen bundles.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca penicula'' occurs in the Fitzgerald River National Park<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="Holliday" /> in the [[Esperance Plains]] [[IBRA|biogeographic region]]<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca penicula''|id = 18782}}</ref> where it grows  in sandy soils near granite outcrops.<ref name=flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=396}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca papillosa'' is listed as "[[Declared Rare and Priority Flora List|Priority Four]]" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]]<ref name="FloraBase" /> meaning that it is rare or near threatened.<ref name=DPAW>{{cite web|title=Conservation codes for Western Australian flora and fauna|url=http://www.dpaw.wa.gov.au/images/documents/plants-animals/threatened-species/Listings/conservation_code_definitions.pdf|publisher=Western Australian Government Department of Parks and Wildlife|accessdate=6 June 2015}}</ref>

216.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name=Scarlet bottlebrush
|image = Melaleuca phoenicea (leaves, flowers, fruit).jpg
|image_caption = ''Melaleuca phoenicea'' leaves, flowers and fruit
|status =
|status_system = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. phoenicea'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca phoenicea''
|binomial_authority = ([[John Lindley|Lindl.]]) [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]] 
|synonyms = 
''Callistemon phoeniceus'' <small> [[John Lindley|Lindl.]] </small>
}}

'''''Melaleuca phoenicea''''', commonly known as '''scarlet bottlebrush''' or '''lesser bottlebrush''', is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. (Some Australian state [[Herbarium|herbaria]] continue to use the name ''Callistemon phoeniceus''.)<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> The [[Noongar]] peoples know the plant as '''Tubada'''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kippleonline.net/bobhoward/plantsframe.html|title=Noongar names for plants|accessdate=26 November 2016|publisher=kippleonline.net}}</ref> It is a shrub with thick, blue-green leaves and spikes of scarlet bottlebrush flowers in spring and summer.

==Description==
''Melaleuca phoenicea'' is a large shrub or small tree growing to {{convert|6|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} high. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|31-114|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|3-10|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, flat and linear to egg-shaped with the narrower end towards the base. The leaves are thick and bluish-green and have a mid-vein, 11-18 indistinct lateral veins and prominent oil glands.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=280}}</ref><ref name=ANPSA>{{cite web|title=Callistemon phoeniceus|url=http://anpsa.org.au/c-phoen1.html|publisher=Australian Native Plants Society Australia|accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=ANBG>{{cite web|last1=Mullins|first1=E.|title=Callistemon phoeniceus|url=https://www.anbg.gov.au/gnp/gnp9/callistemon-phoeniceus.html|publisher=Australian National Botanic Garden|accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref>

The flowers are brilliant red or rich scarlet and are arranged in spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and also on the sides of the branches. The spikes are {{convert|50-65|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with 15 to 55 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|2.9-7.3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages. There are 39-56 stamens in each flower. Flowering occurs mainly from October to January but also at other times of the year and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|4.3-6|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="ANPSA" /><ref name="ANBG" />[[File:Melaleuca phoenicea (near Geraldton).jpg|thumb|225px|''M. phoenicea'' growing near [[Geraldton, Western Australia|Geraldton]]]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca phoenicea'' was first named in 2006 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in [[Novon]] when ''Callistemon phoeniceus'' was transferred to the present [[genus]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca phoenicea''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/613700|publisher=APNI|accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Novon>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=New Combinations in Melaleuca for Australian Species of Callistemon (Myrtaceae)|journal=Novon|date=2006|volume=16|issue=4|page=473|url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.3417/1055-3177%282006%2916%5B468%3ANCIMFA%5D2.0.CO%3B2|accessdate=15 July 2015|doi=10.3417/1055-3177(2006)16[468:NCIMFA]2.0.CO;2}}</ref> It had been formally described in 1839 by botanist John Lindley in "A Sketch of the Vegetation of the Swan River Colony" as ''Callistemon phoeniceum'', later revised to ''Callistemon phoeniceus''.The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''pheonicea'') is from the [[Latin]] word ''[[wikt:phoeniceus|phoeniceus]]'', in turn derived from the [[Ancient Greek]] word ''phoinix'' meaning "purple-red",<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.|page =643}}</ref> referring to the flower colour.<ref name="Brophy" />

''Callistemon phoeniceus'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca phoenicea'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref name '"WCSP">{{WCSP | 31476 | ''Callistemon phoeniceus'' }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca grows in the south west of Western Australia but there are also scattered populations in some of the more arid areas of that state.<ref name="Brophy" /> It grows in sandy soils, often along watercourses.<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Callistemon phoeniceus''|id = 5395}}</ref><ref name=flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=350}}</ref>

==Use in horticulture==
''Melaleuca phoenicea'' is often cultivated as ''[[Callistemon phoeniceus]]''. It is hardy and will grow in most soils provided there is adequate moisture and exposure to the sun. It benefits from light pruning and the application of fertiliser.<ref name="ANBG" /><ref name=Wrigley>{{cite book|last1=Wrigley|first1=John W.|last2=Fagg|first2=Murray|title=Australian native plants : a manual for their propagation, cultivation and use in landscaping|date=1983|publisher=Collins|location=Sydney|isbn=0002165759|page=193|edition=2nd}}</ref>

===Gallery===

Image:Callistemon Phoeniceus @ National Botanic Garden Of Wales (3706963940).jpg|''M. phoenicea'' (as ''Callistemon phoeniceus'') 
Image:Melaleuca phoenicea (near Woodanilling).jpg|''M. phoenicea'' growing near [[Woodanilling, Western Australia|Woodanilling]]

217.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|status =
|status_system = 
|image = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. phoidophylla'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca phoidophylla''
|binomial_authority = [[Bryan Brlow|Barlow]] ex [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca phoidophylla''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It is distinguished by its leaf arrangement, small raised blisters on the leaves and heads of white or cream flowers on the ends of the branches in spring.

==Description==
''Melaleuca phoidophylla'' is a shrub sometimes growing to {{convert|6|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall. Its leaves are arranged in rings of three around the stem and are {{convert|3-7.6|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|0.9-1.6|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, linear to narrow egg-shaped and with a rounded end. The leaves have small blisters and in cross section are crescent moon-shaped to semicircular.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=281}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|page=20|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are cream to white, sometimes pinkish and arranged in heads on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering. The heads are up to {{convert|15|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with 3 to 18 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|1.3-2|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower matures. There are five bundles of stamens around the flower, each with 7 to 11 stamens. Flowering occurs from September to November, and is followed by fruit which are woody, cup-shaped [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|1.8-2|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long in clusters along the stem.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca phoidophylla'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected near [[Pingaring, Western Australia|Pingaring]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca phoidophylla''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561831|publisher=APNI|accessdate=6 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=894|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''phoidophylla'') is derived from [[Ancient Greek]] words meaning blistered leaf, referring to the raised blisters on the leaves of this species.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in and between the [[Katanning, Western Australia|Katanning]], [[Boorabbin, Western Australia|Boorabbin]] and [[Salmon Gums, Western Australia|Salmon Gums]] districts<ref name="Brophy" /> in the [[Avon Wheatbelt]], [[Coolgardie (biogeographic region)|Coolgardie]], [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]] and [[Murchison (biogeographic region)|Murchison]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca phoidophylla''|id = 17144}}</ref> It grows in sandy or clayey soils near lakes and areas that are seasonally flooded.<ref name=flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=396}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca phoidophylla'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

==References==

[[Category:Plants described in 1999]]

217.title: Melaleuca phoidophylla

218.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|image =
|image_caption = 
|status =
|status_system = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. phratra'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca phratra''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
|synonyms = 
<small> ''Callistemon phratra'' ([[Lyndley Craven|Craven]])  Udovicic & [[R.D.Spencer]] </small>
}}

'''''Melaleuca phratra''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to [[Queensland]] in [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state [[Herbarium|herbaria]] use the name ''Callistemon phratra''.)<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> It is a large shrub similar to ''[[Melaleuca paludicola]]'' but has flower spikes that are a shade of pink.

==Description==
''Melaleuca phratra'' is a large shrub or small growing to {{convert|10|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with hard, brown or grey to black fissured bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|22-57|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|1.2-5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, flat, narrow elliptic in shape with a mid-vein and 13 to 24 indistinct lateral veins. The leaves usually have some thickening at the mid-vein and prominent oil glands.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=282}}</ref>

The flowers are arranged in spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering or on the sides of the branches and are {{convert|25-30|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} in diameter with 10 to 30 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|2-3.8|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages and there are 47-72 stamens in each flower. The filaments of the [[stamens]] are pink with a yellow anther. Flowering occurs from November and February and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|3.1-3.7|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca phratra'' was first formally described in 2009 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in [[Novon]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca phratra''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/653270|publisher=APNI|accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=''Melaleuca'' (Myrtaceae) from Australia|journal=Novon|date=2009|volume=19|page=447|doi=10.3417/2007008|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/40330691#page/454/mode/1up|accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''phratra'') is from the [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] words ''phratry'' meaning "member of a clan"<ref name=dictionary>{{cite web|title=phratry|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/phratry|publisher=Merriam-Webster Incorporated|accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref> referring to the similarity of this species to ''[[Melaleuca paludicola|M. paludicola]]'', ''[[Melaleuca quercina|M. quercina]]'' and ''[[Melaleuca sabrina|M. sabrina]]''.<ref name="Brophy" />

''Callistemon phratra'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca phratra'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref name '"WCSP">{{WCSP | 472814 | ''Callistemon phratra'' }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in and between the [[Injune]] and [[Texas, Queensland|Texas]] districts in Queensland. It grows along creek banks.<ref name="Brophy" />

[[Category:Flora of Australia]]
[[Category:Flora of Queensland]]
[[Category:Plants described in 2009]]

219.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = Alpine bottlebrush
|image = Melaleuca pityoides leaves, flowers and fruit.jpg
|image_caption = ''M. pityoides'' leaves, flowers and fruit
|status =
|status_system = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. pityoides'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca pityoides''
|binomial_authority = ([[Ferdinand von Mueller|F.Muell.]]) [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]] 
|synonyms = 
''Callistemon pityoides'' <small> [[Ferdinand von Mueller|F.Muell.]] </small>
}}

'''''Melaleuca pityoides''''', commonly known as '''alpine bottlebrush''', is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the higher areas of south eastern [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state [[Herbarium|herbaria]] continue to use the name ''[[Callistemon pityoides]]'').<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> It is a shrub, often occurring in dense thickets, with hard bark, silvery-grey new growth, almost cylindrical leaves and spikes of flowers that are usually a shade of yellow.

==Description==
''Melaleuca pityoides'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|3|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} high and wide, with hard, grey bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|12-24|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|0.5-2.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, flat to almost cylindrical in cross section, very narrow elliptic to egg-shaped and end with a sharp point. The leaf veins and oil glands are indistinct. The young leaves and branches are often densely covered with silky hairs.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=283}}</ref><ref name=ANBG>{{cite web|title=Callistemon pityoides|url=https://www.anbg.gov.au/gnp/gnp6/cal-pity.html|publisher=Australian National Botanic Garden|accessdate=16 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=RBGS>{{cite web|last1=Spencer|first1=Roger David|last2=Lumley|first2=Peter|title=Callistemon pityoides|url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Callistemon~pityoides|publisher=Royal Botanic Garden Sydney: Plantnet|accessdate=16 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=RBGM>{{cite web|title=Callistemon pityoides|url=http://data.rbg.vic.gov.au/vicflora/flora/taxon/21bba97a-9ac0-41ae-8a9f-a893238ad324|publisher=Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne|accessdate=16 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=ANPSA>{{cite web|title=Callistemon pityoides|url=http://anpsa.org.au/c-pit.html|publisher=Australian Native Plants Society Australia|accessdate=16 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Armidale>{{cite web|last1=Wilson|first1=Neil|title=Callistemon pityoides|url=http://aps-armidale.org.au/resources/facts/profiles/C_pityoides.html|publisher=Australian Plants Society Armidale District|accessdate=16 July 2015}}</ref>

The flowers are a shade of golden-yellow to cream, sometimes tinged with pink or green and are arranged in short spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering. The spikes are {{convert|18-25|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and {{convert|100|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long with 10 to 15 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|2.1-3.4|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages and there are 32-52 stamens in each flower. Flowering occurs from October to February, sometimes in other months and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|3.2-5.1|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="ANBG" /><ref name="RBGS" /><ref name="ANPSA" />[[File:Melaleuca pityoides habit (Torrington).jpg|thumb|225px|''M. pityoides'' (habit) in the [[Torrington, New South Wales|Torrington]] State Conservation Area]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
This species was first formally described in 1883 by Victorian Government Botanist [[Ferdinand von Mueller]], who gave it the name ''Callistemon pityoides'' in ''Australian Chemist and Druggist'', based on material gathered from the environs of the [[Ovens River]] and [[Dumaresq River|"Dumaresque River"]].<ref name=APNI(3)>{{cite web|title=''Callistemon pityoides''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/522716|publisher=APNI|accessdate=23 July 2015}}</ref> He first mentioned ''Melaleuca pithyoides'' without description in 1853 in his ''First General Report of the Government Botanist on the Vegetation of the Colony'' in 1853.<ref name=APNI(2)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca pithyoides''|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/name/apni/233573|publisher=APNI|accessdate=23 July 2015}}</ref> Mueller had collected non-flowering plant material from [[Mount Buffalo National Park|Mount Buffalo]] on an expedition earlier that year.<ref name="APNI" /> 

The name was changed to ''Melaleuca pityoides'' in 2006 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in [[Novon]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca pityoides''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/613701|publisher=APNI|accessdate=23 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Novon>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=New Combinations in Melaleuca for Australian Species of Callistemon (Myrtaceae)|journal=Novon|date=2006|volume=16|issue=4|page=473|url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.3417/1055-3177%282006%2916%5B468%3ANCIMFA%5D2.0.CO%3B2|accessdate=16 July 2015|doi=10.3417/1055-3177(2006)16[468:NCIMFA]2.0.CO;2}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''pityoides'') is from the [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] ''pitys'' meaning “pine”<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref>{{rp|609}} and ''εἶδος (eîdos)'' meaning "likeness”,<ref name="RWB" />{{rp|346}} referring to the similarity of the leaves of this species with those of some kinds of pine trees.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs from the [[Border Ranges National Park|Border Ranges]] district in the far south east of [[Queensland]], south through the [[Northern Tablelands|Northern]], [[Central Tablelands|Central]] and [[Southern Tablelands|Southern]] Tablelands of [[New South Wales]] and the highlands of eastern [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]]. It grows in swampy [[heath]] and rocky streams, often forming thickets to the exclusion of other species.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="ANBG" /><ref name="RBGS" /><ref name="RBGM" />

==Use in horticulture==
''Melaleuca pityoides'' is sometimes cultivated (as ''[[Callistemon pityoides]]''). It grows well in cold climates, including in the [[United Kingdom]], preferring heavier soils and can tolerate poor drainage.<ref name="ANPSA" />

==Gallery==
<gallery>
Image:Melaleuca pityoides habit (near New England National Park).jpg|''M. pityoides'' thicket near [[New England National Park]]
Image:Callistemon pityoides thicket.jpg|''M. pityoides'' thicket in [[Baw Baw National Park]]
</gallery>
