220.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|status =
|status_system = 
|image = Melaleuca podiocarpa (habit).JPG
|image caption = ''M. podiocarpa'' growing near [[Lake Grace, Western Australia|Lake Grace]]
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. podiocarpa'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca podiocarpa''
|binomial_authority = [[Bryan Brlow|Barlow]] ex [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca podiocarpa''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It is a spreading shrub with prickly foliage and small heads of white flowers mostly hidden within the foliage.

==Description==
''Melaleuca podiocarpa'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|2.5|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall. Its leaves are arranged alternately, {{convert|4.5-14|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|1.5-6|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, elliptic to egg-shaped, crescent moon-shaped in cross section and the end tapering to a sharp, prickly point.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=286}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=220–221|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are white, in small heads on the ends and sides of the branches. The heads contain up to 3 individual flowers. The outer surface of the flower cup (the [[hypanthium]]) is hairy. The [[petal]]s are {{convert|4.5-5.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower matures. There are five bundles of [[stamen]]s around the flower, each with 30 to 45 stamens. Flowering occurs from mid spring to mid summer, and is followed by fruit which are solitary, woody, cup-shaped [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|3.8-7.7|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}}.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>
[[File:Melaleuca podiocarpa (leaves, flowers).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. podiocarpa'' leaves and flowers.]]
[[File:Melaleuca podiocarpa (fruits).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. podiocarpa'' fruit]]
[[File:Melaleuca podiocarpa (bark).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. podiocarpa'' bark]]


==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca podiocarpa'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected on the [[Lake King, Western Australia|Lake King]] to [[Norseman, Western Australia|Norseman]] road.<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca podiocarpa''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561834|publisher=APNI|accessdate=7 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=898|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''podiocarpa'') is derived from [[Ancient Greek]] words ''ποδός (podós)'' meaning  “foot”<ref name=Wiktionary(1)>{{cite web|title=-podo|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-podo|publisher=Wiktionary|accessdate=7 June 2015}}</ref> and ''kαρπός (karpós)'' meaning "fruit"<ref name=Wiktionary(2)>{{cite web|title=Karpos|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/karpos|publisher=Wiktionary|accessdate=7 June 2015}}</ref> referring to the foot like base of the fruiting capsules.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in and between the [[Lake King, Western Australia|Lake King]] and [[Grass Patch, Western Australia|Grass Patch]] districts<ref name="Brophy" /> in the [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]] [[IBRA|biogeographic region]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca podiocarpa''|id = 19092}}</ref> It grows in sand, gravel or clay on plains.<ref name=flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=396}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca podiocarpa'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = Gold-tipped bottlebrush
|image = Gardenology.org-IMG 4853 hunt0904.jpg
|image_caption = ''M. polandii'' in [[Huntington Gardens]], ([[Los Angeles]]).
|status =
|status_system =

|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s

|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. polandii'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca polandii''
|binomial_authority = ([[Frederick Manson Bailey|F.M.Bailey]]) [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]] 
|synonyms = 
''Callistemon polandii'' <small> [[Frederick Manson Bailey|F.M.Bailey]] </small>
}}

'''''Melaleuca polandii''''', commonly known as '''gold-tipped bottlebrush''', is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] a small area in far northern [[Queensland]] in [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state [[Herbarium|herbaria]] continue to use the name ''Callistemon polandii''.)<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=15 June 2015}}</ref> It is a dense shrub with bronze-coloured, hairy new growth and spikes of red flowers tipped with yellow.

==Description==
''Melaleuca polandii'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|4|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} high. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|63-129|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|16-35|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, flat, narrow egg-shaped and tapering to a point. The leaves have a distinct mid-vein and 19 to 25 lateral veins. The young leaves and branches are covered with fine, silky hairs.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=287}}</ref><ref name=water>{{cite web|title=Callistemon polandii|url=https://www.sydneywater.com.au/SW/your-home/saving-water-at-home/garden-and-pool/plant-selector/plant-detail/SWP_CDF_DD_050613|publisher=Sydney Water|accessdate=16 July 2015}}</ref>

The flowers are bright red and are arranged in spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and sometimes in the upper leaf axils. The spikes are {{convert|50-60|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} in diameter. The petals are {{convert|3.6-5.3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, fall off as the flower ages and there are 35-50 stamens in each flower. Flowering occurs from late winter to summer, sometimes in other months and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|4.6-6.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="water" />
[[File:Melaleuca polandii.JPG|thumb|225px|''M. polandii'' in [[Australian Botanic Garden Mount Annan]]]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca polandii'' was first named in 2006 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in [[Novon]] when ''Callistemon polandii'' was transferred to the present [[genus]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca polandii''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/613702|publisher=APNI|accessdate=16 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Novon>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=New Combinations in Melaleuca for Australian Species of Callistemon (Myrtaceae)|journal=Novon|date=2006|volume=16|issue=4|page=473|url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.3417/1055-3177%282006%2916%5B468%3ANCIMFA%5D2.0.CO%3B2|accessdate=16 July 2015|doi=10.3417/1055-3177(2006)16[468:NCIMFA]2.0.CO;2}}</ref> ''Callistemon polandii'' was first formally described in 1902 by [[Frederick Manson Bailey]] from a specimen collected in "Bloomfield River [by] Rev. W. Poland". The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''polandii'') honours Wilhelm Poland, a missionary at [[Wujal Wujal, Queensland|Wujal Wujal]] (formerly the Bloomfield River Mission).<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name=Griffith>{{cite web|title=German Missionaries in Australia|url=http://missionaries.griffith.edu.au/biography/poland-wilhelm-georg-friedrich-1866-1955|publisher=Griffith University|accessdate=16 July 2015}}</ref>

''Callistemon polandii'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca polandii'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref name '"WCSP">{{WCSP | 31479 | ''Callistemon polandii'' }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in the [[Cape Flattery (Queensland)|Cape Flattery]] and [[Cooktown]] districts of [[Queensland]] where it grows in dense [[wallum]] [[heath]] in sandy or peaty soils.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Use in horticulture==
''Melaleuca polandii'' is a hardy shrub, suitable for warm coastal areas. It is useful as a screen or hedge but is known to damage wastewater pipes.<ref name="water" /><ref name=Wrigley>{{cite book|last1=Wrigley|first1=John W.|last2=Fagg|first2=Murray|title=Australian native plants : a manual for their propagation, cultivation and use in landscaping|date=1983|publisher=Collins|location=Sydney|isbn=0002165759|page=193|edition=2nd}}</ref>

222.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = ''Melaleuca polycephala''
|status = P3
|status_system = DECF
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. polycephala'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca polycephala''
|binomial_authority = [[George Bentham|Benth.]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca polycephala''''' is a shrub in the myrtle family, [[Myrtaceae]], and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It is a sparsely foliaged, twiggy shrub with deep purple flowers in spring.

==Description==
''Melaleuca polycephala'' is a bushy shrub with tangled branches growing to about {{convert|1|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall and wide. Its leaves are arranged alternately, {{convert|5-15|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|2-4.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, narrow elliptic or narrow egg-shaped, tapering to a sharp point and with the veins prominent on the upper surface.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|page=288|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517}}</ref>

The flowers are arranged in heads on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering. The heads contain between 3 and 7 groups of flowers in threes and are up to {{convert|12|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter. The stamens are in five bundles around the flowers, each bundle containing 3 stamens. Flowering is mainly in September and October and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]] {{convert|2.0-2.8|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and in roughly spherical clusters.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=168–169|edition=2nd}}</ref>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca polycephala'' was first formally described in 1867 by [[George Bentham]] in ''[[Flora Australiensis]]''.<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca polycephala''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/542458|publisher=APNI|accessdate=16 April 2015}}</ref><ref name=Mueller>{{cite book|last1=Mueller|first1=Ferdinand|title=Flora Australiensis, volume 3|date=1866|location=London|pages=152–153|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/41807#page/160/mode/1up|accessdate=16 April 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''polycephala'') is derived from the [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] words ''πολύς (polús)'' meaning “many"<ref name=Wiktionary(1)>{{cite web|title=poly-|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/poly-|publisher=Wiktionary|accessdate=16 April 2015}}</ref> and ''κεφαλή (kephalḗ)'' meaning "head"<ref name=Wiktionary(2)>{{cite web|title=-cephaly|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-cephaly|publisher=Wiktionary|accessdate=16 April 2015}}</ref>  in reference to the large number of flower heads in examples of this species.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in and between the [[Gnowangerup, Western Australia|Gnowangerup]], [[Pingrup, Western Australia|Pingrup]] and [[Jerramungup, Western Australia|Jerramungup]]<ref name="Brophy" /> districts in the [[Esperance Plains]] and [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca polycephala''|id = 5950}}</ref> It grows in clay and sandy clay.<ref name=Flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=396}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca polycephala'' is classified as "[[Declared Rare and Priority Flora List|Priority Three]]" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]]<ref name="FloraBase" /> meaning that it is known from only a few locations and is not currently in imminent danger.<ref name=DPAW>{{cite web|title=Conservation codes for Western Australian flora and fauna|url=http://www.dpaw.wa.gov.au/images/documents/plants-animals/threatened-species/Listings/conservation_code_definitions.pdf|publisher=Western Australian government department of parks and wildlife|accessdate=16 April 2015}}</ref>

223.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|status =
|status_system = 
|image = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. procera'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca procera''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca procera''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It is an erect, spindly shrub with cylinder-shaped leaves and heads of pinkish flowers in later spring or early summer.

==Description==
''Melaleuca procera'' is a  sparsely-branched shrub, growing to {{convert|2|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall. Its leaves are arranged alternately, {{convert|5.5-19|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|0.9-1.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, linear in shape and nearly circular in cross-section, tapering to a rounded end with a sharp point.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=292}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=226–227|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are a shade of pink to mauve, arranged in heads on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and sometimes also in the upper leaf axils. The heads are up to {{convert|30|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and contain 2 to 9 groups of flowers in threes. The outer surface of the flower cup (the [[hypanthium]]) is hairy. The [[petal]]s are {{convert|2.5-3.5|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long and fall off soon after the flower opens. There are five bundles of [[stamen]]s around the flower, each with 8 to 10 stamens. Flowering occurs in November or December, and is followed by fruit which are solitary, woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|3-4|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca procera'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected on the [[Lake King, Western Australia|Lake King]] to [[Norseman, Western Australia|Norseman]] road.<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca procera''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561839|publisher=APNI|accessdate=7 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=899|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''procera'') is derived from [[Latin]] word ''procerus'' meaning  “tall” or "extended",<ref name=Wiktionary>{{cite web|title=procerus|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/procerus|publisher=Wiktionary|accessdate=7 June 2015}}</ref> referring slender habit of this species.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca procera'' occurs in and between the [[Kulin, Western Australia|Kulin]], [[Kalgarin, Western Australia|Kalgarin]] and [[Lake Grace, Western Australia|Lake Grace]] districts<ref name="Brophy" /> in the [[Avon Wheatbelt]] and [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca procera''|id = 18266}}</ref> It grows in sandy loam and gravel<ref name=flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=396}}</ref> in low open heath.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca procera'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

|status =

|species = '''''M. pulchella'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca pulchella''
|binomial_authority = [[Robert Brown (botanist, born 1773)|R.Br.]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca pulchella''''', commonly known as '''claw flower''' and '''claw honey-myrtle''', is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the south of [[Western Australia]]. It is one of only two species of ''[[Melaleuca]]'' to have two kinds of [[stamen]]s. (The other is ''[[Melaleuca violacea]]''). The outer stamens are longer and curved, giving the appearance of a claw to the flower. It is a hardy shrub flowering over a long period and has been a popular garden plant for many years.

==Description==
''Melaleuca pulchella'' is a spreading shrub which may grow to {{convert|1-2|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} high. The numerous arching branches bear many small leaves which are ovate to elliptic in shape and measure {{convert|2-6|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in length by {{convert|1-3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide. The leaves are crescent moon shaped in cross section and the undersides have large oil glands.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=295}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=230–231|edition=2nd}}</ref>

Appearing from September to February, sometimes in April or May, the flowers are pink to mauve in colour. They occur singly or in groups of up to four, forming small heads up to {{convert|20|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter, mostly at or near the ends of the branches. The [[petal]]s are {{convert|3.8-6.6|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower matures. There are five bundles of [[stamen]]s around the flower, each with 45-100 stamens.  Each bundle contains about 45 to 80 short, ([[Sterility (physiology)|sterile]]) stamens and 10 to 15 long, curved, outer stamens. Flowering is followed by fruit which are woody, urn-shaped [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|3.3-4.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and about {{convert|6|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter.<ref name="Brophy"/><ref name="Holliday"/>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca pulchella'' was first formally described in 1812 by [[Robert Brown (Scottish botanist from Montrose)|Robert Brown]] , the description published by [[William Aiton]] in ''[[Hortus Kewensis]]''.<ref name=Aiton>{{cite book|last1=Aiton|first1=William Townsend|last2=Brown|first2=Robert|title=Hortus Kewensis (Volume 4)|date=1812|location=London|page=414|edition=2|url=http://bibdigital.rjb.csic.es/ing/Libro.php?Libro=3050&Pagina=416|accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca pulchella''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/542789|publisher=APNI|accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''pulchella'') is the [[Latin]] adjective ''pulchellus'' meaning "very pretty" (diminutive of ''pulcher''),<ref>{{cite book |author = Simpson DP | title = Cassell's Latin Dictionary | publisher = Cassell Ltd. | year = 1979 |edition = 5 |location = London |page=487 | isbn=0-304-52257-0}}</ref> referring to the flowers of this species.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca sapientes'' occurs along Western Australia's south coast, from [[Hopetoun, Western Australia|Hopetoun]] to [[Israelite Bay, Western Australia|Israelite Bay]]<ref name="Brophy"/><ref name="Holliday"/> in the [[Esperance Plains]] and [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca pulchella''|id = 5955}}</ref> It grows in sandy soils on plains, dunes and swamps.<ref name=flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=396}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca pulchella'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

==Use in horticulture==
''Melaleuca pulchella'''s small size, long flowering period and widely admired flowers make it a popular plant for gardens. It prefers fair drainage and extra water<ref name="Holliday" /> but is adaptable to most garden situations.<ref name=Wrigley>{{cite book|last1=Wrigley|first1=John W.|last2=Fagg|first2=Murray|title=Australian native plants : a manual for their propagation, cultivation and use in landscaping|date=1983|publisher=Collins|location=Sydney|isbn=0002165759|page=86|edition=2nd}}</ref> Unlike many Australian native plants, it is relatively tolerant of phosphates to some degree in cultivation.<ref>{{cite book |author=Lullfitz, George |title=A new image for West Australian plants |isbn=0-9581346-0-X |page=46}}</ref>

|species = '''''M. pustulata'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca pustulata''
|binomial_authority = [[Joseph Dalton Hooker|(Hook.f.)]] [[Otto Kuntze|Kuntze]]
|synonyms=Myrtoleucodendron pustulatum (Hook.f.) Kuntze|}}

'''''Melaleuca pustulata''''', commonly known as '''yellow paperbark''', '''warty paperbark''' or '''Cranbrook paperbark''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to [[Tasmania]] in [[Australia]]. It is an uncommon shrub, one of only two melaleucas that are endemic to that state and one of only eight found naturally occurring there. It has thick, pimply leaves, hairy new growth and large numbers of heads of pale yellow, fragrant flowers in spring or early summer.

==Description==
''Melaleuca pustulata'' is a  densely foliaged shrub, growing to {{convert|5|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with hairy new growth. Its leaves are arranged alternately, sometimes in groups of three and are {{convert|5-10|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|0.5-1.6|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, very narrow elliptic to very narrow egg-shaped, roughly semi-circular in cross section and with the ends tapering to a point. The mature leaves have distinct raised oil glands giving the leaves a blistered appearance.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=298}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=234–235|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are white to yellowish, scented and arranged in spikes or heads on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering. The heads are up to {{convert|18|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and contain 15 to 30 individual flowers. The [[petal]]s are {{convert|2|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower matures. There are five bundles of [[stamen]]s around the flower, each with 5 to 9 stamens. Flowering occurs from September to January and is followed by fruit which are woody, cup-shaped [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|3-5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long in cylindrical clusters along the stem.<ref name="Brophy"/><ref name="Holliday"/>

''Melaleuca pustulata'' is sometimes confused with ''[[Melaleuca ericifolia]]'' which also occurs naturally in Tasmania, however the leaves of that species lack the raised oil glands of ''M. pustulata'' and the outer surface of its flower cup ([[hypanthium]]) is hairy.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca pustulata'' was first formally described in 1847 by [[Joseph Dalton Hooker|Joseph Hooker]] from specimens collected "in [[Campbell Town]] and [[Great Oyster Bay|Oyster Bay]]".<ref name=London>{{cite journal|last1=Hooker|first1=Joseph Dalton|title=Florae Tasmaniae Spicilegium: or, Contributions towards a Flora of Van Diemen's Land|journal=London Journal of Botany|date=1847|volume=6|pages=476–477|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/6317#page/518/mode/1up|accessdate=7 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca pustulata''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/542924|publisher=APNI|accessdate=23 July 2015}}</ref> 

'Melaleuca' is derived from [[Greek language|Greek]] and means 'black and white', a reference to the color of the bark.<ref name="gledhill">Gledhill, David (2008). "The Names of Plants". Cambridge University Press. ISBN 9780521866453 (hardback), ISBN 9780521685535 (paperback).  pp 254</ref>

The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''pustulata'') is derived from the [[Latin]] word ''pustula'' meaning  “blister”,<ref name=Wiktionary>{{cite web|title=pustule|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/pustule|publisher=Wiktionary|accessdate=7 June 2015}}</ref> referring to the prominent oil glands on the leaves of this species.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs near the east coast of Tasmania usually in dry heath, often on shallow soils derived from [[dolerite]].<ref name="Brophy"/><ref name="Holliday"/><ref name=FPA>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca pustulata'' scrub|url=http://www.fpa.tas.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0006/58065/Threatened_native_vegetation_community_information_sheet_-_Melaleuca_pustulata_Scrub.pdf|publisher=Tasmanian government forest practices authority|accessdate=7 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=utas>{{cite web|last1=Jordan|first1=Greg|title=''Melaleuca pustulata''|url=http://www.utas.edu.au/dicotkey/dicotkey/MYRTS/sMelaleuca_pustulata.htm|publisher=University of Tasmania|accessdate=7 June 2015}}</ref>

==Conservation status==
''Melaleuca pustulata'' is declared a rare species under the Tasmanian government Threatened Species Protection Act (1995).<ref name=DPIPWE>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca pustulata''|url=http://www.threatenedspecieslink.tas.gov.au/melaleuca-pustulata|publisher=Tasmanian government Department of Primary Industries, Water and Environment|accessdate=7 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=DPIPWE(2)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca pustulata''|url=http://dpipwe.tas.gov.au/Documents/Melaleuca-pustulata.pdf|publisher=Tasmanian government Department of Primary Industries, Parks, Water and Environment|accessdate=7 June 2015}}</ref>

==Use in horticulture==
''Melaleuca pustulata'' is a useful plant for hedges and windbreaks.<ref name="Holliday" /> It is sometimes cultivated as an ornamental because of its fragrant yellow flowers.<ref>http://davesgarden.com/guides/pf/go/56540/</ref>

|binomial = ''Melaleuca pyramidalis''

|synonyms = ''Callistemon pyramidalis'' {{small|([[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]) Udovicic & R.D.Spencer}}{{br}}
}}

'''''Melaleuca pyramidalis''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to small areas of [[Queensland]] in [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state herbaria use the name ''Callistemon pyramidalis''.<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=31 May 2015}}</ref>) It is closely related to ''Melaleuca citrina'' (''Callistemon citrinus'') but is distinguished from it mainly by leaf and [[stamen]] differences. ''Melaleuca pyramidalis'' is only known from the summits of three mountains in Queensland.

==Description==
''Melaleuca pyramidalis'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|3.5|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with compact, dark grey, papery bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|29-84|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|8-24|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} wide, flat, elliptical in shape with a short stalk. The veins are [[pinnation|pinnate]] and there are only a few scattered, indistinct oil glands. <ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=299}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=''Melaleuca'' (Myrtaceae) from Australia|journal=Novon|date=2009|volume=19|issue=4|pages=448–449|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/124658#page/456/mode/1up|accessdate=1 June 2015|doi=10.3417/2007137}}</ref>

The flowers are red to pink, arranged in spikes up to {{convert|60|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with 20 to 50 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|2.8-6.3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages and there are 35 to 42 stamens in each flower.  Flowering occurs in late winter and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|3.8-5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long in loose clusters along the stem.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name="Craven"/>

''M. pyramidalis'' can be distinguished from the similar ''M. citrina'' by its obscure oil glands (prominent in ''M. citrina'') and yellow [[stamen]] tips (dark red in ''M.citrina''). 
[[File:Melaleuca pyramidalis (flowers) 01.JPG|thumb|225px|Early flowers]]
[[File:Melaleuca pyramidalis (foliage).JPG|thumb|225px|Foliage]]
[[File:Melaleuca pyramidalis (fruits).JPG|thumb|225px|Fruit]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca pyramidalis'' was first formally described in 2009 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Novon]]'' from a specimen collected at the summit of [[Walshs Pyramid]] near [[Gordonvale, Queensland|Gordonvale]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca pyramidalis''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/653271|publisher=APNI|accessdate=1 June 2015}}</ref> In 2012, Udovicic and Spencer gave the species the name ''[[Callistemon pyramidalis]]''<ref name="Udovicic" /> but in 2013, Craven transferred all species previously known as ''Callistemon'' to ''Melaleuca''. Some authorities continue to use ''Callistemon pyramidalis''.<ref name="Udovicic" /> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''pyramidalis'') refers to Walshs Pyramid where the [[Type (biology)|type specimen]] was collected.<ref name="Brophy" />

''Callistemon pyramidalis'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca pyramidalis'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref name '"WCSP">{{WCSP | 471977 | ''Callistemon pyramidalis'' }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca pyramidalis'' occurs on the summits of Walshs Pyramid, [[Mount Diamantina]] (on [[Hinchinbrook Island]]) and [[Mount Leach]] (near [[Ingham, Queensland|Ingham]]). It grows mostly in open forest on rocky hilltops.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="Craven" />

==Conservation==
The classification "Vulnerable" under the IUCN Red List applies to ''Melaleuca pyramidalis'' because it is only known from a few sites.<ref name="Craven" />

'''''Melaleuca quercina''''', commonly known as '''Oakey bottlebrush''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to a small area of [[Queensland]] in [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state herbaria use the name ''Callistemon quercinus''.<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=16 July 2015}}</ref>) It is small tree with dark, corky bark and spikes of yellow, cream or pink bottlebrush flowers in spring and summer.

==Description==
''Melaleuca quercina'' is a large shrub or small tree growing to {{convert|10|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with dark, corky bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|23-74|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|3.5-12|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, more or less flat and elliptical in shape with a longer stalk than other melaleucas. The leaves have a mid-vein and 11-20 lateral veins.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=301}}</ref>

The flowers are a shade of yellow or pink and are arranged in spikes {{convert|25-30|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} in diameter with 15 to 40 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|3.1-4.4|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages and there are 70 to 94 stamens in each flower.  Flowering occurs from October to February and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|3-5.3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long in loose clusters along the stem.<ref name=Brophy/>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca quercina'' was first formally described in 2009 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Novon]]'' from a specimen found near Oakey Creek.<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca quercina''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/653272|publisher=APNI|accessdate=16 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=''Melaleuca'' (Myrtaceae) from Australia|journal=Novon|date=2009|volume=19|page=449|doi=10.3417/2007008|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/40330691#page/454/mode/1up|accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''quercina'') refers to the oak genus ''[[Quercus]]'' in the [[beech]] family [[Fagaceae]] and hence the location Oakey Creek near [[Oakey, Queensland|Oakey]] in Queensland.<ref name="Brophy" />

''Callistemon quercinus'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca quercina'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref name '"WCSP">{{WCSP | 471978 | ''Callistemon quercinus'' }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca quercina'' occurs in the Oakey and [[Dalby, Queensland|Dalby]] districts in Queensland where it grows along the banks and flats of creeks in dark clay soils.<ref name="Brophy" />

228.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = Graceful honey-myrtle
|image = Melaleuca radula 01 gnangarra.jpg
|image caption = ''M. radula'' (cultivated) in [[Kings Park, Western Australia|Kings Park]], [[Perth]]
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. radula'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca radula''
|binomial_authority = [[John Lindley|Lindl.]]
|}}

'''''Melaleuca radula''''', commonly known as '''graceful honey-myrtle''', is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It is an open, spreading shrub with narrow leaves, profuse pink or purple flowers in late winter and smooth, almost spherical fruits.

==Description==
''Melaleuca radula'' is a spreading shrub, growing to {{convert|5|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with coarse bark. Its leaves are arranged in alternating pairs ([[Phyllotaxy|decussate]]) so that they make four rows along the branches. The leaves are {{convert|10-45|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|0.7-2|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, linear to elliptic in shape with the sides turned up so that they are crescent moon-shaped in cross section. There are prominent oil glands on the lower surface.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=304}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=240–241|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are white or more usually a shade of pink to mauve. They are arranged in pairs of up to 5, the flowers on opposite sides of the branches forming a spike up to {{convert|40|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|30|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter. The [[petal]]s are {{convert|4.5-6.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower matures. There are five bundles of [[stamen]]s around the flower, each with 30 to 90 stamens giving the spike a fluffy appearance. Flowering mostly occurs from July to September, and is followed by fruit which are woody, almost spherical [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|4-6|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} in diameter in clusters along the stem.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>
[[File:Melaleuca radula (habit).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. radula'' growing on Mt. O'Brien near [[Wongan Hills, Western Australia|Wongan Hills]]]]
[[File:Melaleuca radula (fruits).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. radula'' fruits and showing curved leaf margins]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca radula'' was first formally described in 1839 by [[John Lindley]] in  an appendix to ''[[Edwards Botanical Register]]'' entitled ''[[A Sketch of the Vegetation of the Swan River Colony]]''.<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca radula''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/543100|publisher=APNI|accessdate=7 June 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''radula'') is derived from [[Latin]] word  meaning  “a scraper” <ref name=Wiktionary>{{cite web|title=radula|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/radula|publisher=Wiktionary|accessdate=7 June 2015}}</ref> but it is not clear why Lindley chose this name.<ref name="Brophy" />
{{wikisourcepar|Edwards's Botanical Register/Appendix to the first twenty-three volumes/A sketch of the vegetation of the Swan River Colony/Myrtaceae#f. 24}}

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in and between the [[Kalbarri, Western Australia| Kalbarri]], [[Perth]] and [[Norseman, Western Australia| Norseman]] districts<ref name="Brophy" /> in the [[Avon Wheatbelt]], [[Coolgardie (biogeographic region)|Coolgardie]], [[Geraldton Sandplains]], [[Jarrah Forest]], [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]], [[Murchison (biogeographic region)|Murchison]], [[Swan Coastal Plain]] and [[Yalgoo (biogeographic region)|Yalgoo]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca radula''|id = 5958}}</ref> It grows in sandy and gravelly soils often near [[granite]] or [[laterite]] and near creeks and streams.<ref name=flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=397}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca radula'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

==References==
{{reflist|30em}}

[[Category:Flora of Western Australia]]
[[Category:Melaleuca|radula]]
[[Category:Myrtales of Australia]]
[[Category:Plants described in 1839]]
[[Category:Rosids of Western Australia]]
[[Category:Endemic flora of Western Australia]]
228.title: Melaleuca radula

229.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = Tinaroo bottlebrush
|image = Callistemon recurvus.jpg
|image_caption = ''M. recurva'' in [[Maranoa Gardens]]
|status =
|status_system = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. recurva'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca recurva''
|binomial_authority = ([[Roger David Spencer|R.D. Spencer]] & Lumley) [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]] 
|synonyms = 
''Callistemon recurvus'' <small> [[Roger David Spencer|R.D. Spencer]] & Lumley </small>
}}

'''''Melaleuca recurva''''', commonly known as '''Tinaroo bottlebrush''', is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] in higher areas of far northern [[Queensland]] in [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state [[Herbarium|herbaria]] continue to use the name ''[[Callistemon recurvus]]'').<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=16 June 2015}}</ref> It is a shrub with spikes of red flowers tipped with yellow in most months of the year and which often has leaves with their edges curled under.

==Description==
''Melaleuca recurva'' is a shrub or small tree growing to {{convert|7|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} high with hard, fibrous bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|15-55|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|2-9|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, flat and narrow egg-shaped with the end tapering to a point. The leaves have indistinct veins and randomly distributed oil glands. The young leaves and branches have fine, silky hairs pressed against their surfaces.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=305}}</ref><ref name=trin>{{cite web|title=Melaleuca recurva|url=http://keys.trin.org.au/key-server/data/0e0f0504-0103-430d-8004-060d07080d04/media/Html/taxon/Melaleuca_recurva.htm|publisher=Australian Tropical Rainforest Plants|accessdate=16 July 2015}}</ref>

The flowers are bright red tipped with yellow and are arranged in spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering, sometimes also in the upper leaf axils. The spikes are {{convert|35-50|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter. The petals are {{convert|2.5-4|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, fall off as the flower ages and there are 26-36 stamens in each flower. Flowering occurs throughout the year but mainly in the cooler months and is followed by fruits which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|4.6-6.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="trin" />

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca recurva'' was first named in 2006 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in [[Novon]] when ''Callistemon recurvus'' was moved to the present [[genus]].<ref name=APNI(1)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca recurva''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/613703|publisher=APNI|accessdate=16 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Novon>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=New Combinations in Melaleuca for Australian Species of Callistemon (Myrtaceae)|journal=Novon|date=2006|volume=16|issue=4|page=473|url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.3417/1055-3177%282006%2916%5B468%3ANCIMFA%5D2.0.CO%3B2|accessdate=16 July 2015|doi=10.3417/1055-3177(2006)16[468:NCIMFA]2.0.CO;2}}</ref> ''Callistemon recurvus'' was first formally described in 1990 by [[Roger David Spencer]] and [[Peter Lumley]] in [[Muelleria (journal)|Muelleria]] from a specimen collected on Mount Stewart, east of [[Herberton, Queensland|Herberton]].<ref name=APNI(2)>{{cite web|title=''Callistemon recurvus''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/551454|publisher=APNI|accessdate=2 September 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''recurva'') is a [[Latin]] word  meaning "recurved", referring to the leaves often being slightly bent backwards.<ref name="Brophy" />

''Callistemon recurvus'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca recurva'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref name '"WCSP">{{WCSP | 31481 | ''Callistemon recurvus'' }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca recurva'' occurs in the higher districts in [[Queensland]] from the [[Atherton Tableland]] south to the [[Bowen, Queensland|Bowen]] district where it grows in dense [[scrubland]] and on rocky outcrops near rivers.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Use in horticulture==
''Melaleuca recurva'' is often cultivated due to the presence of flowers through most of the year.<ref name="trin" />

==References==

[[Category:Flora of Australia]]
[[Category:Flora of Queensland]]
[[Category:Plants described in 1990]]
229.title: Melaleuca recurva

230.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = ''Swamp paperbark''
|image = Melaleuca rhaphiophylla (leaves, flowers).JPG
|image caption = ''M. rhaphiophylla'' leaves and flowers
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. rhaphiophylla'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca rhaphiophylla''
|binomial_authority = [[Johannes Conrad Schauer|Schauer]]
|}}

'''''Melaleuca rhaphiophylla''''', commonly known as '''swamp paperbark''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest Australia|south west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It has narrow, needle-like leaves and profuse spikes of white or yellowish flowers at variable times throughout the year. As its common name suggests, it is usually found in salt marshes, or swamps or along watercourses and occurs over wide areas of the south-west.

==Description==
''Melaleuca rhaphiophylla'' is a  large shrub or small tree, growing to {{convert|10|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall, often multi-stemmed, with a bushy crown and greyish papery bark. Its leaves are soft, arranged alternately, {{convert|8-40|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|0.5-1.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, linear in shape, circular or oval in cross-section and taper to a hooked point.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=306}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=244–245|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are a shade of white to cream, arranged in heads or spikes on the ends of most of the branches which continue to grow after flowering and sometimes also in the upper leaf axils. The heads are up to {{convert|27|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter, {{convert|40|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and contain 4 to 25 groups of flowers in threes. The [[petal]]s are {{convert|2.5-3.5|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower matures. There are five bundles of [[stamen]]s around the flower, each with 11 to 25 stamens. Flowering occurs spasmodically, mainly from May to January and is followed by fruit which are woody, cup-shaped [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|3-6|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|5-6|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} in diameter in clusters along the stem.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/><ref name=water>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca rhaphiophylla''|url=http://www.water.wa.gov.au/PublicationStore/first/84840.pdf|publisher=Government of Western Australia Department of Water|accessdate=7 June 2015}}</ref>
[[File:Melaleuca rhaphiophylla (habit).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. rhaphiophylla'' growing near [[Geraldton]]]]
[[File:Melaleuca rhaphiophylla Swamp paperbark 3 Tone-Perup NR IV-2015.JPG|thumb|225px|''M. rhaphiophylla'' fruits in the Tone-Perup Nature Reserve]]
[[File:Melaleuca rhaphiophylla (bark).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. rhaphiophylla'' bark]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca rhaphiophylla'' was first formally described in 1844 by [[Johannes Conrad Schauer|Johannes Schauer]] in ''[[Plantae Preissianae]]'' from specimens collected "in the sandy plain of the [[Swan River (Western Australia)|Swan River]]" and "in humus on the banks of the [[Avon River (Western Australia)|Avon River]] near the village of [[York, Western Australia|York]]".<ref name=Schauer>{{cite book|last1=Schauer|first1=Johannes Conrad|title=Plantae Preissianae (Volume 1)|date=1844|location=Hamburg|page=143|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/498179#page/148/mode/1up|accessdate=7 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca rhaphiophylla''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/543168|publisher=APNI|accessdate=7 June 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''rhaphiophylla'') is derived from [[Ancient Greek]] words ''rhaphís'' meaning  “a needle”<ref name=Quattrocchi>{{cite book|last1=Quattrocchi|first1=Umberto|title=CRC World Dictionary of Plant Names: Common Names, Scientific Names, Eponyms, Synonyms, and Etymology (Volume IV)|date=2000|publisher=CRC Press|location=Boca Raton, FL|isbn=0-8493-2678-8|page=2292|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=zIOvJSJs-IkC&pg=PA2292&lpg=PA2292&dq=rhaphio+greek&source=bl&ots=RYj--V0une&sig=-JBT6qlRiQv8UqrDpd72RCZHtcg&hl=en&sa=X&ei=dch0VYH9MoSzmwXD7oPACQ&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=rhaphio%20greek&f=false|accessdate=7 June 2015}}</ref> and ''phyllon'' meaning "a leaf"<ref name=Quattrocchi(2)>{{cite book|last1=Quattrocchi|first1=Umberto|title=CRC World Dictionary of Plant Names: Common Names, Scientific Names, Eponyms, Synonyms, and Etymology (Volume IV)|date=2000|publisher=CRC Press|location=Boca Raton, FL|isbn=0-8493-2678-8|page=2652|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=zIOvJSJs-IkC&pg=PA2292&lpg=PA2292&dq=rhaphio+greek&source=bl&ots=RYj--V0une&sig=-JBT6qlRiQv8UqrDpd72RCZHtcg&hl=en&sa=X&ei=dch0VYH9MoSzmwXD7oPACQ&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=phyllon&f=false|accessdate=7 June 2015}}</ref> referring to the needle like foliage of this species.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in and between the [[Kalbarri, Western Australia|Kalbarri]] and [[Albany, Western Australia|Albany]] districts.<ref name=Brophy /><ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca rhaphiophylla''|id = 5959}}</ref> It grows in sandy or clay soils, sometimes with limestone, near watercourses, in swamps and saltmarshes.<ref name="FloraBase" /><ref name=flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=397}}</ref>

==Ecology==
''Melaleuca rhaphiophylla'' provides food for a range of native animals and because of its dense crown, habitat for fauna.<ref name="water" /> Waterbirds use this species as it often grows in areas that are flooded during the breeding season, deterring many predators.<ref name=arboretum>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca rhaphiophylla''|url=http://bpginc.info/Broadwayarbo/Plants/Species_Information_Pages/Melaleuca_rhaphiophylla.html|publisher=Broadway Arboretum, Bassendean|accessdate=7 June 2015}}</ref> Its shallow roots reduce erosion along watercourses, stabilise soils and trap sediment.<ref name="water" /> In some areas, this species is suffering from competition with the introduced ''[[Typha orientalis]]'' which regrows more vigorously after fire.<ref name="arboretum" />

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca rhaphiophylla'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

==Use in horticulture==
This species of melaleuca is a useful shrub for damp locations. It can be used as a screening plant if pruned regularly.<ref name=Wrigley>{{cite book|last1=Wrigley|first1=John W.|last2=Fagg|first2=Murray|title=Australian native plants : a manual for their propagation, cultivation and use in landscaping|date=1983|publisher=Collins|location=Sydney|isbn=0002165759|page=268|edition=2nd}}</ref> Seeds are easily collected from unopened capsules on the plant and grown as tubestock or seeded directly into the soil.<ref name="water" />

==References==
{{reflist|30em}}

[[Category:Melaleuca|rhaphiophylla]]
[[Category:Myrtales of Australia]]
[[Category:Plants described in 1844]]
[[Category:Rosids of Western Australia]]
[[Category:Endemic flora of Western Australia]]
230.title: Melaleuca rhaphiophylla

231.text:
{{italic title}} {{taxobox |name = Scarlet bottlebrush |image = Melaleuca rugulosa.jpg |image_caption = |status = |status_system = |regnum = [[Plantae]] |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s |unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s |unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s |ordo = [[Myrtales]] |familia = [[Myrtaceae]] |genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]'' |species = '''''M. rugulosa''''' |binomial = ''Melaleuca rugulosa'' |binomial_authority = ([[Diederich Franz Leonhard von Schlechtendal|Schltdl.]] ex [[Johann Heinrich Friedrich Link|Link]]) [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]] |synonyms = ''Metrosideros rugulosa'' [[Diederich Franz Leonhard von Schlechtendal|Schltdl.]] ex [[Johann Heinrich Friedrich Link|Link]]
''Callistemon rugulosus'' ([[Diederich Franz Leonhard von Schlechtendal|Schltdl.]] ex [[Johann Heinrich Friedrich Link|Link]]) [[Augustin Pyramus de Candolle|DC.]]
''Callistemon macropunctatus'' ([[Georges Louis Marie Dumont de Courset|Dum.-Cours.]]) A.B.Court
''Callistemon macropunctatus'' var. ''laevifolius ([[Ferdinand von Mueller|F.Muell.]] ex [[Friedrich Anton Wilhelm Miquel|Miq.]])) [[Hansjörg Eichler|H.Eichler]] }} '''''Melaleuca rugulosa''''', commonly known as '''scarlet bottlebrush''', is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to [[South Australia]] and [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] in [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state [[Herbarium|herbaria]] continue to use the name ''Callistemon rugulosus''.{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=16 July 2015}} ''Callistemon coccineus'' and ''Callistemon macropunctatus'' are older names for ''Callistemon rugulosus''.{{cite web|title=Callistemon 'Harkness'|url=https://www.anbg.gov.au/acra/descriptions/acc028.html|publisher=Australian Cultivar Registration Authority|accessdate=20 July 2015}}{{cite web|title=Plant Name Changes|url=http://anpsa.org.au/changes.html|publisher=Australian Native Plants Society Australia|accessdate=20 July 2015}}) It is a shrub with an open straggly habit, stiff, sharply pointed leaves and bright red bottlebrush flowers tipped with yellow in summer. ==Description== ''Melaleuca rugulosa'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|5|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} high with an open, straggling habit and peeling grey bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|21-86|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|2.5-8.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, flat, thick, rigid, narrow elliptic to egg-shaped with the narrower end near the base and have a sharp point. There is a mid-vein, marginal veins and 7-13 indistinct lateral veins. The young leaves and branches are often covered with dense, silky hairs.{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=309}}{{cite web|title=Callistemon rugulosus|url=http://www.flora.sa.gov.au/cgi-bin/texhtml.cgi?form=speciesfacts&family=Myrtaceae&genus=Callistemon&species=rugulosus|publisher=Electronic Flora of South Australia|accessdate=16 July 2015}} The flowers are a shade of red to purple, tipped with yellow and are arranged in spikes around the branches which continue to grow after flowering. The spikes are {{convert|40-65|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and {{convert|50-80|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long with 18 to 60 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|4.4-6.8|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages and there are 34-63 stamens in each flower. Flowering occurs from November to December, sometimes in other months and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|4.5-6.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.[[File:Callistemon macropunctatus.jpg|thumb|225px|''M. rugulosa'' (cultivated) in [[Palmetum of Santa Cruz de Tenerife]]]] ==Taxonomy and naming== ''Melaleuca rugulosa'' was first named in 2006 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in [[Novon]] when ''Callistemon rugulosus'' was transferred to the present [[genus]].{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca rugulosa''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/613704|publisher=APNI|accessdate=16 July 2015}}{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=New Combinations in Melaleuca for Australian Species of Callistemon (Myrtaceae)|journal=Novon|date=2006|volume=16|issue=4|page=473|url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.3417/1055-3177%282006%2916%5B468%3ANCIMFA%5D2.0.CO%3B2|accessdate=16 July 2015|doi=10.3417/1055-3177(2006)16[468:NCIMFA]2.0.CO;2}} It was first formally described in 1822 as ''Metrosideros rugulosa'' by [[Johann Heinrich Friedrich Link]] in ''[[Enumeratio Plantarum Horti Regii Berolinensis Altera]]''.{{cite web|title=''Metrosideros rugulosa''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/473559|publisher=APNI|accessdate=16 July 2015}}{{cite book|last1=Link|first1=Heinrich Friedrich|title=Enumeratio Plantarum Horti Regii Berolinensis Altera (Volume 2)|date=1822|location=Berlin|page=27|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/1101#page/30/mode/1up|accessdate=3 September 2015}} The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''rugulosa'') is from the [[Latin]] word ''[[wikt:ruga#Etymology 3|ruga]]'' meaning “crease” or "wrinkle"{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.|page =340}} but the reason for this naming is unclear. ''Callistemon rugulosus'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca rugulosa'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].{{WCSP | 31485 | ''Callistemon rugulosus'' }} ==Distribution and habitat== This melaleuca occurs from the south east corner of South Australia including the [[Eyre Peninsula]] to western Victoria. It is found in mallee scrubs and low open woodland in the northern [[Grampians National Park|Grampians]], the [[Big Desert Wilderness Park|Big Desert]], the [[Little Desert National Park|Little Desert]], and the [[Mount Lofty Ranges]]. Within these areas it is found in sandy depressions and near watercourses in soils that are seasonally moist. It grows in [[shrubland]] and [[forest]] near swamps and watercourses.{{cite book|author=Costermans, L.|title=Native Trees and Shrubs of South-eastern Australia|publisher=Rigby|location=Australia | year=1981 | isbn=072701403X}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} [[Category:Melaleuca|rugulosa]] [[Category:Flora of Australia]] [[Category:Flora of South Australia]] [[Category:Flora of Victoria (Australia)]] [[Category:Plants described in 1822]]
231.title: Melaleuca rugulosa

232.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = ''Melaleuca ryeae''
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. ryeae'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca ryeae''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
|}}

'''''Melaleuca ryeae''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest Australia|south west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It is a small shrub, closely resembling ''[[Melaleuca amydra]]'' with its small leaves and profuse heads of pink to purple flowers but ''M.amydra'' has narrower leaves ({{convert|1.5-2|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}}) and does not have spherical clusters of fruits.

==Description==
''Melaleuca ryeae'' is a small shrub sometimes growing to {{convert|1.5-2.5|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with woolly hairs on the young growth. Its leaves are arranged alternately, mostly {{convert|3-4|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|0.5-1.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, flat and egg-shaped with the narrower end at the base.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=310}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=248–249|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are a shade of pink, arranged in heads on the ends of most of the branches which continue to grow after flowering and sometimes also in the upper leaf axils. The heads are up to {{convert|25|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and contain 8 to 15 groups of flowers in threes. The [[petal]]s are {{convert|2.5-3.3|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower matures. There are five bundles of [[stamen]]s around the flower, each with 5 to 9 stamens. Flowering occurs in spring and is followed by fruit which are woody, cup-shaped [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|2.5-4|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and usually in almost spherical clusters along the stem.<ref name="Brophy"/><ref name="Holliday"/>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca ryeae'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected {{convert|15|km|mi|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} north of [[Badgingarra, Western Australia|Badgingarra]].<ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=899|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref><ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca ryeae''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561875|publisher=APNI|accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''ryeae'') honours Barbara Rye, a botanist and student of the family Myrtaceae.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in and between the [[Arrino, Western Australia|Arrino]], [[Eneabba, Western Australia|Eneabba]] and [[Bullsbrook, Western Australia|Bullsbrook]] districts<ref name="Brophy" /> in the [[Avon Wheatbelt]], [[Geraldton Sandplains]] and [[Swan Coastal Plain]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]]. It grows in swamps, in seasonally wet areas and on sandplains.<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca ryeae''|id = 19365}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca ryeae'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

==Use in horticulture==
This species of melaleuca has been cultivated in temperate areas with winter rainfall, forming compact shrubs which are especially attractive in flower.<ref name="Holliday"/>

232.title: Melaleuca ryeae

233.text:
{{italictitle}}
{{taxobox
|status =
|status_system = 
|image = Melaleuca sabrina (leaves, flowers).JPG
|image caption = ''M. sabrina'' leaves and flowers
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. sabrina'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca sabrina''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
|synonyms = ''Callistemon sabrina'' {{small|([[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]) Udovicic & [[R.D.Spencer]]}}{{br}}
}}

'''''Melaleuca sabrina''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to a small area near the border between [[New South Wales]] and [[Queensland]] in [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state herbaria use the name ''Callistemon sabrina''.<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=16 July 2015}}</ref>) It is a shrub with fibrous bark and red or pink bottlebrush flowers, tipped with yellow in spring and summer. It is similar to ''[[Melaleuca paludicola]]'' but distinguished from it by its stamens which are almost twice as long as those of ''M. paludicola''.

==Description==
''Melaleuca sabrina'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|4|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with fibrous bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|10-59|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|1-3.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, more or less flat and linear to very narrow egg-shaped with the narrow end towards the base. The leaves have a mid-vein and 11-20 indistinct lateral veins.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=311}}</ref>

The flowers are a shade of red or pink, tipped with yellow and are arranged in spikes {{convert|30-50|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} in diameter with 5 to 25 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|3.2-5.4|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages and there are 49 to 73 stamens in each flower.  Flowering occurs from October to March and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|3.5-5.8|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name="Brophy" />
[[File:Melaleuca sabrina (habit).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. sabrina'' growing on the banks of the [[Severn River (Queensland)|Severn River]]]]
[[File:Melaleuca sabrina (fruits).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. sabrina'' fruit]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca sabrina'' was first formally described in 2009 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Novon]]''.<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca sabrina''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/653273|publisher=APNI|accessdate=16 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=''Melaleuca'' (Myrtaceae) from Australia|journal=Novon|date=2009|volume=19|pages=449–450|doi=10.3417/2007008|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/40330691#page/457/mode/1up|accessdate=16 July 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''sabrina'') is the name of a [[Hafren|river nymph]] in [[Celtic mythology]] who was supposed to live in the [[River Severn]] in the [[United Kingdom]] - the [[type (biology)|type specimen]] for ''Melaleuca sabrina'' was found near the [[Severn River (Queensland)|Severn River]] in Queensland.<ref name="Brophy" />

''Callistemon sabrina'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca sabrina'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref name '"WCSP">{{WCSP | 471979 | ''Callistemon sabrina'' }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca sabrina'' occurs in and between the [[Stanthorpe, Queensland|Stanthorpe]] district in Queensland and [[Tenterfield, New South Wales|Tenterfield]] in New South Wales where it grows along the banks of watercourses and between granite boulders.<ref name="Brophy" />

234.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = ''Melaleuca sapientes''
|image = Melaleuca sapientes.jpg
|image caption = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. sapientes'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca sapientes''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
|}}

'''''Melaleuca sapientes''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]], [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It is a small shrub with silky grey leaves and small heads of pinkish flowers in spring or early summer. The attractive, silvery foliage has made this melaleuca a popular garden plant under the incorrect name of ''[[Melaleuca holosericea]]'', a similar but much rarer species.

==Description==
''Melaleuca sapientes'' is a dense, spreading shrub growing to {{convert|1-3|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with whitish-grey, papery bark and silvery foliage. Its leaves are arranged alternately, mostly {{convert|6-19.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|0.8-2.1|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, linear to very narrow egg-shaped, usually half moon-shaped in cross section and covered with soft, silky hairs.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=314}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=250–251|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are a shade of pink or purple, arranged in heads on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and sometimes also in the upper leaf axils. The heads are up to {{convert|20|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and contain two to six groups of flowers in threes. The outer surface of the flower cup (the [[hypanthium]]) is  silky-hairy. The [[petal]]s are {{convert|1.2-2|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower matures. Five bundles of [[stamen]]s are seen around the flower, each with seven to nine stamens. Flowering occurs between August and January and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|3-4.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and usually in small clusters along the stem.<ref name="Brophy"/><ref name="Holliday"/>[[File:Melaleuca sapientes (habit).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. sapientes'' growing in the Holt Nature Reserve near [[Salmon Gums, Western Australia|Salmon Gums]]]]


==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca sapientes'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected {{convert|12|km|mi|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} north of [[Salmon Gums, Western Australia|Salmon Gums]].<ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=899|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref><ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca sapientes''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561877|publisher=APNI|accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''sapientes'') honours Rob and Ann Smart, farmers near [[Jerramungup, Western Australia|Jerramungup]], for their assistance with research into the ''Melaleuca ''genus.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in and between the [[Jerramungup, Western Australia|Jerramungup]], [[Hyden, Western Australia|Hyden]], [[Salmon Gums, Western Australia|Salmon Gums]], and [[Ponier Rock]] districts<ref name="Brophy" /> in the [[Coolgardie (biogeographic region)|Coolgardie]], [[Esperance Plains]] and [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca sapientes''|id = 18276}}</ref> It grows in gravel, sandy clay, or loam on slopes.<ref name=flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=397}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca sapientes'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

==Use in horticulture==
This species of melaleuca has been cultivated as ''[[Melaleuca holosericea]]'', mainly because of its attractive, silvery foliage. It grows well in a range of soils.<ref name="Holliday"/>

File:Melaleuca sapientes (bark).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. sapientes'' bark
</gallery>
