235.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = ''Melaleuca scalena''
|image = Melaleuca scalena habit).JPG
|image caption = ''M. scalena'' growing near [[Babakin, Western Australia|Babakin]]
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. scalena'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca scalena''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]] & [[Brendan Lepschi|Lepschi]]
|}}

'''''Melaleuca scalena''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest Australia|south west]] of [[Western Australia]]. Plants of this species were previously included in ''[[Melaleuca uncinata]]'' or '''broombush''' until a review of that species in 2004. Its leaves are narrow cylinders, the flowers in small yellow heads and the fruits tightly packed together in oval clusters. This species is very similar to ''[[Melaleuca hamata]]'' but the plants have a comparatively scruffy or less strong and healthy appearance.

==Description==
''Melaleuca scalena'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|3|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with peeling, papery bark. Its leaves are {{convert|19-85|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|0.8-1.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, roughly circular in cross section, with the end tapering to a point and often with a short [[bristle]].<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|pages=316–317}}</ref>

The flowers are pale yellow and arranged in heads containing 5 to 14 groups of flowers in threes. There are 5 [[sepal]]s which are almost free from each other and five petals, each broadly egg-shaped, {{convert|0.9-1.3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and which fall off as the flower opens. There are five bundles of [[stamen]]s around the flower, each with 3 to 9 stamens. Flowering occurs between October and December and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]] packed closely together so that they appear as a single structure, {{convert|6-8|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and slightly less in diameter.<ref name="Brophy"/>
[[File:Melaleuca scalena (leaves, flowers, fruits).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. scalena'' leaves and flowers]]
[[File:Melaleuca scalena (bark).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. scalena'' bark]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca scalena'' was first formally described in 2004 by [[Lyndley Craven]] and Brendan Lepschi in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected {{convert|27|km|mi|sigfig=1}} north-west of [[Babakin, Western Australia|Babakin]].<ref name=CSIRO>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=Brendan J.|last3=Broadhurst|first3=Linda|last4=Byrne|first4=Margaret|title=Taxonomic revision of the broombush complex in Western Australia (Myrtaceae, Melaleuca uncinata s.l.)|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=2004|volume=17|issue=3|pages=266–267|doi=10.1071/SB04001|url=http://www.publish.csiro.au/paper/SB04001.htm|accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca scalena''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/589521|publisher=APNI|accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''scalena'') is from the [[Latin]] word meaning "unequal" referring to the impoverished appearance of this species compared to ''Melaleuca hamata''.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in and between the [[Wyalkatchem, Western Australia|Wyalkatchem]], [[Mount Walker, Western Australia|Mount Walker]], [[Woodanilling, Western Australia|Woodanilling]] and [[Dumbleyung, Western Australia|Dumbleyung]] districts<ref name="Brophy" /> in the [[Avon Wheatbelt]], [[Coolgardie (biogeographic region)|Coolgardie]], [[Esperance Plains]], [[Jarrah Forest]], [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]] and [[Yalgoo (biogeographic region)|Yalgoo]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]]. It grows in gravel, sand or loam on flats and drainage lines near salt lakes.<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca scalena''|id = 20290}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca scalena'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

==References==
{{reflist|30em}}

[[Category:Myrtales of Australia]]
[[Category:Plants described in 2004]]
[[Category:Rosids of Western Australia]]

235.title: Melaleuca scalena

236.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|status =

|image = Melaleuca serpentina (leaves, flowers).JPG
|image caption = ''M. serpentina'' leaves and flowers
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. serpentina'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca serpentina''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
|synonyms = ''Callistemon serpentinus'' {{small|([[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]) Udovicic & R.D.Spencer}}{{br}}
}}

'''''Melaleuca serpentina''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Barraba, New South Wales|Barraba]] district in [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state herbaria continue to use the name ''Callistemon serpentinus''.<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=31 May 2015}}</ref>) It is a shrub with yellow or creamy-green bottlebrush flowers. It is similar to ''[[Melaleuca citrina]]'' but can be distinguished from that species by its flower colour (red in ''M. citrina'') and its shorter [[stamen]]s.

==Description==
''Melaleuca serpentina'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|4|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with hard, papery bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|21-53|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|2-5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, more or less flat, narrow elliptical to egg-shaped with the narrow end towards the base and an end tapering to a sharp point. The leaves have a mid-vein but the lateral veins are obscure and there are many distinct oil glands.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=323}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=''Melaleuca'' (Myrtaceae) from Australia|journal=Novon|date=2009|volume=19|issue=4|page=450|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/124658#page/456/mode/1up|accessdate=16 July 2015|doi=10.3417/2007137}}</ref>

The flowers are creamy green to yellow and are arranged in spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and also in the leaf axils. The spikes are {{convert|30-40|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with 15 to 35 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|2.2-4|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages and there are 37 to 51 stamens in each flower.  Flowering occurs in April, October and December and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|4.2-4.6|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name="Craven"/>
[[File:Melaleuca serpentina (habit).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. serpentina'' growing in a small creek at Upper [[Bingara]]]]
[[File:Melaleuca serpentina (leaves, flowers, fruits).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. serpentina'' leaves, flowers and fruit]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca serpentina'' was first formally described in 2009 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Novon]]'' from a specimen collected adjacent to the Woodsreef [[asbestos]] mine near [[Barraba, New South Wales|Barraba]].<ref name="Craven" /><ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca serpentina''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/653274|publisher=APNI|accessdate=16 July 2015}}</ref> In 2012, Udovicic and Spencer gave the species the name ''[[Callistemon serpentinus]]''<ref name="Udovicic" /> but in 2013, Craven transferred all species previously known as ''Callistemon'' to ''Melaleuca''. Some authorities continue to use ''Callistemon serpentinus''.<ref name="Udovicic" /> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''serpentina'') refers to this species often occurring on soils derived from [[serpentinite]].<ref name="Brophy" />

''Callistemon serpentinus'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca serpentina'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref name '"WCSP">{{WCSP | 471980 | ''Callistemon serpentinus'' }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca serpentina'' occurs in the Barraba district growing in grassy [[woodland]] on soils derived from serpentinite.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="Craven" />

==References==
{{reflist|30em}}

[[Category:Melaleuca|serpentina]]
[[Category:Flora of Australia]]
[[Category:Flora of New South Wales]]
[[Category:Plants described in 2009]]
236.title: Melaleuca serpentina

{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|image = Melaleuca shiressii.JPG 
|image_caption = ''M. shiressii'' in [[Australian Botanic Garden Mount Annan]]
|status =
|status_system = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]

|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. shiressii'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca shiressii''
|binomial_authority = ([[William Blakely|Blakely]]) [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]] 
|synonyms = ''Callistemon shiressii'' <small> [[William Blakely|Blakely]] </small>
|synonyms_ref = <ref name="APNI"/>
}}

'''''Melaleuca shiressii''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to a small area in [[New South Wales]] in [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state [[Herbarium|herbaria]] continue to use the name ''Callistemon shiressii''.)<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=16 July 2015}}</ref> It is rare shrub or small tree with pale, papery bark, sharp-pointed leaves and spikes of white to pale cream bottlebrush flowers in spring and summer.

==Description==
''Melaleuca shiressii'' is a shrub or small tree growing to {{convert|12|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} high with white or grey papery bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|19-66|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|3-10|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, more or less flat, narrow elliptic or narrow egg-shaped and end in a sharp point. There is a mid-vein, marginal veins and 12-23 distinct lateral veins and there are many distinct oil glands. The edges of the leaves are often curled under and the lower surface is paler than the upper one.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=325}}</ref><ref name=RBGS>{{cite web|last1=Spencer|first1=Roger|last2=Lumley|first2=Peter|title=Callistemon shiressii|url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Callistemon~shiressii|publisher=Royal Botanic Gardens Sydney: Plantnet|accessdate=17 July 2015}}</ref>

The flowers are cream or greenish-cream and are arranged in spikes at the end of, or around the branches which continue to grow after flowering. The spikes are {{convert|18-22|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and {{convert|30-50|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long with 5 to 25 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|1.7-3.3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages and there are 48-84 stamens in each flower. Flowering occurs from September to January and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|2.5-3.7|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="RBGS" />


==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca shiressii'' was first named in 2006 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in [[Novon]] when ''Callistemon shiressii'' was transferred to the present [[genus]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca shiressii''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/613706|publisher=APNI|accessdate=17 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Novon>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=New Combinations in Melaleuca for Australian Species of Callistemon (Myrtaceae)|journal=Novon|date=2006|volume=16|issue=4|page=473|url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.3417/1055-3177%282006%2916%5B468%3ANCIMFA%5D2.0.CO%3B2|accessdate=17 July 2015|doi=10.3417/1055-3177(2006)16[468:NCIMFA]2.0.CO;2}}</ref> ''Callistemon shiressii'' was first formally described in 1941 by [[William Blakely]].<ref name=APNI(2)>{{cite web|title=''Callistemon shiressii''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/523051|publisher=APNI|accessdate=3 September 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''shiressii'') honours David William Campbell Shiress who, with William Blakely, collected the [[type (biology)|type specimen]] "on shale ridges about 1 mile north-west of Narara railway station".<ref name="Brophy" /> David Shiress, who lived from about 1862 to 1944, was an accountant and apparently a friend of William Blakely.<ref name=ANBG>{{cite web|title=Shiress, David William Campbell (c. 1862 - 1944)|url=http://www.anbg.gov.au/biography/shiress-david-william-campbell.html|publisher=Australian National Botanic Garden|accessdate=9 September 2015}}</ref>

''Callistemon shiressii'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca shiressii'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref name '"WCSP">{{WCSP | 31504 | ''Callistemon shiressii'' }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca shiressii'' occurs in and between the [[Singleton, New South Wales|Singleton]] and [[Richmond, New South Wales|Richmond]] districts in New South Wales. It grows in moist forests and on ridges .<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="RBGS" />

==Gallery==
<gallery>
Image:Melaleuca shiressii habit.jpg|''M. shiressii'' habit in the [[Australian National Botanic Gardens]]
Image:Melaleuca shiressii bark.JPG|''M. shiressii'' bark
Image:Melaleuca shiressii fruit.JPG|''M. shiressii'' maturing [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s
</gallery>

238.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|status = P1
|status_system = DECF
|name = ''Melaleuca similis''
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. similis'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca similis''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
|}}

'''''Melaleuca similis''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest Australia|south west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It is a small shrub, similar to ''[[Melaleuca stramentosa]]'' with its narrow, almost cylindrical leaves and heads of pink to purple flowers but lacks the matted, silky hairs on the young leaves and outer edge of the flower cup.

==Description==
''Melaleuca similis'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|0.6|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with dense foliage. Its leaves are {{convert|4-9.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|1-1.4|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, linear to very narrow egg-shaped, roughly circular in cross section.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=327}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=268–269|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are a shade of pink to purple and arranged in heads on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and sometimes also in the upper leaf axils. Each head contains up to 4 groups of flowers in threes and is up to {{convert|12|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter. The outer surface of the flower cup (the [[hypanthium]]) is hairy although it lacks the woolly, matted hairs of ''M. stramentosa''. The petals are {{convert|1.2-1.7|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower matures. There are five bundles of [[stamen]]s around the flower, each with 4 or 5 stamens. Flowering occurs in October or November and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]] {{convert|2.5-3|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long in loose clusters along the stem.<ref name="Brophy"/><ref name="Holliday" />

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca similis'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected about {{convert|35|km|mi|sigfig=1}} west of [[Scaddan, Western Australia|Scaddan]].<ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=903|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref><ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca similis''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561887|publisher=APNI|accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''similis'') is a [[Latin]] word meaning "similar"<ref name=Wiktionary>{{cite web|title=similis|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/similis|publisher=Wiktionary|accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref> referring to the similarity of this species to others in the area, especially ''[[Melaleuca plumea]]'' and ''[[Melaleuca stramentosa]]''.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca similis'' occurs in the [[Ravensthorpe, Western Australia|Ravensthorpe]] district<ref name="Brophy" /> in the [[Esperance Plains]] and [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]]. It grows in sand along drainage lines.<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca similis''|id =19608}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca similis'' is listed as "[[Declared Rare and Priority Flora List|Priority One]]" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]],<ref name="FloraBase" /> meaning that it is poorly known occurring in only a few locations and is potentially at risk.<ref name=codes>{{cite web|title=Conservation codes for Western Australian Flora and Fauna|url=http://www.dpaw.wa.gov.au/images/documents/plants-animals/threatened-species/Listings/conservation_code_definitions.pdf|publisher=Government of Western Australia Department of Parks and Wildlife|accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref>

239.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|status =

|image caption = ''M. societatis'' leaves, flowers and fruit
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. societatis'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca societatis''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
|}}

'''''Melaleuca societatis''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest Australia|south west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It is a dwarf shrub with small, fleshy leaves and many heads of pink or purple flowers in spring, followed by "[[Ball (association football)|soccer-ball]]" fruit.

==Description==
''Melaleuca societatis'' is a small shrub growing to {{convert|0.7|m|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} high, rarely to {{convert|2|m|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}}. Its leaves are {{convert|3.5-8.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|0.8-1.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, linear to oblong in shape, roughly circular in cross section and with a blunt end.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=328}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=258–259|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are a shade of deep pink to purple and arranged in heads or short spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and sometimes also in the upper leaf axils. Each head contains 4 to 9 groups of flowers in threes and is up to {{convert|12|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter. The petals are {{convert|1.0-1.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower matures. There are five bundles of [[stamen]]s around the flower, each with 3 to 6 stamens. Flowering occurs between August and January and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|2.5-3|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long in small, tight, spherical clusters along the stem.<ref name="Brophy"/><ref name="Holliday" />
[[File:Melaleuca societatis (habit).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. societatis'' growing near [[Lake King, Western Australia|Lake King]]]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca societatis'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected {{convert|16|km|mi|sigfig=1}} south of [[Lake King, Western Australia|Lake King]].<ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=904|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref><ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca societatis''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561888|publisher=APNI|accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''societas'') is from the [[Latin]] word "societas" meaning "association",<ref name=Wiktionary>{{cite web|title=societas|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/societas|accessdate=9 June 2015}}</ref> referring to the appearance of the fruiting clusters which look like an [[Association football|Association]] (soccer) football.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in and between the [[Stirling Range]], [[Jerramungup, Western Australia|Jerramungup]], [[Salmon Gums, Western Australia|Salmon Gums]] and [[Israelite Bay, Western Australia|Israelite Bay]] districts<ref name="Brophy" /> in the [[Coolgardie (biogeographic region)|Coolgardie]], [[Esperance Plains]] and [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]]<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca societatis''|id =18165}}</ref> where it grows sand, clay or loam in [[Mallee (habit)|mallee]] [[shrubland]].<ref name=flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=397}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca societatis'' is listed as "Not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

[[Category:Myrtales of Australia]]
[[Category:Plants described in 1999]]
[[Category:Rosids of Western Australia]]

{{taxobox
|image = Melaleuca stereophloia (habit).JPG

|status = 
|status_system = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. stereophloia'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca stereophloia''
|binomial_authority = ([[K.J.Cowley]]) [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca stereophloia''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest Australia|south west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It is similar to the '''broombush''', ''[[Melaleuca uncinata]]'' with its needle-like leaves and heads of yellow to white flowers, but its back is hard and fibrous rather than papery .

==Description==
''Melaleuca stereophloia'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|4|m|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} high with hard, fibrous, grey bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately, {{convert|11-44|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|1-2.2|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, linear in shape, circular in cross section and tapering near the end with a hooked tip.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=340}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|page=300|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are yellow to white and arranged in heads or short spikes on the sides of the branches. Each head contains 4 to 13 groups of flowers in threes and is up to {{convert|15-17|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter. The petals are {{convert|0.9-2|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower matures. There are five bundles of [[stamen]]s around the flower, each with 3 to 7 stamens. Flowering occurs between August and October and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|1.8-2.2|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long in tight, almost spherical clusters.<ref name="Brophy"/><ref name="Holliday" />
[[File:Melaleuca stereophloia (leaves, flowers .JPG|thumb|225px|''M. stereophloia'' leaves and flowers]]
[[File:Melaleuca stereophloia (fruits).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. stereophloia'' fruit]]
[[File:Melaleuca stereophloia (bark).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. stereophloia'' bark]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca stereophloia'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected {{convert|24|km|mi|sigfig=1}} east  of [[Koorda, Western Australia|Koorda]].<ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=905|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref><ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca stereophloia''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561896|publisher=APNI|accessdate=10 June 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''stereophloia'') is from the [[Ancient Greek]] words ''στερεός (stereós)'' meaning "hard" or "solid"<ref name=Wiktionary(1)>{{cite web|title=stereo|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/stereo|accessdate=10 June 2015}}</ref> and ''λοιός (phloiós)'' meaning “bark”,<ref name=Wiktionary(2)>{{cite web|title=φλοιός|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/φλοιός#Ancient_Greek|accessdate=10 June 2015}}</ref> referring to the hard bark of this species, distinguishing it from ''[[Melaleuca uncinata]]''.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca stereophloia'' occurs in and between the [[Wooramel Station]], [[Meekatharra, Western Australia|Meekatharra]], [[Coorow, Western Australia|Coorow]] and [[Koorda, Western Australia|Koorda]] districts<ref name="Brophy" /> in the [[Avon Wheatbelt]], [[Carnarvon (biogeographic region)|Carnarvon]], [[Coolgardie (biogeographic region)|Coolgardie]], [[Geraldton Sandplains]], [[Murchison (biogeographic region)|Murchison]], [[Swan Coastal Plain]] and [[Yalgoo (biogeographic region)|Yalgoo]] biogeographic regions<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca stereophloia''|id =19449}}</ref> where it grows in sand, clay or loam over [[laterite]], [[granite]] or [[sandstone]] near watercourse, lakes, saltpans and saline areas.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="FloraBase" />

==Ecology==
Vegetation associations where ''M. stereophloia'' is the dominant species in closed [[shrubland]] near claypans are habitat for the [[Slender-billed thornbill]], ''Acanthiza iredalei''.<ref name=epa>{{cite web|title=Slender-billed Thornbill habitat assessment|url=http://www.epa.wa.gov.au/EIA/EPAReports/Documents/1388%20-%2020101119_OPR_Slender-billedThornbill%20V4_DC.pdf|publisher=Western Australian Government Environmental Protection Authority|accessdate=10 June 2015}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca stereophloia'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

==Uses==

===Essential oils===
''Melaleuca stereophloia'' leaves have a high [[Eucalyptol|cineole]] content and may therefore be useful in the production of these compounds for flavourings, medicines and insect repellant.<ref name=avongro>{{cite web|title=Integrated Brushwood plantings for NRM benefits to farming systems|url=http://avongro.com.au/Webpages/documents/BrushwoodandNRMfinal.pdf|publisher=Avongrow; Wheatbelt tree cropping|accessdate=10 June 2015}}</ref>

===Brushwood===
This species [[Coppicing|coppices]] well and may therefore be useful in [[Melaleuca uncinata|brushwood]] production.<ref name="avongro" />

==References==
{{reflist|30em}}

[[Category:Melaleuca|stereophloia]]
[[Category:Myrtales of Australia]]
[[Category:Plants described in 1999]]
[[Category:Rosids of Western Australia]]
[[Category:Endemic flora of Western Australia]]
240.title: Melaleuca stereophloia

241.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|image = 
|status = 
|status_system = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. stipitata'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca stipitata''
|binomial_authority = ([[K.J.Cowley]]) [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca stipitata''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to a small area in the [[Northern Territory]] of [[Australia]]. It is a rare species, only discovered in 1991 and is unusual in that it is the only known example of ''[[Melaleuca]]'' having stalked flowers. Its leaves have an essential oil with a pleasant, lemon scent possibly suitable for commercial production.

==Description==
''Melaleuca stipitata'' is a shrub or tree growing to about {{convert|4|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with grey, papery bark and [[Glabrousness|glabrous]] branches and twigs. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|18.5-75|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|0.8-4.8|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide and leaves that are flat and narrow but otherwise variable in shape.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=341}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|page=68|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are white or cream-coloured and are arranged in spikes on the ends of branches which sometimes continue to grow after flowering. The spikes are up to {{convert|15|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with 3 to 12 groups of flowers in threes and there are often leaves amongst the flower in the spike. The petals are {{convert|1.5-1.8|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower matures. The floral cup (the [[hypanthium]]) has a short stalk - an unusual feature for a melaleuca. Flowering occurs in December and is followed by fruit which are woody, cup-shaped [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|2.2-3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca stipitata'' was first formally described in 1997 by [[Lyndley Craven]] and Bryan Barlow in ''[[Novon]]'' from a specimen collected below the Bukbukluk Lookout along the [[Kakadu Highway]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca stipitata''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561897|publisher=APNI|accessdate=10 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=Novon>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyndley|last2=Barlow|first2=Bryan|title=New taxa and new combinations in ''Melaleuca'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Novon|date=1997|volume=7|issue=1|pages=118–119|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/639828#page/118/mode/1up|accessdate=10 June 2015|doi=10.2307/3392182}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''stipitata'') is a [[New Latin]] word meaning "possessing a stalk"<ref name=Wiktionary>{{cite web|title=stipitate|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/stipitate#English|publisher=Wiktionary|accessdate=10 June 2015}}</ref> referring to the unusual stalked [[hypanthium]] of the flowers.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in the Bukbukluk area in the [[Kakadu National Park]].<ref name="Brophy" /> It grows in woodland on [[shale|shaly]] slopes.<ref name="Novon" />

==Use as a source of essential oils==
The oil extracted from the leaves of ''Melaleuca stipitata'' is lemon scented. It consists mainly of [[Monoterpene|monoterpenoids]] which in turn contain about 43% the [[isomers]] of [[citral]] (neral and geranial), and 10% [[terpinen-4-ol]].<ref name=Williams>{{cite book|last1=Williams|first1=Cheryll|title=Medicinal plants in Australia|date=2010|publisher=Rosenberg|location=Dural, N.S.W.|isbn=9781877058943|page=315|edition=1st|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=TZBN667HIaEC&pg=PA256&lpg=PA256&dq=Melaleuca+stipitata&source=bl&ots=I-rzD09VCo&sig=mYa9fFZ47qK0NItL3yn83gqprqw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDMQ6AEwBWoVChMI0bfDmr2ExgIViHm8Ch1URAAV#v=onepage&q=Melaleuca%20stipitata&f=false|accessdate=10 June 2015}}</ref> It is possible that this plant may be suitable for commercial development because of the antimicrobial properties<ref>{{cite journal | author = Onawunmi, G.O. |year=1989 | title=Evaluation of the antimicrobial activity of citral |journal=Lett. Appl. Microbial. | volume=9 |pages=105–108 | doi = 10.1111/j.1472-765X.1989.tb00301.x | issue = 3}}</ref> of these compounds.<ref name="Brophy" />

241.title: Melaleuca stipitata

242.text:
{{taxobox
|image = 
|status = 
|status_system = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. stramentosa'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca stramentosa''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca stramentosa''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It is a small, bushy shrub similar to ''[[Melaleuca similis]]'' with its cylindrical leaves and heads of pink to purple flowers but differs in have matted, woolly hairs around the flowers and on the young leaves.

==Description==
''Melaleuca stramentosa'' is a densely-foliaged shrub sometimes growing to {{convert|1.5|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall. Its young growth is covered with matted, silky or woolly hairs. The leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|6-12|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|1.0-1.5|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} wide, linear to very narrow egg-shaped and semi-circular to almost circular in cross section.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=342}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=268–269|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are a shade of pink to purple and are arranged in heads on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and sometimes also in the upper leaf axils. The heads are up to {{convert|17|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with up to 4 groups of flowers in threes. The petals are {{convert|1.3-2|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower matures. The outer surface of the floral cup (the [[hypanthium]]) is hairy and there are five bundles of stamens around the flower, each with 4 to 6 stamens. Flowering occurs mainly in October and is followed by fruit which are woody, cylindrical [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|4.0|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide and long, in irregular, loose clusters along the stems.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca stramentosa'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected near [[Jerdacuttup, Western Australia|Jerdacuttup]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca stramentosa''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561899|publisher=APNI|accessdate=10 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=906|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''stramentosa'') is derived from the [[Latin]] word ''stramentum'' meaning "straw", "litter" or "thatch"<ref name=Wiktionary>{{cite web|title=stramentum|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/stramentum|publisher=Wiktionary|accessdate=10 June 2015}}</ref> referring to the silky or woolly hairs seen on the young growth of this species.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in the [[Ravensthorpe, Western Australia|Ravensthorpe]] district in the [[Esperance Plains]] [[IBRA|biogeographic region]]<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca stramentosa''|id =18262}}</ref> where it grows in sand or gravel in [[heath]] on plains.<ref name=flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=397}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca stramentosa'' is classified as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name=FloraBase/>

|binomial = ''Melaleuca subulata''

|synonyms = 
''Callistemon subulatus'' <small> [[Edwin Cheel|Cheel]] </small>
}}

'''''Melaleuca subulata''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to south eastern [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state [[Herbarium|herbaria]] continue to use the name ''[[Callistemon subulatus]]'').<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=17 July 2015}}</ref> It is a small, spreading shrub with hard bark, dense foliage, cylindrical leaves and spikes of dark crimson flowers in summer.

==Description==
''Melaleuca subulata'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|1-2|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} high with hard, fibrous bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|18-50|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|1-3.1|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, cylindrical or shaped like a [[bradawl]].<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=351}}</ref><ref name=RBGS>{{cite web|last1=Spencer|first1=Roger|last2=Lumley|first2=Peter|title=Callistemon subulatus |url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Callistemon~subulatus|publisher=Royal Botanic Gardens Sydney: Plantnet|accessdate=17 July 2015}}</ref>

The flowers are a deep crimson colour and are arranged in spikes at the end of, or around the branches which continue to grow after flowering. The spikes are {{convert|30-60|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and {{convert|40-80|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long with 20 to 80 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|2.5-5.2|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages and there are 16-27 stamens in each flower. Flowering occurs from November to May and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|3-5.1|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|4-5|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} in diameter.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="RBGS" />[[File:Melaleuca subulata habit.jpg|thumb|225px|''M. subulata'' in the [[Australian National Botanic Gardens]]]][[File:Melaleuca subulata foliage.jpg|thumb|225px|''M. subulata'' foliage]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca subulata'' was first named in 2006 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in [[Novon]] when ''Callistemon subulatus'' was transferred to the present [[genus]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca subulata''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/613707|publisher=APNI|accessdate=17 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Novon>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=New Combinations in Melaleuca for Australian Species of Callistemon (Myrtaceae)|journal=Novon|date=2006|volume=16|issue=4|page=473|url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.3417/1055-3177%282006%2916%5B468%3ANCIMFA%5D2.0.CO%3B2|accessdate=17 July 2015|doi=10.3417/1055-3177(2006)16[468:NCIMFA]2.0.CO;2}}</ref> ''Callistemon subulatus'' was first formally described by botanist [[Edwin Cheel]] in 1925 in ''[[Linnean Society of New South Wales|Proceedings of the Linnean Society of New South Wales Series]]''.<ref name=APNI(2)>{{cite web|title=''Callistemon subulatus''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/523142|publisher=APNI|accessdate=21 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Cheel>{{cite journal|last1=Cheel|first1=Edwin|title=Two New Species of ''Callistemon'' with notes on certain other species|journal=Proceedings of the Linnean Society of New South Wales|date=1925|volume=1|page=259|url=http://biodiversitylibrary.org/item/108646#page/305/mode/1up|accessdate=21 July 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''subulata'') refers to the [[subulate]] shape of the leaves.<ref name="Brophy" />

''Callistemon subulatus'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca subulata'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref name '"WCSP">{{WCSP | 31511 | ''Callistemon subulatus'' }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in and between the [[Heathcote, New South Wales|Heathcote]] and [[Mittagong]] districts in [[New South Wales]] and [[East Gippsland]] in [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]]. It grows in creek beds and on the banks of streams in forests.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="RBGS" />

==Use in horticulture==
''Melaleuca subulata'' is commonly cultivated because of it abundant, attractive flowers. It is hardy but benefits from the application of low-phosphorus fertiliser.<ref name=Wrigley>{{cite book|last1=Wrigley|first1=John W.|last2=Fagg|first2=Murray|title=Australian native plants : a manual for their propagation, cultivation and use in landscaping|date=1983|publisher=Collins|location=Sydney|isbn=0002165759|page=194|edition=2nd}}</ref><ref name=ANPS>{{cite web|last1=Howes|first1=Jeff|title=Callistemon subulatus|url=http://www.austplants-nsw.org.au/40-membersarticles/plant-profiles/68-callistemon-subulatus.html|publisher=Australian Native Plants Society|accessdate=17 July 2015}}</ref>

{{taxobox

|status =

|species = '''''M. sylvana'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca sylvana''
|binomial_authority = ([[K.J.Cowley]]) [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca sylvana''''' is a plant in the myrtle family [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to a small area near [[Ravenshoe, Queensland|Ravenshoe]] in [[Queensland]], [[Australia]]. It is a newly described (2004) species similar to ''[[Melaleuca monantha]]'' with its tiny leaves and heads of white flowers but is a larger, single stemmed shrub or tree with a less dense crown.

== Description ==
''Melaleuca sylvana'' is a shrub or small tree growing to a height of {{convert|5|m|ft|abbr=on}} with an open crown. Its leaves are arranged in alternating pairs ([[Phyllotaxy|decussate]]), so that there are four rows of leaves along the stems. The leaves are {{convert|1.5-3.7|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|0.9-1.7|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, egg-shaped with the narrower end at the base and cresecent- or half-moon shaped in cross section.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=352}}</ref><ref name=Muelleria>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyndley A.|last2=Ford|first2=Andrew J.|title=A new species of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) from northern Queensland, Australia|journal=Muelleria|date=2004|volume=20|pages=3–8|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref>

The flowers are white and arranged in heads or short spikes between the leaves on the fresh growth. The head are up to {{convert|18|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter, and contain up to 10 individual flowers. The [[stamen]]s are arranged in five bundles around the flower with 9 to 12 stamens per bundle. Flowers appear in December and are followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|4|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|4-5|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} wide in nearly spherical clusters about {{convert|9|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter.

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca sylvana'' was first formally described in 2004 by [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]] and Andrew Ford in ''[[Muelleria (journal)|Muelleria]]''<ref name="Muelleria" /><ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca sylvana''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/590871|publisher=APNI|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> from a specimen collected on a powerline access road near [[Herberton, Queensland|Herberton]].  The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''sylvana'') is from the [[Latin]] word ''sylva'' (or ''silva'') meaning "wood" or "forest"<ref name=Wiktionary)>{{cite web|title=silva|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/silva#Latin|publisher=Wiktionary|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> referring to the most frequent habitat of this species.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in the [[Ravenshoe, Queensland|Ravenshoe]] and Herberton districts where it grows in [[heath]], [[forest]] and [[woodland]] often on soils derived from [[rhyolite]].<ref name="Muelleria" />

==Ecology==

===Response to fire===
After fire, ''Melaleuca sylvana'' resprouts at the stem base and along stems from [[Epicormic shoot|epicormic buds]].<ref name="Muelleria" />

|species = '''''M. thapsina'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca thapsina''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca thapsina''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It is a prickly shrub with fibrous or papery bark, yellow to cream coloured flowers and tightly packed cylinders of fruiting capsules.

==Description==
''Melaleuca thapsina'' is a shrub sometimes growing to {{convert|4|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with papery or fibrous bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|11-56|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|1.0-1.6|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, linear in shape and almost circular in cross section with the tip tapering to a sharp point.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=357}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=284–285|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are cream coloured to bright yellow and are arranged in heads on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and sometimes also in the upper leaf axils. The heads are up to {{convert|18|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with 2 to 13 groups of flowers in threes. The petals are {{convert|1.0-2.2|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower matures. The outer surface of the floral cup (the [[hypanthium]]) is hairy and there are five bundles of stamens around the flower, each with 6 to 8 stamens. Flowering occurs mainly in spring and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|2.0-2.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, packed tightly together in spherical or oblong clusters.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca thapsina'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected {{convert|110|km|mi|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} north-east of [[Lake King, Western Australia|Lake King]] on the track to [[Norseman, Western Australia|Norseman]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca thapsina''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561912|publisher=APNI|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=908|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''thapsina'') is derived from the [[Ancient Greek]] word ''thapsinos'' meaning "yellow"<ref name=Dress>{{cite book|last1=Cleland|first1=Liza|last2=Davies|first2=Glenys|last3=Llewellyn-Jones|first3=Lloyd|title=Greek and Roman dress from A to Z|date=2007|publisher=Routledge|location=London|isbn=0415226619|page=215|edition=Digital print.|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=nTaCAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA59&dq=thapsinos&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=thapsinos&f=false|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> referring to the colour of the flowers.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in and between the Lake King, Norseman, [[Ravensthorpe, Western Australia|Ravensthorpe]] and [[Esperance, Western Australia|Esperance]] districts<ref name="Brophy" /> in the [[Coolgardie (biogeographic region)|Coolgardie]], [[Esperance Plains]] and [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca thapsina''|id = 19399}}</ref> It grows in a range of vegetation associations in sand and clay.<ref name="Holliday" />

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca thapsina'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

[[Category:Flora of Western Australia]]

'''''Melaleuca tinkeri''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It is one of the smallest melaleucas and is distinguished by its warty, hairy leaves, heads of pinkish flowers in late winter to spring and its spherical fruiting clusters.

==Description==
''Melaleuca tinkeri'' is a shrub rarely growing to more than {{convert|1|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|8-34|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|0.6-1.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, linear to narrow egg-shaped with the narrower end at the base. The younger leaves are covered with soft, silky hairs and the oil glands are raised, giving the leaves a warty appearance.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=361}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=292–293|edition=2nd}}</ref>

The flowers are pinkish to purple and are arranged in heads on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and sometimes also in the upper leaf axils. The heads are up to {{convert|17|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter with 4 to 12 groups of flowers in threes. The petals are {{convert|1.0-1.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower matures. The outer surface of the floral cup (the [[hypanthium]]) is hairy and there are five bundles of stamens around the flower, each with 3 to 6 stamens. Flowering occurs from July to October and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|2.5-3.0|mm|in|sigfig=2}} long, packed tightly together in spherical or oblong clusters.<ref name=Brophy/><ref name=Holliday/>
[[File:Melaleuca tinkeri (habit).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. tinkeri'' growing near [[Dongara, Western Australia|Dongara]]]]
[[File:Melaleuca tinkeri (fruits).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. tinkeri'' fruit]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca tinkeri'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]'' from a specimen collected {{convert|7|km|mi|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} east of [[Eneabba, Western Australia|Eneabba]].<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca tinkeri''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561915|publisher=APNI|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|page=909|doi=10.1071/SB98019}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''tinkeri'') honours Allan Tinker for his knowledge of the flora of the Eneabba area.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in the [[Yandanooka, Western Australia|Nandanooka]] and [[Lesueur National Park]] areas<ref name="Brophy" /> in the [[Avon Wheatbelt]] and [[Geraldton Sandplains]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca tinkeri''|id = 18278}}</ref> It grows in shallow, gravelly sand over [[laterite]] or [[granite]].<ref name="Brophy" />

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca tinkeri'' is listed as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

==References==

247.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = ''Melaleuca triumphalis''
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_subclassis = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. triumphalis'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca triumphalis''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca triumphalis''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Victoria River (Northern Territory)|Victoria River]] district of the [[Northern Territory]] in [[Australia]]. It was discovered on a 1996 expedition commemorating the work of the early German-Australian botanist, [[Ferdinand von Mueller]]. It is a shrub with grey foliage and contrasting green heads of flowers in spring.

==Description==
''Melaleuca triumphalis'' grows to a height of {{convert|2.5|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} and has grey, rather papery bark and hairy young stems. Its leaves are arranged alternately, narrow elliptic in shape, {{convert|60-140|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|15-25|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, covered with fine hairs and have 3 to 5 longitudinal veins.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|page=367|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517}}</ref><ref name=ntepa>{{cite book|last1=Lewis|first1=Donna|last2=Cowie|first2=Ian|last3=Kerrigan|first3=Raelee|title=Flora of conservation significance|date=5 April 2006|publisher=Department of natural resourcesenvironment of the arts|page=7|url=http://www.ntepa.nt.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0008/20042/2.Floraofconservationsignificance.pdf|accessdate=27 April 2015}}</ref>

The flowers are arranged in heads or short spikes up to {{convert|65|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and contain 10 to 20 groups of flowers in threes. The flowers appear in September and are green, fading to yellow. The petals are {{convert|5.1-7|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower matures. The stamens are arranged in bundles of five around the flower, with 7 to 12 stamens in each bundle. The base of the flower is hairy and {{convert|2.8-4.6|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long. The woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]] are {{convert|3.7-5.6|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca triumphalis'' was first described in 1998 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Muelleria (journal)|Muelleria]]''<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca triumphalis''|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/645645|publisher=APNI|accessdate=28 April 2015}}</ref> from a specimen collected in the [[Judbarra / Gregory National Park]] on the 1996 expedition to commemorate the centenary of the death of Ferdinand von Mueller.<ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyndley|title=A result of the 1996 Mueller Commemorative Expedition to northwestern Australia: Melaleuca triumphalis, sp. nov. (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=1998|volume=11|pages=1–4}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''triumphalis'') is a reference to the triumphal results of Mueller on the [[Augustus Charles Gregory|Gregory]] expedition and to the collection of a specimen of this species on the centenary expedition.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca triumphalis'' occurs in the [[Victoria River (Northern Territory)|Victoria River]] district in springs at the base of waterfalls and at the top of [[scree]] slopes.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="ntepa" />

==Conservation==
A search for individuals of this species in the Judbarra / Gregory National Park found 37 populations however it is possible that ''M. triumphalis'' also occurs in other places with similar ecological niches such as the [[Keep River National Park]]. It has been recommended that the species be classified as "vulnerable".<ref name=CSIRO>{{cite journal|last1=Crase|first1=Beth|last2=Cowie|first2=Ian D.|last3=Michell|first3=Carrie R.|title=Distribution and conservation status of the rare plants ''Melaleuca triumphalis'' and ''Stenostegia congesta'' (Myrtaceae), Victoria River district, northern Australia|journal=Australian Journal of Botany|date=2006|volume=54|issue=7|pages=641|doi=10.1071/BT05159|url=http://www.publish.csiro.au/paper/BT05159.htm|accessdate=27 April 2015}}</ref>

248.text:
{{taxobox
|image = Melaleuca tuberculata (leaves, flowers, fruit).JPG
|image caption = ''M. tuberculata'' (leaves, flowers, fruit)
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. tuberculata'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca tuberculata''
|binomial_authority = [[Johannes Conrad Schauer|Schauer]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca tuberculata''''' is a small, variable shrub in the myrtle family [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. There are three distinct varieties of this species, each with a different leaf size and shape, different distributions and somewhat different habitat preferences.

==Description==
''Melaleuca tuberculata'' grows to a height of {{convert|0.2-2|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}}. Its leaves are arranged alternately, {{convert|2–19|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|0.8–3.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide and are linear to narrow oval in shape.

The flowers are arranged in heads up to {{convert|25|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter, at or near the ends of the branches, with one to seven groups of flowers, each with three individual flowers. There are hairy brown [[bract]]s at the base of the flowers and the flower buds are covered with white, woolly hairs. The flowers appear from August to December, varying slightly with each variety, and are pale to mid-pink or mauve. The [[stamen]]s are arranged in bundles of five around the flower, with six to ten stamens in each bundle, the bright yellow [[anther]]s contrasting with the mauve filaments. The cup-shaped base of the flower (the [[hypanthium]]) is hairy and {{convert|1.5-3|mm|in|sigfig=1}} long. The woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]] are {{convert|3-4|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and wide.<ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=298–299|edition=2nd}}</ref><ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|pages=368–369|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517}}</ref>

The three varieties can be distinguished on the basis of the sizes of their leaves:<ref name="Brophy" />
*var. ''arenia'' - {{convert|2–4.2|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|1.1–2.3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide;
*var. ''macrophylla'' - {{convert|4.5–18.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|1.2–3.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide;
*var. ''tuberculata'' - {{convert|2.5–13.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|0.8–1.3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide.
[[File:Melaleuca tuberculata (habit).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. tuberculata'' growing 50 km west of  [[Esperance, Western Australia|Esperance]]]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca tuberculata'' was first formally described in 1844 by [[Johannes Conrad Schauer]] in ''[[Plantae Preissianae]]''.<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca tuberculata''|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/545409|publisher=APNI|accessdate=12 March 2015}}</ref><ref name=Lehmann>{{cite book|last1=Lehmann|first1=J.G.C.|title=Plantae Preissianae|date=1844|location=Hamburg|page=139|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/498179#page/144/mode/1up}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''tuberculata'') is derived from the [[Latin]] word ''tuberculatus'' meaning "warty"<ref name=Wiktionary>{{cite web|title=tuberculatus|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/tuberculatus#Latin|publisher=Wiktionary|accessdate=14 March 2015}}</ref> "in reference to the prominent oil glands on the leaves".<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca tuberculata'' occurs in the [[Avon Wheatbelt]], [[Esperance Plains]], [[Jarrah Forest]] and [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca tuberculata''|id = 15673}}</ref> It  grows in a variety of soils over [[ironstone]] or [[laterite]], on undulating plains and high areas.<ref name=Flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=398}}</ref>

The distribution of the varieties is as follows:<ref name="Brophy" />
*var. ''arenia'' - the [[Bendering, Western Australia|Bendering]]–[[Kulin, Western Australia|Kulin]]–[[Hyden, Western Australia|Hyden]]–[[Pingaring, Western Australia|Pingaring]] district;
*var. ''macrophylla'' - from the [[Kulin, Western Australia|Kulin]]–[[Jerramungup, Western Australia|Jerramungup]] district eastwards to the [[Grass Patch, Western Australia|Grass Patch]] – [[Israelite Bay, Western Australia|Israelite Bay]] district.
*var. ''tuberculata'' - [[Brookton, Western Australia|Brookton–Narrogin]] district eastwards to the [[Esperance, Western Australia|Esperance]] – Israelite Bay district.

==Conservation==
This species is classified as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase" />

249.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = ''Melaleuca undulata''
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. undulata'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca undulata''
|binomial_authority = [[George Bentham|Benth]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca undulata''''', commonly known as '''hidden honey-myrtle''' is a shrub in the myrtle family [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the south of [[Western Australia]]. It is a spreading, moderately dense, perennial, woody shrub with creamy-white flowers in small clusters.

==Description==
''Melaleuca undulata'' grows to a height of about {{convert|0.3-2|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} spreading to {{convert|2|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} or more. Its leaves are arranged alternately, mostly lance-shaped to oval, {{convert|3-15|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|1.5-4|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide and slightly hairy.

The flowers are arranged in heads up to {{convert|27|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter scattered along the branches, with 1 to 18 flowers in each head. The flowers mainly appear from October to March and are white to cream.  The stamens are arranged in bundles of five around the flower, with 8 to 30 stamens in each bundle. The base of the flower is [[glabrousness|glabrous]] and {{convert|1.2–2.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long. The woody capsules are {{convert|2.5–4|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|page=70|edition=2nd}}</ref><ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|page=373|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517}}</ref><ref name=JSTOR>{{cite web|title=Isotype of ''Melaleuca undulata'' Benth. subsp. crebra Barlow [family MYRTACEAE]|url=http://plants.jstor.org/stable/history/10.5555/al.ap.specimen.k000793374|publisher=JSTOR|accessdate=14 March 2015}}</ref>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca undulata'' was first formally described in 1867 by [[George Bentham]] in ''[[Flora Australiensis]]''.<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca undulata''|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/545581|publisher=APNI|accessdate=14 March 2015}}</ref><ref name=Mueller>{{cite book|last1=Mueller|first1=Ferdinand|title=Flora Australiensis, volume 3|date=1866|location=London|page=154|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/41807#page/143/mode/1up|accessdate=14 March 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''undulata'') is derived from the [[Latin]] ''undulatus'' meaning "wavy" <ref name=Wiktionary>{{cite web|title=undulatus|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/undulatus#Latin|publisher=Wiktionary|accessdate=14 March 2015}}</ref> "in reference to the leaf blade being wavy".<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs from the [[Stirling Range National Park|Stirling Range]] – [[Broomehill, Western Australia|Broomehill]] district eastwards to the [[Israelite Bay, Western Australia|Israelite Bay]] district. It grows in mallee and heath, in swampy and areas, river beds and edge of clay pans in sand, clay on [[laterite]] gravel.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca undulata'' is classified as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca undulata''|id = 5985}}</ref>

==Use in horticulture==
This is a hardy species suitable as a low, informal, prickly hedge. It will grow in most soils and aspects.<ref name=Wrigley>{{cite book|last1=Wrigley|first1=John|last2=Fagg|first2=Murray|title=Australian native plants : a manual for their propagation, cultivation and use in landscaping|date=1983|publisher=Collins|location=Sydney|isbn=0002165759|pages=270–271|edition=2nd}}</ref>

250.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = ''Melaleuca urceolaris''
|image = Melaleuca urceolaris (habit).JPG
|image caption = ''M. urceoloris'' growing in the [[Lesueur National Park]]
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. urceolaris'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca urceolaris''
|binomial_authority = [[Ferdinand Mueller|F.Muell.]] ex [[George Bentham|Benth]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca urceolaris''''' is a low, spreading shrub in the myrtle family [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. Although it is rare in cultivation, it is an attractive garden plant due to its soft foliage and white flowers which fade to pink or red. It is similar to ''[[Melaleuca scabra]]'' with which it has often been confused.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Description==
''Melaleuca urceolaris'' grows to a height of about {{convert|1.5|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} spreading to {{convert|1|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} or more with its low spreading branches. Its leaves are arranged alternately, mostly linear, {{convert|6.7–20|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|0.6–1|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} with a covering of small soft hairs giving the leaves a greyish-green colour.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="Holliday" />

The flowers are arranged in heads up to {{convert|25|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter, at or near the ends of the branches, with 2 to 12 flowers in each head. The flowers appear from August and November and are initially white to cream or lemon-yellow but age to  pinkish or red. The stamens are arranged in bundles of five around the flower, with 9 to 15 stamens in each bundle. The base of the flower is hairy and {{convert|1.5–2.5|mm|in|sigfig=1}} long. The fruit are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|2.8–4|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|page=374|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517}}</ref><ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=302–303|edition=2nd}}</ref>
[[File:Melaleuca urceolaris (leaves, flowers).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. urceolaris'' leaves and flowers]]
[[File:Melaleuca urceolaris (leaves, fruits).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. urceolaris'' fruit]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca urceolaris'' was first formally described in 1867 by [[George Bentham]] in ''[[Flora Australiensis]]''.<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca urceolaris''|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/545735|publisher=APNI|accessdate=14 March 2015}}</ref><ref name=Mueller>{{cite book|last1=Mueller|first1=Ferdinand|title=Flora Australiensis, volume 3|date=1866|location=London|page=154|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/41807#page/162/mode/1up|accessdate=14 March 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''urceolaris'') is derived from the [[Latin]] ''urceus'' meaning "jug" or "pitcher"<ref name=Wiktionary>{{cite web|title=urceus|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/urceus#Latin|publisher=Wiktionary|accessdate=14 March 2015}}</ref> referring to the shpae of the fruit.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca urceolaris'' occurs in the [[Arrino, Western Australia|Arrino]]-[[Jurien Bay, Western Australia|Jurien Bay]]-[[Gingin, Western Australia|Gingin]] districts in the [[Avon Wheatbelt]], [[Geraldton Sandplains]], [[Jarrah Forest]], [[Mallee (biogeographic region)|Mallee]] and [[Swan Coastal Plain]] [[IBRA|biogeographic regions]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca urceolaris''|id = 5986}}</ref> It grows in dense heath, low shrubland and woodland on sand, sand over laterite, sandy clay, and gravel.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Conservation==
''Calothamnus urceolaris'' is classified as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name=FloraBase/>

==Uses==
===Horticulture===
This species is described as "a handsome foliage shrub, spectacular in flower in good forms"<ref name="Holliday" /> growing well in poor sandy soil in winter-rainfall, temperate to semi-dry areas.<ref name=Wrigley>{{cite book|last1=Wrigley|first1=John|last2=Fagg|first2=Murray|title=Australian native plants : a manual for their propagation, cultivation and use in landscaping|date=1983|publisher=Collins|location=Sydney|isbn=0002165759|page=270|edition=2nd}}</ref>

===Essential oils===
This leaf oil of this species is mostly monoterpenoid yielding about 0.6% (weight/weight) from fresh leaves.<ref name="Brophy" />
