251.text:
{{taxobox
| image = Melaleuca uxorum 02.JPG
| image caption =''M. uxorum'' on Mount Emerald, Queensland
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. uxorum'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca uxorum''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]], [[G.Holmes]] & [[Sankowsky]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca uxorum''''' is a plant in the myrtle family [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the northern [[Herberton Range]] in [[Far North Queensland|far north Queensland]]. It is a newly described (2004) species similar to ''[[Melaleuca sylvana]]'' and ''[[Melaleuca monantha]]'', also from far north Queensland.

== Description ==
''Melaleuca uxorum'' is a shrub growing to a height of {{convert|1|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}}. Its leaves are arranged in alternating pairs ([[Phyllotaxis|decussate]]), {{convert|2–4.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|1.3–2.7|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, v-shaped in cross section and lacking a stalk.<ref name="Brophy" />

Head of flowers appear on the ends of the branches in November and December, each head composed of 4 to 12 groups of flowers, each group composed of three flowers. The heads are {{convert|18–25|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter. The [[stamen]]s are pure white, in five bundles around the flower with 6 to 12 stamens per bundle. The fruit are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]] {{convert|5–3.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=383}}</ref>

==Taxonomy and naming==
This species was first formally described in 2004 by [[Lyndley Craven]],  [[Glenn Holmes (botanist)|Glenn Holmes]] and [[Garry Sankowsky]] in ''[[Muelleria (journal)|Muelleria]]'' from a specimen collected {{convert|1.2|km|mi|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} north west of Mt Emerald.<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca uxorum''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/nsl/services/instance/apni/589344|publisher=APNI|accessdate=8 March 2017}}</ref><ref name="Muelleria">{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyndley A.  and G.Sankowsky|last2=Holmes|first2=Glenn|last3=Sankowsky|first3=Garry|title=''Melaleuca uxorum'' (Myrtaceae) , a new species from north-eastern Australia|journal=Muelleria|date=2003|volume=18|pages=3–5}}</ref>  The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''uxorum'') is from the [[Latin]] ''uxor'' meaning "wife", "spouse" or "consort"<ref name=Wiktionary>{{cite web|title=uxor|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/uxor|publisher=Wiktionary|accessdate=31 May 2015}}</ref> "in collective honour of Kirsty, Jenny and Nada, the wives, respectively, of each of the authors of this name, for their companionship in the field and enthusiasm for plants generally".<ref name="Brophy" />
[[File:Melaleuca uxorum 01.JPG|thumb|225px|''M.uxorum'' foliage and fruit]]
[[File:Melaleuca uxorum.JPG|thumb|225px|''M.uxorum'' habitat]]

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca uxorum'' occurs in the northern Herberton Range on pavements of acidic volcanic rock, in association with ''[[Eucalyptus lockyeri]]''.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Ecology==

===Response to fire===
After fire, ''Melaleuca uxorum'' resprouts at the stem base and along stems from [[Epicormic shoot|epicormic buds]]. The species forms small colonies which appear to have developed from both sexual and asexual reproduction.<ref name=CSIRO>{{cite journal|last1=Ford|first1=Andrew J|last2=Hardesty|first2=Britta Denise|title=Species adaptation to both fire and climate change in tropical montane heath: Can Melaleuca uxorum (Myrtaceae) survive?|journal=Pacific Conservation Biology|date=2012|volume=18|issue=4|pages=319–324|doi=10.1071/PC120319|url=http://www.publish.csiro.au/nid/302/paper/PC120319.htm|accessdate=14 March 2015}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca uxorum'' is classified as ''Endangered''<ref name=Conservation>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca uxorum''|url=http://wetlandinfo.ehp.qld.gov.au/wetlands/ecology/components/species/?melaleuca-uxorum|publisher=Queensland government: Department of Environment and Heritage Protection|accessdate=14 March 2015}}</ref> by the Queensland [[Nature Conservation Act 1992]].

==References==

252.text:
{{taxobox
|''Melaleuca venusta''
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. venusta'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca venusta''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca venusta''''' is a shrub in the myrtle family [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the west coast of [[Western Australia]]. It is a shrub with silvery leaves and heads of pink to purple flowers which fade to white and with a restricted distribution, north of the [[Murchison River (Western Australia)|Murchison River]] district.

==Description==
''Melaleuca venusta'' is a branching, open shrub which grows to a height of {{convert|1.5|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}}. Its leaves are arranged alternately, are oblong to ovate with a short point on the end and {{convert|18-45|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long by {{convert|6-11|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}}. Both surfaces of the leaves are densely covered with silky hairs giving the foliage a silvery grey colour.

The flowers are arranged in heads about {{convert|32|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter on the ends of the branches, each head composed of 6 to 13 groups of three flowers. The stamens are grouped in five bundles around the flower, each bundle consisting of 7 to 11 stamens. The stamens give the flowers a pinkish mauve to purple colour which fades rapidly to white. The flowers appear mainly in October and November and are followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]] {{convert|2.5-3.5|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} in spherical clusters.<ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|pages=304–305|edition=2nd}}</ref><ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|page=376|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517}}</ref>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca venusta'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]''.<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca venusta''|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561927|publisher=APNI|accessdate=12 March 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|pages=915|doi=10.1071/SB98019|url=http://www.publish.csiro.au/paper/SB98019.htm|accessdate=12 March 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''venusta'') is from the [[Latin]] ''venustus'' meaning "lovely" or "charming".<ref name=Wiktionary>{{cite web|title=venustus|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/venustus#Latin|accessdate=13 March 2015|ref=Wiktionary}}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Melaleuca venusta'' only occurs in the [[Kalbarri, Western Australia|Kalbarri]] district in the [[Geraldton Sandplains]] [[IBRA|biogeographic zone]] north of the Murchison River. It grows in sand over limestone.<ref name="Holliday" /><ref name="Brophy" />

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca venusta'' is classified as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca venusta''|id = 196310}}</ref>

==Use in horticulture==
The species is not known in cultivation but its mauve flowers contrasting with its attractive silvery foliage suggest it "merits trial as an ornamental shrub in dry Mediterranean climates".<ref name="Brophy" />

==References==

252.title: Melaleuca venusta

253.text:
{{taxobox
|image = 
|status = 
|status_system = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''<ref>Craven. "New combinations in Melaleuca for Australian species of Callistemon (Myrtaceae)." 2006, vol. 16, no4, pp. 468-475.</ref>
|species = '''''M. villosisepala'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca villosisepala''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca villosisepala''''' is a shrub in the myrtle family [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It is a shrub with narrow leaves, heads of pink to mauve flowers which fade to white and is similar to ''[[Melaleuca wonganensis]]'' except that its heads of flowers are smaller and pinkish rather than deep purple.

==Description==
''Melaleuca villosisepala'' grows to a height of {{convert|0.2-1.3|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}}. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|3-15|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|0.5-1.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, linear to oblong, silky-hairy at first but becoming [[Glabrousness|glabrous]] as they age.<ref name="Holliday" /><ref name="Brophy" />

The flowers are arranged in heads about {{convert|20|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter, near the ends of the branches, with one to six groups of flowers, each with three individual flowers. The base of the flowers is hairy, {{convert|1.5-3|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and the stamens are arranged around each flower in five bundles, each containing 5 to 9 stamens. The flowers are pink or mauve and fade to white and from September to February. The fruit are {{convert|2.5-4.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|page=226|edition=2nd}}</ref><ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|page=377|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517}}</ref>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca villosisepala'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]''.<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca villosisepala''|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561928|publisher=APNI|accessdate=12 March 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|pages=915|doi=10.1071/SB98019|url=http://www.publish.csiro.au/paper/SB98019.htm|accessdate=12 March 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''villosisepala'') is derived from the [[Latin]] ''villoso'' meaning "hairy",<ref name=Wiktionary>{{cite web|title=villoso|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/villoso|publisher=Wiktionary|accessdate=13 March 2015}}</ref> referring to the hairy lobes of the [[Sepal|calyx]].

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs from the [[Southern Cross, Western Australia|Southern Cross]]-[[Coolgardie]] districts, south to the [[Stirling Range National Park|Stirling Range]]-[[Ravensthorpe, Western Australia|Ravensthorpe]] districts in the [[Esperance Plains]] [[IBRA|biogeographical zone]].<ref name="Holliday" /><ref name=Flora>{{cite book|last1=Paczkowska|first1=Grazyna|last2=Chapman|first2=Alex R.|title=The Western Australian flora : a descriptive catalogue|date=2000|publisher=Wildflower Society of Western Australia|location=Perth|isbn=0646402439|page=398}}</ref> It grows in  red-brown clay-loam, often in roadside remnant vegetation.<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca villosisepala''|id = 18395}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca villosisepala'' is classified as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name="FloraBase"/>

254.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name=Weeping bottlebrush
|status =
|status_system = 
|image = Melaleuca viminalis.jpg
|image caption = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. viminalis'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca viminalis''
|binomial_authority = ([[Daniel Solander|Sol.]] ex [[Joseph Gaertner|Gaertn.]]) [[Norman Byrnes (botanist)|Byrnes]]
|synonyms = 
''Metrosideros viminalis'' {{small| [[Daniel Solander|Sol.]] ex [[Joseph Gaertner|Gaertn.]] }}{{br}}
''Callistemon viminalis'' {{small| ([[Daniel Solander|Sol.]] ex [[Joseph Gaertner|Gaertn.]]) [[George Don|G.Don]] }}{{br}}
}}

'''''Melaleuca viminalis''''', commonly known as '''weeping bottlebrush''', or '''creek bottlebrush''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to [[New South Wales]], [[Queensland]] and [[Western Australia]]. (Some Australian state herbaria continue to use the name ''Callistemon viminalis''.<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=31 May 2015}}</ref>) It is a multi-trunked, large shrub or tree with hard bark, often pendulous foliage and large numbers of bright red bottlebrush flowers in spring and summer. It is possibly the most commonly cultivated melaleuca in gardens and its cultivars are often grown in many countries.

==Description==
''Melaleuca viminalis'' is a large shrub or small tree growing to {{convert|10|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with hard, fibrous, furrowed bark, a number of trunks and usually pendulous branches. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|25-138|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|3-27|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, more or less flat, very narrow elliptical to narrow egg-shaped with the narrower end towards the base and the other end tapering to a sharp point. The leaves have a mid-vein, 9-27 lateral veins and large number of conspicuous oil glands.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|pages=378–379}}</ref><ref name=RBGS>{{cite web|last1=Spencer|first1=Roger|last2=Lumley|first2=Peter|title=Callistemon viminalis|url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Callistemon~viminalis|publisher=Royal Botanic Garden Sydney: Plantnet|accessdate=17 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=trin>{{cite web|title=Melaleuca viminalis|url=http://keys.trin.org.au/key-server/data/0e0f0504-0103-430d-8004-060d07080d04/media/Html/taxon/Melaleuca_viminalis.htm|publisher=Australian Tropical Rainforest Plants|accessdate=17 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=ANPSA>{{cite web|title=Callistemon viminalis|url=http://anpsa.org.au/c-vim.html|publisher=Australian Native Plants Society Australia|accessdate=17 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=ANBG>{{cite web|last1=Jackson|first1=Ron|title=Callistemon viminalis|url=https://www.anbg.gov.au/gnp/gnp12/callistemon-viminalis.html|publisher=Australian National Botanic Garden|accessdate=17 July 2015}}</ref>

The flowers are bright red and are arranged in spikes on and around the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering. The spikes are {{convert|35-50|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and {{convert|40-100|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long with 15 to 50 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|3.4-5.9|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages and the stamens are arranged in five bundles around the flower. The bundles are sometimes obscure but each contains 9 to 14 stamens.  Flowering occurs from September to December and often sporadically throughout the year. Flowering is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]], {{convert|3.8-4.8|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|5-6|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} in diameter.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="RBGS" /><ref name="trin" /><ref name="ANPSA" /><ref name="ANBG" />

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca viminalis'' was first named in 2009 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Novon]]'' when ''Callistemon viminalis'' was transferred to the present [[genus]].<ref name=APNI(1)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca viminalis''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/545796|publisher=APNI|accessdate=17 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=''Melaleuca'' (Myrtaceae) from Australia|journal=Novon|date=2009|volume=19|page=449|doi=10.3417/2007008|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/40330691#page/451/mode/1up|accessdate=17 July 2015}}</ref> ''Metrosideros viminalis'' was first formally described in 1788 by [[Joseph Gaertner]] in [[De Fructibus et Seminibus Plantarum]].<ref name=APNI(2)>{{cite web|title=''Metrosideros viminalis''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/474188|publisher=APNI|accessdate=3 September 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''viminalis'') is from the [[Latin]] word ''[[wikt:vimen|vimen]]'' meaning an "osier" or "pliant twig"<ref name="RWB">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Roland Wilbur|title=The Composition of Scientific Words|date=1956|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.|page=836}}</ref> referring to the weeping habit of the branchlets of this species.<ref name="Brophy" />

There are two subspecies:
*''Melaleuca viminalis ''<small>([[Daniel Solander|Sol.]] ex [[Joseph Gaertner|Gaertn.]]) [[Norman Byrnes (botanist)|Byrnes]]</small> subsp.'' viminalis''<ref name=APNI2>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca viminalis'' subsp.''viminalis''|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/nsl/services/api/name/apni/223940|publisher=APNI|accessdate=17 July 2015}}</ref> which is a multi-trunked shrub or small tree growing to {{convert|15|m|ft|sigfig=1}} high and which often flowers throughout the year;<ref name="Brophy" /> 
*''Melaleuca viminalis '' subsp. ''rhododendron''<small> [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]] </small>,<ref name=APNI3>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca viminalis'' subsp. ''rhododendron''|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/nsl/services/api/instance/apni/653277|publisher=APNI|accessdate=17 July 2015}}</ref> a single-stemmed tree growing to {{convert|35|m|ft|sigfig=1}} high which flowers mostly in September and October, and occurs only in the [[Injune]] district in Queensland.<ref name="Brophy" />

''Callistemon viminalis'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca viminalis'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref name '"WCSP">{{WCSP | 31513 | ''Callistemon viminalis'' }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs along the eastern part of Queensland from the [[Cape York Peninsula]] south to [[Moree, New South Wales|Moree]] and [[Grafton, New South Wales|Grafton]] in New South Wales. There are also [[Disjunct distribution|disjunct]] populations in the far north and south-west of Western Australia. It mostly grows in and along watercourses, mainly in [[sandstone]] or [[granite]] country.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="RBGS" /><ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca viminalis''|id = 37683}}</ref>

==Ecology==
''Melaleuca viminalis'' provides food for [[nectivore]]s. Its adaptations to survive strong currents during flood events allow it to slow the flow of floodwater and reduce erosion, thereby improving the water quality in streams and rivers. The matted roots of this species also strengthen the soil of riverbanks, further reducing the potential for erosion.<ref name=Ipswich>{{cite web|title=Weeping bottlebrush|url=http://www.ipswich.qld.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0009/20124/profile_4_weeping_bottlebrush.pdf|publisher=Ipswich City Council|accessdate=17 July 2015}}</ref>

==Use in horticulture==
A widely grown garden plant and street tree, usually known as ''Callistemon viminalis'', ''Melaleuca viminalis'' is a hardy species in most soils when grown in full sun. It is useful as a screening plant and is suitable for planting as a street tree.<ref name=Wrigley>{{cite book|last1=Wrigley|first1=John W.|last2=Fagg|first2=Murray|title=Australian native plants : a manual for their propagation, cultivation and use in landscaping|date=1983|publisher=Collins|location=Sydney|isbn=0002165759|page=194|edition=2nd}}</ref> It needs regular watering but can survive drought as a mature plant although it is not frost hardy and will succumb to salt spray.<ref name="ANPSA" /><ref name="ANBG" />

Many cultivars of this species have been developed as cultivars of ''Callistemon''.<ref name="ANBG" /> They include:

*[[Callistemon 'Captain Cook'|''C. viminalis'' 'Captain Cook']];
*''C. viminalis 'Rose Opal';
*''C. 'Dawson River Weeper';
*''C. 'Hannah Ray';
*''C. viminalis 'Prolific';
*''C. viminalis 'Hen Camp Creek';
*''C. viminalis 'Wild River'.

==References==
{{reflist|30em}}

[[Category:Flora of Australia]]
[[Category:Flora of New South Wales]]
[[Category:Flora of Queensland]]
[[Category:Plants described in 1788]]

255.text:
{{italic title}} {{taxobox |name = Lime bottlebrush |image = IMG 8060-Callistemon viridiflorus.jpg |image_caption = ''M. virens'' flowers, fruit and new growth |status = |status_system = |regnum = [[Plantae]] |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s |unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s |unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s |ordo = [[Myrtales]] |familia = [[Myrtaceae]] |genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]'' |species = '''''M. virens''''' |binomial = ''Melaleuca virens'' |binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]] |synonyms = ''Metrosideros viridiflora'' [[John Sims (taxonomist)|Sims]]
''Callistemon viridiflorus'' ([[John Sims (taxonomist)|Sims]]) [[Robert Sweet (botanist)|Sweet]] }} '''''Melaleuca virens''''', commonly known as '''lime bottlebrush''', is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to [[Tasmania]] in [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state [[Herbarium|herbaria]] continue to use the name ''Callistemon viridiflorus''.){{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=21 July 2015}} It is one of only two melaleucas endemic to Tasmania, the other being ''[[Melaleuca pustulata]]'' although another six also occur there. A small to medium shrub growing mostly in subalpine areas, it has hard, leathery, sharply pointed leaves and spikes of yellow or greenish flowers in early summer, ==Description== ''Melaleuca virens'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|3|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|14-37|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|1.8-5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, flat, elliptic to lance-shaped, sometimes slightly curved and taper to a sharp point. The side-veins are indistinct but the mid-vein and oil glands are visible on both surfaces.{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=384}}{{cite web|last1=Jordan|first1=Greg|title=Melaleuca virens|url=http://www.utas.edu.au/dicotkey/dicotkey/MYRTS/sCallistemon_viridiflorus.htm|publisher=University of Tasmania|accessdate=21 July 2015}}{{cite web|title=Plants for special places|url=http://www.apstas.com/Plants_for_Special_Places2.html|publisher=Hobart District Group of The Australian Plants Society - Tasmania Inc.|accessdate=21 July 2015}} The flowers are a shade of yellow to greenish-yellow and are arranged in spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and also on the sides of the branches. The spikes are {{convert|30-50|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and {{convert|40-60|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long with 20 to 80 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|2.7-4.9|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages and there are 19-36 stamens in each flower, sometimes arranged in 5 groups. Flowering occurs from November to May and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|4.5-6|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long. ==Taxonomy and naming== ''Melaleuca virens'' was first named in 2006 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in [[Novon]] when ''Callistemon viridiflorus'' was transferred to the present [[genus]].{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca virens''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/613708|publisher=APNI|accessdate=22 July 2015}}{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=New Combinations in Melaleuca for Australian Species of Callistemon (Myrtaceae)|journal=Novon|date=2006|volume=16|issue=4|page=473|url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.3417/1055-3177%282006%2916%5B468%3ANCIMFA%5D2.0.CO%3B2|accessdate=21 July 2015|doi=10.3417/1055-3177(2006)16[468:NCIMFA]2.0.CO;2}} ''Metrosideros viridiflora'' was first formally described in 1825 by [[John Sims (taxonomist)|John Sims]] in [[Curtis's Botanical Magazine]].{{cite web|title=''Metrosideros viridiflora''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/474222|publisher=APNI|accessdate=22 July 2015}}{{cite book|last1=Sims|first1=John|title=Curtis's Botanical Magazine (Volume 52)|date=1825|publisher=Sherwood, Jones & Co.|location=London|page=2602|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/14336#page/1/mode/1up|accessdate=22 July 2015}} In 1826 it was renamed ''Callistemon viridiflorus'' by [[Robert Sweet (botanist)|Sweet]] in [[Hortus Britannicus]].{{cite web|title=''Callistemon viridiflorus''|url= https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/523212|publisher=APNI|accessdate=22 July 2015}}{{cite book|last1=Sweet|first1=Robert|title=Hortus Britannicus|date=1826|publisher=James Ridgway|location=Piccadilly|page=155|edition=1|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/95164#page/165/mode/1up|accessdate=22 July 2015}} The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''virens'') is from the [[Latin]] word ''viridus'' meaning “green”{{cite web|title=palus|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/viridis|publisher=Wiktionary|accessdate=22 July 2015}} referring to the flower colour of this species. ==Distribution and habitat== ''Melaleuca virens'' occurs throughout Tasmania but is more common in wet places in mountain or colder areas of the state. It grows in [[swamps]], in [[heath]] and on [[Gymnoschoenus sphaerocephalus|buttongrass]] plains. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} [[Category:Melaleuca|virens]] [[Category:Flora of Australia]] [[Category:Flora of Tasmania]] [[Category:Plants described in 1825]]
255.title: Melaleuca virens

256.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|image = Melaleuca williamsii subsp. williamsii (leaves, flowers).JPG
|image_caption = ''M. williamsii'' subsp. ''williamsii'' growing near [[Hillgrove, New South Wales|Hillgrove]] 
|status =VU
|status_system = EPBC
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. williamsii'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca williamsii''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
|synonyms = 
''Callistemon pungens'' <small> [[Peter Lumley|Lumley]] & [[Roger David Spencer|R.D.Spencer]] </small>
}}

'''''Melaleuca williamsii''''' is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to an area between north-eastern [[New South Wales]] and south eastern [[Queensland]] in [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state [[Herbarium|herbaria]] continue use the name ''Callistemon pungens''.)<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> It is a distinctive shrub with stiff branches, silvery new growth, prickly leaves and spikes of purple flowers in late spring. It is classified as a vulnerable species under the Australian Government Endangered Species Protection Act.

==Description==
''Melaleuca williamsii'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|2.5|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall with rigid branches and new growth covered with soft, silky hairs giving a silvery appearance. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are {{convert|18-68|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|3-14|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, narrow elliptic to narrow egg-shaped and flat to half-moon shaped in cross section. They have a sharp tip {{convert|1-2|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, a mid vein, indistinct lateral veins and oil glands visible on both surfaces.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|pages=387–388}}</ref><ref name=RBGS>{{cite web|last1=Wilson|first1=Pete |title=''Callistemon pungens''|url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Callistemon~pungens|publisher=Royal Botanic Garden Sydney: Plantnet|accessdate=21 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=OEH>{{cite web|title=Callistemon pungens - profile|url=http://www.environment.nsw.gov.au/threatenedSpeciesApp/profile.aspx?id=20241|publisher=NSW Government Office of Environment and Heritage|accessdate=14 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Commonwealth>{{cite web|title=Approved Conservation Advice for Callistemon pungens|url=http://www.environment.gov.au/biodiversity/threatened/species/pubs/55581-conservation-advice.pdf|publisher=Australian Government Department of the Environment|accessdate=21 July 2015}}</ref>

The flowers are deep red, white, or a shade of pink to purple. They are arranged in spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering. The spikes are up to {{convert|25-45|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter and {{convert|50-60|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long with 10 to 65 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|2.1-5.8|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages and there are 25 to 66 stamens per flower. Flowering occurs from October to December and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|3.9-6.6|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="RBGS" /><ref name="OEH" /><ref name="Commonwealth" />
[[File:Callistemon pungens HRM2.JPG|thumb|225px|''M. williamsii'' in the [[Real Jardín Botánico de Madrid|Royal Botanical Garden of Madrid]]]]
[[File:Melaleuca williamsii subsp. williamsii (habit).JPG|thumb|225px|''M. williamsii'' subsp. ''williamsii'' habit]]
[[File:Melaleuca williamsii subsp. williamsii mature fruits.JPG|thumb|225px|''M. williamsii'' subsp. ''williamsii'' mature fruits]]

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca williamsii'' was first named in 2009 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in [[Novon]] when ''Callistemon pungens'' was transferred to the present [[genus]].<ref name=APNI(1)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca williamsii''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/613709|publisher=APNI|accessdate=21 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=''Melaleuca'' (Myrtaceae) from Australia|journal=Novon|date=2009|volume=19|page=452|doi=10.3417/2007008|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/40330691#page/454/mode/1up|accessdate=21 July 2015}}</ref> It had previously been known as ''Callistemon pungens'', first formally described by [[Roger David Spencer|Roger Spencer]] and [[Peter Lumley]] in 1990 in Muelleria, based on plant material collected from near [[Hillgrove, New South Wales|Hillgrove]].<ref name=APNI(2)>{{cite web|title=''Callistemon pungens''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/552238|publisher=APNI|accessdate=3 September 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''williamsii'') honours [[John Beaumont Williams]], a botanist who was expert in the flora of the [[Northern Tablelands]] region of New South Wales.<ref name="Brophy" />

There are three subspecies:
*''Melaleuca williamsii'' subsp. ''fletcheri''<ref name=APNI(3)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca williamsii'' subsp. ''fletcheri''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/653280|publisher=APNI|accessdate=21 July 2015}}</ref> which has stamens up to {{convert|19|mm|in|sigfig=1}} long, flower spikes {{convert|30-45|mm|in|sigfig=1}} wide, pink or mauve stamens and occurs in the [[Stanthorpe]] district in Queensland;
*''Melaleuca williamsii'' subsp. ''synoriensis''<ref name=APNI(4)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca williamsii'' subsp. ''synoriensis''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/653281|publisher=APNI|accessdate=21 July 2015}}</ref> which has stamens up to {{convert|11|mm|in|sigfig=1}} long, flower spikes {{convert|25-30|mm|in|sigfig=2}} wide and occurs in the [[Gibraltar Range]] and [[Point Lookout (New South Wales)|Point Lookout]] districts in New South Wales;
*''Melaleuca williamsii'' subsp. ''williamsii''<ref name=APNI(5)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca williamsii'' subsp. ''williamsii''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/name/apni/216819|publisher=APNI|accessdate=21 July 2015}}</ref> which has stamens up to {{convert|19|mm|in|sigfig=1}} long, flower spikes {{convert|30-45|mm|in|sigfig=1}} wide, red, crimson or purple stamens and occurs in the Northern Tablelands region of [[New South Wales]].

''Callistemon pungens'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca williamsii'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref name '"WCSP">{{WCSP | 31480 | ''Callistemon pungens'' }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in the higher altitude regions of north eastern New South Wales and south eastern Queensland. It grows in [[granite]] and [[trachyte]] rock crevices in forest and heath and on sandy or shallow rocky soil.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="RBGS" />

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca williamsii'' (as ''Callistemon pungens'') has been classified as "vulnerable" by the Scientific Committee of the NSW Government Department of Environment and Heritage<ref name="OEH" /> and by the Australian Government Department of the Environment.<ref name="Commonwealth" />

==References==
{{reflist|30em}}

[[Category:Flora of Australia]]
[[Category:Flora of New South Wales]]
[[Category:Plants described in 1990]]
256.title: Melaleuca williamsii

257.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = Wimmera bottlebrush
|status = CR
|status_system = EPBC
|status_ref = <ref name="environment" />
|image = Callistemon wimmerensis.jpg
|image_caption = ''M. wimmerensis'' in [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Melbourne]] 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. wimmerensis.jpg'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca wimmerensis.jpg''
|binomial_authority = (Marriott & G.W.Carr) [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
|synonyms = 
''Callistemon wimmerensis'' <small> Marriott & G.W.Carr </small>
}}

'''''Melaleuca wimmerensis''''', commonly known as the '''Wimmera bottlebrush''', is a plant in the myrtle [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the state of [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] in [[Australia]]. (Some Australian state [[Herbarium|herbaria]] continue to use the name ''Callistemon wimmerensis'').<ref name=Udovicic>{{cite journal|last1=Udovicic|first1=Frank|last2=Spencer|first2=Roger|title=New combinations in ''Callistemon'' (Myrtaceae)|journal=Muelleria|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=23–25|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_30-1_3_Udovicic_Spencer.pdf|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> It is a recently (2008) discovered shrub, often with many stems arising from a [[lignotuber]] and is similar to ''[[Melaleuca paludicola]]'' but has pink or mauve flowers tipped with yellow anthers over a short period between October and early December.

==Description==
''Melaleuca wimmerensis'' is a shrub growing to {{convert|10|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} tall, often multistemmed with a dense crown and fibrous, grey to brown bark. Its leaves are arranged alternately and are mainly {{convert|30-50|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|4-7|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, narrow elliptic to egg-shaped tapering to a sharply pointed end. There is a mid-vein but the lateral veins are indistinct. Oil glands are visible on the lower surface of the leaves.<ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517|page=390}}</ref><ref name=Marriott>{{cite journal|last1=Marriott|first1=Neil|last2=Carr|first2=Geoffrey|title=A new species of Callistemon (Myrtaceae, Melaleuceae) from Victoria, Australia|journal=Muelleria|date=2008|volume=26|issue=2|pages=57–63|url=http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/documents/Muelleria_26%282%29%2C_p57-63%2C_Marriott__Carr%2C_new_Callistemon.pdf|accessdate=22 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=environment>{{cite web|title=Approved Conservation Advice for Callistemon wimmerensis (Wimmera Bottlebrush)|url=http://www.environment.gov.au/cgi-bin/sprat/public/publicspecies.pl?taxon_id=82943#summary|publisher=Australian Government Department of the Environment|accessdate=22 July 2015}}</ref>

The flowers are arranged in spikes on the ends of branches which continue to grow after flowering and are {{convert|32-35|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} in diameter with 12 to 50 individual flowers. The petals are {{convert|4-5|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long and fall off as the flower ages and there are 45-50 stamens in each flower. The filaments of the [[stamens]] are pink, tipped with a yellow anther. Flowering occurs over a short period between October and December and is followed by fruit which are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsule]]s, {{convert|4.5–5.0|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long when mature.<ref name="Brophy" /><ref name="Marriott" />

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Callistemon wimmerensis'' was first formally described in 2008 by Neil Marriott and Geoffrey Carr in [[Muelleria (journal)|Muelleria]], based on a population occurring on [[crown land]] on the west bank of the [[Mackenzie River (Victoria)|Mackenzie River]] near [[Horsham, Victoria|Horsham]]. In 2011 another population was reported to have been discovered in a swamp in the [[Grampians National Park|southern Grampians]].<ref name="Marriott" /><ref name="discovered">{{cite web|title=What’s in the Bush 2 Rare Callistamon|date=31 January 2011|publisher=Australian Plants Society, Geelong|url=http://www.apsgeelong.org/Newsletters/2011/March-2011.pdf|accessdate=22 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Callistemon wimmerensis''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/632702|publisher=APNI|accessdate=22 July 2015}}</ref> [[Lyndley Craven]] transferred the species to ''Melaleuca'' in 2009, giving the description in [[Novon]].<ref name=APNI(2)>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca wimmerensis''|url=  https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/653282|publisher=APNI|accessdate=22 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=Lyn A.|title=''Melaleuca'' (Myrtaceae) from Australia|journal=Novon|date=2009|volume=19|page=446|doi=10.3417/2007008|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/40330691#page/453/mode/1up|accessdate=22 July 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''wimmerensis'') refers to the locality where the species is found.<ref name="Brophy" />

''Callistemon wimmerensis'' is regarded as a synonym of ''Melaleuca wimmerensis'' by the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref name '"WCSP">{{WCSP | 372445 | ''Callistemon wimmerensis'' }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs in the [[Wimmera]] district in Victoria growing in [[woodland]] near rivers and streams.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca wimmerensis'' (as ''Callistemon wimmerensis'') has been classified as "critically endangered" by the Australian Government Department of the Environment.<ref name="environment" />

==References==
{{reflist|30em}}

[[Category:Melaleuca|wimmerensis]]
[[Category:Flora of Australia]]
[[Category:Flora of Victoria (Australia)]]
[[Category:Plants described in 2009]]
257.title: Melaleuca wimmerensis

258.text:
{{taxobox
|image = 
|status = 
|status_system = 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperm]]s
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicot]]s
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosid]]s
|ordo = [[Myrtales]]
|familia = [[Myrtaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Melaleuca]]''
|species = '''''M. wonganensis'''''
|binomial = ''Melaleuca wonganensis''
|binomial_authority = [[Lyndley Craven|Craven]]
}}

'''''Melaleuca wonganensis''''' is an erect shrub in the myrtle family [[Myrtaceae]] and is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Southwest_Australia|south-west]] of [[Western Australia]]. It is a shrub with narrow leaves and purple to deep mauve flowers and is restricted in its distribution to the [[Wongan Hills]] district.

==Description==
''Melaleuca wonganensis'' grows to a height of {{convert|1-1.4|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}}. Its leaves are arranged alternately, are linear to tear-drop shaped with a very short stalk and a rounded end. The leaves are {{convert|7.5-20|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|0.8-1.4|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} wide, often covered with fine hairs and have three longitudinal veins.

The flowers are arranged in heads about {{convert|25|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter, near the ends of the branches, with two to five groups of flowers, each with three individual flowers. The flowers appear in September and October and are purple or deep mauve. The stamens are arranged in bundles of five around the flower, with seven to ten stamens in each bundle. The base of the flower is hairy and {{convert|2.0-2.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long. The fruit are woody [[Capsule (botany)|capsules]] {{convert|3-4.5|mm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} long and wide.<ref name=Holliday>{{cite book|last1=Holliday|first1=Ivan|title=Melaleucas : a field and garden guide|date=2004|publisher=Reed New Holland Publishers|location=Frenchs Forest, N.S.W.|isbn=1876334983|page=226|edition=2nd}}</ref><ref name=Brophy>{{cite book|last1=Brophy|first1=Joseph J.|last2=Craven|first2=Lyndley A.|last3=Doran|first3=John C.|title=Melaleucas : their botany, essential oils and uses|date=2013|publisher=Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research|page=391|location=Canberra|isbn=9781922137517}}</ref>

==Taxonomy and naming==
''Melaleuca wonganensis'' was first formally described in 1999 by [[Lyndley Craven]] in ''[[Australian Systematic Botany]]''.<ref name=APNI>{{cite web|title=''Melaleuca wonganensis''|url=https://biodiversity.org.au/boa/instance/apni/561936|publisher=APNI|accessdate=12 March 2015}}</ref><ref name=Craven>{{cite journal|last1=Craven|first1=L. A.|last2=Lepschi|first2=B. J.|title=Enumeration of the species and infraspecific taxa of Melaleuca (Myrtaceae) occurring in Australia and Tasmania|journal=Australian Systematic Botany|date=1999|volume=12|issue=6|pages=915|doi=10.1071/SB98019|url=http://www.publish.csiro.au/paper/SB98019.htm|accessdate=12 March 2015}}</ref> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] (''wonganensis'') is a reference to its distribution in the Wongan Hills district.<ref name="Brophy" />

==Distribution and habitat==
This melaleuca occurs only in the Wongan Hills district. It usually grows in depressions near salt lakes in [[calcareous]] soils.<ref name=FloraBase>{{FloraBase|name=''Melaleuca xerophila''|id = 5991}}</ref> It grows in dense scrub or heath on sand, clayey sand with lateritic pebbles and sand over granite and laterite.<ref name="Brophy" /> The type specimen has the note that it was collected on "Gently undulating terrain, east of hills, orange clayey sand with numerous lateritic pebbles. Melaleuca heath-thicket by side of road. Locally common."<ref name=JSTOR>{{cite web|title=Isotype of ''Melaleuca wonganensis'' Craven [family MYRTACEAE]|url=http://plants.jstor.org/stable/10.5555/al.ap.specimen.perth01585800|publisher=JSTOR|accessdate=12 March 2015}}</ref>

==Conservation==
''Melaleuca wonganensis'' is classified as "not threatened" by the [[Government of Western Australia]] [[Department of Parks and Wildlife (Western Australia)|Department of Parks and Wildlife]].<ref name=FloraBase/>

==Uses==

===Essential oils===
This leaf oil of this species is mostly monoterpenes yielding about 0.5% (weight/weight) from fresh leaves.<ref name="Brophy" />

* ''Wollastonia insularis'' <small>DC.</small>
* ''Wollastonia scabriuscula'' <small>DC. ex Decne.</small>
* ''Wollastonia strigulosa'' <small>(Gaudich.)</small>
* ''Wollastonia zanzibarensis'' <small>DC.</small>
}}
'''''Melanthera biflora''''',<ref>[http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl/record/gcc-114619 'Melanthera biflora' The Plant list]</ref> also known as '''sea daisy''', '''beach daisy''' and '''sea ox-eye''', ({{lang-hi|''Bhringaraaja''}}; {{lang-ms|Serunai laut, Pokok serunai}}; {{lang-fj|Kovekove, Sekava}}; [[Maldivian language|Maldivian]]: ''Mirihi''; [[Samoan language|Samoan]]: ''Ateate''; {{lang-th|เบญจมาศน้ำเค็ม}} or ผักคราดทะเล;<ref>[http://tanhakit.blogspot.com/2010/12/blog-post_2776.html Mangrove forest: เบญจมาศน้ำเค็ม]</ref> [[Tongan language|Tongan]]: ''Ate''), is a  species of flowering plant in the [[Asteraceae|aster family]]. It is a [[scandent]], rough-looking and fast-growing plant with a wide distribution.

==Distribution==
''Melanthera biflora'' is a moderately [[Salt tolerant plant|salt-tolerant plant]] found in the [[tropical belt]] of the [[Indo-Pacific]] region, including [[China]], the [[Indian Subcontinent]], [[Southeast Asia]], [[Queensland]], and islands of the [[Pacific Islands|Pacific]] such as [[Fiji]], [[Niue]], [[Tonga]], [[Samoa]] and the [[Cook Islands]].

It is found commonly in islands and in coastal areas, although it sometimes occurs inland in neglected and unmanaged plantations as well as in [[ruderal]] environments.<ref>[http://jxb.oxfordjournals.org/content/44/10/1551.full.pdf Response of Melanthera biflora to Salinity and Water Stress]</ref>

Together with ''[[Portulaca oleracea]]'', ''[[Ipomoea pes-caprae]]'' and ''[[Digitaria ciliaris]]'', ''Melanthera biflora'' is usually one of the first species colonizing [[Land degradation|degraded or altered environments]] in tropical zones of the planet.<ref>Heatwole, H., Done, T., Cameron, E. ''Community Ecology of a Coral Cay, A Study of One-Tree Island, Great Barrier Reef, Australia.'' Series: Monographiae Biologicae, Vol. 43, p. 102</ref>

==Description==
''Melanthera biflora'' is a hardy and somewhat woody, sprawling perennial herb or subshrub. Stems are elongate and branched; they can reach up to 2 m but will bend after reaching a certain height. It can scramble and straggle over the ground or climb leaning on other plants for support. The leaves are ovate, shortly tapering at the base. It produces small yellow [[Head (botany)|flower heads]] with a diameter of about 8–10 mm. The fruits form a dense head.<ref>[http://bie.ala.org.au/species/urn:lsid:biodiversity.org.au:apni.taxon:634515 Melanthera biflora (L.) Wild - Atlas of Living Australia]</ref>
{|
|- valign="top"
|[[File:Melanthera biflora088.JPG|thumb|250px|General appearance of the shrub.]]
|[[File:Wollastonia biflora.jpg|thumb|250px|Flowering shrub from [[Tonga]] growing along the seashore.]]
|}

==Uses==
Despite the rough appearance of the plant, the leaves are edible.<ref>[http://ecoport.org/ep?Plant=2162 Ecoport]</ref><ref name="tropical.theferns.info">[http://tropical.theferns.info/viewtropical.php?id=Melanthera+biflora Melanthera biflora - Useful Tropical Plants]</ref> In [[Malaysian cuisine]] the shoots are eaten cooked as a [[leaf vegetable]] and in [[Langkawi]] they are eaten raw with [[chilli]] and ''[[sambal]]'' [[shrimp paste]]. 
Leaves also have traditional medicinal uses as [[poultice]] or as [[decoction]].<ref name="Globinmed - Wedelia biflora">[http://www.globinmed.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=104438:wedelia-biflora&catid=199&Itemid=139 Globinmed - Wedelia biflora]</ref><ref>[https://www.academia.edu/8069104/Rules_for_Maldivian_Trading_Ships_Travelling_Abroad_1925_and_a_Sojourn_in_Southern_Ceylon Rules for Maldivian Trading Ships Travelling Abroad (1925)]</ref>

''Melanthera biflora'' has traditionally been used as a [[Medicinal plants|medicinal plant]] in many cultures.<ref name="HG"/> Leaves are especially valued against stomachache.<ref name="tropical.theferns.info"/> In [[Fiji]] the leaves are used to treat [[acne]].<ref name="Globinmed - Wedelia biflora"/>
Root extracts have [[anthelmintic]] properties<ref>Cheryll Williams, ''Medicinal Plants in Australia Volume 4: An Antipodean Apothecary,'' Volume 4, p. 58</ref> and flowers can be used as a [[purgative]].<ref name="HG">{{cite web
 | url=http://www.stuartxchange.org/Hagonoi.html
 | title=Hagonoi / Wedelia Biflora
 | publisher = Philippine Medicinal Plants
 | accessdate=2008-04-07
}}</ref>

This plant is also used as [[fodder]] for rabbits.

|binomial = ''Mentha australis''
|binomial_authority = R. Br.

'''''Mentha australis''''' is known by the common names of ''river mint, native mint, native peppermint,'' and ''Australian mint''.<ref>{{cite book |last=Quattrocchi |first=Umberto |title=CRC World dictionary of plant names: Common names, Scientific Names, Eponyms, Sonyonyms, and Etymology |volume=III M-Q |year=1999 |publisher=CRC Press |pages=1659}}</ref> It is a mint species within the genus ''[[Mentha]]''.

It is a native of eastern Australia, occurring in every state and territory except [[Western Australia]]. It is also naturalized on the North Island of [[New Zealand]].<ref>[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=124435 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families]</ref>

'''''Mentha satureioides''''', commonly known as '''native pennyroyal''' or '''creeping mint''', is a [[species]] of herbaceous perennial native to southern + eastern [[Australia]] ([[Queensland]], [[New South Wales]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], [[South Australia]]).<ref name="floransw">{{NSW Flora Online|genus=Mentha |species=satureioides |author=  B.J. Conn}}</ref> It was first described by prolific botanist [[Robert Brown (botanist, born 1773)|Robert Brown]] in 1810.<ref>{{APNI | name = ''Mentha satureioides'' R.Br. | id = 22779}}</ref>

263.text:
{{italic title}} {{taxobox |name = holly-leaved naiad
spiny water nymph
大茨藻 da ci zao |image = Najas_marina_060628_Korea.jpg |regnum = [[Plantae]] |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Monocots]] |ordo = [[Alismatales]] |familia = [[Hydrocharitaceae]] |genus = ''[[Najas]]'' |species = '''''N. marina''''' |binomial = ''Najas marina'' |binomial_authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]] |synonyms = *''Ittnera major'' (All.) C.C.Gmel. *''Ittnera najas'' C.C.Gmel. *''Najas fluviatilis'' Poir. *''Najas fucoides'' Griff. *''Najas gracilis'' (Morong) Small *''Najas laevis'' Lojac. *''Najas latifolia'' A.Braun *''Najas major'' All. *''Najas maritima'' Pall. *''Najas microcarpa'' (A.Braun) Bolle ex Christ *''Najas monosperma'' Willd. *''Najas muricata'' Thuill. *''Najas polonica'' Zalewski *''Najas tetrasperma'' Willd. |synonyms_ref=[http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/kew-308286 The Plant List] }} '''''Najas marina''''' is a species of [[aquatic plant]] known by the common names '''spiny water nymph''', '''spiny naiad''' and '''holly-leaved naiad'''. It is an extremely widespread species, reported across Europe, Asia, Africa, Australia, the Americas and many oceanic islands. It can be found in many types of [[freshwater]] and [[Brackish water|brackish]] aquatic habitat, including bodies of [[alkaline]] water.Stuckey, R. L. 1985. Distributional history of Najas marina (spiny naiad) in North America. Bartonia 51: 2--16. {{Cite web|url=http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=200024705|title=Najas marina in Flora of North America @ efloras.org|website=www.efloras.org|access-date=2017-01-31}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=2&taxon_id=200024705|title=Najas marina in Flora of China @ efloras.org|website=www.efloras.org|access-date=2017-01-31}} ''Najas marina'' is an annual producing a slender, branching stem up to 40 or 45 centimeters in maximum length. The evenly spaced leaves are up to 4 centimeters long, 1 to 3 millimeters wide, and edged in tiny sawlike teeth. The leaf has prickles along its midvein. Minute flowers occur in the leaf axils. The plant is [[Plant sexuality|dioecious]], with male and female flower types occurring on separate individuals.{{Cite journal|last=von,|first=Linné, Carl|last2=Lars,|first2=Salvius,|date=1753-01-01|title=Caroli Linnaei ... Species plantarum|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/359036#page/457/mode/1up|language=en|volume=vol. 2}}Tzvelev, Nikolai Nikolaievich. 1976. Novosti Sistematiki Vysshikh Rastenii. Moscow & Leningrad 13: 18, ''Najas major'' var. ''polonica'' Triest, Ludwig J. 1988. Mém. Acad. Roy. Sci. Outre-Mer, Sci. Nat. Nouv. Sér. 22(1): 54 ''Najas marina'' var. ''ohwii'' ==Varieties and subspecies== {{stack|[[File:Najas marina.jpeg|thumb]]}} A long list of varietal and subspecific names have been proposed over the years. At present, only 9 are widely accepted:[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/qsearch.do Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families, genus ''Najas''] *''Najas marina'' subsp. ''arsenariensis'' (Maire) L.Triest - [[Algeria]] *''Najas marina'' var. ''brachycarpa'' Trautv. - [[China]] and [[Kazakhstan]] *''Najas marina'' subsp. ''commersonii'' L.Triest - [[Madagascar]], [[Mauritius]], [[Réunion]] *''Najas marina'' var. ''grossidentata'' Rendle - [[Korea]] and [[Manchuria]] *''Najas marina'' var. ''intermedia'' (Wolfg. ex Gorski) Rendle - [[Spain]], [[Sicily]], [[Africa]], the [[Middle East]], [[China]], [[Sri Lanka]] *''Najas marina'' var. ''marina'' *''Najas marina'' subsp. ''marina'' *''Najas marina'' subsp. ''sumatrana'' (W.J.de Wilde) L.Triest - [[Sumatra]] *''Najas marina'' var. ''zollingeri'' Rendle - [[Bali]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://ucjeps.berkeley.edu/cgi-bin/get_JM_treatment.pl?8169,8177,8182 Jepson Manual Treatment] *[http://plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=NAMA USDA Plants Profile] *[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=200024705 Flora of North America] *[http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?400101 GRIN Species Profile] *[http://calphotos.berkeley.edu/cgi/img_query?query_src=photos_index&where-taxon=Najas+marina Photo gallery] [[Category:Hydrocharitaceae]] [[Category:Freshwater plants]] [[Category:Brackish water plants]] [[Category:Plants described in 1753]] [[Category:Flora of North America]] [[Category:Flora of South America]] [[Category:Flora of Africa]] [[Category:Flora of temperate Asia]] [[Category:Flora of tropical Asia]] [[Category:Flora of Europe]] [[Category:Flora of Australia]] [[Category:Endangered species of the British Isles]] {{monocot-stub}}

'''''Najas tenuifolia''''' is an [[aquatic plant]] growing in fresh water ponds. It is a native to [[Hong Kong]], [[Thailand]], [[Indonesia]] ([[Java]], [[Maluku Islands|Maluku]], [[Sulawesi]], [[Bali]], [[Lombok]], [[Timor]]), the [[Philippines]] and [[Australia]] (every state and territory except [[Tasmania]]).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Robert,|first=Brown,|date=1810-01-01|title=Prodromus florae Novae Hollandiae et Insulae Van-Diemen,|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/2954501#page/213/mode/1up345|language=en}}</ref>

==Varieties and Subspecies==
Four varietal are currently recognized:<ref name="miriammoses"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/qsearch.do|title=World Checklist of Selected Plant Families: Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew|website=apps.kew.org|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-01-31}}</ref>

*''Najas tenuifolia'' var. ''celebica'' <small>(Koord.) W.J.de Wilde</small> - [[Sulawesi]]<ref name="whereswaldo">de Wilde, Willem Jan Jacobus Oswald. 1962. Flora Malesiana 6: 168.</ref><ref>Koorders, Sijfert Hendrik . 1898. Mededeelingen uit's Lands Plantentuin 19: 270, ''Najas celebica''</ref>
*''Najas tenuifolia'' var. ''pseudograminea'' <small>(W.Koch) W.J.de Wilde</small> - most of specific range<ref name="whereswaldo"/><ref>Koch, Walo. 1935.  Berichte der Schweizerischen Botanischen Gesellschaft 44: 339, ''Najas pseudograminea''</ref>
*''Najas tenuifolia'' var. ''tenuifolia''  - [[Sulawesi]], [[Australia]]

'''''Nasturtium microphyllum''''', the '''onerow yellowcress''',<ref>{{PLANTS|id=NAMI2|taxon=Nasturtium microphyllum|accessdate=18 July 2015}}</ref> is an aquatic plant species widespread across [[Europe]] and [[Asia]], and naturalized in the [[United States]], [[Canada]], [[Mexico]], [[Central America]], [[Australia]], and other places. It occurs in wet locations generally at elevations less than 1500 m. It has been reported from every Canadian province except [[Nova Scotia]] and [[Saskatchewan]]. In the US, it is fairly common in [[New England]], [[New York (state)|New York]], and [[Michigan]], with scattered populations in the southern and western parts of the country.<ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=250063804 Flora of North America v 7 p 490, ''Nasturtium microphyllum'']</ref><ref>Reichenbach, Heinrich Gottlieb Ludwig. 1832,  Flora Germanica Excursoria 683, ''Nasturtium microphyllum''</ref><ref>Löve, Áskell & Löve, Doris Benta Maria. 1948. Iceland University Institute of Applied Science Department of Agriculture Report, Reykjavik,  3: 109, ''Rorippa microphylla''</ref>

266.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = ''Notoleptopus''
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Malpighiales]]
|familia = [[Phyllanthaceae]]
|tribus = [[Poranthereae]]
|genus = '''''Notoleptopus'''''
|genus_authority = [[Maria Sergeevna Vorontsova|Voronts.]] & [[Petra Hoffmann|Petra Hoffm.]]
|type_species = '''''Notoleptopus decaisnei'''''
|type_species_authority = (Bentham) Vorontsova & Petra Hoffm.
|species = '''''N. decaisnei'''''
|binomial = ''Notoleptopus decaisnei''
|binomial_authority = ([[George Bentham|Bentham]]) Vorontsov. & Petra Hoffm.
|}}
'''''Notoleptopus''''' is a [[monotypic]] [[genus]] of [[Angiosperms|flowering plant]]s in the [[Family (biology)| family]] [[Phyllanthaceae]]. It is one of eight genera in the [[Tribe (biology)| tribe]] [[Poranthereae]]. The sole [[species]] is '''''Notoleptopus decaisnei'''''. It is a [[monoecious]] [[shrub]], [[Indigenous (ecology)| native]] to [[Australia]], [[New Guinea]], and [[Indonesia]].

''Notoleptopus decaisnei'' had long been treated as a species of ''[[Leptopus]]'', but in 2007, a [[molecular phylogenetic]] [[Research| study]] of [[DNA sequence]]s found it to be [[sister taxon| sister]] to a [[clade]] consisting of ''[[Pseudophyllanthus]]'' and ''[[Poranthera]]''. <ref name="vorontsova2007"> Maria S. Vorontsova, Petra Hoffmann, Olivier Maurin, and Mark W. Chase. 2007. "Phylogenetics of tribe Poranthereae (Phyllanthaceae)." ''American Journal of Botany'' '''94'''(12):2026-2040. </ref> In 2008, the new genus ''Notoleptopus'' was created for it. <ref name="vorontsova2008"> Maria S. Vorontsova and Petra Hoffmann. 2008. "A phylogenetic classification of tribe Poranthereae (Phyllanthaceae)." ''Kew Bulletin'' '''63'''(1):41-59. </ref>

{{speciesbox |image = Nymphaea pubescens1MTFL.jpg |image_caption = Hairy water lily (''Nymphaea pubescens'') |genus = Nymphaea |species = pubescens |authority = [[Carl Ludwig Willdenow|Willd.]] |synonyms = ''Nymphaea rubra'' [[Roxb.]] ex Andrews

''Nymphaea magnifica'' (Salisb.) Conard
''Nymphaea purpurea'' Rehnelt & F. Henkel
''Nymphaea rosea'' (Sims) Sweet }} '''''Nymphaea pubescens''''', the '''hairy water lily''' or '''pink water-lily''', is a species of [[Nymphaeaceae|water lily]]. ==Distribution== [[File:Lotus pond Sambuor.jpg|thumb|left|''Nymphaea pubescens'' in a lake in Cambodia.]] This plant is common in shallow lakes and ponds throughout temperate and tropical Asia: [[Bangladesh]], [[India]], [[Sri Lanka]], [[Yunnan]], [[Taiwan]], [[Philippines]], [[Cambodia]], [[Laos]], [[Myanmar]], [[Thailand]], [[Vietnam]], [[Indonesia]] and [[Malaysia]]. It is also found in northeastern [[Australia]] and [[Papua New Guinea]].[http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/tax_search.pl?Nymphaea%20pubescens Taxonomy] The hairy water lily is found both as a cultivated plant as well as in the wild. It prefers non-acidic waters and it does not tolerate temperatures below 15 °C. ==Description== The hairy water lily is an aquatic plant having erect perennial [[rhizome]]s or rootstocks that anchor it to the mud in the bottom. The rhizomes produce slender [[stolon]]s. Its leave blades are round above the water and heart-shaped below 15–26(–50) cm, papery, abaxially densely pubescent. Some of the leaves that emerge rise slightly above the water held by their stem in [[sacred lotus|lotus]] fashion, but most of them just float on the surface. The floating leaves have undy edges that make a [[crenellate]] effect. The hairy water lily is also commercialized as an [[aquarium]] plant. The underwater leaves of this species have a handsome appearance that is appreciated by aquarists who often remove the floating leves to keep it as a fully subaquatic plant.[http://www.aquaticcommunity.com/tr/Nymphaeapubescens.php Nymphaea pubescens] The flowers are quite large, about 15 cm in diameter when fully open. They tend to close during the daytime and open wide at night. Their color varies from white to pink, [[mauve]] or purple depending from the variety or [[Hybrid (biology)|hybrid]]. ==Naming and variants== [[Image:2007 nymphaea rubra.jpg|thumb|left|''Nymphaea rubra'']] The hairy water lily is known as ''Shapla'' in [[Bengali language|Bengali]], ''Kokaa'' in [[Hindi]] and ''Kumuda'' in [[Sanskrit]].[http://www.plantnames.unimelb.edu.au/Sorting/Nymphaea.html#pubescens Names] The leaves of this plant have fuzzy or hairy undersides and the stems are covered by the same hairs as well, hence the name ''"pubescens"'' or "hairy" of the species. This is not a characteristic that is apparent when looking at the plant from above the water though. This species of water lily has quite a few artificially raised varieties, in addition to many natural hybrids. ''Nymphaea pubescens'' is known under a number of different synonyms, the most common of which is ''Nymphaea rubra'' for the reddish variant known under the commercial name '''Red water lily''', which often has also purplish leaves. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons|Nymphaea pubescens}} * {{cite book |last=Islam |first=Sirajul |year=2012 |chapter=National Emblem |chapter-url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=National_Emblem |editor1-last=Islam |editor1-first=Sirajul |editor1-link=Sirajul Islam |editor2-last=Jamal |editor2-first=Ahmed A. |title=Banglapedia: National Encyclopedia of Bangladesh |edition=Second |publisher=[[Asiatic Society of Bangladesh]]}} * [http://www.banglajol.info/index.php/JBS/article/viewFile/2197/1959 Studies on Nymphaea species in Bangladesh] * [http://www.ars-grin.gov/misc/mmpnd/Nymphaea.html Sorting Nymphaea names] * [http://www.victoria-adventure.org/waterlilies/species_galleries/lotos_pubescens.html Nymphaea pubescens - Pictures] * [http://flora.huh.harvard.edu/china/PDF/PDF06/NYMPHAEA.pdf Flora of China 6: 116–118. 2001 - Nymphaea 睡莲属] {{taxonbar}} [[Category:Nymphaea|pubescens]] [[Category:Flora of Bangladesh]] [[Category:Flora of India]] [[Category:Flora of Southeast Asia]] [[Category:Flora of New Guinea]] [[Category:Flora of Australia]]

269.text:
{{italic title}}
{{Taxobox
| name = ''Ophioglossum lusitanicum''
| image = Ophioglossum lusitanicum.jpg
| regnum = [[Plant]]ae
| divisio = [[Fern|Pteridophyta]]
| classis = [[Psilotopsida]]
| ordo = [[Ophioglossales]]
| familia = [[Ophioglossaceae]]
| genus = ''[[Ophioglossum]]''
| species = '''''O. lusitanicum'''''
| binomial = ''Ophioglossum lusitanicum''
| binomial_authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]
| synonyms = 
*''Ophioglossum coriaceum '' <small>A. Cunn.</small>
*''Ophioglossum gramineum '' <small>Willd.</small>
*''Ophioglossum vulgatum'' subsp. ''lusitanicum''
*''Ophioglossum vulgatum'' var. ''lusitanicum''
}}

'''''Ophioglossum lusitanicum''''', the '''least adder's-tongue''',<ref name=BSBI07>{{cite web |title=BSBI List 2007 |publisher=Botanical Society of Britain and Ireland |url=http://www.bsbi.org.uk/BSBIList2007.xls |format=xls |archive-url=http://www.webcitation.org/6VqJ46atN |archive-date=2015-02-25 |accessdate=2014-10-17}}</ref> is a small [[fern]] of the family [[Ophioglossaceae]]. It is categorised as [[Vulnerable species|Vulnerable]] by the [[IUCN]] (2001).<ref>[http://plantnetwork.org/projects/datasheets/ophilusi.pdf Plant Network datasheet on ''Ophioglossum lusitanicum'']</ref>

== Description ==
''Ophioglossum lusitanicum'' is a small winter annual fern, and consists of a simple sterile blade attached to a spike-like fertile blade with between three and eight sunken [[sporangia]] on either side. The whole plant rarely exceeds a height of 2 cm.<ref name="Stace">[[Stace, Clive]], (1997). ''New Flora of The British Isles'', second edition. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press</ref>   

This species has a [[chromosome number]] of 2''n'' = 250–260.<ref name="Stace"/>

== Distribution ==
''Ophioglossum lusitanicum'' is native to: the western seaboard of [[Europe]] ([[Great Britain]], [[Spain]] and [[Portugal]]); the Atlantic Islands ([[Cape Verde]] and the [[Canary Islands]]); the [[Middle East]] ([[Israel]] and [[Iran]]);<ref>Naqinezhad, AR & Kavousi, K. (2004) [http://www.sid.ir/en/VEWSSID/J_pdf/105320040208.pdf The easternmost distribution of Ophioglossum lusitanicum L., new to flora of Iran]. –''Iran Journ. Bot.'' 10 
(2): 167-171.</ref>) South America ([[Peru]] and [[Argentina]]); and [[Australasia]] ([[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]]).<ref>[http://www.discoverlife.org/20/m?kind=Ophioglossum+lusitanicum&b=EOL/pages/597760 Encyclopedia of Life: ''Ophioglossum lusitanicum'']</ref> 

The distribution in Britain is restricted to one small area of coastal heath on [[St Agnes, Isles of Scilly|St Agnes]], [[Isles of Scilly]] where it was discovered by [[John Raven]] in 1950. It grows in short turf on [[Wingletang Down (St Agnes)|Wingletang Down]] where some of the colonies are suffering from an increase of competitive grasses, gorse (''[[Ulex europaeus]]'') and bramble (''[[Rubus fruticosus]]'').<ref>Bennallick, I.J., French, C.F and Parslow, R.E. (2009) Vascular Plants. In CISFBR, ''Red Data Book for Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly''. 2nd Edition. Praze-an-Beeble: Croceago Press.</ref> ''Ophioglossum lusitanicum'' is listed on Schedule 8 of the [[Wildlife and Countryside Act]] 1981, and is within a [[Site of Special Scientific Interest]] (SSSI).

In Australasia and South America, this species is represented by a [[subspecies]], ''Ophioglossum lusitanicum'' subsp. ''coriaceum'' <small>(A. Cunn.) R.T. Clausen</small> <ref>[http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl/record/tro-26605579 The Plant List.org: ''Ophioglossum lusitanicum'' subsp. ''coriaceum'']</ref><ref>[http://nzpcn.org.nz/flora_details.asp?ID=2207 NZ Plant Conservation Network: ''Ophioglossum coriaceum'']</ref>

===Ecology===
As this species is a winter annual, it requires a warm winter environment. In its British populations, it favours thin, unshaded, peaty soils in south-facing localities.<ref>[http://www.brc.ac.uk/plantatlas/index.php?q=plant/ophioglossum-lusitanicum Online Atlas of the British Flora: ''Ophioglossum lusitanicum'']</ref> 

''Ophioglossum lusitanicum'' subsp. ''coriaceum'' has a much broader ecological range in southern Australia, where habitats include damp open sites; from coast meadows to alpine grassland..<ref>[http://pierreo.cochard.free.fr/AustralianFerns/Ophioglossum_lusit.html Ferns of New South Wales: ''Ophioglossum lusitanicum'']</ref> It is found in [[New South Wales]], [[Tasmania]], [[Queensland]], and other states.<ref>[http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Ophioglossum~lusitanicum Royal Botanic Garden Sydney: ''Ophioglossum lusitanicum'']</ref>

|synonyms_ref=<ref name=efloras>{{cite web|url=http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=5&taxon_id=200025751|title=''Oplismenus compositus''|publisher=Flora of Pakistan|accessdate=May 16, 2013}}</ref>}}

'''''Oplismenus compositus''''' (commonly known as '''running mountaingrass''') is a species of [[perennial plant]] from [[Poaceae]] family that can be found throughout  [[Asia]] ([[Pakistan]]<ref name=efloras/> [[China]]), [[Africa]], [[Australia]], [[South America]], [[Mexico]]<ref name=kew>{{cite web|url= http://www.kew.org/data/grasses-db/www/imp06755.htm|author1=W.D. Clayton |author2=M. Vorontsova |author3=K.T. Harman |author4=H. Williamson |title=''Oplismenus compositus''|publisher=GrassBase|work= The Board of Trustees, [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew|Royal Botanic Gardens]]|location=[[Kew]]|accessdate=May 15, 2013}}</ref> and [[Hawaii]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=opco2|title=Oplismenus compositus (L.) P. Beauv. Running Mountain Grass |publisher=PLANTS Profile|work=[[United States Department of Agriculture|USDA]]|accessdate=May 15, 2013}}</ref>

==Description==
The plant is {{convert|15|–|150|cm}} long. The leaves are [[lanceolate]], ovate, are {{convert|2|–|16|cm}} long and {{convert|8|–|35|mm}} wide. It leaf blades are [[Leaf#Venation (arrangement of the veins)|venated]] and have obscure cross veins with an apex which is acuminate or slightly acute. ''O. compositus'' have a [[raceme]] which is composed from [[inflorescence]]. It is borne on a side of central axis, is unilateral and is {{convert|2.5|–|11|cm}} long. The central inflorescence axis {{convert|5|–|25|cm}} long with angular [[rhachis]] and is either glabrous or pilose on the bottom. [[Spikelet]]s come in 2 rows which are fertile, pedicelled, and sessile. The pedicels are oblong. The spikelets also have one basal sterile [[floret]]s and one fertile florets while its [[rhachilla]] is not extended. They are {{convert|2.5|–|4|mm}} in length and are [[lanceolate]].<ref name=kew/>

The [[chaff|glume]] is shorter than a spikelet and thinner than fertile [[lemma (botany)|lemma]]. It lower glume is ovate with its [[awn (botany)|awn]] being {{convert|3|–|10|mm}} in length. The upper glume is also ovate, but unlike the lower, is also herbaceous with glabrous surface which can be pubescent as well. It is also obtuse and is {{convert|0|-|4|mm}} in length. Florets are {{convert|2|-|2.5|mm}} in length and are pubescent, [[emarginate gills|emarginate]], and [[mucronate]] as well. Both florets and glumes are 1-keeled, but the veins are different; Glumes are 5 while florets are 7–11. The [[fruit]] is linear and is {{convert|0.5|mm}} in length.<ref name=kew/>

Fragmenta Phytographiæ Australiæ 3: 30-31] in Latin</ref><ref>[http://www.tropicos.org/Name/40034376 Tropicos, ''Osbornia'' F. Muell.]</ref> It contains only one known species, i.e., '''''Osbornia octodonta''''', native to [[Borneo]], the  [[Philippines]], and [[Australia]] ([[Northern Territory]], [[Queensland]], and northern [[Western Australia]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=144500|title=World Checklist of Selected Plant Families: Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew|publisher=|accessdate=19 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=''Osbornia''|work= The Plant List |url=http://www.theplantlist.org/browse/A/Myrtaceae/Osbornia/ |accessdate=2011-04-10}}</ref><ref name=":0"/>

'''''Pentapogon''''' is a [[genus]] of [[Australia]]n plants in the [[Poaceae|grass family]].<ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/2954329#page/41/mode/1up Brown, Robert 1810.  Prodromus Florae Novae Hollandiae 173] in Latin</ref><ref>[http://www.tropicos.org/Name/40003903 Tropicos, Pentapogon R. Br.]</ref> The only known species is '''''Pentapogon quadrifidus'''''. It is native to every [[Australia]]n State except [[Queensland]], and is also naturalised on the [[South Island of New Zealand]].<ref name=h/><ref>[http://bie.ala.org.au/species/Pentapogon Atlas of Living Australia, Pentapogon]</ref><ref>Wilson, A. (ed.) (2009). Flora of Australia 44A: 1-410. Australian Government Publishing Service, Canberra.</ref><ref>Edgar, E & Connor, H.E. (2010). Flora of New Zealand , ed. 2, 5: 1-650. R.E.Owen, Government Printer, Wellington</ref> (A former ''Pentapogon'' species, ''Pentapogon drummondii'', is now placed in ''[[Calamagrostis]]'' as ''[[Calamagrostis drummondii]]''.)

'''Water-pepper''', '''water pepper''' or '''marshpepper knotweed''' (''Persicaria hydropiper'', [[synonymy|syn.]] ''Polygonum hydropiper'') is a plant of the family [[Polygonaceae]]. It grows in damp places and shallow water. It is a widespread plant,<!--not cosmopolitan because Africa  South America missing from list--> found in Australia, New Zealand, temperate Asia, Europe, and North America.<ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=2&taxon_id=200006723 Flora of China, ''Polygonum hydropiper'' Linnaeus, 1753.  <big>辣蓼</big> la liao ]</ref><ref>Dennis I. Morris DI (2009) Polygonaceae, version 2009:1. In MF Duretto (Ed.) Flora of Tasmania Online. 17 pp. (Tasmanian Herbarium, Tasmanian Museum & Art Gallery: Hobart). ISBN 978-1-921599-30-9 (PDF). www.tmag.tas.gov.au/floratasmania</ref><ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Persicaria%20hydropiper.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref><ref>[http://luirig.altervista.org/flora/taxa/index1.php?scientific-name=persicaria+hydropiper Altervista Flora Italiana, ''Persicaria hydropiper'' (L.) Spach] includes photos, drawings, European distribution map</ref> It has some use as a spice because of its pungent flavor.

==Description==
Water pepper is an annual herb with an erect stem growing to a height of {{convert|20|to|70|cm|0|abbr=on}}. The leaves are alternate and almost stalkless. The leaf blades are narrowly ovate and have entire margins  fringed by very short hairs. They are tapering with a blunt apex. Each leaf base has stipules which are fused into a stem-enclosing sheath that is loose and fringed at the upper end. The [[inflorescence]] is a nodding spike. The perianth of each tiny flower consists of four or five segments, united near its green base and white or pink at the edges. There are six stamens, three fused carpels and three styles. The fruit is a dark brown oval, flattened nut.<ref name=NatureGate>{{cite web |url=http://www.luontoportti.com/suomi/en/kukkakasvit/water-pepper |title=Water pepper: ''Persicaria hydropiper'' |publisher=NatureGate |accessdate=2013-12-30}}</ref>

==Active ingredients==
Water-pepper has several [[active ingredient]]s. Two bicyclic [[sesquiterpenoid]]s are present, [[polygodial]] (tadeonal, an [[saturation (chemistry)|unsaturated]] [[aldehyde|dialdehyde]] with a [[drimane]] backbone) and [[waburganal]], which has been found responsible for the pungent taste (hence its edibility).<ref name=jonasshon-1996>Jonassohn, M. (1996). Sesquiterpenoid unsaturated dialdehydes - Structural properties that affect reactivity and bioactivity. Doctoral thesis, Lund University, Sweden. ISBN 91-628-2215-2. {{cite web|url= |title=[http://www.organic.lu.se/Publications/Ph.%20D.%20theses/Jonassohn.pdf] }}[http://www.organic.lu.se/Publications/Ph.%20D.%20theses/Jonassohn.pdf] {{small|(730 [[Kibibyte|KiB]])}}</ref> The plant also contains [[rutin]], a source of the bitter taste impression.

The plant contains an [[essential oil]] (0.5%) which consists of [[monoterpenoid]]s and [[sesquiterpenoid]]s: [[alpha-Pinene|α-pinene]], [[beta-Pinene|β-pinene]], [[cineol|1,4-cineol]], [[fenchone]], [[α-humulene]], [[β-caryophyllene]], [[trans-β-bergamotene]]. [[Carboxylic acid]]s ([[cinnamic acid|cinnamic]], [[valeric acid|valeric]] and [[caproic acid]]) and their [[ester]]s were present in traces. The composition depends strongly on genetic factors.

==Edibility==
In [[Japan]] this plant's [[leaf|leaves]] are used as a [[vegetable]] - these are from the [[cultivar]], not the [[wild type]] which has a far more [[pungent]] taste. Wild waterpepper produces oils that cause skin irritation,<ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=242100096 Flora of North America]</ref> and the many acids in its tissues, including [[formic acid]], make the plant unpalatable to livestock.<ref>[http://www.illinoiswildflowers.info/weeds/plants/waterpepper.htm Illinois Wildflowers]</ref> Young red sprouts are used as a [[sashimi]] garnish, and are known as {{nihongo||紅蓼|beni-tade|red water pepper}}. Though livestock do not eat the wild type, some insects do, giving rise to the Japanese saying {{Nihongo||蓼食う虫も好き好き|Tade kuu mushi mo sukizuki|Some insects eat water pepper and like it}}, which may be translated as “There is no accounting for taste.” or more narrowly “Some prefer nettles.”

The seeds of the water-pepper may be added to [[wasabi]].
{{Commons|Persicaria hydropiper}}

'''Water-pepper sauce''' are known as {{nihongo||蓼酢|Tade-zu|water pepper vinegar}} is a sauce traditionally made from finely chopped [[Water-pepper]] leaves, soaked in [[vinegar]], and a small amount of [[rice|steamed-rice]]. Occasionally, the juice from a squeezed [[Citrus × sphaerocarpa|Kabosu]] is added. In [[Japanese cuisine]] it is traditionally used as a complement to [[grilled]] [[Freshwater fish]] (but usually not other grilled fishes).
