'''''Persicaria lapathifolia''''' ([[synonym (taxonomy)|syn.]] '''''Polygonum lapathifolium'''''), known as '''pale persicaria''',<ref name=BSBI07>{{cite web |title=BSBI List 2007 |publisher=Botanical Society of Britain and Ireland |url=http://www.bsbi.org.uk/BSBIList2007.xls |format=xls |archive-url=http://www.webcitation.org/6VqJ46atN |archive-date=2015-02-25 |accessdate=2014-10-17}}</ref>  is a plant of the family [[Polygonaceae]].  It is closely related to ''[[Persicaria maculosa]]'' and as such is considered a weed in Britain and Europe. Other common names for the plant include '''pale smartweed''', '''curlytop knotweed''', and '''willow weed'''. It is a [[cryptic species complex|species complex]] made up of a great many varying forms, sometimes considered varieties. The environment also has a strong influence on the [[Morphology (biology)|morphology]] of an individual plant.

==Description==
''Persicaria lapathifolia'' is an annual herb with erect reddish stems with swollen joints, growing to a height of {{convert|20|to|80|cm|0|abbr=on}}. The leaves are alternate with short stalks, often densely hairy underneath. The leaf blades often have a dark-coloured blotch in the centre and are lanceolate or narrowly elliptical and have entire margins. Each leaf base has stipules which are fused into a stem-enclosing sheath that is loose and fringed with few if any hairs at the upper end. The [[inflorescence]] is a dense spike, often nodding. The perianth of each tiny pink flower consists of four or five lobes, fused near the base. There are six stamens, two partially fused carpels and two styles. The fruit is a rounded, flattened nut. This plant flowers from July to September in northern temperate regions.<ref name=NatureGate>{{cite web |url=http://www.luontoportti.com/suomi/en/kukkakasvit/pale-persicaria |title=Pale persicaria: ''Persicaria lapathifolia'' |publisher=NatureGate |accessdate=2013-12-30}}</ref><ref name=lisa>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=242100098 Flora of North America, ''Persicaria lapathifolia'' (Linnaeus) Gray, 1821. Pale smartweed , renouée à feuilles de patience ]</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Persicaria lapathifolia'' is found in many parts of both the [[Old World]] and [[New World]].<ref name=lisa/><ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=5&taxon_id=242100098 Flora of Pakistan, ''Persicaria lapathifolia'' (L.) S. F. Gray]</ref><ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=2&taxon_id=200006724 Flora of China, ''Polygonum lapathifolium'' Linnaeus, 1753.  <big>马蓼</big> ma liao ]</ref><ref>[http://luirig.altervista.org/flora/taxa/index1.php?scientific-name=persicaria+lapathifolia Altervista Flora Italiana, ''Persicaria lapathifolia'' (L.) Gray] includes numerous photos plus European distribution map</ref><ref>[http://bie.ala.org.au/species/urn:lsid:biodiversity.org.au:apni.taxon:387570 Atlas of Living Australia,  ''Persicaria lapathifolia'' (L.) Gray, Pale Knotweed]</ref> Many varietal and sub-specific names have been coined, as the plant is morphologically variable. The species is found growing on the sea shore and in disturbed ground such as arable land, gardens, waste ground, rubbish tips and road verges.<ref name=NatureGate/>

| taxon = Platycerium bifurcatum
| authority = ([[Cav.]]) [[C.Chr.]]
| synonyms = }}

'''''Platycerium bifurcatum''''', the '''elkhorn fern''' or '''staghorn fern''', is a [[species]] of [[fern]] [[native plant|native]] to Java, New Guinea and southeastern Australia, in New South Wales, Queensland and on Lord Howe Island. It is a bracket [[epiphyte]] occurring in and near [[rainforest]]s. Growing to {{convert|90|cm|0|abbr=on}} tall by {{convert|80|cm|0|abbr=on}} broad, it has heart-shaped sterile fronds {{convert|12|-|45|cm|0|abbr=on}} long, and arching grey-green fertile fronds which are forked and strap-shaped, and grow up to {{convert|90|cm|0|abbr=on}} long.<ref name=RHSAZ>{{cite book|title=RHS A-Z encyclopedia of garden plants|year=2008|publisher=Dorling Kindersley|location=United Kingdom|isbn=1405332964|pages=1136}}</ref>

The [[Botanical name#Binary name|specific epithet]] ''bifurcatum'' means bifurcated or forked, referring to the fertile fronds.<ref>http://www.anbg.gov.au/gnp/interns-2004/platycerium-bifurcatum.html</ref>

''Platycerium bifurcatum'' is widely cultivated as an [[ornamental plant]] for gardens. With a minimum temperature requirement of {{convert|5|C|F|abbr=on}}, in [[temperateness|temperate]] regions it may be grown outdoors in sheltered locations, otherwise as a [[houseplant]].<ref name=RHSAZ /> It has gained the [[Royal Horticultural Society]]'s [[Award of Garden Merit]].<ref>{{cite web|title=RHS Plant Selector - ''Platycerium bifurcatum''|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=1488|accessdate=27 May 2013}}</ref>

|image = Gardenology.org-IMG 9307 rbgm10dec.jpg

|unranked_divisio = [[Flowering plant|Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]

|genus = ''[[Plectranthus]]''
|species = '''''P. argentatus'''''
|binomial = ''Plectranthus argentatus''
|binomial_authority = [[Stanley Thatcher Blake|S.T.Blake]]
|}}

'''''Plectranthus argentatus''''' ([[common name]] '''silver spurflower''') is a [[species]] of [[flowering plant]] in the [[Lamiaceae|mint]] [[family (biology)|family]]. It is [[native plant|native]] to rock outcrops and [[rainforest]] in the border region of Queensland and New South Wales, Australia. Growing to {{convert|1|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} tall and broad, it is a spreading [[deciduous]] [[shrub]]. The hairy leaves are [[ovate]] to broad-ovate, 5–11.5 cm long, 3–5.5 cm wide with [[crenate]] margins. The hairs give the plant an overall sage green to silvery colour. The flowers are borne on terminal [[raceme]]s up to {{convert|30|cm|0|abbr=on}} long, and are bluish white.<ref name=RHSAZ>{{cite book|title=RHS A-Z encyclopedia of garden plants|year=2008|publisher=Dorling Kindersley|location=United Kingdom|isbn=1405332964|pages=1136}}</ref>
<ref>Plant profile, NSW Flora Online. [http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Plectranthus~argentatus]</ref>

Originally described by Queensland botanist [[Stanley Thatcher Blake]], its [[Botanical name#Binary name|specific epithet]]  ''argentatus'' is Latin for "silver",<ref>{{cite book|author = Simpson DP| title = Cassell's Latin Dictionary  | publisher = Cassell Ltd.| year = 1979|edition = 5|location = London| isbn=0-304-52257-0}}</ref> referring to its foliage.

==Cultivation==
''Plectranthus argentatus'' is cultivated in [[temperateness|temperate]] regions as an ornamental [[bedding plant]] for its attractive silvery foliage. It strikes readily from cuttings, or can be grown from seed as a [[Hardiness (plants)|half-hardy]] annual. It has gained the [[Royal Horticultural Society]]'s [[Award of Garden Merit]].<ref>{{cite web|title=RHS Plant Selector - ''Plectranthus argentatus''|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=1491|accessdate=28 May 2013}}</ref>

Kuntze *''Majana grandifolia'' (Benth.) Kuntze *''Majana multiflora'' (Benth.) Kuntze *''Majana pumila'' (Blanco) Kuntze *''Majana scutellariodes'' (L.) Kuntze *''Majana secundiflora'' (Benth.) Kuntze *''Ocimum peltatum'' Schweigg. ex Schrank *''Ocimum scutellarioides'' L. *''Perilla nankinensis'' Wender. *''Plectranthus aromaticus'' Roxb. *''Plectranthus blumei'' (Benth.) Launert *''Plectranthus ingratus'' Blume *''Plectranthus laciniatus'' Blume *''Plectranthus nudiflorus'' (Poir.) Willd. *''Plectranthus scutellarioides'' Blume nom. illeg. *''Solenostemon blumei'' (Benth.) M.Gómez *''Solenostemon scutellarioides'' (L.) Codd }} |synonyms_ref = {{cite web |url=http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/kew-158489 |title=The Plant List: A Working List of All Plant Species |accessdate=June 19, 2014}} |}} '''''Plectranthus scutellarioides''''', commonly known as '''coleus''', is a [[species]] of [[flowering plant]] in the [[family (biology)|family]] [[Lamiaceae]] (the mint or deadnettle family), [[native plant|native]] to southeast Asia through to Australia. Typically growing to {{convert|60|-|75|cm|0|abbr=on}} tall and wide, it is a bushy, woody-based [[evergreen]] [[perennial plant|perennial]], widely grown for the highly decorative [[variegation|variegated]] leaves found in cultivated varieties. Another common name is '''painted nettle''', reflecting its relationship to deadnettles (''[[Lamium]]'' species), which are in the same family. (True nettles and their close kin are in the family [[Urticaceae]].) The [[synonym (taxonomy)|synonyms]] '''''Coleus blumei''''' and '''''Solenostemon scutellarioides''''' are also widely used names for this species. ==Description== ''Plectanthrus scutellarioides'' is an upright [[Annual plant|annual]] or short-lived [[perennial plant]] plant. It may be as much as {{cvt|1|m|ft|0}} tall, with well branched, more-or-less four-sided stems. Shorter, more trailing forms have sometimes been described as separate species, under names such as ''Coleus pumilus'' or ''Solenostemon pumilus'', but are all now considered part of the very variable ''P. scutellarioides''. The species is extremely variable in the colour and shape of the leaves. They are somewhat fleshy, varying in size from {{cvt|1.5|–|10|cm|in|1}} long by {{cvt|1|–|6|cm|in|1}} wide, generally [[Glossary of leaf morphology|ovate]] in shape, and borne on [[Petiole (botany)|petioles]] (stalks) from {{cvt|0.5|–|5|cm|in|1}} long. The leaf margin is divided to a variable degree. Hairs are present on both sides of the leaf. The [[inflorescence]] is borne on the end of a stem and, like the leaves, is very variable in size; it may be up to {{cvt|4|cm|in|1}} long, with few or many flowers. The [[Sepal|calyx]] is bell-shaped, initially only {{cvt|1|–|2|mm|in|2}} long, but lengthening to {{cvt|5|–|7|mm|in|1}} when in fruit. The bluish-purple [[petal]]s are joined to form a typical two-lipped [[Lamiaceae|labiate]] flower, {{cvt|8|–|10|mm|in|1}} long. The [[stamen]]s are joined for about half their length and are covered by the upper lip of the flower. The fruit is described as a "nutlet", and is black, about {{cvt|1|mm|in|2}} long. The leaves of the wild species may be somewhat variegated, but this has been developed to an extreme degree in cultivated varieties, whose leaves may include one or more shades of green, white, cream, yellow, pink, red, maroon and dark purple. ==Taxonomy== The species was first described by [[Carl Linnaeus]] in 1763, as ''Ocimum scutellarioides''. The genus ''[[Ocimum]]'' is best known for ''[[Ocimum basilicum]]'', sweet basil. The [[Botanical name#Binary name|specific epithet]] ''scutellarioides'' means "resembling the genus ''[[Scutellaria]]''" – a genus also in the Lamiaceae, whose name is derived from the Latin ''scutella'', meaning a small dish or bowl. Genera and species related to ''Ocimum'', placed in the tribe Ocimeae, have been the subject of considerable taxonomic confusion, and ''P. scutellarioides'' has been placed in several genera and been given multiple synonyms. [[Robert Brown (botanist, born 1773)|Robert Brown]] transferred ''O. scutellarioides'' to the genus ''[[Plectranthus]]'' in 1810. [[George Bentham]] transferred it to the genus ''Coleus'' as ''Coleus scutellarioides'' in 1830, and in 1832 also described ''Coleus blumei'', now regarded as just a variant of this species. It was transferred to ''Solenostemon'' by [[Leslie E. W. Codd]] in 1975. Placement in the genus ''Coleus'', and the name ''Coleus blumei'', led to the name "coleus", still widely used by horticulturalists and gardeners, and now treated as a [[common name]] for this species. The synonym ''Solenostemon scutellarioides'' is also widely used. Within ''Plectranthus'', [[Molecular phylogenetics|molecular phylogenetic]] studies suggest that ''P. scutellarioides'' is most closely related to ''[[Plectranthus fredericii]]'' and some other species that are purely African in distribution. ==Distribution and habitat== ''Plectranthus scutellarioides'' is native to India (including the Himalayas), Sri Lanka, China, Burma, Thailand, Laos, Vietnam, Malaysia, Indonesia and Australia. It is cultivated worldwide and sometimes naturalized in other tropical regions. In its native habitat, it is found at elevations of {{cvt|100|–|1600|m|ft}}, where it flowers and fruits throughout the year. ==Cultivation== ===History=== The species was first introduced into Europe from Java in 1851 by a Dutch horticulturalist. At this time, there were few leaf colors and shapes. A wider variety was available by 1877, when the American William Bull offered seeds at 43 US cents each. However, by selecting for seed production, early flowering was inadvertently favored, and leaf color also declined in intensity. Coleus breeding revived in the early 1940s, and by the 1980s, the availability of an improved range of cultivars led to coleus becoming the tenth most important bedding crop in the US. More recently, vegetative propagation has enabled cultivars with novel leaf colors and shapes to be offered for sale. Plants with trailing as well as upright habits are now available.{{Cite thesis |last1=Nguyen |first1=Phuong Ngoc |date=2007 |title=Genetic, Molecular and Breeding Study of Coleus (''Solenostemon scutellarioides'' (L.) Codd) during Growth and Development |type=PhD thesis |publisher=University of Florida |url=http://etd.fcla.edu/UF/UFE0021516/nguyen_p.pdf |accessdate=2017-02-16 }} ===Cultivars===
File:Coleus sp.3.jpg File:Solenostemon scutellarioides 001.jpg File:India Goa biodiversity.jpg File:Coleus sp.6.jpg File:Leaves 1.JPG File:Starr 021122-0100 Solenostemon scutellarioides.jpg File:Starr 070906-8695 Solenostemon scutellarioides.jpg File:SolenostemonCoeusMendel.jpg File:Starr 070906-8698 Solenostemon scutellarioides.jpg File:DSC 4138 - Solenostemon scutellarioides (Buntnessel).JPG
The leaves of coleus cultivars vary in color, from pale yellow to dark purple; in variegation, from almost one color to many colours; in patterning, from symmetrical to irregular; and in shape, from broad to narrow and from small-toothed to wavy margins.
The leaves of [[cultivar]]s typically show sharp contrasts between their colors; particular leaves may be several shades of green, pink, yellow, "black" (a very dark purple), maroon, cream, white, and red (somewhat resembling the unrelated ''[[Caladium]]''). The leaf shape also varies from broadly ovate to more narrowly lanceolate. The leaf margins may have small or large teeth or be wavy, as may the whole leaf. New cultivars with different leaf shapes and color combinations are constantly being created. The following cultivars have gained the [[Royal Horticultural Society]]'s [[Award of Garden Merit]]: {| |- valign=top | *'Crimson Ruffles'{{cite web|title=RHS Plant Selector - ''Solenostemon scutellarioides'' 'Crimson Ruffles'|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=4142|accessdate=4 July 2013}}       *'Lord Falmouth'{{cite web|title=RHS Plant Selector - ''Solenostemon scutellarioides'' 'Lord Falmouth'|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=5805|accessdate=4 July 2013}} *'Picturatus'{{cite web|title=RHS Plant Selector - ''Solenostemon scutellarioides'' 'Picturatus'|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=4144|accessdate=4 July 2013}} *'Pineapple Beauty'{{cite web|title=RHS Plant Selector - ''Solenostemon scutellarioides'' 'Pineapple Beauty'|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=4145|accessdate=4 July 2013}} | *'Pineapplette'{{cite web|title=RHS Plant Selector - ''Solenostemon scutellarioides'' 'Pineapplette'|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=4146|accessdate=4 July 2013}} *'Royal Scot'{{cite web|title=RHS Plant Selector - ''Solenostemon scutellarioides'' 'Royal Scot'|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=4147|accessdate=4 July 2013}} *'Walter Turner'{{cite web|title=RHS Plant Selector - ''Solenostemon scutellarioides'' 'Walter Turner'|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=4148|accessdate=4 July 2013}} *'Wisley Tapestry'{{cite web|title=RHS Plant Selector - ''Solenostemon scutellarioides'' 'Wisley Tapestry'|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=4149|accessdate=4 July 2013}} |} Green coloration is due to the amount of [[chlorophyll]] present in the chloroplasts in the leaves. Red, purple, pink, and orange colors are due to [[anthocyanins]] – water-soluble, flavonoid biosynthetic pigments, found in the foliage in addition to chlorophyll. The increase in anthocyanin production is accompanied by a decrease in chlorophyll production. The production of anthocyanins and chlorophyll is affected by light levels; the more light is present, the more anthocyanins are produced, with an inverse relationship to the production of chlorophyll. Anthocyanins are created inside the cell and facilitate [[photosynthesis]] in leaves that are exposed to very intense or prolonged sunlight by providing protection from damage caused by [[ultraviolet]] light. Some coleus cultivars over-produce anthocyanins and under-produce chlorophyll to the extent that optimal growth is prevented. ===Care=== In cultivation, plants grow well in moist well-drained soil, and are usually {{cvt|0.5|–|1|m|ft|1}} tall, though some may grow as tall as {{cvt|2|m|ft}}. Coleus are grown as [[ornamental plant]]s. They are heat-tolerant, but they do less well in full sun in subtropical areas than in the shade. In areas without freezing temperatures, plants can usually be kept as [[Perennial plant|perennials]] if well managed. In colder areas, they are often grown as [[Annual plant|annual]]s, since the plants are not hardy and become leggy with age. In bright, hot areas, the colors of the plant are typically more intense in shade than in full sun, and the plants require less water there. Coleus also make low-maintenance [[houseplant]]s, and can often be propagated by clipping a piece of stem just below the leaves and putting the stem in water to root. Young inflorescences may be removed to keep plants more compact.{{cite web|url=https://www.gardeningknowhow.com/ornamental/foliage/coleus/growing-coleus-houseplants.htm |title=Indoor Coleus Care: How To Grow A Coleus Houseplant |date= |accessdate=2017-05-09}} ===Propagation=== {{unreferenced section|date=February 2017}} There are two ways to [[plant propagation|propagate]] coleus. Seeds are inexpensive and easily obtainable, though named cultivars do not come true from seeds. To germinate seeds, simply sprinkle seeds on the soil surface and press down. Seeds require light to germinate, so should not be covered. They may be kept moist by growing in a container covered with plastic, or by misting seeds daily. Sprouts can show color in as little as two weeks. Alternatively, [[cutting (plant)|cutting]]s can be taken. Cuttings root readily in plain water, without the addition of rooting hormone (although it is still beneficial). ===Diseases=== The downy mildew ''Peronospora'' sp. makes leaves brownish and can also cause leaf curling and twisting. It is harder to control this mildew on stems compared to leaves.[http://gpnmag.com/articles/new%20disease%20attacking%20coleus.pdf] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111009115505/http://gpnmag.com/articles/new%20disease%20attacking%20coleus.pdf |date=October 9, 2011 }} Another disease is [[impatiens necrotic spot virus]] which causes brown or yellow spots on leaves, rings, black or brown stem discoloration, and brown leaf veins, ultimately resulting in plant death. The disease is spread by an insect called a [[thrips]] that carries the virus from an infected plant to an uninfected one. It only takes a few of these insects to infect a whole greenhouse.[http://www.plantpath.wisc.edu/pddc/factsheets/INSV.pdf Plant Disease Diagnostic Clinic University of Wisconsin-Madison and UW-Extension] ==Psychoactivity== ''Plectranthus scutellarioides'', under the name ''Coleus blumei'', has been reported to have very mild relaxing and/or hallucinogenic effects when consumed. The effects of the plant have not been scientifically explored in great detail, but the plant is known to have been used by the [[Mazatec people|Mazatec Indians]] of southern Mexico for its mind-altering effects.{{cite book|last=Schultes|first=Richard Evans|others=Illustrated by Elmer W. Smith|title=Hallucinogenic Plants|year=1976|publisher=Golden Press|location=New York|series=Golden Guides|isbn=978-0-307-24362-1|oclc=2761333|page=138|url=http://www.erowid.org/library/books_online/golden_guide/g131-140.shtml#COLEUS|authorlink=Richard Evans Schultes|accessdate=2011-07-22}} ==Gallery== File:Coleus inflorescence.JPG|Inflorescence File:Coleus tree.jpg|Cultivar grown as a short standard {{commons category|Solenostemon scutellarioides}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em|refs= {{Cite book |last=Hyam |first=R. |last2=Pankhurst |first2=R.J. |year=1995 |title=Plants and their names : a concise dictionary |publication-place=Oxford |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=978-0-19-866189-4 |lastauthoramp=yes }} {{cite web |url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?317146 |title=Taxon: Plectranthus scutellarioides (L.) R. Br. |website=USDA Germplasm Resources Information Network (GRIN) |accessdate=2017-02-15}} {{Citation |last1=Nguyen |first1=P. |last2=Dal Cin |first2=V. |date=2009 |title=The role of light on foliage colour development in coleus (''Solenostemon scutellarioides'' (L.) Codd) |journal=Plant Physiology and Biochemistry |volume=47 |pages=934–945 |doi=10.1016/j.plaphy.2009.06.006 |pmid=19631554 |lastauthoramp=yes }} {{Cite journal |last1=Nguyen |first1=P. |last2=Quesenberry |first2=K. |last3=Clark |first3=D. |date=2008 |title=Genetics of Growth Habit and Development of New ''Coleus'' (''Solenostemon'') Varieties with Trailing Habit and Bright Color |journal=Journal of Heredity |volume=99 |issue=6 |pages=573–580 |doi=10.1093/jhered/esn054 |pmid=18603655 |lastauthoramp=yes }} {{Cite journal |last1=Paton |first1=Alan J |last2=Springate |first2=David |last3=Suddee |first3=Somran |last4=Otieno |first4=Donald |last5=Grayer |first5=Renée J |last6=Harley |first6=Madeline M |last7=Willis |first7=Fiona |last8=Simmonds |first8=Monique S. J |last9=Powell |first9=Martyn P |last10=Savolainen |first10=Vincent |date=2004 |title=Phylogeny and evolution of basils and allies (Ocimeae, Labiatae) based on three plastid DNA regions |journal=Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution |volume=31 |issue=1 |pages=277–299 |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1055790303003099 |accessdate=2017-02-13 |doi=10.1016/j.ympev.2003.08.002 |lastauthoramp=yes }} {{cite book |title=RHS A-Z encyclopedia of garden plants |year=2008 |publisher=Dorling Kindersley |location=United Kingdom |isbn=1405332964 |page=1136}} {{Cite journal |last1=Suddee |first1=S. |last2=Paton |first2=A.J. |last3=Parnell |first3=J.A.N. |date=2004 |title=A Taxonomic Revision of Tribe Ocimeae Dumort. (Lamiaceae) in Continental South East Asia II. Plectranthinae |journal=Kew Bulletin |volume=59 |issue=3 |pages=379–414 |accessdate=2017-02-15 |doi=10.2307/4110950 |jstor=4110950 |lastauthoramp=yes }} }} [[Category:Plectranthus|scutellarioides]] [[Category:Flora of Australia]] [[Category:Flora of Indo-China]] [[Category:Flora of Malesia]] [[Category:Garden plants of Asia]] [[Category:House plants]]

'''''Pleurocarpaea''''' is a [[genus]] of Australian plants in the [[Vernonieae|evil tribe]]<ref>[http://sterlingkeeley.wordpress.com/vernonieae/ Dr. Sterling C. Keeley, University of Hawai`i, Vernonieae- The Evil Tribe]</ref> within the [[Asteraceae|daisy family]].<ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/11160647#page/468/mode/1up Bentham, George. 1867. Flora australiensis:a description of the plants of the Australian territory 3: 460-461] entirely in English</ref><ref>[http://www.tropicos.org/Name/40011745 Tropicos, Pleurocarpaea Benth.]</ref><ref>Dunlop, C.R. (1991). The genus ''Pleurocrpaea'' Benth. (Astereaceae: Vernonieae). ''Journal of the Adelaide Botanic Gardens'' 14 (1): 93-98.</ref>

;Species<ref>[http://dixon.iplantcollaborative.org/CompositaeWeb/Default.aspx?Page=AdvNameSearch Flann, C (ed) 2009+ Global Compositae Checklist ]</ref><ref>[http://bie.ala.org.au/species/urn:lsid:biodiversity.org.au:apni.taxon:108918 Atlas of Living Australia]</ref>

'''''Pleurostylia opposita''''' is a species of [[shrub]] in the [[Celastraceae|bittersweet family]].<ref>http://www.theplantlist.org/browse/A/Celastraceae/Pleurostylia/</ref> It is distributed throughout the [[India]], [[Indonesia]], [[Malaysia]], [[New Guinea]], [[Philippines]], [[Sri Lanka]], [[Thailand]], [[Vietnam]], [[Australia]] and [[China]].

'''''Pogostemon stellatus''''' is an aquatic [[Perennial plant|perennial]] herb from eastern and southeastern [[Asia]], the [[Indian Subcontinent]], [[New Guinea]], and northern [[Australia]].<ref name=k>[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=162189 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families]</ref> Because of its extensive geographic distribution, there are many different color and leaf forms of this plant in the wild. It is a highly prized and sought after [[aquatic plant]] in the aquarium trade.

|familia = [[Convolvulaceae]]
|genus = [[Polymeria]]
|species= ''P. calycina''
|binomial = ''Polymeria calycina''
|binomial_authority =

'''''Polymeria calycina''''', also known as '''Slender [[Convolvulaceae|Bindweed]]''', is a species of prostrate herbaceous vine native to northern and Eastern Australia. The species grows in [[savanna]] woodlands, open forests and occasionally grasslands.

|binomial_authority= [[Adolphe-Théodore Brongniart|Brongn.]]<ref name=APNI/>

'''''Poranthera microphylla''''' sometimes referred to as the '''Small Poranthera''', is a widespread [[Australian]] [[annual plant|annual]] [[herbaceous plant|herb]] that grows naturally in a variety of habitats. A tiny soft plant, up to 10 cm in height with weak branches. Occasionally noticed after wet winters when it comes into flower. The specific epithet ''microphylla'' refers to the very small leaves.<ref name=Robinson-2003/>

289.text:
{{Speciesbox |name=Cardwell lily
Northern Christmas lily |taxon = Proiphys amboinensis |image = Cardwell Lilies.JPG |image_caption = ''Proiphys amboinensis'' in [[Cooktown]] Queensland |authority = (L.) Herb. |synonyms=*''Amaryllis rotundifolia'' Lam. *''Cearia amboinensis'' (L.) Dumort. *''Cepa amboinensis'' (L.) Kuntze *''Crinum nervosum'' L'Hér. *''Eurycles alata'' Sweet *''Eurycles amboinensis'' (L.) Lindl. ex Loudon *''Eurycles australasica'' (Ker Gawl.) G.Don *''Eurycles coronata'' Sweet *''Eurycles javanica'' M.Roem. *''Eurycles nervosa'' G.Don *''Eurycles nuda'' Sweet *''Eurycles rotundifolia'' M.Roem. *''Pancratium amboinense'' L. *''Pancratium australasicum'' Ker Gawl. *''Pancratium nervifolium'' Salisb. *''Pancratium ovatifolium'' Stokes *''Stemonix nervosus'' (L'Hér.) Raf. |synonyms_ref=[http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/kew-285743 The Plant List] |}} '''''Proiphys amboinensis''''' ([[synonymy|syn.]] ''Eurycles amboinensis'') was named after the island of Ambiona, now [[Ambon Island|Ambon]], in [[Indonesia]]. Common names include '''Cardwell lily''' and '''northern Christmas lily''' (as it usually flowers around Christmas). It is considered native to [[Thailand]], [[Indonesia]] ([[Maluku Islands|Maluku]], [[Sulawesi]], [[Bali]], [[Lombok]], [[Timor]]), the [[Philippines]], the [[Bismark Archipelago]], [[Vanuatu]], [[New Guinea]], [[Queensland]] and [[Western Australia]]. Is also naturalized in [[Seychelles]], [[Sri Lanka]], [[Solomon Islands]], [[Niue]], [[Society Islands]], [[Caroline Islands]] and [[Mariana Islands]].[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=285743 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families]Fay, Michael F. and Mark W. Chase. 1996. Resurrection of Themidaceae for the ''Brodiaea'' alliance, and Recircumscription of Alliaceae, Amaryllidaceae and Agapanthoideae. Taxon 45 (3):441-451. ==Description== ''Proiphys amboinensis'' produces nearly circular leaves followed by attractive scented white flowers with yellow throats. The larger leaves can be over 25 cm long have a leaf stem up to 46 cm long. The pure white flowers are 5 cm wide each with up to 18 flowers in a cluster on stalks over 50 cm. long. Flowering typically begins in late December and is followed by the production of green to blackish capsules 25–30 mm across. The leaves die away in the dry season.Beasley, John. 2006. ''Plants of Tropical North Queensland: the Compact Guide''. Footloose Publications, Kuranda. ISBN 1-876617-13-6.Herbert, William. 1821. Appendix 42, ''Proiphys amboinensis''[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/358310#page/303/mode/1up Linnaeus, Carl von. 1753, Species Plantarum 1: 291. ''Pancratium amboinense'' ] Rafinesque, Constantine Samuel. 1833. Atlantic Journal, and Friend of Knowledge, Philadelphia 165, ''Stemonix nervosus'' [http://www.anbg.gov.au/gnp/gnp14/proiphys-genus.html Australian National Botanic Gardens and Centre for Australian National Biodiversity Research, The genus ''Proiphus''][http://bie.ala.org.au/species/urn:lsid:biodiversity.org.au:apni.taxon:306345# Atlas of Living Australia, ''Proiphys amboinensis'' (L.) Herb.] ==Cultivation and uses== ''Proiphys amboinensis'' prefers open, lightly shaded rainforest. It grows quickly after the arrival of the wet season The plant prefers a fairly well shaded position. A good container plant. Needs lots of water in the growing season. Propagate from seed or lift the bulb.Scarth-Johnson, Vera. 2000. ''National Treasures: Flowering Plants of Cooktown and Northern Australia''. Vera Scarth-Johnson Gallery Association. ISBN 0-646-39726-5 (pbk.) ISBN 0-646-39725-7 Limited Edition - Leather Bound. [[File:Cardwell Lily flower.JPG|thumb|center|Cardwell Lily flower]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} * [[Category:Flora of Australia]] [[Category:Flora of Papuasia]] [[Category:Flora of Malesia]] [[Category:Amaryllidoideae]] [[Category:Asparagales of Australia]]

[[File:Prostanthera phylicifolia 01 Pengo.jpg|thumb|''[[Prostanthera phylicifolia]]'']]
[[File:Prostanthera magnifica KP gnangarra-10.jpg|thumb|''[[Prostanthera magnifica]]'']]
'''''Prostanthera''''', commonly known as '''mintbush''' or '''mint bush''', is a [[genus]] of [[flowering plant]]s of the [[family (biology)|family]] Lamiaceae. There are about 90 species within the genus, all of which are [[endemism|endemic]]  to Australia. The word is derived from the Greek for an appendage. Within the flowers are small spur-like appendages on the [[anther]]s.<ref>Les Robinson, ''Field Guide to the Native Plants of Sydney'', ISBN 978-0-7318-1211-0 page 180</ref>

They are bushy, [[evergreen]] [[shrubs]], usually with strongly aromatic leaves, and 2-lipped, 5-lobed flowers. They are cultivated as [[ornamental plants|ornamentals]] and for essential oils and spices. All require varying degrees of winter protection in [[temperateness|temperate]] regions, and are usually grown under glass.<ref name=RHSAZ>{{cite book|title=RHS A–Z encyclopedia of garden plants|year=2008|publisher=Dorling Kindersley|location=United Kingdom|isbn=1405332964|pages=1136}}</ref>

''Prostanthera'' species are used as food plants by the [[larva]]e of [[Hepialidae|hepialid]] [[moth]]s of the genus ''[[Aenetus]]'' including ''A. eximia'' and ''A. ligniveren''.

291.text:
{{taxobox
|image = Prostanthera cuneata.jpg
|image_caption = ''Prostanthera cuneata'', [[Mount Baw Baw]], Victoria
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]]
|ordo = [[Lamiales]]
|familia = [[Lamiaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Prostanthera]]''
|species = '''''P. cuneata'''''
|binomial = ''Prostanthera cuneata''
|binomial_authority = [[Benth]]<ref name=APNI/>
|}}

'''''Prostanthera cuneata''''' ('''alpine mint bush''' or '''rough mint bush''') is a [[species]] of [[flowering plant]] in the [[family (biology)|family]] Lamiaceae, [[native plant|native]] to south-eastern Australia.<ref name=NSW>{{cite web |url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Prostanthera~cuneata |title=''Prostanthera cuneata'' |accessdate=2009-12-08 |author=|work= PlantNET - New South Wales Flora Online |publisher=Royal Botanic Gardens & Domain Trust, Sydney Australia}}</ref> It is a bushy [[evergreen]] [[shrub]] with a compact habit, growing to {{convert|90|cm|0|abbr=on}} both in height and width. The leaves have a rounded apex and cuneate base and are 4 to 5 mm long and 3 to 3.5 mm wide.<ref name=NSW/> The leaves are strongly aromatic when crushed.<ref name=RHSAZ>{{cite book|title=RHS A-Z encyclopedia of garden plants|year=2008|publisher=Dorling Kindersley|location=United Kingdom|isbn=1405332964|pages=1136}}</ref> Flowers are produced from November to April (mid-spring to mid-autumn) in the species' native range. These are solitary and axillary, and clustered toward the end of the stems. They are {{convert|10|-|15|cm|0|abbr=on}} long, and white with multiple purple to red coloured spots in the throat.<ref name=NSW/>

The [[Botanical name#Binary name|specific epithet]] ''cuneata'' means "wedge-shaped".<ref name=RHSLG>{{cite book|last=Harrison|first=Lorraine|title=RHS Latin for gardeners|year=2012|publisher=Mitchell Beazley|location=United Kingdom|isbn=9781845337315|pages=224}}</ref>

The species was first formally described by botanist [[George Bentham]] in 1848 in ''[[Prodromus Systematis Naturalis Regni Vegetabilis]]''.<ref name =APNI>{{cite web |url=http://www.anbg.gov.au/cgi-bin/apni?TAXON_NAME=Prostanthera+cuneata|title= ''Prostanthera cuneata'' |accessdate=2009-12-08 | work=[[Australian Plant Name Index]] (APNI), IBIS database|publisher = Centre for Plant Biodiversity Research, Australian Government, Canberra}}</ref> It occurs in alpine and subalpine closed heath and shrubland in [[granite]]-based soils in New South Wales and Victoria, often in association with snow gums (''[[Eucalyptus pauciflora]]'').<ref name=TAS/><ref name=NSW/> In Tasmania, the species is listed as "presumed to be extinct" under the state's [[Threatened Species Protection Act 1995]].<ref name=TAS>{{cite web|title=''Prostanthera cuneata''|work=Threatened Flora of Tasmania|publisher=Department of Primary Industries, Parks, Water and Environment (Tasmanaia)|url=http://www.dpipwe.tas.gov.au/inter.nsf/Attachments/SSKA-76H7VH/$FILE/Prostanthera%20cuneata.pdf|accessdate=20 February 2013}}</ref>

In cultivation this plant has gained the [[Royal Horticultural Society]]'s [[Award of Garden Merit]].<ref name="plantselector">{{cite web|title=''Prostanthera cuneata'' AGM|work=Plant Selector|publisher=Royal Horticultural Society|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=3470|accessdate=20 February 2013}}</ref> It has an [[hardiness (plants)#Hardiness ratings|RHS hardiness rating]] of H3 (half hardy)<ref name="plantselector"/> and is suited to [[USDA hardiness zone]]s 8 to 9.<ref name="Turner1999">{{cite book|editor=Turner, R.J. |editor2=Wasson E.|title=Botanica: the illustrated A-Z of over 10,000 garden plants and how to cultivate them|year=1999|edition=3|publisher=Gordon Cheers|isbn=978-0-09-183616-0}}</ref>

    }}
|synonyms_ref = <ref>{{citation
|url=http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/kew-165761
|title=The Plant List: A Working List of All Plant Species
|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref>

'''''Prostanthera rotundifolia''''' ('''roundleaf mint bush''') is a [[species]] of [[flowering plant]] in the [[family (biology)|family]] Lamiaceae, one of about 90 Australian [[endemism|endemic]] species from the [[genus]] ''[[Prostanthera]]''. Its native distribution is in South Australia, New South Wales, Victoria and Tasmania. The species is listed as vulnerable in Tasmania.

It is an [[evergreen]], branched [[shrub]], which may reach up to {{convert|4|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} tall by {{convert|3|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} broad.<ref name=RHSAZ>{{cite book|title=RHS A-Z encyclopedia of garden plants|year=2008|publisher=Dorling Kindersley|location=United Kingdom|isbn=1405332964|pages=1136}}</ref> It has dark green, strongly aromatic, round leaves {{Convert|4|-|10|mm}} long, and cup-shaped purple flowers 1 cm across between September and October.

The [[Botanical name#Binary name|specific epithet]] ''rotundifolia'' means "rounded leaves".<ref name=RHSLG>{{cite book|last=Harrison|first=Lorraine|title=RHS Latin for gardeners|year=2012|publisher=Mitchell Beazley|location=United Kingdom|isbn=9781845337315|pages=224}}</ref>

In cultivation it has gained the [[Royal Horticultural Society]]'s [[Award of Garden Merit]].<ref>{{cite web|title=RHS Plant Selector - ''Prostanthera rotundifolia''|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=3472|accessdate=27 June 2013}}</ref> In [[temperateness|temperate]] regions it must be grown in a frost-free environment.

Essential oils can be extracted from the leaves.

Seem.|work=ITIS Standard Reports|publisher=[[Integrated Taxonomic Information System]]|accessdate=March 23, 2009}}</ref>

'''''Psydrax odorata''''', known as '''''alahe{{okina}}e''''' in [[Hawaiian language|Hawaiian]], is a species of [[flowering plant|flowering]] [[shrub]] or small [[tree]] in the [[Coffea|coffee]] family, [[Rubiaceae]].<ref name="USDA">{{cite web |url=http://plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=PSOD|title=''Psydrax odorata'' (G. Forst.) A.C. Sm. & S. Darwin|work=The PLANTS Database|publisher=[[United States Department of Agriculture|USDA]]|accessdate=March 23, 2009}}</ref> It is native to the [[Pacific Islands]], [[New Guinea]] and [[Australia]].<ref name=WCSP/><ref name="Auwahi">{{cite paper|url= http://www.hear.org/naturalareas/auwahi/ethnobotany_of_auwahi.pdf|format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]]|title=Auwahi: Ethnobotany of a Hawaiian Dryland Forest|first=A. C.|last=Medeiros|author2=C.F. Davenport |author3=C.G. Chimera |publisher=Cooperative National Park Resources Studies Unit, [[University of Hawaii at Manoa|University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa]]|year=1998}}</ref>

==Description==
The species range from {{convert|6|-|30|ft|m|abbr=on}} in height, has a spread of {{convert|3|-|7|ft|m|abbr=on}},<ref name=hawaii>{{cite web|url=http://www2.hawaii.edu/~eherring/hawnprop/psy-odor.htm|title=''Psydrax odorata''|work=Hawaiian Native Plant Propagation Database|publisher=[[University of Hawaii at Manoa|University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa]]|accessdate=March 23, 2009}}</ref> and a trunk width of up to {{convert|4|in|cm|abbr=on}}.<ref name="CFTH">{{cite web|url= http://www.ctahr.hawaii.edu/forestry/trees/CommonTreesHI/CFT_Canthium_odoratum.pdf|format=PDF|title=Alaheʻe|first=Elbert L.|last=Little Jr.|author2=Roger G. Skolmen |work=Common Forest Trees of Hawaii (Native and Introduced)|publisher=[[United States Forest Service]]|year=1989}}</ref> The leaves are glossy green in colour, are up to {{convert|3.5|in}} long and elliptic. The [[fruit]]s of the plant are quite round, are black in colour and 3/8 wide.<ref name=hawaii/>

==Ecology==
The fruits produce many seeds which are often attacked by the [[larva]]e of [[Alucita objurgatella|Orneodes objurgatella]], a species of moth.<ref name=hawaii/>

==Habitat==
The species can be found growing in dry shrub land and in dry to moist forests at elevations of up to {{convert|2700|ft|-2}}.<ref name=hawaii/>

==Uses==
[[Native Hawaiians]] used the very hard wood of ''alahe{{okina}}e'' to make ''ko{{okina}}i alahe{{okina}}e'' ([[adze]]s for cutting softer woods such as ''[[Wiliwili|Erythrina sandwicensis]]''), ''{{okina}}ō{{okina}}ō'' ([[digging stick]]s), and ''{{okina}}o'' (short [[spear]]s). A black dye was made from the [[Leaf|leaves]].<ref name="Auwahi"/>

'''''Pteris ensiformis''''', the '''slender brake''',<ref>{{PLANTS|id=PTEN|taxon=Pteris ensiformis|accessdate=15 October 2015}}</ref> '''silver lace fern''', '''sword brake fern''', or '''slender brake fern''', is a plant species in the genus [[Pteridoideae]] subfamily of the [[Pteridaceae]].<ref name=Christenhusz-2011/>  It is found in [[Asia]] and the Pacific.

==Uses==
===Beverages===
It is the most common ingredient of traditional herbal drinks in Taiwan containing different phenolic compounds : [[kaempferol]] 3-O-α-l-rhamnopyranoside-7-O-[α-d-apiofuranosyl-(1-2)-β-d-glucopyranoside], 7-O-[[caffeic acid|caffeoyl]][[hydroxymaltol]] 3-O-β-d-glucopyranoside, [[hispidin]] 4-O-β-d-glucopyranoside, [[kaempferol]] 3-O-α-l-rhamnopyranoside-7-O-β-d-glucopyranoside, [[caffeic acid]], [[5-O-caffeoylquinic acid]], [[3,5-di-O-caffeoylquinic acid]] and [[4,5-di-O-caffeoylquinic acid]].<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Chen | first1 = Y. | last2 = Chang | first2 = F. | last3 = Lin | first3 = Y. | last4 = Wang | first4 = L. | last5 = Chen | first5 = J. | last6 = Wu | first6 = Y. | last7 = Wu | first7 = M. | title = Identification of phenolic antioxidants from Sword Brake fern (''Pteris ensiformis'' Burm.) | doi = 10.1016/j.foodchem.2007.03.055 | journal = Food Chemistry | volume = 105 | pages = 48 | year = 2007 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref>

This plant is resistant to [[arsenic]]-induced oxidative stress.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Singh | first1 = N. | last2 = Ma | first2 = L. Q. | last3 = Srivastava | first3 = M. | last4 = Rathinasabapathi | first4 = B. | title = Metabolic adaptations to arsenic-induced oxidative stress in ''Pteris vittata'' L and ''Pteris ensiformis'' L | doi = 10.1016/j.plantsci.2005.08.013 | journal = Plant Science | volume = 170 | issue = 2 | pages = 274 | year = 2006 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref>

[[Benzoyl-beta-D-glucoside]], as well as [[pterosin]] [[sesquiterpene]]s can be found in ''P. ensiformis''.<ref>{{Cite journal 
| last1 = Chen | first1 = Y. H.
| last2 = Chang | first2 = F. R. 
| last3 = Lu | first3 = M. C. 
| last4 = Hsieh | first4 = P. W. 
| last5 = Wu | first5 = M. J. 
| last6 = Du | first6 = Y. C. 
| last7 = Wu | first7 = Y. C. 
| doi = 10.3390/molecules13020255 
| title = New Benzoyl Glucosides and Cytotoxic Pterosin Sesquiterpenes from ''Pteris ensiformis'' Burm 
| journal = Molecules 
| volume = 13 
| issue = 2 
| pages = 255–266 
| year = 2008 
| pmid = 18305416
| pmc = 
}}</ref>

===Cultivation===
''Pteris ensiformis'' is cultivated as an [[ornamental plant]] for tropical and [[subtropical climate]] gardens, and as a [[house plant]].
;Cultivars
* ''Pteris ensiformis'' 'Victoriae', the Victoria fern
* ''Pteris ensiformis'' 'Evergemiensis'

295.text:
[[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], [[Australia]] contains approximately 32,000 hectares<ref>http://www.vicrainforest.org/</ref> of [[temperate rainforest]] in various regions. The areas with rainforest include: [[East Gippsland]], [[Strzelecki Ranges]], [[Wilsons Promontory]], [[Central Highlands (Victoria)|Central Highlands]], and [[Otway Ranges]]. The rainforests vary between cool temperate, warm temperate, and mixed cool temperate.

== Protection ==
In Victorian forests subject to timber harvesting operations rainforest is protected by the Code of Practice for Timber Production (DSE 2007), which requires that:

:"Rainforest communities in Victoria must not be harvested. Rainforest communities must be protected from the impacts of harvesting through the use of appropriate buffers to maintain microclimatic conditions and protect from disease and other disturbance."

However, mixed cool temperate rainforest has not been completely mapped in Victoria, and no pre-logging surveys occur to check for this forest type. Old growth forest, with trees dating from pre-1900s, are also meant to be protected.

Victorian rainforests occurring inside national parks are protected from logging.

Rainforest does not regenerate following clearfell, [[Clearcutting|coupe logging]], which is practiced in Victoria.

== Plant species == 

There are many plant species found in the various rainforests of Victoria, which differentiate it from [[wet sclerophyll forest]]. This is a combined list of differential species from the various rainforest areas in Victoria.<ref>''A Field Guide to Rainforest Identification in Victoria.'' 2008. David Cameron. Department of Sustainability and Environment. ISBN 978-1-74208-899-0</ref>

296.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = Large River Buttercup
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|ordo = [[Ranunculales]]
|familia = [[Ranunculaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Ranunculus]]''
|species = '''''R. papulentus'''''
|binomial = ''Ranunculus papulentus''
|binomial_authority = [[Ronald Melville|Melville]]
|}}

'''''Ranunculus papulentus''''', commonly known as the '''large river buttercup''', is a [[buttercup]] that is [[endemism|endemic]] to south-eastern [[Australia]].

==Description==
The large river buttercup is an upright [[perennial]] [[Herbaceous plant|herb]] 10–25 cm in height with underground [[stolon]]s. The flowering stems are slender and erect, 3–30 cm in height. It has 2-4 [[flower]]s with spreading, glossy yellow [[petal]]s.<ref name=AMLR>Adelaide and Mount Lofty Ranges Threatened Species Profile</ref>

It has [[leaf|leaves]] with lamina 2–4 cm long.  The three primary segments each have 3–5 lobes or teeth, or are rarely entire.  The [[petiole (botany)|petiole]] is usually 4–25 cm long.  The petals are 7–12 mm long and 2–4 mm wide. The [[nectar]]y lobes are elliptical or semicircular.  It usually has 12–36 [[achene]]s, 1.7–3.6 mm long, with the lateral faces irregularly wrinkled or pitted, or rarely smooth, and when mature often pale and thickened along the dorsal ridge.<ref name=NSWFOL>New South Wales Flora Online</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
It has been recorded from [[New South Wales]], [[Victoria, Australia|Victoria]], [[South Australia]] and the [[Australian Capital Territory]].  It occurs in [[freshwater]] [[wetland]] environments, on mud or in pools.<ref name=AMLR/>

==Biology and ecology==
Flowering may occur from spring to autumn.<ref name=NSWFOL/>  The plant has a [[rhizome|rhizomatous]] habit which aids its spread.<ref name=AMLR/>

{{taxobox |image = Rhus taitensis, flowering.jpg |regnum = [[Plant]]ae |unranked_divisio = [[Flowering plant|Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]] |ordo = [[Sapindales]] |familia = [[Anacardiaceae]] |genus = ''[[Sumac|Rhus]]'' |species = '''''R. taitensis''''' |binomial = ''Rhus taitensis'' |binomial_authority = [[Jean Baptiste Antoine Guillemin|Guill.]] ''Rhus taitensis'' was first named and described in ''Annales des Sciences Naturelles; Botanique'' sér. 2, 7: 361. 1837 {{ cite web |url=http://www.ipni.org:80/ipni/idPlantNameSearch.do?id=78196-3 |title=Plant Name Details for ''Rhus taitensis'' |quote=Crescit in ins. Taiti (Bertero et Moerenh) |work=[[International Plant Names Index|IPNI]] |accessdate=June 12, 2011}} {{ cite web |url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?101813 |title=''Rhus taitensis'' information from NPGS/GRIN |author=[[Germplasm Resources Information Network|GRIN]] |work=Taxonomy for Plants |publisher=[[United States Department of Agriculture|USDA]], [[Agricultural Research Service|ARS]], National Genetic Resources Program |location=National Germplasm Resources Laboratory, [[Beltsville, Maryland]] |date=May 9, 2011 |accessdate=May 15, 2011}} |synonyms = ''Rhus retusa'' [[Heinrich Zollinger|Zoll.]] ex [[Adolf Engler|Engl.]]
''Rhus rufa'' [[Johannes Elias Teijsmann|Teijsm.]] & [[Simon Binnendijk|Binn.]] : List sources : ''Rhus retusa'' in ''Monographiae Phanerogamarum'' 4 1883 {{ cite web |url=http://www.ipni.org:80/ipni/idPlantNameSearch.do?id=78031-3 |title=Plant Name Details for ''Rhus retusa'' Engl. |quote=Java (Zoll. Pl. jav., n. 3463 in herb. var.); Celebes, in peninsula borealis Monado (Teysm. in herb. Bogor., herb. Lugd. bat. atque herb. Monac.). Australia, Rockingham's Bay (F. von Muell. in herb. var.). [Note: Not validly published by Teysmann & Binnendijk, Cat. Pl. Hort. Bot. Bogor. (1866) 230.] |work=IPNI |accessdate=May 15, 2011}} ''Rhus retusa'' in ''Catalogus Plantarum quae in Horto Botanico Bogoriensi Coluntur'' 230. 1866 [[Bogor|Buitenzorg]] {{ cite web |url=http://www.ipni.org:80/ipni/idPlantNameSearch.do?id=70816-1 |title=Plant Name Details for ''Rhus retusa" Zoll. ex Teijsm. & Binn. |work=IPNI |accessdate=May 15, 2011}} ''Rhus rufa'' in ''Natuurkundig Tijdschrift voor Nederlandsch Indië'' 27. 1864 {{ cite web |url=http://www.ipni.org:80/ipni/idPlantNameSearch.do?id=78153-3 |title=Plant Name Details for ''Rhus rufa'' |quote=Monado; nom. incol. Kajoe-Kambing. |work=[[International Plant Names Index|IPNI]] |accessdate=May 15, 2011}} }} '''''Rhus taitensis''''' is a small [[tree]] or [[shrub]] in the [[Anacardiaceae|sumac family]] of plants. It is found from tropical [[Asia]], to [[Australia]] and many islands of the [[Pacific ocean]]. The chemical [[tetrahydroxysqualene]] from dried and ground parts of ''R. taitensis'' has ''[[in vitro]]'' activity against ''[[Mycobacterium tuberculosis]]''{{ cite journal |author1=Noro J.C. |author2=Barrows L.R. |author3=Gideon O.G. |author4=Ireland C.M. |author5=Koch M. |author6=Matainaho T. |author7=Piskaut P. |author8=Pond C.D. |author9=Bugni T.S. |title=Tetrahdroxysqualene from Rhus taitensis shows antimycobacterial activity against Mycobacterium tuberculosis |journal=Journal of Natural Products |year=2008 |issue=71 |pages=1623–1624 |accessdate=May 15, 2011 |pmc=2807728 |pmid=18710283 |doi=10.1021/np800082e}} and the plant has been used in [[folk medicine]] locally to treat [[diarrhea]] and [[hearing loss]].{{cite web|author=James A. Duke |title=''Rhus taitensis'' (ANACARDIACEAE) |publisher=Dr. Duke's Phytochemical and Ethnobotanical Databases |url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/duke/ethnobot.pl?ethnobot.taxon=Rhus%20taitensis |accessdate=May 15, 2011}} ==Distribution== The native range of ''R. taitensis'' includes Asian countries, such as [[Indonesia]] (in the [[Sulawesi]], [[Irian Jaya]], eastern [[Java]], the [[Lesser Sunda Islands]], and the [[Moluccas]]), [[Malaysia]], [[Papua New Guinea]], and the [[Philippines]]; western and south central Pacific island locales, such as the [[Society Islands]] of [[French Polynesia]] (the type specimens were collected from the island of [[Tahiti]] by [[Carlo Luigi Giuseppe Bertero]] and [[J. A. Moerenhout]] during an expedition described in Moerenhout's book entitled ''Voyages aux îles du Grand Océan''),{{ cite book |author=J.A. Moerenhout |title=Voyages aux îles du Grand Océan |year=1837 |location=Paris}} [[Niue]], [[Palau]] and others within [[Micronesia]], and the [[Solomon Islands]]; and [[Australia]] (in northeastern [[Queensland]]). ==References== {{commons category}} {{reflist}} [[Category:Rhus|taitensis]] [[Category:Plants described in 1837]] [[Category:Flora of Australia]] [[Category:Flora of French Polynesia]] [[Category:Flora of Malesia]] [[Category:Flora of Niue]] [[Category:Flora of Palau]] [[Category:Flora of Papuasia]] [[Category:Medicinal plants]] {{Anacardiaceae-stub}}

| binomial = ''Rhynchosia minima''
| binomial_authority = ([[L.]]) [[DC.]]

'''''Rhynchosia minima''''' is a species of flowering plant in the [[Fabaceae|legume family]] known by the common names '''least snout-bean''', '''burn-mouth-vine''', and '''jumby-bean'''.<ref name=grin>[http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?31750 ''Rhynchosia minima''.] Germplasm Resources Information Network.</ref> It can be found on every continent.<ref name=morris>Morris, J. B. (2008). [http://naldc.nal.usda.gov/download/44528/PDF ''Rhynchosia minima'' (L.) DC. - regeneration, characterization and potential uses for natural products and flavonoids.] ''Plant Genetic Resources Newsletter'' 153 15-19.</ref> It is [[introduced species|naturalized]] in [[Hawaii]].<ref name=pier>[http://www.hear.org/pier/species/rhynchosia_minima.htm ''Rhynchosia minima''.] Pacific Island Ecosystems at Risk.</ref>

This perennial herb has twining or trailing stems which can reach 1.2 meters in length. The leaves are made up of three leaflets measuring up to 3<ref name=fao>[http://www.fao.org/ag/AGP/AGPC/doc/Gbase/data/pf000060.htm ''Rhynchosia minima''.] FAO.</ref> to 3.5 centimeters long.<ref name=woods>Woods, M. and J. Key. (2009). [http://www.phytologia.org/Phytologia%20PDFs/91%281%29pdfFiles/91%281%293-17WoodsRhynchosia.pdf The genus ''Rhynchosia'' (Fabaceae) in Alabama.] ''Phytologia'' 91(1).</ref> The [[inflorescence]] is a [[raceme]] of up to 15 flowers. The flowers are yellow with purple or brown veining and measure up to 8 millimeters long. The fruit is one or two centimeters long.<ref name=fao/><ref name=woods/>

This common plant is used as animal forage.<ref name=fao/><ref name=morris/>

'''''Rubus parvifolius''''', called '''Japanese bramble, '''or''' Australian raspberry ''' in the United States<ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=200011513 Flora of North America, ''Rubus parvifolius'' Linnaeus, 1753.  Japanese bramble, Australian raspberry or bramble ]</ref> or '''native raspberry''' in Australia<ref name=matilda/> is a species of plants in the [[Rosaceae|rose family]]. It is a scrambling shrub native to eastern Asia (China, Japan, Korea, Vietnam) and Australia.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?32409 |title=USDA GRIN Taxonomy |accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=tabby>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=2&taxon_id=200011513 Flora of China, ''Rubus parvifolius'' Linnaeus, 1753.  <big>茅莓</big> mao mei ]</ref><ref name=matilda>[http://bie.ala.org.au/species/urn:lsid:biodiversity.org.au:apni.taxon:377756# Atlas of Living Australia]</ref> It has also become naturalized in a few scattered locations in the United States.<ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Rubus%20parvifolius.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref>

''Rubus parvifolius'' is a shrub up to 2 meters tall with arching branches armed with curved prickles. Young stems are finely pubescent, becoming hairless with age. The leaves are pinnate with 3 to 5 toothed leaflets. Flowers are numerous, in clumps at the end of stems, and have red or pink petals. The red fruit is 1 cm wide.<ref name=tabby/><ref>[http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Rubus~parvifolius PlantNET, ''Rubus parvifolius'' plant profile]</ref>

==Uses==
The red fruit is pleasantly flavored and can be eaten raw or used in [[sauces]] and [[jams]]. The dried fruit are used in [[traditional Chinese medicine]].<ref>{{citation |chapter=''Rubus parvifolius'' |chapter-url=http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=2&taxon_id=200011513 |title=Flora of China online |author1=Cuizhi Gu |author2=Chaoluan Li |author3=Lingdi Lu |author4=Shunyuan Jiang |author5=Crinan Alexander |author6=Bruce Bartholomew |author7=Anthony R. Brach |author8=David E. Boufford |author9=Hiroshi Ikeda |author10=Hideaki Ohba |author11=Kenneth R. Robertson |author12=Steven A. Spongberg  |last-author-amp=yes |accessdate=16 May 2015 |year=2003 |volume=9}}</ref>
It has shown [[hepatoprotective]] and [[antioxidant]] activities in studies on mice.<ref>Gao J, Sun CR, Yang JH, Shi JM, Du YG, Zhang YY, Li JH, Wan HT.,"Evaluation of the hepatoprotective and antioxidant activities of Rubus parvifolius L."  J Zhejiang Univ Sci B. 2011 Feb;12(2):135-42</ref>

301.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = Atherton Raspberry
|image = Rubus probus fruit1.JPG
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Rosales]]
|familia = [[Rosaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Rubus]]''
|species = '''''R. probus'''''
|binomial = ''Rubus probus''
|binomial_authority=[[L.H.Bailey]] 1923
|}}

'''''Rubus probus''''' (syn. ''[[Rubus muelleri]]''), or '''Atherton Raspberry''', is a wild tropical [[raspberry]] species native to [[Papua New Guinea]] and [[Australia]].<ref>{{cite web | title = ''Rubus probus'' | url = http://anpsa.org.au/r-pro.html | publisher = [[Australian Native Plants Society]] | date = 21 October 2014 }}</ref><ref>[http://bie.ala.org.au/species/urn:lsid:biodiversity.org.au:apni.taxon:260265# Atlas of Living Australia, ''Rubus probus'' L.H.Bailey, Wild Raspberry]</ref>

Atherton raspberry is upright in habit and exhibits low thorniness in comparison to most ''[[Rubus]]'' species. The leaves are shiny and compound. It produces an edible red berry. <ref>Bailey, Liberty Hyde. 1923. Gentes Herbarum; Occasional Papers on the Kinds of Plants 1(4): 150–151</ref>

It has been commercially cultivated to a limited extent in Australia as a cool season [[punnet]] fruit.

==Weed risk==
There is concern that ''R. probus'' could become a rampant environmental [[weed]], similar to [[blackberry]], when grown outside of its natural range.

|''Rubus linearifolius'' <small>Hayata </small>

'''''Rubus rosifolius''''', (sometimes spelled ''Rubus rosaefolius''), also known as '''roseleaf bramble''', '''Mauritius raspberry''', '''thimbleberry''' and '''bramble of the Cape'''<ref>{{citation |url=https://npgsweb.ars-grin.gov/gringlobal/taxonomydetail.aspx?id=32436 |title=USDA GRIN Taxonomy |accessdate=10 August 2016}}</ref> is a prickly subshrub native to rainforest and tall open forest of the [[Himalayas]], [[East Asia]], and eastern [[Australia]]. It is also found abundantly in the [[Brazil]]ian states [[Minas Gerais]], [[Rio de Janeiro (state)|Rio de Janeiro]] and to the south as far as [[Rio Grande do Sul]].<ref>Frutas Brasileiras e Exóticas Cultivadas, Harri Lorenzi et al., Instituto Plantarum de Estudos da Flora, 2006</ref> The plant can also be found in a lot of San Francisco neighborhoods. This plants also grows in the wild in [[Puerto Rico]].

Rose-leaf bramble leaves are compound with toothed margins, with glandular-hairs on both sides of leaflets. Flowers are white in panicles or solitary.<ref>[http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Rubus~rosifolius  PlantNET, ''Rubus rosifolius'' plant profile]</ref> Edible fruit are 2 cm long.

Leaves stay green and fruits ripen in early autumn in Eastern Australia.

==Uses==
Although ''R. rosifolius'' is rarely cultivated, the plant has several uses. The fruit is sweet and pleasant flavoured when grown with good soil moisture. The fruit is also sold at markets in the Himalayas.<ref>Gamble, J. S., ''A Manual of Indian Timbers'', Bishen Singh Mahendra Pal Singh, 1972</ref>

The leaf is used as a [[medicinal]] [[herbal tea]] for treating [[diarrhea|diarrhoea]], [[menstrual]] pains, [[morning sickness]] and labour pains.<ref>Low, T., ''Bush Medicine - A Pharmacopoeia of Natural Remedies,'' 1990,  ISBN 0-207-16462-2</ref> The leaf contains [[essential oils]].<ref>Southwell, I., 'The Constituents of Rubus rosifolius. The Structure of Rosifoliol, a Biogenetically Significant Sesquiterpenoid',
''Australian Journal of Chemistry'', 1978, vol. 31(11), pp2527 - 2538 [http://www.publish.csiro.au/paper/CH9782527.htm]</ref>

==Weed risk==
''Rubus rosifolius'' is an introduced environmental [[weed]] in the [[Hawaiian Islands]], [[Puerto Rico]] and [[French Polynesia]], and extreme caution should be adopted when considering introducing this plant into regions where it is not already native.<ref>[http://www.hear.org/gcw/species/rubus_rosifolius/ ''Rubus rosifolius'' weed profile, Global Compendium of Weeds]</ref><ref>''Rubus rosifolius'' plant profile, Plants Database, United States Department of Agriculture [http://plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=RURO]</ref>

*''Rubus moluccanus'' var. ''sieboldii'' <small>(Blume) Kuntze</small>
*''Rubus subramiflorus'' <small>Kuntze</small>
|}}

'''''Rubus sieboldii''''', the '''Molucca Raspberry''', is a [[flowering plant]] in the genus ''[[Rubus]]''. The species is native to [[Australia]], and mid-western [[Asia]], in the [[Himalaya Mountains]] and foothills. The shrubs prefer low wetland areas, with very good sun exposure, though the plants can tolerate moderate shade.

==Uses==
The plant's leaves stimulate blood flow in the pelvic area and uterus. They are also [[abortifacient]] and [[astringent]], lending to their use to treat urinary tract infections. Molucca Raspberries are edible, and contain large amounts of antioxidant power.[http://www.news-medical.net/?id=28419] They are rich with bioactive phytochemicals, antioxidant compounds, and show stronger radical scavenging activities than blueberries.<ref>[http://www.emaxhealth.com/74/14556.html Emaxhealth, Australian native fruits bear sweet antioxidants]</ref><ref>[http://www.news-medical.net/?id=28419 Medical Science News, accessed October 23, 2007].</ref>

304.text:
{{taxobox
|image = Ruppia_maritima_South_Chungcheong,_South_Korea_27_Jun_2006.jpg
|image_caption = ''Ruppia maritima''
|status = LC |status_system = IUCN3.1 
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Monocots]]
|ordo = [[Alismatales]]
|familia = [[Ruppia]]ceae
|genus = ''[[Ruppia]]''
|species = '''''R. maritima'''''
|binomial = ''Ruppia maritima''
|binomial_authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]
}}
'''''Ruppia maritima''''' is a species of [[aquatic plant]] known by the common names '''beaked tasselweed''', '''widgeon grass''',<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.forest.go.kr/kna/special/download/English_Names_for_Korean_Native_Plants.pdf|title=English Names for Korean Native Plants|publisher=[[Korea National Arboretum]]|year=2015|isbn=978-89-97450-98-5|location=Pocheon|pages=614|access-date=24 December 2016|via=[[Korea Forest Service]]}}</ref> '''ditch-grass''' and '''tassel pondweed'''.  Despite its [[scientific name]], it is not a [[Marine biology|marine plant]]; is perhaps best described as a [[halophyte|salt-tolerant]] [[freshwater]] species.<ref name=class>Kantrud, H. A. (1991). [http://www.npwrc.usgs.gov/resource/plants/ruppia/class.htm Classification and Distribution - Wigeongrass (''Ruppia maritima'' L.): A literature review.]  U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service.</ref> The generic name ''Ruppia'' was dedicated by Linnaeus to the German botanist Heinrich Bernhard Ruppius (1689-1719) and the specific name (maritima) translates to "of the sea".

==Distribution==
It can be found throughout the world, most often in coastal areas, where it grows in [[brackish water]] bodies, such as [[marsh]]es. It is a dominant plant in a great many shoreline regions. It does not grow well in [[turbidity|turbid]] water or low-oxygen substrates.<ref name=habitat>Kantrud, H. A. (1991). [http://www.npwrc.usgs.gov/resource/plants/ruppia/habitat.htm Habitat - Wigeongrass (''Ruppia maritima'' L.): A literature review.]  U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service.</ref>

==Description==
{{stack|[[File:Ruppiamaritima.jpg|thumb]]}}
''Ruppia maritima'' is a thread-thin, grasslike annual or perennial<ref name=class/> herb which grows from a [[rhizome]] anchored shallowly in the wet substrate. It produces a long, narrow, straight or loosely coiled [[inflorescence]] tipped with two tiny flowers. The plant often self-pollinates, but the flowers also release [[pollen]] that reaches other plants as it floats away on bubbles.<ref name=repro>Kantrud, H. A. (1991). [http://www.npwrc.usgs.gov/resource/plants/ruppia/develop.htm Development and Reproduction - Wigeongrass (''Ruppia maritima'' L.): A literature review.]  U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service.</ref>

The fruits are [[drupe]]lets. They are [[biological dispersal|dispersed]] in the water and inside the guts of fish and waterbirds that eat them.<ref name=repro/> The plant also [[vegetative reproduction|reproduces vegetatively]] by sprouting from its rhizome to form colonies.<ref name=repro/>

==Taxonomy and nomenclature==
On the basis of molecular phylogenetic analyses, a species complex, named ''R''. ''maritima'' complex, had been discerned,<ref>Ito Y., T. Ohi-Toma, J. Murata & Nr. Tanaka (2010) [http://www.amjbot.org/content/97/7/1156.short Hybridization and polyploidy of an aquatic plant, ''Ruppia'' (Ruppiaceae), inferred from plastid and nuclear DNA phylogenies] ''American Journal of Botany'' '''97:''' 1156-1167</ref> which was then extended to include eight lineages,<ref>Ito Y., T. Ohi-Toma, J. Murata & Nr. Tanaka (2013) [http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10265-013-0570-6 Comprehensive phylogenetic analyses of the ''Ruppia'' ''maritima'' complex focusing on taxa from the Mediterranean] ''Journal of Plant Research'' '''126:''' 753-762</ref> or nine lineages.<ref>Ito, Y., T. Ohi-Toma, Nr. Tanaka, J. Murata, A.M. Muasya (2015) [http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.1600/036364415X689988 Phylogeny of Ruppia (Ruppiaceae) revisited: Molecular and morphological evidence for a new species from Western Cape, South Africa] '' Systematic Botany'' '''40:''' : 942-949</ref>

A lectotype for ''[[Ruppia cirrhosa|R. cirrhosa]]'' is designated and the name is shown to be a homotypic synonym of ''R. maritima''.<ref name="Ito et al. 2017">[[Yu Ito (botanist)|Ito, Y.]], T. Ohi-Toma, C. Nepi, A. Santangelo, A. Stinca, N. Tanaka, & J. Murata (2017) [https://doi.org/10.12705/661.11 Towards a better understanding of the ''Ruppia maritima'' complex (Ruppiaceae): Notes on the correct application and typification of the names ''R. cirrhosa'' and ''R. spiralis''] ''[[Taxon]]'' '''66:''' 167-171</ref>

==Wetlands and wildlife==
This plant is an important part of the diet of many species of [[waterfowl]]. In many areas, [[Restoration ecology|wetlands restoration]] begins with the recovery and protection of this plant.<ref>Kantrud, H. A. (1991). [http://www.npwrc.usgs.gov/resource/plants/ruppia/intro.htm Introduction - Wigeongrass (''Ruppia maritima'' L.): A literature review.]  U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service.</ref>

==See also==

*[[Wetland conservation]]
*[[Wetland classification]]
*[[Constructed wetland]]

*''Sagittaria mohrii'' <small>J.G. Sm. ex C. Mohr</small>

|synonyms_ref=<ref>[http://www.tropicos.org/Name/900231?tab=synonyms Tropicos]</ref>
|}}
'''''Sagittaria platyphylla''''', the '''delta arrowhead''',<ref>{{PLANTS|id=SAPL|taxon=Sagittaria platyphylla|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref> '''broad-leaf arrowhead''' or '''delta duck-potato''', is a plant species native to the eastern [[United States]]. The core of its range extends from central [[Texas]] to the [[Florida Panhandle]] north to southern [[Illinois]]. Isolated populations have been reported from [[Washington (state)|Washington State]], [[Missouri]], [[Kansas]], [[Ohio]], [[Kentucky]], [[Pennsylvania]], [[West Virginia]], eastern [[Virginia]], [[North Carolina|North]] and [[South Carolina]] and eastern [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[Nuevo León]], [[Michoacán]] and [[Panamá]]. It has also become a noxious weed in [[Australia]].<ref>[http://www.weeds.org.au/cgi-bin/weedident.cgi?tpl=plant.tpl&state=nsw&s&region=ml&card=W13 Australian Weeds Committee, Weed Identification Guide, ''Sagittaria platyphylla'' ]</ref> The plant is an [[Emergent plant|emergent]] [[Aquatic plant|aquatic]] found in ponds, lakes and slow-moving streams.<ref name="iowerwqueriw89">{{Cite web|url=http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=222000354|title=Sagittaria platyphylla in Flora of North America @ efloras.org|website=www.efloras.org|access-date=2017-01-30}}</ref><ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Sagittaria%20platyphylla.png BONAP (Biota of North America Project) floristic synthesis, ''Sagittaria platyphylla'']</ref><ref>Correa A., M.D., C. Galdames & M. Stapf. 2004. Catálogo de las Plantas Vasculares de Panamá 1–599. Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute, Panama.</ref>

''Sagittaria platyphylla'' is a perennial herb up to 150 cm tall, producing underground [[corms]] (similar to [[tubers]]). The plant reproduces by means of [[stolons]] as well as seeds. Some leaves are totally [[Submerged aquatic vegetation|submerged]], others [[Emergent plant|emergent]] (raising above the surface of the water). Submerged leaves have flattened [[Petiole (botany)|petioles]] but no true blades. Emergent leaves have ovate to elliptical blades up to 17 cm long. [[Inflorescence]] is a [[raceme]] with 3-9 [[Whorl (botany)|whorls]] of flowers. Flowers are white, up to 2 cm in diameter.
<ref name="iowerwqueriw89"/><ref>Smith, Jared Gage. 1894. North American Species of ''Sagittaria'' and ''Lophotocarpus'' 29.</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Asa,|first=Gray,|date=1867-01-01|title=Manual of the botany of the northern United States :|url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/38145483#page/9/mode/1up|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tropicos.org/ImageFullView.aspx?imageid=57332|title=Image|website=www.tropicos.org|access-date=2017-01-30}}</ref><ref>Haynes, R. R. & L.B. Holm-Nielsen. 1994. The Alismataceae. Flora Neotropica 64: 1–112.</ref><ref>Czerepanov, S. K. 1981.  	Sosudistye Rasteniia SSSR 509 pages. Nauka, Leningradskoe Otd-nie, Leningrad.</ref><ref>Correll, D. S. & M. C. Johnston. 1970. Manual of the Vascular Plants of Texas i–xv, 1–1881. The University of Texas at Dallas, Richardson</ref><ref>Wunderlin, R. P. 1998. Guide to the Vascular Plants of Florida i–x, 1–806. University Press of Florida, Gainesville.</ref><ref>Godfrey, R. K. & J. W. Wooten. 1979. Aquatic and Wetland Plants of Southeastern United States Monocotyledons 1–712. The University of Georgia Press, Athens</ref>

{{italic title}}
{{taxobox

|synonyms =

*''Sagitta palustris'' <small>Bubani</small>
*''Sagittaria acuminata'' <small>Sm.</small>
*''Sagittaria aquatica'' <small>Lam.</small>
*''Sagittaria bulbosa'' <small>(Poir.) Donn</small>
*''Sagittaria heterophylla'' <small>Schreb.</small>
*''Sagittaria minor'' <small>Mill.</small>
*''Sagittaria tenuior'' <small>Gand.</small>
*''Sagittaria vulgaris'' <small>Gueldenst.</small>
*''Vallisneria bulbosa'' <small>Poir.</small>
|synonyms_ref=<ref>[http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/kew-287474 The Plant List]</ref>
}}
'''''Sagittaria sagittifolia''''' (also called '''arrowhead''' due to the shape of its leaves) is a [[flowering plant]] in the family [[Alismataceae]], native to [[wetland]]s most of [[Europe]] from [[Ireland]] and [[Portugal]] to [[Finland]] and [[Bulgaria]], and in [[Russia]], [[Ukraine]], [[Siberia]], [[Japan]], [[Turkey]], [[China]], [[Australia]], [[Vietnam]] and the [[Caucasus]]. It is also cultivated as a food crop in some other countries. In [[Great Britain|Britain]] it is the only native ''Sagittaria''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=287474|title=World Checklist of Selected Plant Families: Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew|website=apps.kew.org|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-01-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/167821/0|title=Sagittaria sagittifolia (Arrowhead)|website=www.iucnredlist.org|access-date=2017-01-30}}</ref>
[[File:Tachi Omodaka inverted.png|thumb|沢瀉]]
''Sagittaria sagittifolia'' is a [[herbaceous]] [[perennial plant]], growing in water from 10–50 cm deep. The [[leaf|leaves]] above water are arrowhead-shaped, the leaf blade 15–25 cm long and 10–22 cm broad, on a long petiole holding the leaf up to 45 cm above water level. The plant also has narrow linear submerged leaves, up to 80 cm long and 2 cm broad. The [[flower]]s are 2-2.5 cm broad, with three small sepals and three white petals, and numerous purple stamens.

==Cultivation and uses==
The round [[tuber]] is edible. It tastes bland, with a starchy texture, similar to a [[potato]] but somewhat crunchier, even when cooked. In Japan, it is known as '''Omodaka,オモダカ,  沢瀉, 澤瀉,面高 , '''  and its tuber is eaten particularly on the [[Chinese New Year]].  In China, it is known as 慈姑 cí gū and often used in winter hot pots. In Vietnam, the plant's young petiole leaves and rhizomes are used for soups.<ref>{{ cite book | first1=Yoshitaka | last1=Tanaka | first2=Nguyen | last2=Van Ke | date=2007 | title=Edible Wild Plants of Vietnam: The Bountiful Garden | publisher=Thailand: Orchid Press | isbn=9745240893 | page=17}}</ref>

Remnants of ''Sagittaria sagittifolia'' have been found in the Paleolithic/Mesolithic site of Całowanie in Poland.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Kubiak-Martens|first=Lucyna|title=Evidence for possible use of plant foods in Palaeolithic and Mesolithic diet from the site of Całowanie in the central part of the Polish Plain|journal=Vegetation History and Archaeobotany|year=1996|volume=5|issue=1-2|pages=33–38|doi=10.1007/BF00189433|url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/aj286518013457n7/}}</ref>

Seven new ent-rosane diterpenoids and a new labdane diterpene were recently (2006) purified from the Chinese medicinal plant, ''Sagittaria sagittifolia'' (Alismaceae). Four of these compounds (Sagittine A–D) exhibited antibacterial activity against ''[[Streptococcus mutans]]'' and ''[[Actinomyces naeslundii]]'' while another ([[Sagittine E]]) was only active against ''A. naeslundii'' (MIC = 62.5 μg ml–1). Recently, the same group identified five new diterpenoids from ''[[Sagittaria pygmaea]]''. None of these displayed activity against ''A. actinomycetemcomitans'', while four of the others were active against ''A. viscosus'' and three were active against ''S. mutans'', of which 18-ß-D-3',6'-diacetoxyglucopyranosyl-ent-kaur-16-ene was the most active.<ref>B.Parimala Devi et al. / Journal of Pharmacy Research 2009, 2(11),1669-1675 http://jpronline.info/article/view/906/708</ref>

==As a weed==
''Sagittaria sagittifolia'' can be weedy or invasive according to the USDA, Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), Plant Protection and Quarantine (PPQ). It also appears on state noxious weed lists for 46 states.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://plants.usda.gov/core/profile?symbol=SASA7|title=Plants Profile for Sagittaria sagittifolia (arrowhead)|website=plants.usda.gov|access-date=2017-01-30}}</ref>

==See also==

'''''Samolus repens''''' is a species of [[Samolus|water pimpernel]] native to Australia, New Zealand and near-by Pacific islands, and South America (South Chile),<ref name=CDWS1982>{{cite journal |author=[[Wim Crusio|Crusio W.E.]] |title=Het geslacht ''Samolus'' L. |journal=Communications of the Dutch Waterplant Society |volume=2 |issue= |pages=13–25 |year=1982 |language=Dutch}}</ref> where it is common in temperate and subtropic coastlines. Common names include '''creeping brookweed'''<ref name=Harden>{{cite web |author=Harden, G.J.|title=''Samolus repens'' (J.R.Forst. & G.Forst.) Pers. |url=http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Samolus~repens|accessdate=1 April 2011|work= PlantNET - New South Wales Flora Online |publisher=Royal Botanic Gardens & Domain Trust, Sydney Australia}}</ref> and '''creeping bushweed'''.<ref name=Johns>{{cite web|author=Johns, Louise|title=Online Field guide to Common Saltmarsh Plants of Queensland|publisher=Department of Primary Industries and Fisheries|url=http://www.alocasia.com.au/qld_saltmarsh_plants/herbarium/other-plant-types/creeping-bushweed|accessdate=1 April 2012}}</ref> ''Samolus repens'' has small white or occasionally pink flowers with a flowering period from September through to March or April.<ref name=Johns/><ref name=Harden/>

== Taxonomy ==
The species was first described by [[Georg Forster]] in 1776 as ''Sheffieldia repens'' and placed in the genus ''Samolus'' in 1805 by [[Christiaan Hendrik Persoon]].<ref name=CDWS1982/> The following synonyms exist:<ref name=CDWS1982/><ref name=CDWS1984/>

{{wikispecies|Samolus valerandi}}
'''''Samolus valerandi''''' is a species of [[Samolus|water pimpernel]] native to a very wide area across [[Europe]], [[Africa]], [[Asia]], [[Australia]], and the [[Americas]]. Common names include '''seaside brookweed''',<ref>{{PLANTS|id=SAVA3|taxon=Samolus valerandi|accessdate=28 October 2015}}</ref> '''brookweed''', '''thin-leaf brookweed''', '''water cabbage''', and '''water rose'''.<ref>Huxley. A. ''The New RHS Dictionary of Gardening''. 1992. MacMillan Press 1992 ISBN 0-333-47494-5</ref>

==Ecological aspects==
Shallow water and wet soils. Along creeks, ditches and seepage areas.

==Cultivation==
The plant can be grown in [[pond]]s, bog gardens, and damp areas in the garden. ''S. valerandi'' prefers light (sandy), medium (loamy), and heavy (clay) soils, preferably neutral or basic (alkaline) soils. It cannot tolerate shade and likes a bright, sunny position. It requires moist or wet soil and can even grow in water. The plant can tolerate maritime exposure and is self-fertile. ''S. valerandi'' is sometimes grown in [[aquarium]]s, although they seem to last only a limited time when grown fully submersed.

'''''Schoenoplectus pungens''''' is a species of flowering plant in the [[Cyperaceae|sedge family]] known by the common names '''common threesquare''',<ref>{{PLANTS|id=SCPU10|taxon=Schoenoplectus pungens|accessdate=1 February 2016}}</ref> '''common three-square bulrush'''<ref name=poppy>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=242357940 Flora of North America]</ref> and '''sharp club-rush'''.<ref name=BSBI07>{{cite web |title=BSBI List 2007 |publisher=Botanical Society of Britain and Ireland |url=http://www.bsbi.org.uk/BSBIList2007.xls |format=xls |archive-url=http://www.webcitation.org/6VqJ46atN |archive-date=2015-02-25 |accessdate=2014-10-17}}</ref> It is a [[herbaceous]] [[Emergent plant|emergent]] plant that is widespread across much of [[North America|North]] and [[South America]] as well as [[Europe]], [[New Zealand]] and [[Australia]].<ref name=tabby>[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=263065 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families]</ref><ref name=Wisplants>{{cite web|title=Family Cyperaceae Schoenoplectus pungens (Vahl) Palla|url=http://wisplants.uwsp.edu/scripts/detail.asp?SpCode=SCHPUN|publisher=Wisplants|accessdate=4 February 2013}}</ref><ref>Jermy, C., Simpson, D., Foley, M. & Porter, M. (2007). Sedges of the British Isles. B.S.B.I. Handbook No. 1 , ed. 3: 1-554. Botanical Society of the British Isles, London.</ref><ref>Govaerts, R. & Simpson, D.A. (2007). World Checklist of Cyperaceae. Sedges: 1-765. The Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew.</ref><ref>Castroviejo, S. & al. (eds.) (2008). Flora Iberica 18: 1-420. Real Jardín Botánico, CSIC, Madrid.</ref><ref>Rothrock, P.E. (2009). Sedges of Indiana and adjacent states: the non-Carex species: 1-271. Indiana Academy of Sciences.</ref><ref>Danylyk, I.M. & Honcharenko, V.I. (2009). ''Schoenoplectus pungens'' (Vahl) Palla (Cyperaceae), a new species for of the Ukrainian flora. Ukrayins'k Botanichnyi Zhurnal 66: 650-655.</ref><ref>Acevedo-Rodríguez, P. & Strong, M.T. (2012). Catalogue of seed plants of the West Indies. Smithsonian Contributions to Botany 98: 1-1192.</ref>

==Information==
''Schoenoplectus pungens'' is a long-lived perennial herb up to 1.5 m tall, found in open, sun-lit marshes and along the shores of lakes and ponds, in water up to 1 m deep. It is resistant to fire.<ref name=CalFlora>{{cite web|title=Schoenoplectus pungens  (Vahl) Palla|url=http://www.calflora.org/cgi-bin/species_query.cgi?where-calrecnum=10359|publisher=CalFlora|accessdate=4 February 2013}}</ref><ref name=Characteristics>{{cite web|title=Conservation Plant Characteristics|url=http://plants.usda.gov/java/charProfile?symbol=SCPUP5|publisher=USDA.gov|accessdate=4 February 2013}}</ref><ref name=NativePC>{{cite web|title=Schoenoplectus pungens v. pungens (Scirpus pungens, Scirpus americanus)|url=http://www.nativeplantcenter.net/?q=plants/791|publisher=Native Plant Center|accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref><ref name=CalFloraPungens>{{cite web|title=Scirpus pungens  Vahl three square|url=http://www.calflora.org/cgi-bin/species_query.cgi?where-taxon=Scirpus+pungens|publisher=CalFlora|accessdate=4 February 2013}}</ref> The species is closely related to ''S. americanus,'' and many ''S. pungens'' specimens have long been misidentified as ''S. americanus.''<ref name=poppy/>

==Characteristics==
The foliage is dark green, rough and dense. The flowers are blue. The seeds are brown.<ref name=Characteristics />
