335.text:
{{Speciesbox |image = Urena lobata at Kadavoor.jpg |taxon = Urena lobata |authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]] |synonyms = {{Plainlist | style = margin-left: 1em; text-indent: -1em; | *''Urena americana'' L. f. *''Urena chinensis'' Osbeck *''Urena diversifolia'' Schumach. *''Urena grandiflora'' DC. *''Urena monopetala'' Lour. *''Urena reticulata'' Cav. *''Urena scabriuscula'' DC. *''Urena tomentosa'' Blume *''Urena trilobata'' Vell. }} |synonyms_ref = {{citation |url=http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/kew-2449399 |title=The Plant List: A Working List of All Plant Species |accessdate=17 March 2017}}{{citation |url=http://www.ipni.org/ipni/idPlantNameSearch.do?id=261608-2 |title=The International Plant Names Index |accessdate=17 March 2017}} }} '''''Urena lobata''''', commonly known as '''Caesarweed'''{{PLANTS|id=URLO|taxon=Urena lobata|accessdate=27 July 2015}} or '''Congo jute''',{{cite book|author=Chhabilendra Roul|title=The International Jute Commodity System|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r0gH_ID_AMcC&pg=PA7|date=1 January 2009|publisher=Northern Book Centre|isbn=978-81-7211-274-5|page=7}}{{cite book|author=LeRoy Holm|title=World Weeds: Natural Histories and Distribution|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i7JjRXH6uq4C&pg=PA238|date=5 March 1997|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-0-471-04701-8|page=238}} is an annual, variable, erect, ascendant under shrub measuring up to {{convert|0.5|meters|feet}} to {{convert|2.5|meters|feet}} tall. The stems are covered with minute star-like hairs and often tinged purple. It is widely distributed as a weed in the tropics of both hemispheres including [[Brazil]] and [[Southeast Asia]].{{cite web|url=http://www.globinmed.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=79095:urena-lobata-l&catid=385:u|title=Globinmed - Globinmed|author=|date=|work=globinmed.com|accessdate=15 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?40900|title=Urena lobata information from NPGS/GRIN|author=|date=|work=ars-grin.gov|accessdate=15 September 2015}} == Description == Each individual plant grows as a single stalk that freely sends out bushy stems. The leaf shape is [[Leaf shape|palmately lobed]] (having lobes that spread out like fingers on a hand). Like the stem, the leaves also have tiny hairs. Flowers of the plant are pink-violet and grow one centimeter in width. The fruit is also hairy and may stick to clothing material or fur.{{Cite web|title = Caesar's weed|url = http://plants.ifas.ufl.edu/node/460|website = Center for Aquatic and Invasive Plants|accessdate = 31 July 2015|publisher = University of Florida, IFAS}} == Invasiveness == The plant can invade areas of ecological disturbance as well as eroded places, crop plantations, and pastures. Of the places where Caesarweed is a weed, it is considered an invasive species in the state of Florida, United States. There, it grows as an annual weed in most parts except for the southern region, where it may live perennially. In Florida, the plant has been reported to grow rapidly from {{convert|0.5|meter|feet}} to {{convert|2|meter|feet}} by the end of its first year of growth. The plant is not competitive in tall grasses or under canopies. The [[University of Florida]]'s pest management procedures for handling this plant include prevention through treating before seeds form and maneuvering vehicles to avoid driving near Caesarweed, mulching and shading to prevent germination, and the use of chemical herbicides. [[File:Encyclopdieoud01soci 0813.jpg|left|thumb|Page 693 of the first volume of the third edition of the ''Encyclopedie'']] ==Aguaxima in ''L'Encyclopédie''== In the ''[[Encyclopédie ou Dictionnaire raisonné des sciences, des arts et des métiers]]'' (Vol. 1 [1751], p. 191), [[Denis Diderot]]'s article about the plant is listed under the heading '''''Aguaxima''''', a common Portuguese name for the plant.Diderot, Denis. (1751). Aguaxima. ''[[Encyclopédie|Encyclopédie ou Dictionnaire raisonné des sciences, des arts et des métiers, par une Société de Gens de lettres]]''. Retrieved 16 September 2013 from [http://artflsrv02.uchicago.edu/cgi-bin/philologic/getobject.pl?c.0:905.encyclopedie0513 The Project for American and French Research on the Treasury of the French Language (ARTFL)].[http://www.cpqba.unicamp.br/plmed/docs/colecao2002.pdf Brazilian popular names of various medicinal plants]. Coleção Brasileira de Microrganismos de Ambiente e Indústria.[http://www.hostdime.com.br/dicionario/guaxima.html Guaxima]. ''Diccionario da Lingua Portuguesa'' (hostdime.com.br). {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425141600/http://www.hostdime.com.br/dicionario/guaxima.html |date=April 25, 2012 }} The entry is notable not for its one sentence description of its subject ("Aguaxima, a plant growing in Brazil and on the islands of South America."), but for Diderot's editorializing that follows it. Frustrated by the uselessness of such a poor article, he muses about what audience it could possibly serve. His conclusion is a succinct critique of the popular assumption that [[encyclopedia]]s should be measured according to their breadth or comprehensiveness rather than quality.{{cite book|last=Blom|first=Philipp|title=A Wicked Company: The Forgotten Radicalism of the European Enlightenment|pages=247–248|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hFEa7773xAIC|publisher=Basic Books|date=2013}}{{cite book|title=Planet Word|last=Davidson|first=J.P.|publisher=Penguin UK|date=2011|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OqfUJI3a5q4C}}{{page needed|date=April 2016}}
Aguaxima, a plant growing in Brazil and on the islands of South America. This is all that we are told about it; and I would like to know for whom such descriptions are made. It cannot be for the natives of the countries concerned, who are likely to know more about the aguaxima than is contained in this description, and who do not need to learn that the aguaxima grows in their country. It is as if you said to a Frenchman that the pear tree is a tree that grows in France, in Germany, etc . It is not meant for us either, for what do we care that there is a tree in Brazil named aguaxima, if all we know about it is its name? What is the point of giving the name? It leaves the ignorant just as they were and teaches the rest of us nothing. If all the same I mention this plant here, along with several others that are described just as poorly, then it is out of consideration for certain readers who prefer to find nothing in a dictionary article or even to find something stupid than to find no article at all.Diderot, Denis. (2007). Aguaxima. ''Encyclopédie ou Dictionnaire raisonné des sciences, des arts et des métiers, par une Société de Gens de lettres'' (translation by Malcolm Eden). Retrieved 16 September 2013 from [http://quod.lib.umich.edu/d/did/did2222.0000.243?view=text;rgn=main The Encyclopedia of Diderot & d'Alembert Collaborative Translation Project website]. Ann Arbor, MI: MPublishing, University of Michigan Library.

Inst.|isbn=978-971-22-0130-1|pages=58–59}} }} ==External links== {{Wikispecies|Urena lobata}} {{WestAfricanPlants|Urena lobata}} {{portalbar|Plants|Biology|Caribbean|South America|Southeast Asia}} {{taxonbar}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Hibisceae]] [[Category:Flora of Central America]] [[Category:Flora of the Caribbean]] [[Category:Flora of South America]] [[Category:Flora of Southeast Asia]] [[Category:Flora of Australia]] [[Category:Flora of China]] [[Category:Plants described in 1753]] [[Category:Taxa named by Carl Linnaeus]] [[Category:Encyclopédie]] [[Category:Invasive plant species]] [[Category:Invasive plant species in South Africa]] [[Category:Invasive plant species in the United States]]

'''''Utricularia linearis''''' is a [[carnivorous plant]] belonging to the [[genus]] ''[[Utricularia]]''. It is known only from a single unnamed lagoon in [[Howard Springs, Northern Territory|Howard Springs]], [[Northern Territory]], [[Australia]].<ref>Wakabayashi, H. 2010. {{cite web|url= http://www.asahi-net.or.jp/~ze9h-wkby/U_linearis-WEB.pdf |title=''Utricularia linearis'' (Lentibulariaceae), a new species from the Howard Springs, Northern Territory, Australia. }} ''[[Journal of Insectivorous Plant Society]]'' '''61'''(4): 88–92.</ref>

337.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = ''Vitex rotundifolia''
|image = Vitex rotundifolia 03.JPG
|image_caption = ''Vitex rotundifolia'' flowers and foliage in Incheon, Korea
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]]
|ordo = [[Lamiales]]
|familia = [[Lamiaceae]]
|subfamilia = [[Viticoideae]]
|genus = ''[[Vitex]]''
|species = '''''V. rotundifolia'''''
|binomial = ''Vitex rotundifolia''
| binomial_authority = [[L.f.]]
|}}
{{commons|Vitex_rotundifolia|Vitex rotundifolia}}
'''''Vitex rotundifolia''''', the '''roundleaf chastetree'''<ref>{{PLANTS|id=VIRO80|taxon=Vitex rotundifolia|accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref> or '''beach vitex''' is a species of ''Vitex'' that is native to seashores throughout the Pacific. Its range includes continents and islands stretching from India east to Hawaii and from Korea south to Australia. This woody perennial plant typically grows approximately 1 m in height. It has a sprawling growth habit and produces runners that root regularly at nodes. This rooting pattern allows the plant to spread rapidly. At maturity, ''V. rotundifolia'' produces blue-purple flowers that are borne in clusters and ultimately yield small brown-black fruits. Its leaves are rounded at the tips with green upper surfaces and silver lower surfaces. While the plant is a seashore obligate, it grows over a wide latitude range. It has been used for medicinal purposes throughout its native range. More recently, it was imported to the eastern United States where it has become a seashore invasive. Control efforts are presently underway to protect the fragile beach dune ecosystem.

==Description==
''V. rotundifolia'' is a sprawling [[shrub]] that can grow as tall as 1.5 m though it typically ranges from 0.5 to 1 m in height. As a product of its rapid nodal [[root]]ing, the plant can form dense mats reaching in excess of 10 m from the parent plant.<ref name = "Munir">{{cite journal |quotes= |last=Munir |first=A.A. |year= 1987 |title=A taxonomic revision of the genus ''Vitex'' L. (Verbenaceae)* in Australia |journal=Journal of the Adelaide Botanic Garden  |volume=10 |issue=1 |pages=31–79}}</ref> New stems are green, square and fleshy initially before maturing brown and woody. Older, large-diameter stems are covered with heavily fissured bark. Running horizontal stems produce frequent upright branches. Leaves are strongly aromatic, intensifying when crushed.<ref name = "Wagner">{{cite book |last1=Wagner |first1=W.L |author2=D.R  Herbst |author3=S.H. Sohmer |title=Manual of the Flowering Plants of Hawai'i |year=1999 |publisher=Bishop Museum Press |location=Honolulu |isbn=0-8248-2166-1}}</ref> The majority of leaves are [[leaf|simple]], but they can occasionally be [[palmate]] [[trifoliate]] or 2-leaved.<ref name = "Munir"/> Leaves measure 2 to 6.5 cm in length and 1-4.5 cm in width.<ref name = "Wagner"/> Leaf margins are [[entire leaf|entire]]. The leaf shape varies from [[ovate]] to [[obovate]] with [[Angle#Types of angles|acute]] bases and [[obtuse angle|obtuse]] apexes. Occasionally, leaf apexes are [[Angle#Types of angles|acute]] or emarginate. Upper leaf surfaces are dark green whereas lower leaf surfaces range in color from silver to white to light green; all leaf surfaces are [[tomentose]].<ref>{{cite book |author=Flora of Taiwan Editorial Committee |first1=W.L |authorlink1= |editor1-link= |others= |title=Flora of Taiwan |volume=4 |year=1978 |publisher=Epoch |location=Taipei  |isbn= |doi=}}</ref> [[Petiole (botany)|Petiole]] bases are typically somewhat purple and measure 0 to 1 cm in length. Blades are cupped downward slightly. Leaf veins are lighter green than surrounding tissue. Flowers are borne in [[Indeterminate growth|indeterminate]] [[panicles]] that may be [[inflorescence|terminal]] or [[inflorescence|axillary]]. Infloresences measure 3 to 7 cm in length. The [[Calyx (botany)|calyx]] is cup-shaped and 4 to 4.5 cm long. Flowers are [[zygomorphic]], purple to blue-purple, and short pedunculate. They are two-lipped and funnel-form (measuring 8 mm in length). Four stamens are [[didynamous]] and extend beyond the [[Petal#Corolla|corolla]] tube (measuring 9 to 10 mm). The [[Style (botany)|style]] extends beyond the [[stamens]] (total length: 12 mm).<ref name = "Wagner"/> Pollen is [[tricolpate]]. [[Ovary (plants)|Ovaries]] consist of two [[carpels]] with each containing two single seeded [[locule]]s. Fruits are globose [[drupes]] that are green while immature but turn yellow and red before maturing to bluish black.<ref name = "FOCEC">{{cite book |author= Flora of China Editorial Committee |first1= R. M. |authorlink= |title=Flora of China |volume=17 |year=1994 |publisher= |location= |chapter=Vitex |pages=28–32 |isbn= |url=http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=2&taxon_id=134644 |accessdate=6 June 2010 }}</ref> The fruits are frequently incorrectly characterized in the literature as "[[seeds]] or [[berries]]". Each drupe contains a maximum of four seeds though there are usually fewer as a result of seed abortion.<ref name = "dekok07">{{cite journal |quotes= |last=de Kok |first=R.  |authorlink= |year= 2007 |title=The genus ''Vitex'' (Lamiaceae) in New Guinea and the South Pacific Islands |journal=Kew Bulletin  |volume=62 |issue= |pages=587–603 |id= |url= |accessdate= }}</ref> Each seed is encapsulated in a separate compartment. [[Endosperm]] is absent.<ref name ="Corner">{{cite journal |quotes= |last=Corner |first=E. J. H. |year= 1939 |title=Notes on the systematy and distribution of Malayan phanerogams III |journal=Gard. Bull. Straits Settlem. |volume=10 |issue= |pages=239–329 |id= |url= |accessdate= }}</ref> Seeds germinate into tender [[seedlings]] that bear two [[cotyledons]] and quickly develop two red-margined true leaves. [[Ploidy]] level is 2n = 32, 34*.<ref name = "Wagner"/>
[[File:Vitex rotundifolia 06.JPG|right|thumb|alt=|''Vitex rotundifolia'' stem in Incheon, Korea]]

== Taxonomy ==
''Vitex rotundifolia'' is a member of the family [[Lamiaceae]] <ref name ="IPNI">{{Cite web |url=http://www.ipni.org |title=International Plant Names Index |accessdate=6 June 2010 |authorlink= |format= |work= |publisher= |pages= |language= |quote= }}</ref> and subfamily [[Viticoideae]].<ref name = "Harley">{{cite book |last1= Harley |first1= R. M. |authorlink= |author2= S. Atkins |author3= A. L. Budantsev |author4= P. D. Cantino |author5= B. J. Conn |author6= R. Grayer |author7= M. M. Harley |author8= R. de Kok |author9= T. Krestovskaja |author10= R. Morales |author11= A. J. Paton |author12= O. Ryding |author13= T. Upson |editor= Kubitzki K., Kadereit J. W. |title=The families and genera of vascular plants |volume=7 |year=2004 |publisher=Springer |location=Berlin |chapter=Labiatae |pages=167–275 |isbn=978-3-540-40593-1 }}</ref> The plant was originally described by the son of [[Carolus Linnaeus]], [[Carl Linnaeus the Younger]]<ref name="IPNI" /> The original description was published in ''[[Supplementum Plantarum]]'' in 1782.<ref name="IPNI" /> The generic epithet, ''Vitex'', is derived from the Latin ''viere'', meaning “to bind or twist” in reference to the rope-like stems produced by some species in the genus.<ref name = "Wagner"/> The specific epithet, ''rotundifolia'', is derived from the Latin ''rotundus'', which means "round, spherical", and ''folium'', meaning "leaf.” This is a reference to the rounded character of the leaves.

=== Family level classification ===
''Vitex'' and all other members of the family [[Verbenaceae]] save those in the subfamily Verbenoideae were recently moved to the family [[Lamiaceae]].<ref name="Harley" /> As a result of this reorganization, two [[monophyletic]] families were established from the [[paraphyletic]] Verbenaceae and [[polyphyletic]] Lamiaceae.<ref name = "Cantino">{{cite book |last= Cantino |first= P.D. |editor= R.M. Harley, T. Reynolds |title=Advances in Labiatae Science |year=1992 |publisher=Royal Botanical Gardens |location=Kew |chapter=Toward a phylogenetic classification of the Labiatae |pages=27–37|isbn=0-947643-52-4}}</ref> This new classification scheme was initially proposed by Cantino in 1992.<ref>{{cite book |last1= Cantino |first1= P.D. |author2=R.M. Harley |author3=S.J. Wagstaff|editor= R.M. Harley, T. Reynolds |title=Advances in Labiatae Science |year=1992 |publisher=Royal Botanical Gardens |location=Kew |chapter=Genera of Labitae: Status and Classification |pages=511–522|isbn=0-947643-52-4}}</ref> Subsequent [[cpDNA]] analysis,<ref>{{cite journal |last=Wagstaff |first=S. J. |author2=L. Hickerson |author3=R. Spangler |author4=P. A. Reeves |author5=R. G. Olmstead 1998  |title=Phylogeny in Labiatae s. l., inferred from cpDNA sequences |year=1998 |journal=Plant Systematics and Evolution |volume=209 |pages=265–274 |doi= 10.1007/BF00985232 |issue=3–4}}</ref> [[RuBisCO large subunit|rbcL]] sequence analysis,<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.2307/2419684 |last=Wagstaff |first=S. J.  |authorlink= |author2=R. G. Olmstead  |year= 1997 |title=Phylogeny of Labiatae and Verbenaceae Inferred from rbcL Sequences |journal=Systematic Botany  |volume=22 |issue=1 |pages=165–179 |jstor=2419684}}</ref> [[chemotaxonomic]] studies,<ref>{{cite journal |last=vonPoser |first=G.L. |author2=M. E. Toffoli |author3=M. Sobral |author4=A.T. Henriques |year= 1997 |title=Iridoid glucosides substitution patterns in Verbenaceae and their taxonomic implication |journal=Plant Systematics and Evolution  |volume=205 |issue=3–4 |pages=265–287 |doi= 10.1007/BF01464409}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Alvarenga |first=S. A. V. |author2=J. P. Gastmans |author3=G. V. Rodrigues |author4=P. R. H. Moreno |author5=V. P. Emerenciano  |year= 2001 |title=A computer-assisted approach for chemotaxonomic studies - diterpenes in Lamiaceae |journal= Phytochemistry |pmid=11281136  |volume=56 |issue=6 |pages=583–595 |doi=10.1016/S0031-9422(00)00424-6 }}</ref> and morphological analyses <ref>{{cite journal |last=Ryding |first=O. |year= 2007 |title=Amount of calyx fibres in Lamiaceae, relation to calyx structure, phylogeny and ecology |journal=Plant Systematics and Evolution |volume=268 |pages=45–58 |doi=10.1007/s00606-007-0537-y }}</ref> have supported the original logic for family reorganization.

This revision has resulted in some confusion regarding the classification of ''V. rotundifolia'' in the literature. Despite the fact that the revision is well supported with volumes of data, many authors continue to incorrectly place the plant in Verbenaceae.

===Species level classification===
Recent revisions of the genus ''Vitex'' have placed ''V. rotundifolia'' in synonymy with ''V. trifolia'' subsp. ''littoralis'' Steenis.<ref name = "dekok07"/><ref>{{cite journal |last=de Kok |first=R. |year= 2008 |title=The genus ''Vitex'' (Labiatae) in the Flora Malesiana region, excluding New Guinea |journal=Kew Bulletin  |volume=63 |issue=1 |pages=17–40 |doi=10.1007/s12225-007-9013-7}}</ref> Previous researchers have placed ''V. rotundifolia'' within ''V. trifolia''. Moldenke (1958) <ref>{{cite journal |last=Moldenke |first=H.N. |year= 1958 |title=Materials toward a monograph of the genus ''Vitex'' X |journal=Phytologia  |volume=6 |pages=129–192 }}</ref> placed ''V. rotundifolia'' in synonymy with ''V. trifolia'' var. ''simplicifolia''. The placement of Moldenke was in disagreement with Corner (1939),<ref name ="Corner"/> which held ''V. rotundifolia'' as distinct from ''V. trifolia''. The placement of Corner was subsequently supported by several authors: Fosberg (1962),<ref>{{cite journal |last=Fosberg |first=F.R.  |year= 1962 |title=Miscellaneous notes on Hawaiian plants – 3 |journal=Occasional Papers of the Bernice P. Bishop Museum |volume=23 |issue=2 |pages=29–44}}</ref> Munir (1987),<ref name = "Munir"/> and Wagner (1999).<ref name = "Wagner"/>

===Common Names===
[[File:Vitex rotundifolia 01.JPG|right|thumb|alt=|''Vitex rotundifolia'' growing on rocks in Incheon, Korea]]
Likely due to the wide range over which ''V. rotundifolia'' is native, the plant has acquired a host of common names.

'''English speaking countries'''
* Beach vitex <ref name ="USDA1">{{Cite web |url=http://www.invasivespeciesinfo.gov/plants/beachvitex.shtml  |title=Invasive Species: Plants - Beach Vitex (''Vitex rotundifolia'') |accessdate=6 June 2010 |author=USDA |authorlink= |year=2010 |work= |publisher= |pages= |language= |quote= }}</ref>
* Round-leaved chaste tree <ref name ="USDA">{{Cite web |url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/tax_search.pl?Vitex%20rotundifolia  |title=Germplasm Resources Information Network - (GRIN):''Vitex rotundifolia'' |accessdate=6 June 2010 |author=USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program, National Germplasm Resources Laboratory. |authorlink= |year=2010 |format= |work= |publisher= |pages= |language= |quote= }}</ref>
* Single-leaf chaste tree <ref name ="Porcher">{{Cite web |url=http://gmr.landfood.unimelb.edu.au/Plantnames/Sorting/Vitex.html  |title=Sorting ''Vitex'' Names. Multilingual Multiscript Plant Name Database - A Work in Progress. Institute of Land & Food Resources. The University of Melbourne. Australia. |accessdate=6 June 2010 |author=Porcher, M. H |authorlink= |year=2010 |work= |publisher= |pages= |language= |quote= |display-authors=etal}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
* Chasteberry <ref name = "USDA1"/>
* Monk’s pepper <ref name = "USDA1"/>

'''China'''
* Dan ye man jing <ref name = "FOCEC"/><ref name= "USDA"/>

'''Japan'''
* Hamagou <ref>{{cite journal |last=Shin’ichi |first=F. |author2=N. Kiyo |author3=M. Kayo  |year= 2000 |title=Constituents of the essential oil of ''Vitex rotundifolia'' Linn fil |journal=Koryo, Terupen oyobi Seiyu Kagaku ni kansuru Toronkai Koen Yoshishu  |volume=44 |pages=44–46 }}</ref>

'''Korea'''
* Man Hyung Ja <ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0378-8741(00)00258-0 |last=Shin |first=T.Y. |author2= S.H. Kim |author3= J.P. Lim |author4= E.S. Suh |author5= H.J. Jeong |author6= B.D. Kim |author7= E.J. Park |author8= W.J. Hwang |author9= D.G. Rye |author10= S.H. Baek |author11= N.H. An |author12= H.M. Kim |year= 2000 |title=Effect of ''Vitex rotundifolia'' on immediate-type allergic reaction |journal=Journal of Ethnopharmacology |volume=72 |issue=3 |pages=443–450 |pmid= 10996284 }}</ref>

'''Hawaii'''
* Kolokolo kahakai<ref name ="HNPPD">{{Cite web |url=http://www2.hawaii.edu/~eherring/hawnprop/vit-rotu.htm |title=Hawaiian Native Plant Propagation Database:''Vitex rotundifolia'' |accessdate=6 June 2010 |author=University of Hawaii at Manoa: College of Tropical Agriculture and Human Resources |year=2010 }}</ref>
* Hinahina kolo <ref name = "HNPPD"/>
* Manawanawa<ref name = "HNPPD"/>
* Mawanawana<ref name = "HNPPD"/>
* Pohinahina<ref name = "HNPPD"/>
* Polinalina <ref name = "HNPPD"/>

===Hybrids===
Multiple [[Hybrid (biology)|hybrids]] between ''[[Vitex agnus-castus]]'' and ''Vitex rotundifolia'' have been developed at the [[Chicago Botanic Garden]]. These cultivars have undergone successful trials at [[Longwood Gardens]].<ref name = "amn">{{cite journal |last=Metrustry |first=D. |author2=T. Anisko  |date=15 September 2006 |title=Versatile Vitex |journal=American Nurseryman |pages=34–26 |url=http://www.longwoodgardens.org/docs/research/VitexANM.pdf |accessdate=6 June 2010}}</ref> The characteristics of the hybrids are more like those of ''V. rotundifolia'' than ''V. agnus-castus''.<ref name = "amn"/> However, the hybrids are more upright than ''V. rotundifolia'' and have been described as "open and spreading." The leaf characteristics are intermediate between the two parent plants while the blue-purple flower color of the parents persists in the hybrid.<ref name = "amn"/>

==Distribution and habitat==
[[File:Starr 050516-1299 Vitex rotundifolia.jpg|right|thumb|alt=|''Vitex rotundifolia'' on a beach in [[Hawaii]], US]]
''V. rotundifolia'' grows along sandy and rocky coasts from 0 to 15 m above sea level.<ref name = "Wagner"/> Plants grow down to the ocean waves themselves. ''V. rotundifolia'' is highly tolerant of the harsh beach dune environment characterized by intense heat, high wind, coarse-textured soil, and elevated salinity.<ref>{{cite book |author=Dirr |first1=M. A. |title=Manual of woody landscape plants: Their identification, ornamental characteristics, culture, propagation, and uses |year=1998 |publisher=Stipes |location=Champaign, IL |page=1092 |isbn=978-0-87563-795-2}}</ref>

This plant's natural range includes much of the [[Pacific Rim]] and many of the Pacific islands. The plant was observed by Munir from Northern and Western Australia, New Guinea, Indonesia, New Caledonia, Polynesia, Hawaii, Malaya, Philippines, and Hong Kong.<ref name="Munir"/> Moldenke reported ''V. rotundifolia'' in Brazil, Mauritius, Reunion, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Andaman Islands, China, Taiwan, Japan, Ryukyu Islands, Korea, Indochina, Thailand, Borneo, and Sarawak.<ref name = "Mold71">{{cite book |author=Moldenke|first1=H. N. |title=A fifth Summary of the Verbenaceae, Avicenniaceae, Stilbaceae, Dicrastylidaceae, Synphoremaceae, Nyctanthaceae, and Eriocaulaceae of the World etc.  |volume=1 & 2 |year=1971 |publisher=H.N. & A.L. Moldenke |location=Painfield, NJ |isbn= }}</ref><ref name = "Mold80">{{cite book |author=Moldenke |first1=H. N. |title=Phytologia Memoirs. II A sixth Summary of the Verbenaceae, Avicenniaceae, Stilbaceae, Chloanthaceae, Synphoremaceae, Nyctanthaceae, and Eriocaulaceae of the World etc. |year=1980  |publisher=H.N. & A.L. Moldenke |location=Painfield, NJ }}</ref> The plant has also been observed in southern India.<ref>{{cite journal |quotes= |last=Sivarajan |first=V.V.  |authorlink= |author2=K.S. Manilal  |year= 1982 |title=Notes on some interesting species of Verbenaceae from South India|journal=J. Econ. Tax. Bot. |volume=3 |pages=813–817 }}</ref> Cultivation of ''V. rotundifolia'' has been reported in England, Florida, Germany, the Hawaiian Islands, Hong Kong, Java, Johnston Island, Maryland, and New York.<ref name = "Mold80"/> At present in the United States, beach vitex has become naturalized only in southeastern states along the east and gulf coasts.<ref name="Cousins">{{cite journal |last=Cousins |first=M.M. |author2=J. Briggs |author3=C. Gresham |author4=J. Whetstone |author5=T. Whitwell  |year= 2010 |title=Beach Vitex (''Vitex rotundifolia''): An Invasive Coastal Species|journal=Invasive Plant Science and Management |volume=3 |issue=3 |pages=340–345  |doi=10.1614/IPSM-D-09-00055.1}}</ref>

==Biology and Ecology==
Beach vitex is a [[perennial]] that grows throughout the summer months in [[temperate]] and [[tropical]] areas of the Pacific. In temperate areas, the plant is [[deciduous]] and loses its leaves during the cool nights of fall. In the southeastern United States, leaves emerge in April while flowering occurs from June–August with fruiting following shortly thereafter. Fruits may remain attached to the plant into the early spring. ''V. rotundifolia'' is capable of overwintering on the dunes in South and North Carolina and in gulf coastal areas. It can survive in USDA [[hardiness zones]] 6b to 10.

===Growth===
The plant grows rapidly, and reproduces through vegetative means.<ref name="Cousins"/> As the plant matures, it begins to flower. After maturation, the plant produces large numbers of fruits (up to 5581 fruits per square meter).<ref name="Cousins"/>

===Pollination===
Insect visitation is the likely method of pollen transfer due to the spatial separation of the [[anthers]] and [[stigma (botany)|stigma]], which would make self-pollination unlikely. Abe reported ''V. rotundifolia'' flowers on [[Nishino-shima Island]] were visited by flies, honey bees, beetles, butterflies, and ants though most of the visitors were ants.<ref name = "Abe">{{cite journal |last=Abe |first=T. |year= 2006 |title= Colonization of Nishino-shima Island by plants and arthropods 31 years after eruption  |journal= Pacific Science  |volume=60 |pages=355–365  |doi= 10.1353/psc.2006.0014 |issue=3}}</ref><ref name = "Ab">{{cite journal |last=Abe |first=T. |year= 2006 |title= Threatened pollination systems in native flora of the Ogasawara (Bonin) Islands |journal= Annals of Botany |volume=98 |pages=317–334 |doi=10.1093/aob/mcl117 |issue=2 |pmid=16790463 |pmc=2803473}}</ref> Diverse groups of pollinators visit the flowers in search of the 0.5 µl/flower nectar reward.<ref name ="Ab"/> Due to this wide range of visitors, it is unlikely the plant would require a specialist insect to mediate successful pollination.

===Dormancy===
Evidence indicates that beach vitex possesses a combinational [[dormancy]] mechanism. This dormancy mechanism is made up of a physical dormancy component and a physiological dormancy component.<ref name = "Cousin">{{cite journal |quotes= |last=Cousins |first=M.M. |author2=J. Briggs |author3=T. Whitwell |author4=C. Gresham |author5=J. Whetstone  |year= 2010 |title= Reestablishment Potential of Beach Vitex (''Vitex rotundifolia'' L. f.) Following Removal and Control Efforts |journal=Invasive Plant Science and Management |volume=3 |issue=3 |pages=327–333   |doi= 10.1614/IPSM-D-09-00062.1 }}</ref> The physical dormancy mechanism is believed to be inforced at least in part by cuticular alkanes that prevent water penetration.<ref name = "Cousi">{{cite journal |doi=10.1021/jf8025259 |last=Cousins |first=M.M. |author2=C. Gresham |author3=M. B. Riley |author4=T. Whitwell  |year= 2009 |title=Beach Dune Sand Hydrophobicity Due to the Presence of Beach Vitex (''Vitex rotundifolia'' L. f.) |journal=Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry |volume=57 |issue=2 |pages=409–415 |pmid= 19090757}}</ref> The mechanism of the physiological dormancy component is not yet fully understood.<ref name ="Cousin"/> This dormancy mechanism allows for the establishment of a substantial soil seed bank that is capable of surviving and producing new seedlings in excess of 4 years after all vegetation has been removed.<ref name ="Cousin"/> Dormancy mechanisms also allow the plant to undergo long-distance dispersal.

===Dispersal===
There is substantial supportive evidence of a water-based dispersal mechanism for beach vitex fruits. ''V. rotundifolia'' plants are present throughout the Pacific including coastal areas of two continents and many islands. Bird dispersal is highly unlikely as there is no fleshy fruit reward; water dispersal is the most likely dispersal means capable of enabling dispersal over such long distances.<ref name = "Cousins"/> Fruits are covered with thick coatings of [[hydrophobic]] [[cuticular]] [[alkanes]] allowing them to resist water penetration for extended periods.<ref name = "Cousin"/><ref name = "Cousi"/>  Researchers have observed ''V. rotundifolia'' fruits floating on rivers and oceans.<ref name = "Munir"/>

===Genetic Diversity===
Genetic diversity within populations has been found to be much lower than the average for most woody plants.<ref name = "Yeeh">{{cite journal |quotes= |last=Yeeh |first=Y. |authorlink= |author2=S. S. Kang |author3=H. G. Chung |author4=M. S. Chung |author5=M. G. Chung  |year= 1996 |title= Genetic and clonal diversity in Korean populations of ''Vitex rotundifolia'' (Verbenaceae) |journal= Journal of Plant Research  |volume=109 |issue=2 |pages=161–168 |doi=10.1007/BF02344541 }}</ref> Additionally, the divergence between populations was found to be higher. There were large genetic differences between populations, indicating there is limited gene flow between populations. This is understandable due to the limited [[ecological niche]] beach vitex inhabits. Since the populations are largely [[Clonal interference|clonal]], this may enhance [[genetic drift]]. Significant variations have been observed with regard to [[genotype]] and [[chemotype]] of various beach vitex samples collected from across China. Genotypic and chemotypic variations were closely associated.<ref name = "Hu1">{{cite journal |last=Hu |first=Y. |author2=Q.Y. Zhang |author3=H.L. Xin |author4=L.P. Qin |author5=B.R. Lu |author6=K. Rahman |author7=H.C. Zheng |year= 2007 |title= Association between chemical and genetic variation of ''Vitex rotundifolia'' populations from different locations in China: its implication for quality control of medicinal plants |journal= Biomedical Chromatography |pmid=17474140  |volume=21 |issue=9 |pages=967–975 |doi=10.1002/bmc.841}}</ref> Large genetic variation between populations was observed with lower variation within populations, and plants within 20 m of each other were closely related. It was believed that differentiation of separated populations might be the cause of variations between populations.<ref name = "Hu2">{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1744-7909.2008.00635.x |last=Hu |first=Y. |author2=Y. Zhu |author3=Q.Y. Zhang |author4=H.L. Xin |author5=L.P. Qin |author6=B.R. Lu |author7=K. Rahman |author8=H.C. Zheng |year= 2008 |title= Population Genetic Structure of the Medicinal Plant ''Vitex rotundifolia'' in China: Implications for its Use and Conservation  |journal= Journal of Integrative Plant Biology |volume=50 |issue=9 |pages=1118–1129 |pmid= 18844780 }}</ref>

==Medicinal Uses==
''V. rotundifolia'' has many medicinal uses. These uses generally parallel those of ''[[Vitex agnus-castus]]''.

==Environmental Concerns==
In areas where it has been introduced outside of its native range, ''V. rotundifolia'' has proven to be an [[invasive species]]. This plant dominates dune ecosystems leading to a reduction in the prevalence of [[native species]].<ref name = "Gresham">{{cite web |author=Gresham, C. |author2=A. Neal  |year= 2004 |url=http://www.northinlet.sc.edu/beachvitex/media/gresham_manuscript.pdf |title= An evaluation of the invasive potential of beach vitex (''Vitex rotundifolia'') |accessdate=27 March 2010 }}</ref> Native species exclusion is of particular concern because some of the species that share a [[Ecological niche|niche]] with ''V. rotundifolia'', such as sea beach amaranth (''[[Amaranthus pumilus]]'' Rafinesque), are presently listed as [[threatened]].<ref name = "fws">{{cite web |url=http://www.fws.gov/northeast/njfieldoffice/Endangered/amaranth.html |author=U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service |title=Sea beach Amaranth (''Amaranthus pumilus'') [threatened] |accessdate=23 June 2010 |year= 2010}}</ref>

''V. rotundifolia'' fruits have been shown to transfer cuticular [[alkanes]] to the sand substrate. This results in intense sand [[hydrophobicity]] that persists in the soil for many years.<ref name = "Cousi"/> This hydrophobicity might negatively impact dune recovery or serve as a means for limiting growth of native plant species.<ref name = "Cousi"/>

Sea turtle conservation groups have publicized concerns that dense ''V. rotundifolia'' growth may prevent sea turtles from reaching acceptable nesting sites.<ref name = "bvtf">{{cite web |url=http://www.beachvitex.org/ |title= Beach Vitex Task Force |accessdate=15 June 2010 |year= 2010}}</ref> These same organizations believe that ''V. rotundifolia'' may limit the ability of baby turtles to reach the ocean after they hatch. A recent ''USA Today'' article mentioned these concerns as part of an effort to raise awareness of ''V. rotundifolia'',<ref>{{cite journal |last=Dorell |first=O. |year= 2009 |url= http://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/environment/2009-10-15-beachvine_N.htm |title= Invasive vines assault East Coast beaches  |journal= USA Today |issue=15 October |pages=8A |doi= }}</ref> and has at least one review article.<ref name = "Cousins"/> However, these concerns have not been validated scientifically. Several sea turtle species nest along the coasts of the Carolinas. These include the endangered [[loggerhead turtle]] (''Caretta caretta''), the endangered [[green turtle]] (''Chelonia mydas''), and the critically endangered [[Kemp's Ridley]] (''Lepidochelys kempii''). If scientific evidence is found to support claims that ''V. rotundifolia'' harms sea turtles, this threat would constitute a substantial environmental issue.

Beach vitex emits large amounts of [[methyl chloride]] from its leaves.<ref name = "yokouchi">{{cite journal |last=Yokouchi |first=Y. |author2=T. Saito |author3=C. Ishigaki |author4=M. Aramoto  |year= 2007 |title= Identification of methyl chloride-emitting plants and atmospheric measurements on a subtropical island  |journal= Chemosphere |pmid=17462706 |volume=69 |issue=4 |pages=549–553 |doi=10.1016/j.chemosphere.2007.03.028 }}</ref> ''V. rotundifolia'' was one of the six highest emitting species of 33 possessing this characteristic.<ref name = "yokouchi"/> A total of 187 species were examined. Methyl chloride is produced naturally, but may be responsible for a substantial portion of the negative impacts on the stratospheric [[ozone layer]].

===Legislation===
In light of the invasive characteristics of ''V. rotundifolia'', it has been added to the North Carolina Noxious Weed List (effective 2/1/2009). Plants on this list are effectively banned within the state in that possession, sale, and transport of these species is illegal.
<ref name = "ncnoxweed">{{cite web |url=http://www.agr.state.nc.us/plantindustry/plant/weed/noxweed.htm |author=North Carolina Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services |title=North Carolina Noxious Weeds List |accessdate=23 June 2010 |year= 2009}}</ref>
Virginia has enacted a permanent statewide [[quarantine]] (effective 05/07/12) to limit further ''V. rotundifolia'' spread.
<ref name = "vaquar">{{cite web |url=http://www.vdacs.virginia.gov/news/releases-b/120409beachvitex.shtml |author=Virginia Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services |title=Board of agriculture and consumer services issues permanent beach vitex quarantine |accessdate=23 June 2010 |year= 2009}}</ref> At least 12 municipalities in North and South Carolina have enacted ordinances that ban ''V. rotundifolia'' planting and require homeowners to remove established plantings from their property .<ref name = "bvtf"/>

===Control Measures===
Initially, beach vitex stems are wounded using a [[machete]]. A 5.25% solution of [[imazapyr]] is applied to the wounded areas of the stems. After a period of 6 months, all stems are removed. This treatment procedure is repeated until zero regrowth is observed.<ref name="Cousins"/> [[Triclopyr]] may be used to treat small resprouts and seedlings.<ref name="Cousins"/>

| genus_authority = Broth. ''in'' H.G.A. Engler & K.A.E. Prantl, 1906<ref name="Klazenga">{{cite web|url= http://www.anbg.gov.au/abrs/Mosses_online/Lembophyllaceae_Weymouthia.pdf|last1=  Klazenga|first1=N.|last2= Milne|first2= J.|title=Australian Mosses Online. 30. Lembophyllaceae: Weymouthia.(2012)|accessdate=2 December 2012}}</ref>
| subdivision_ranks = species
| subdivision =
* ''W. mollis'' <small>(Hedw., 1801) ([[Type (biology)|Type]])</small> synonyms ''Isothecium molle'', ''Leskea mollis'', ''Meteorium molle'', ''Neckera mollis'', ''Pilotrichella mollis'', ''P. weymouthii'', ''Stereodon mollis''
* ''W. cochlearifolia'' <small>(Schwägr., 1816)</small> synonyms ''W. billardierei'', ''W. cochlearifolia'' var. ''billardierei'', ''Coelidium cochlearifolium'', ''Hypnum cochlearifolium'', ''Isothecium cochlearifolium'', ''Lembophyllum cochlearifolium'', ''Neckera billardierei'', ''Porotrichum cochlearifolium'', ''Pilotrichella billardierei'', ''Stereodon cochlearifolius''
}}

'''''Weymouthia''''' is a genus of two species belonging to the [[Hypnales|feather mosses]]. 
''Weymouthia'' occurs in southern South America, New Zealand and south-eastern Australia and [[Lord Howe Island]]. It is characterised by (i) its [[monopodial]], often hanging growth form; (ii) slight differences between stem and branch leaves; and (iii) the straight perichaetial leaves. In contrast to other genera in the Lembophyllaceae, secondary stems appear unable to arch back to the [[Substrate (biology)|substrate]] and then root and form a new creeping stem.<ref name="Klazenga"/>

== Etymology ==
''Weymouthia'' was named in honour of [[William Weymouth|William Anderson Weymouth]] (1842–1932), a prominent Tasmanian botanist.<ref name="Klazenga"/> The species [[epithet]] ''mollis'' meaning soft, flabby, weak or feeble in Latin, refers to the exclusively hanging branches in this species. The species epithet ''cochlearifolia'' refers to the spoon-shaped leaves that resemble those of [[Cochlearia|scurvy-grass]].

== Taxonomy ==
''Weymouthia'' has traditionally been assigned to the [[Meteoriaceae]], mainly because of the hanging branches<!--- "and the [[peristome]] of ''W. mollis'' being a reduced hypnobryaceous structure", but I don't know what "hypnobryaceous" is, so for now I leave it out --->. Later the genus was included in the Lembophyllaceae,<ref name="Klazenga"/> but according to recent cladistic analyses based on DNA, this family is [[polyphyletic]], and its revision is to be expected.<ref>{{cite journal|last1= Merget|first1= Benjamin|last2= Wolf|first2= Matthias|year= 2010|title= A molecular phylogeny of Hypnales (Bryophyta) inferred from ITS2 sequence-structure data|journal= BMC Research Notes|volume= 3|pages= 320|doi= 10.1186/1756-0500-3-320|url= http://www.biomedcentral.com/1756-0500/3/320}}</ref>

== Key to the species ==
{|
|- valign="top"  align="left"
! scope="row" width="3%" | '''1''' 
| width="97%"  | Leaves oblong, more than twice as long as wide; upper laminal cells not or shallowly pitted. → '''''Weymouthia mollis'''''

|- valign="top" align="left"
! scope="row" width="3%" | '''-''' 
| width="97%"  | Leaves broadly ovate, less than twice as long as wide; upper laminal cells strongly pitted. → '''''Weymouthia cochlearifolia'''''<ref name="Klazenga"/>
|}

'''''Xyris complanata''''', known as the '''feathered yellow-eye''' is a tufted [[Herbaceous plant|herb]] in the [[Xyridaceae]] family. It is native to southern [[China]], [[India]], [[Sri Lanka]], [[Thailand]], [[Cambodia]], [[Laos]], [[Vietnam]], [[Malaysia]], [[Indonesia]] ([[Java]], [[Sulawesi]], [[Kalimantan]], [[Sumatra]]), the [[Philippines]], [[New Guinea]] and [[Australia]] ([[New South Wales]], [[Queensland]], [[Northern Territory]] and [[Western Australia]]). It is also  naturalized in [[Hawaii]] where it is known as '''Hawai'i yelloweyed grass'''.<ref name=brooke>[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=272599 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families, ''Xyris complanata'']</ref><ref>{{PLANTS|id=XYCO|taxon=Xyris complanata|accessdate=7 August 2015}}</ref><ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=2&taxon_id=240001630 Flora of China, Vol. 24 Page 5, <big>硬叶葱草</big> ying ye cong cao, ''Xyris complanata'' R. Brown, Prodr. 256. 1810. ]</ref> In [[New South Wales]] it grows in moist areas, often near swamps or in [[heathland]].

The specific epithet ''complanata'' refers to the flattened leaf stalk.<ref>Les Robinson - Field Guide to the Native Plants of Sydney, ISBN 978-0-7318-1211-0 page 279</ref>  This species first appeared in scientific literature in the year 1810.<ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/2954412#page/124/mode/1up Robert Brown. 1810.  Prodromus Florae Novae Hollandiae 256, ''Xyris complanata'']</ref>

342.text:
{{italic title}}
{{About|saltwater eelgrasses|freshwater eelgrasses|Vallisneria}}
{{taxobox
|name=''Zostera'' (marine eelgrasses)
|image = Eelgrass.jpg
|image_caption = ''[[Zostera marina]]''
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Monocots]]
|ordo = [[Alismatales]]
|familia = [[Zosteraceae]]
|genus = '''''Zostera'''''
|genus_authority= [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]
|synonyms_ref=<ref name=y/>
|synonyms=
*''Alga'' <small>Tourn. ex Lam.</small>
*''Heterozostera'' <small>(Setch.) Hartog</small>
*''Nanozostera'' <small>Toml. & Posl.</small>
| range_map = World map ocean genus-Zostera.jpg
| range_map_width=200px
| range_map_caption = Global distribution map of ''Zostera''. Green indicates presence.
}}
[[Image:Zostera.jpg|thumb|right|''Zostera'' sp in Mussel Ridge Channel, Birch Island, [[Maine]]]]
'''''Zostera''''' is a small [[genus]] of widely distributed [[seagrass]]es, commonly called '''marine eelgrass''' or simply '''eelgrass'''. The genus ''Zostera'' contains 15 species.

==Ecology==
''[[Zostera marina]]'' is found on sandy substrates or in [[estuary|estuaries]], usually submerged or partially floating. Most ''Zostera'' are [[perennial]].  They have long, bright green, ribbon-like leaves, the width of which are about {{convert|1|cm|1}}. Short stems grow up from extensive, white branching [[rhizome]]s. The flowers are enclosed in the sheaths of the leaf bases; the fruits are bladdery and can float.

''Zostera'' beds are important for sediment deposition, substrate stabilization, as substrate for epiphytic [[algae]] and micro-invertebrates, and as nursery grounds for many species of economically important fish and shellfish. ''Zostera'' often forms beds in [[bay mud]] in the estuarine setting. It is an important food for [[brant goose|Brent geese]] and [[wigeon]]s, and even (occasionally) [[caterpillar]]s of the [[grass moth]] ''[[Dolicharthria punctalis]]''.

The [[slime mold]] ''[[Labyrinthula|Labyrinthula zosterae]]'' can cause the wasting disease of ''Zostera'', with ''Z. marina'' being particularly susceptible, causing a decrease in the populations of the fauna that depend on ''Zostera''.

''Zostera'' is able to maintain its [[Turgor pressure|turgor]] at a constant pressure in response to fluctuations in environmental [[osmolarity]]. It achieves this by losing solutes as the tide goes out and gaining solutes as the tide comes in.

==Distribution==

The genus as a whole is widespread throughout seashores of much of the Northern Hemisphere as well as [[Australia]], [[New Zealand]], [[Southeast Asia]] and southern [[Africa]]. The discovery of ''[[Zostera chilensis|Z. chilensis]]'' in 2005 adds an isolated population on the Pacific coast of [[South America]] to the distribution. One species (''[[Zostera noltii|Z. noltii]]'') occurs along the land-locked [[Caspian Sea]].

===Current Status===
Eelgrass once grew in abundance in [[Barnegat Bay]], [[New Jersey]], where it was harvested, dried and used for insulation in houses, such as the governor's summer mansion in [[Island Beach State Park]]. A blight decimated the eelgrass, which ended harvesting of the plant. The plant is making a gradual comeback.

==Uses==
Eelgrass has been used for food by the [[Seri people|Seri]] tribe of [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native Americans]] on the coast of [[Sonora]], [[Mexico]]. The rhizomes and leaf-bases of eelgrass were eaten fresh or dried into cakes for winter food. It was also used for smoking [[deer]] meat. The [[Seri language]] has many words related to eelgrass and eelgrass-harvesting. The month of April is called ''xnoois ihaat iizax'', literally "the month when the eelgrass seed is mature".<ref name="Felger 1985">{{cite book |last1=Felger |first1=Richard |last2=Moser |first2=Mary B. |author2link=Mary B. Moser|title=People of the Desert and Sea: Ethnobotany of the Seri Indians |location=Tucson |year=1985 |publisher=University of Arizona Press }}</ref>

''Zostera'' has also been used as packing material and as stuffing for mattresses and cushions.

On the [[Denmark|Danish]] island of [[Læsø]] it has been used for thatching roofs. Roofs of eelgrass are said to be heavy, but also much longer-lasting and easier to thatch and maintain than roofs done with more conventional thatching material.

''Zostera'' can also be utilized to produce biomass energy using the [[Jean Pain]] method.

==Species==
;Accepted species<ref name="y">{{Cite web|url=http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=309029|title=World Checklist of Selected Plant Families: Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew|website=apps.kew.org|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-02-02}}</ref>
{{columns-list|2|
#''[[Zostera angustifolia]]'' <small>(Hornem.) Rchb.</small> - Russian Far East, British Isles, Denmark, Sweden
# ''[[Zostera asiatica]]'' <small>Miki</small> - Russian Far East, Japan, Korea, NE China
